HEADLINE: Versace Family Seeks Partners to RegainControl of Stores 

BYLINE:  By LESLIE KAUFMAN and ANDREW ROSS SORKIN 

 BODY:
The family-owned fashion design house of Gianni Versace S.p.A. -- most famous for dressing celebrities in clingy and revealing gowns -- is trying to sell a minority stake to outsiders, according to executives who have been approached by the company. 
 The Versaces want to raise about $176 million in cash for a three-year program that would include renovating older stores, repurchasing franchised stores and expanding a leather goods and accessory line. Roughly $26 million of the amount raised, the executives said, would go straight to the family to pay off estate taxes that were incurred when the family sold the art collection and homes of Gianni Versace, the company's founder, after he was killed in 1997. 
 The design house began approaching private firms within the last two weeks, and Versace executives are leaving it to prospective partners to value the $176 million stake as a percentage of the company. Some executives think the cash would be worth roughly 35 to 40 percent of the company. Versace has not released final sales figures for 2001, but expects them to approach $450 million. 
The private equity firms approached include the Texas Pacific Group based in the United States and two British firms, CVC Capital Partners and Doughty Hanson, all of whom declined comment or could not be reached. Any deal could take several months to complete. 
Although selling a majority stake in the firm would be more appealing to investors, the Versaces are not willing to sell a stake in the firm so large that control might pass out of their hands, according to executives close to the deal.
The decision to raise money in the private market indicates that, for now, the company has shelved its plans for an initial public offering of stock, which it had been considering at the time of Gianni Versace's death.
Versace executives confirmed yesterday that they were in negotiations for the financing. The company would comment no further except to say that the cash was necessary to help Versace pursue its strategy of buying back control of its own stores and merchandise.
Versace currently has 112 stores, but 89 are owned by franchisees. The company recently bought back control of seven United States stores and a majority stake in the company that runs its Asian operations.
"We are continuing to implement a plan, which began in 2000, to take control of and invest in the company," said Lou Colasuonno, a spokesman for Versace. "And it takes capital for growth."
The negotiations offer the first glimpse of how the closely held company has fared since its founder and design visionary, Gianni Versace, was shot outside his Miami Beach villa in 1997.
Since his death, the company has continued to produce its couture line and other more affordable brands under the creative direction of his sister, Donatella, selling lines like Versace Jeans, Versus, Versace Sport and Versace Classic. Santo Versace, Gianni's brother and business partner, has continued to mind the company's finances.
Mr. Versace's two siblings and Donatella's daughter, Allegra Beck, now own the company in its entirety.
Despite Mr. Versace's untimely death, the house has managed to maintain the quality most important yet most ethereal for a fashion house: cachet. Versace gowns still adorn stars at major award presentations -- Jennifer Lopez, for example, wore a girlish bubble-gum pink number to this year's Academy Awards. Chelsea Clinton, Madonna and Gwyneth Paltrow were much photographed at the Versace couture show in Paris in January. And Versace's fall ready-to-wear collection, which was on the runways in Milan last month, got rave reviews from the style press.
Still, sales have not fully rebounded since Gianni Versace's death. The year he died, the company reported annual sales of $560 million. The company reported sales of $374 million in 1999 and $392 million in 2000. 
There have also been large expenditures. In 2000, Versace began its effort to take control of all aspects of producing and selling its merchandise. Vertical integration is the only way a design company can totally control its own image, something that is increasingly considered a must in luxury retailing. But it is expensive, and the effort is a major factor in Versace's attempts to sell a stake in the company. 
To keep up with Gucci, the gold standard in the high-fashion business, Versace also wants to renovate stores that have grown shabby under the care of other owners. And the company wants money to expand its leather goods and accessory lines, highly profitable businesses for other fashion houses.
News that Versace is shopping around for an investor comes as the European luxury market, red hot last year, has gone cold.
A sharp economic slowdown in America has cut into sales of many luxury brands. LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton, the most voracious of Europe's acquirers of luxury brands, has experienced a slump in cash flow after paying steep prices for Donna Karan International and Fendi.

CORRECTION-DATE: April 17, 2002

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day yesterday about plans by the fashion design house of Gianni Versace to sell a minority stake to outsiders included an erroneous number from the company for its stores. Versace owns 112 stores directly; 89 others are owned by franchisees. The total is not 112.

HEADLINE: Chavez Offers Words of Reconciliation 

BYLINE:  By JUAN FORERO 

DATELINE: CARACAS, Venezuela, April 15 

 BODY:
President Hugo Chavez, addressing worried Venezuelans a day after he regained power when an attempt to oust him failed, abandoned his familiar combative style today and reached out to his opponents with messages of reconciliation. 
 In a speech he delivered before reporters at the presidential palace, the scene of his triumphant return, Mr. Chavez acknowledged that popular discontent had generated the huge protest that forced him from office for 48 hours. He said he was "anguished" by the violence in which at least 14 anti-government demonstrators were killed. 
 He said that he bore no grudges, and that he was willing to listen to the grievances of an opposition that draws its support from Venezuela's small but influential upper and middle classes.
"We do not hate, that is a lie," the president said in a speech that lasted two hours and 20 minutes. "There is no hate in my heart for the upper classes of Venezuela. We are not in a time of hate. We are in a time of love."
The tone of the speech, and the news conference that followed it, was a startling break with the past. Before he was toppled briefly by a surging opposition movement led by business and labor leaders and dissident military officers, Mr. Chavez had rarely offered a kind word for the Venezuelan elite, whom he called "subversives" who should move to Miami.
But questions abounded here about whether Mr. Chavez, a former paratrooper elected in 1998 on a pledge to reshape Venezuela to benefit the poor, had really changed his political outlook. Mr. Chavez's aggressive moves to intervene in the management of the state-owned oil industry, take control of unions and impose tight control on the National Assembly had polarized the society.
Mr. Chavez has sought to signal that he is prepared for some change.
Today he announced that he would organize "round-table" discussions between government officials and opposition leaders, beginning next week, to attempt to resolve disputes.
Mr. Chavez also said he and leaders of the Catholic Church "are capable of accepting our differences so that we can have dialogue and cooperation." In the past, he referred to clergy as "devils in vestments."
Referring to the United States, which did not conceal its satisfaction with his ouster, the president appeared to give Washington the benefit of the doubt. "I think they were victims of misinformation," he said.
At the same time, Mr. Chavez made it clear that he continued to be in charge and that he was not prepared to alter the course of his populist revolution. The government will move forward with policies that have riled Mr. Chavez's opposition, like a controversial land reform, officials said.
However, seeking to quell concerns about possible repression, Jose Vicente Rangel, the defense minister and a close ally of the president, said the cabinet members selected on Friday for the short-lived interim government had been released from custody. 
Pedro Carmona Estanga, the businessman who was sworn in as interim president that day, was released from state security headquarters and sent home under house arrest. Looking tired, he told reporters he had been treated well.
"I reiterate my most sincere wish for peace in the country," he said. "Let us hope that all the events that happened lead to the reconciliation and reunification of Venezuelans."
Mr. Rangel, the defense minister, echoed Mr. Chavez at the Miraflores presidential palace, saying, "The entire government is ready to make changes." 
On Sunday, just hours after military commanders and crowds of protesters loyal to him had reclaimed the presidential palace, Mr. Chavez announced that the board of directors he had appointed to the state-owned oil firm, Petroleos de Venezuela, had resigned. The appointment angered executives at the traditionally autonomous company, a pillar of Venezuela's economy, whose protests evolved into a general strike, which led to Mr. Chavez's short-lived removal.
Mr. Chavez acknowledged today that some of his supporters were armed during street disturbances on Thursday and he suggested that they could be responsible for some of the violence that led to opposition protesters' deaths that day. The killings sparked a rebellion by some military commanders. 
After retaking the government, Mr. Chavez's ministers angrily denied those initial accusations, saying that most of those who died were the president's supporters and even government workers. But today Mr. Chavez made a startling admission.
"I don't deny it -- it would be false to say that there was no gunfire from our side to theirs," Mr. Chavez said. "In fact, there is evidence that some of our supporters were armed -- but not only our people." 
Still, in Venezuela and abroad, where Venezuela's political situation moves the oil markets, there was skepticism about Mr. Chavez's ability or desire to be conciliatory. On Sunday, in a speech at a military base, he referred to the protest leaders as oligarchs, a term he often uses to deride opponents.
The price of oil, which had fallen upon news of Mr. Chavez's ouster on Friday, rose today as concerns were raised about the future of Petroleos de Venezuela.
Analysts said that Mr. Chavez remained on unsteady ground. Mr. Chavez has the support of only about 34 percent of Venezuelans, according to a poll in March. Perhaps most troubling for his government are doubts about the military's loyalty. 
At least 20 generals and admirals are jailed now and facing charges for their role in the uprising, with dozens of lower-ranking officers also in custody. The depth of the allegiance of those officers who remained with Mr. Chavez is unclear. 
At Petroleos de Venezuela, which was trying to get back to normal after severe disruptions in the production and export of oil, the same office workers who had led protests against Mr. Chavez remained skittish. One top executive, Eddie Ramirez, whose firing along with a handful of other executives on Sunday energized protesters, wondered about his future and that of the company.
"If they don't reinstate the ones who were retired, the corporation could come tumbling down," said Mr. Ramirez, explaining that the loss of experienced managers was damaging to the company.

HEADLINE: Metro Briefing New York: Manhattan: Navy Yard Chief Named 

BYLINE:  By Terry Pristin (NYT) (Compiled by Anthony Ramirez) 

 BODY:
 Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced the appointment of Eric J. Deutsch yesterday as president of the nonprofit corporation that manages the Brooklyn Navy Yard. 
About 3,000 people are employed by businesses in the 264-acre Navy yard, which became an industrial park in 1971. Mr. Deutsch, 35, a senior vice president with the city's Economic Development Corporation, also served as executive director of the Group of 35, a panel formed by Senator Charles E. Schumer to seek ways of creating new office space in the city over the next two decades. Terry Pristin (NYT)

HEADLINE: Losing Latin America 

BYLINE:  By PAUL KRUGMAN; E-mail: krugman@nytimes.com

 BODY:
Many people, myself included, would agree that Hugo Chavez is not the president Venezuela needs. He happens, however, to be the president Venezuela elected -- freely, fairly and constitutionally. That's why all the democratic nations of the Western Hemisphere, however much they may dislike Mr. Chavez, denounced last week's attempted coup against him. 
 All the democratic nations, that is, except one. 
 Here's how the BBC put it: "Far from condemning the ouster of a democratically elected president, U.S. officials blamed the crisis on Mr. Chavez himself," and they were "clearly pleased with the result" -- even though the new interim government proceeded to abolish the legislature, the judiciary and the Constitution. They were presumably less pleased when the coup attempt collapsed. The BBC again: "President Chavez's comeback has . . . left Washington looking rather stupid." The national security adviser, Condoleezza Rice, didn't help that impression when, incredibly, she cautioned the restored president to "respect constitutional processes."
Surely the worst thing about this episode is the betrayal of our democratic principles; "of the people, by the people, for the people" isn't supposed to be followed by the words "as long as it suits U.S. interests."
But even viewed as realpolitik, our benign attitude toward Venezuela's coup was remarkably foolish. 
It is very much in our interest that Latin America break out of its traditional political cycle, in which crude populism alternated with military dictatorship. Everything that matters to the U.S. -- trade, security, drugs, you name it -- will be better if we have stable neighbors.
But how can such stability be achieved? In the 1990's there seemed, finally, to be a formula; call it the new world order. Economic reform would end the temptations of populism; political reform would end the risk of dictatorship. And in the 1990's, on their own initiative but with encouragement from the United States, most Latin American nations did indeed embark on a dramatic process of reform both economic and political.
The actual results have been mixed. On the economic side, where hopes were initially highest, things have not gone too well. There are no economic miracles in Latin America, and there have been some notable disasters, Argentina's crisis being the latest. The best you can say is that some of the disaster victims, notably Mexico, seem to have recovered their balance (with a lot of help, one must say, from the Clinton administration) and moved onto a path of steady, but modest, economic growth. 
Yet economic disasters have not destabilized the region. Mexico's crisis in 1995, Brazil's crisis in 1999, even Argentina's current crisis did not deliver those countries into the hands either of radicals or of strongmen. The reason is that the political side has gone better than anyone might have expected. Latin America has become a region of democracies -- and these democracies seem remarkably robust.
So while the U.S. may have hoped for a new Latin stability based on vibrant prosperity, what it actually got was stability despite economic woes, thanks to democracy. Things could be a lot worse.
Which brings us to Venezuela. Mr. Chavez is a populist in the traditional mold, and his policies have been incompetent and erratic. Yet he was fairly elected, in a region that has come to understand the importance of democratic legitimacy. What did the United States hope to gain from his overthrow? True, he has spouted a lot of anti-American rhetoric, and been a nuisance to our diplomacy. But he is not a serious threat.
Yet there we were, reminding everyone of the bad old days when any would-be right-wing dictator could count on U.S. backing.
As it happens, we aligned ourselves with a peculiarly incompetent set of plotters. Mr. Chavez has alienated a broad spectrum of his people; the demonstrations that led to his brief overthrow began with a general strike by the country's unions. But the short-lived coup-installed government included representatives of big business and the wealthy -- full stop. No wonder the coup collapsed.
But even if the coup had succeeded, our behavior would have been very stupid. We had a good thing going -- a new hemispheric atmosphere of trust, based on shared democratic values. How could we so casually throw it away?

HEADLINE: Congressman Asks Chase to Explain Enron Loans 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: HOUSTON, April 15 

 BODY:
J. P. Morgan Chase has been asked by a House Democrat to explain its role in a series of loans to Enron partnerships that may have helped to keep debt off the books.
 Representative Henry A. Waxman, a California Democrat involved in Congressional investigations into the collapse of Enron, asked J. P. Morgan to provide details about loans to several Enron-related entities that he says allowed a partnership called Sequoia to avoid recording debt. Mr. Waxman is seeking information about each loan transaction and whether J .P. Morgan intended them to help Enron improve its financial statements. 
 Transactions involving the Sequoia partnership "do not appear to have served a legitimate economic purpose," Mr. Waxman wrote to William B. Harrison Jr., J. P. Morgan's president and chief executive. "Rather, on their face, they appear to have been designed to allow Enron to covertly borrow hundreds of millions of dollars in undisclosed loans."
Congress is stepping up its investigation into the role investment banks played in Enron's bankruptcy, the largest in United States history. The House Energy and Commerce Committee, on which Mr. Waxman serves, sent letters last month to J. P. Morgan and eight other banks requesting information, including whether Enron pressed them to make investments.
J. P. Morgan and the other banks are also facing shareholder lawsuits that contend the banks made billions in fees for helping to set up Enron partnerships that were little more than "Ponzi schemes" that helped inflate the company's stock price.
J. P. Morgan has filed its own lawsuit that seeks to force Enron to release more than $2.1 billion it says Enron is holding on the bank's behalf. Mr. Waxman indicated that court filings by J. P. Morgan in that case are raising a new line of inquiry for Congressional investigators looking at five partnerships: Sequoia, Choctaw, Cherokee, Zephyrus and Enron Finance Partners.

HEADLINE: Tax Treaties With Small Nations Turn Into a New Shield for Profits 

BYLINE:  By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
Some large companies, encouraged by top law and accounting firms, are adopting a new strategy to cut taxes legally on profits they make in this country.
 The technique works this way: A company transfers profits earned in America to a paper company in another country, like Barbados or Luxembourg, that has a special kind of tax treaty with the United States. 
 These treaties, originally intended to serve American economic interests abroad, allow companies through accounting sleight of hand to transform taxable profits into expenses that they can deduct on their American tax return. These tax-deductible expenses include interest payments to the overseas company, royalties for use of the company's logo and fees for management advice from the overseas company.
The paper company then sends the money to the United States company's worldwide headquarters in Bermuda, which has no income tax and is the tax haven of choice for many companies. In short, what once were taxable profits have been turned into virtually untaxed dollars for use anywhere in the world. 
Large publicly traded companies can use this method to reduce taxes on American profits to as little as 11 percent, from an average of 21.5 percent.
Nabors Industries and Weatherford Industries, two oil drilling services companies in Houston, and Stanley Works, a Connecticut maker of hammers and other hand tools, are among the first companies preparing to use the strategy to reduce taxes paid to the American government on profits earned in the United States. Other companies with headquarters in Bermuda, including Tyco International, Ingersoll-Rand and the consulting firm Accenture, have adopted other methods to accomplish the same goal.
The new techniques are being promoted by leading accounting and law firms, said Beth Brooke, a vice chairman of Ernst & Young, the accounting and consulting firm. 
Accounting and consulting firms advising on these strategies include Arthur Andersen, Deloitte & Touche, KPMG, PricewaterhouseCoopers and Grant Thornton. The top law firms include Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom; Baker & McKenzie; Sutherland, Asbill & Brennan; and Arnold & Porter.
"Everyone wants this business," said the general counsel of one company using one of the methods, who spoke on the condition that neither he nor his employer be identified. 
Several dozen companies were already using part of this technique -- incorporating in Bermuda while keeping their headquarters in the United States -- to eliminate their taxes on profits made overseas. Senators Max Baucus, Democrat of Montana, and Charles E. Grassley, Republican of Iowa, introduced legislation last week to close the loophole, which was disclosed in The New York Times in February.
But the new strategies go beyond the techniques addressed in the legislation. The key is to use treaties with Barbados, Luxembourg and other havens. Companies need the third country and a Bermuda headquarters because the United States does not have a tax treaty with Bermuda.
One leading tax lawyer, David P. Hariton of Sullivan & Cromwell in New York, said he expected the debate to shift once members of Congress and citizens understood the impact on American tax revenues.
"If the transaction serves only to eliminate the U.S. tax on foreign-source income, there are good policy arguments for allowing it," Mr. Hariton said. "If, on the other hand, it serves to eliminate U.S. tax on U.S. income then the transaction is of greater concern."
Nabors Industries, the largest oil drilling services company in the United States, is one corporation preparing to use the tax-avoidance techniques. It has proposed to its shareholders an incorporation as a Bermuda company that would have its legal residence in Barbados. To qualify the company as a resident of Barbados, the Nabors chief executive, Eugene M. Isenberg, simply has to meet with his directors once a year on that island, experts said.
Because of the tax treaty, dollars can be moved untaxed from the company's taxable American pocket to its Barbados pocket, from which 99 percent of the money can then move on to tax-free Bermuda and remain in the hands of the company.
These companies are then free to invest the money anywhere. Weatherford International, another oil services company, said in documents sent to investors that its arrangement means that it will be able to "commit additional capital to international expansion" and "will facilitate the cost-effective acquisition and operation of non-U.S. business."
By creating a tax triangle out of the United States, Bermuda and a country like Barbados or Luxembourg, and pushing every rule to the limit, companies can legally pay as little as 11 percent of their American profits in taxes to the United States, said Richard E. Andersen, a tax lawyer at Arnold & Porter in New York and author of "Income Tax Treaties of the U.S.," a tax guide published by Warren Gorham & Lamont. 
Congress imposes a 35 percent tax on profits of large companies, but after taking advantage of deductions and loopholes, the largest 9,669 companies paid an average of 21.5 percent of their profits in American income taxes in 1998, the latest data from the Internal Revenue Service shows. These taxes totaled $141.6 billion, or nearly 18 percent of the total income taxes paid by companies and individuals.
Just how much companies expect to save on taxes on their United States profits is not known because the companies have not disclosed it.
One of the most common of the new tax avoidance techniques, which does not yet have a commonly used name, works this way. First, a company reincorporates in Bermuda or a similar tax haven where there is no income tax and where all it needs is a mail drop. That allows the company to eliminate American taxes on its profits overseas.
How much companies pay in taxes on their overseas profits depends on which countries they operate in and their tax strategies. But most of those using this arrangement have said they expect to lower worldwide income taxes from more than a third of their profits to a quarter or less.
The key to the new method is setting up a paper company in a third country that has a tax treaty with the United States allowing companies to move large amounts of money to an overseas parent company and to reclassify these formerly taxable profits as deductions. 
For example, the profits made in the United States can be shipped abroad tax free in the form of royalties for using the company's logo, the rights to which are owned by the overseas parent. As another example, the overseas parent can lend money to the American operation, which uses its United States profits to pay interest, for which it takes a deduction. The overseas parent can also charge management fees for services provided to its American subsidiary, and, once again, be paid from once-taxable profits. 
Without the Barbados or Luxembourg connection, however, the ability to reduce American taxes on American profits is limited by other tax rules.
Companies using the techniques, asked about it last week, either did not respond, declined to comment or reiterated previous remarks about eliminating American taxes on profits earned outside the United States.
"We are pretty much radio silent these days" on taxes, said Paul Dickard, a spokesman for Ingersoll-Rand, an industrial manufacturer that maintains its operating headquarters in Woodcliff Lake, N.J.
Under current rules, only publicly traded companies can take advantage of these techniques. Individual Americans are taxed on their worldwide income whether they live in the United States or overseas, making a Bermuda mail drop worthless to them. The treaties exclude family-owned businesses, partnerships and professional corporations.
Lawyers and accountants who are promoting the strategies -- they charge hourly fees for this kind of work -- say that Congress is forcing companies into them by not modernizing the corporate income tax. 
Typical of these statements were remarks by Ms. Brooke of Ernst & Young, who said that "to become globally competitive, companies have to unshackle themselves from the arcane U.S. tax system that in essence results in U.S. company profits being taxed in multiple places."
Ms. Brooke acknowledged that companies that do this can also pay lower taxes on profits earned in the United States. "The issue is global competitiveness and that includes taxes paid in the United States on profits earned there," she said.
Mr. Andersen, the tax treaty expert, said the techniques were quite legal. "Congress wrote the statute and the I.R.S. wrote regulations that not only allow this, but give signposts on a perfectly clear road map" showing how to move to a tax haven like Bermuda and take advantage of a second country's tax treaty, Mr. Andersen said. 
"If Congress wants to say this is a time of war and you can't do this anymore and if you do we will put you in handcuffs and throw you in prison that is fine with me," he added. "But until they do, it is perfectly appropriate to do what the law provides."
But Lee Sheppard, a lawyer whose essays in the journal Tax Notes are read by experts in legal tax avoidance, disagreed. "I do not believe for one second that abusing these treaties is what Congress intended," she said.
"Nobody in Congress said you can pretend to be resident in Barbados and not pay your taxes," she added.
"The real problem here is that Congress trusts these guys to act responsibly and so do the tax administrators at Treasury and the I.R.S., and no one who writes the laws and the treaties and the regulations ever thought they would behave like this."
Treasury Department officials, who oversee the tax collection system, said the new strategies reveal "inadequacies in our current tax rules that can be taken advantage of" by companies.
"We are aware that these types of transactions may be used to reduce the U.S. taxes paid on U.S. income," said Mark A. Weinberger, Treasury assistant secretary for tax policy. "That is one of the reasons we are so concerned about the marked increase in the number and size of these transactions."
It was not immediately clear how the provisions creating the loopholes were written into the treaties. Experts said there were several ways to close the loopholes, including renegotiating the treaties and rewriting the rules on what constitutes a corporate headquarters for tax purposes. 
Senators Baucus and Grassley, who introduced the legislation to close the Bermuda loophole, said the new techniques might require further legislation.
"The companies reincorporating in tax haven countries, and their executives, are still physically located in the United States," Senator Baucus said. "Their executives and employees enjoy all the privileges afforded to honest U.S. taxpayers."
The new strategies, Mr. Baucus said, are "making a mockery of honest taxpayers." 
"We need to continue to step up efforts to ensure that they pay their fair share," he added.
Mr. Grassley has said that using the Bermuda methods is unpatriotic.
Both senators said that while they wanted to end these techniques, they would also investigate how to overhaul the corporate tax system and close loopholes.

HEADLINE: Broadcasting the War 

BYLINE:  By Max Rodenbeck; Max Rodenbeck is Middle East correspondent for The Economist and author of "Cairo: The City Victorious."

DATELINE: CAIRO 

 BODY:
Bahrain is as far from Ramallah as Bermuda is from ground zero. Yet it was a Palestinian flag that shrouded the body of Muhammad Jumaa, a Bahraini janitor felled by a policeman's plastic bullet in a protest at the American embassy, when he was buried last week. He was hailed as the latest martyr for Palestine.
Never, in a half century of Middle Eastern conflict, have ordinary Arabs so identified with the Palestinian tragedy as they do today. As network coverage of Vietnam shocked Americans with the immediacy of a far-off war, satellite television's insistent, graphic imagery of the intifada has taken its bloody drama into millions of Arab households. 
 Before Israel's reinvasion of the West Bank, neither its own leaders nor America's appear to have appreciated how the new power and reach of the Arab media could work against the Israelis. While other Arabs have always taken the Palestinians' side, the violent images are increasing the sense of personal interest in the conflict. When half a million Moroccans marched in a recent protest against Israel, many carried placards saying, "We are all Palestinians." 
 The perspective is different, of course, from that of Americans watching the televised war in Vietnam. Arabs see the current conflict through "Vietnamese" eyes -- as the story of a kindred people fighting to rid their land of a brutal occupying army. The drama generates not weariness with war but a thirst for justice, for sacrifice and revenge.
Some may dismiss such passions as the product of propaganda, and it is true that the region's news media are hardly beyond reproach. Hezbollah runs a technically impressive and visually compelling satellite channel that beams nonstop incitement to attack "the Zionist enemy." Even Al Jazeera, the most editorially sophisticated of the Arab satellite channels, stoops to hyperbolic use of terms like genocide to describe Israel's iron-fisted methods. More often than not, Israeli losses are passed off lightly. 
Stories of Palestinian casualties, by contrast, are textured with memory. Some have become household names from Morocco to Muscat: Muhammad al-Dura, the 12-year-old boy from Gaza whose father could not shield him from a hail of Israeli gunfire; or Wafa Idris and Ayat al-Akhras, the first female suicide bombers, who were the objects of a tribute by Egyptian movie stars during a charity performance at Cairo's opera house.
Yet Arab coverage of the conflict is not really much more one-sided than, say, America's gung-ho coverage of the Persian Gulf war. (Or, for that matter, Israeli reporting on the intifada: Most Tel Aviv editors seem to accept Prime Minister Ariel Sharon's view that the press's job is "to give the nation pride and hope.") The fact is that Arab television, radio, newspapers and magazines have come a long way in recent years. Gone is the time when Arabs had to turn for the truth to the BBC, as in the Six Day War of 1967, when Egyptians learned from London of a calamitous defeat even as Cairo trumpeted triumph.
In the heyday of Arab nationalism, in the 1960's, it was said that the sound of battle should drown all other voices -- that there should be no dissent. Now that private satellite channels vie with state broadcasters and Arabic dailies published in London compete with local newspapers, there are multiple voices. Some, like Al Jazeera, rival and sometimes surpass Western models for the quality and timeliness of their reporting. It was Al Jazeera that broke the story of the April 7 ambush in Jenin in which Israel lost 14 men.
To an extent, it is the very modernity of today's Arab media that fuels passions. Television has a natural penchant for stripping events of their historical context, instead framing them as a sequence of climaxes under one dramatic heading, like "America's War on Terror." Yet it does not really require subtle manipulation to frame the ongoing tragedy as an epic struggle of the weak against the strong. The imagery saturating Arab screens, of tanks crushing ambulances and helicopters rocketing refugee camps, is, alas, all too real.

HEADLINE: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE; 
Mining a Revenue Stream

BYLINE:  By ROBERT SHAROFF 

 BODY:
"I call it stadia-mania," Martin Greenberg said of the wave of stadium construction in the last decade. Mr. Greenberg is managing director of ScheerGame, a sports and entertainment development and consulting firm in Milwaukee, and author of "The Stadium Game" (Marquette University Press, 2001), a book on stadium development.
 By the end of the 1990's, he said, 46 percent of all major league sports teams were playing in stadiums that were less than 10 years old. 
 A major reason for the new projects, Mr. Greenberg said, is the rise of premium seating -- like sky boxes, club seats and so-called personal-seat licenses -- as a major source of revenue for team and stadium owners. 
Football sky boxes, in particular, are seen as desirable, as the money from these amenities, unlike revenue from general gate receipts and personal-seat licenses, is not subject to the National Football League's rules on revenue sharing.
"It' a huge economic incentive for N.F.L. clubs," said Matthew Mitten, director of the National Sports Law Institute at Marquette Law School in Milwaukee. 
At the new Soldier Field, sky boxes are to be priced from $70,000 to $300,000 a year, while full-price club seat buyers will pay $195 to $315 a game, in addition to a one-time licensing fee of $2,900 to $10,000 a seat.
These prices put the Bears near the top for premium seating. According to Media Ventures, a publishing company in Milwaukee that tracks stadium revenues, sky boxes start as low as $24,000 for the Atlanta Falcons at the Georgia Dome and go as high as $358,000 for the New York Jets at Giants Stadium. It said that prices for club seats start at $440 a year for the Buffalo Bills at Ralph Wilson Stadium and top out at $6,000 a year for the New England Patriots at CMGI Field in Foxboro, Mass. ROBERT SHAROFF

HEADLINE: Though Coke Reports Loss, Some Foresee Better Days 

BYLINE:  By GREG WINTER 

 BODY:
Despite a long-awaited resurgence in soda sales, Coca-Cola announced a $125 million loss for the first quarter yesterday, primarily because of required mandatory changes in its accounting methods and the dwindling value of its plants in ailing economies of Latin America. 
 Although revenue rose 3 percent for the quarter, to $4.08 billion from $3.96 billion in the period a year earlier, net income dropped by almost $1 billion. The bulk of that decrease stemmed from a required overhaul in the way companies account for their acquisitions -- a shift that, almost alone, produced a loss of 5 cents a share, in contrast to a profit of 38 cents a share a year earlier. 
Without the accounting changes, or the $157 million cost of writing down assets in Latin America, mostly in Argentina, Coke's earnings fell a penny shy of the 38 cents a share analysts had forecast. The company cited weakness in the Japanese yen, the Argentine peso, the Venezuelan bolivar and the South African rand as causes for its performance. 
Yet behind the loss, the beginnings of a turnaround promised by Douglas N. Daft, Coke's chief executive, seemed visible. After years of little movement, Coke's sales in North America, its largest market, increased 5 percent, feeding a newfound confidence among company executives. Shares of Coke rose $1.49 yesterday, to $53.88. 
"The fact of the matter is, cola growth has been reasserted in North America," said Jeffrey Dunn, president of Coke's operations in the United States, in a conference call with analysts and investors. 
To some, Mr. Dunn's declaration was a bit of an overstatement, particularly because Coke's most recent results were buoyed by an Easter holiday that occurred in the first quarter this year. Still, when compared with the inertia in the carbonated-drink industry over the last two years, most analysts viewed the 3 percent increase in Coke's soda sales as refreshing. "The sleepy giant is in the waking," said Andrew Conway of Credit Suisse First Boston. "Is it going at the speed it needs to be going? No. But it's headed in the right direction."
Indeed, the company's confidence grew enough for it to raise its earnings estimate for all of 2002, if only by a penny, after years of guarding against investor disappointment by whittling its own growth targets. With a lower tax rate than previously expected, the company said its earnings estimates should increase to a range of $1.77 to $1.81 a share from a range of $1.76 to $1.80.
Marc Cohen, a Goldman, Sachs analyst, remarked: "It's not a number that causes an earthquake, but it is significant. As far as we remember, this is the first time that the company has guided numbers higher in three years."
It is somewhat unclear why soda consumption, particularly in the United States, seems to be edging out of its slump. But part of the resurgence can be attributed to the soda companies, which have been expanding their carbonated-drink offerings in an effort to lure consumers back to the kinds of drinks that brought them success in the 1990's. 
"The category badly needed some news and excitement," said John Sicher, editor of Beverage Digest, an industry newsletter. "With products like Pepsi's Code Red last year, and now Vanilla Coke this year, it seems to be getting some."

HEADLINE: Factory Output Rises; Oil Costs Worrisome 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 16 

 BODY:
Industrial production posted the biggest gain in nearly two years, the Federal Reserve reported today. But prices crept slightly higher, reflecting a worrisome rise in oil costs, a potential hazard for the young economic recovery.
 The Fed said that output at the nation's factories, mines and utilities rose 0.7 percent in March, after a 0.3 percent gain in February -- a sign that the turnaround in manufacturing is gaining momentum. It was the third consecutive monthly increase and surpassed expectations. 
 Though the economic revival is not causing a run-up in consumer prices, soaring oil costs are a concern. A drastic increase could slow or derail recovery. "Oil prices -- that's the great wild card," said David Seiders, chief economist for the National Association of Home Builders.
In a separate report, the Labor Department said the Consumer Price Index, a closely watched inflation gauge, rose 0.3 percent in March, after a 0.2 percent advance in February. Analysts had expected a 0.5 percent increase. Virtually all the pickup came from energy prices, which rose 3.8 percent, the biggest increase in 10 months.
Middle East tension was the main force behind the increase. Oil prices retreated last week, then rose on Monday, stoked by political uncertainties in Venezuela, a leading exporter. Today, oil edged up 18 cents further in New York, settling at $24.75.
While many economists think that energy prices will moderate, they acknowledge that soaring energy costs are a potential Achilles' heel for the recovery. "In general, higher oil prices are a bad thing for the economy," said Bill Cheney, chief economist at John Hancock. "They represent a very real cost to the U.S. that feeds through the whole economy." 
Gasoline prices went up 8 percent in March, the largest advance in six months, reflecting higher crude oil costs and greater demand. Fuel oil prices rose 2.2 percent, the biggest increase since December 2000, and natural gas prices rose 0.8 percent.
Food prices were up 0.2 percent for the second consecutive month.
Excluding energy and food prices, the so-called core rate of inflation moderated, rising just 0.1 percent last month, down from a 0.3 percent increase. This suggested that most other prices remained under control.
In the Fed's report, the 0.7 percent increase in industrial output matched the rise registered in May 2000 -- before battered industries fell into a slump. For the first quarter, industrial activity rose at a pace of 2.5 percent, a big improvement over the 6.7 percent rate of decline in the last quarter of 2001.
At factories, production rose 0.8 percent in March, the strongest showing in two years.
As manufacturers pick up steam, home building, which propped up the economy during the slump, is losing somewhat.
Housing construction fell 7.8 percent in March, the largest decline in two years, the Commerce Department said today. Analysts had expected a 3.9 percent decline. Even with the drop, builders began work on 1.65 million units, at an annual pace, a still robust level. While economists predict a slowing, they still expect healthy activity.

HEADLINE: Music Services Aren't Napster, But the Industry Still Cries Foul 

BYLINE:  By MATT RICHTEL 

 BODY:
The record industry's legal victory over Napster last year has neither stopped the trading of free music online nor halted a slide in music sales.
 A new generation of free music exchanges has blossomed in place of Napster, which was forced offline by a California court in July and has yet to return. So the record companies have found themselves back in courtrooms worldwide and are facing a more complicated set of legal questions. 
 The results have been mixed, with record companies applauding a decision reached last week by a Japanese court against a Napsterlike service there, but denouncing one last month in the Netherlands, where a court found that the users, not the music service, were to blame. 
In perhaps the most significant battle, the music and movie industries are in Federal District Court in Los Angeles fighting three services -- Kazaa (whose software is now distributed by Sharman Networks), Grokster and Morpheus, from StreamCast Media -- that can be used to exchange not only music, but also films and other digital media. Tens of thousands of new users download the free software each day. The networks are supported by advertising that they send to users' computers.
Underscoring the industry's woes, a survey released today by the International Federation of the Phonographic Industry, an international record industry trade group, found that revenue from global music sales fell 5 percent in 2001, to $33.7 billion. The federation attributes the decline, the largest since the mid-1980's, to the global economic slowdown and the copying of music, though it could not provide figures indicating the precise impact of either factor.
Still, Jay Berman, the chief executive of the industry federation, asserted that the sales declines "reflect the fact that the commercial value of music is being widely devalued by mass copying and piracy."
Some industry analysts disagree. Aram Sinnreich, a music industry analyst with Jupiter Communications, said that sales were dropping because of the cyclical nature of the music market. "Very little of it can be ascribed to online music sharing," he said.
Increasingly, these matters are being debated in court.
Last week, in a lawsuit filed by Japanese record companies, the Tokyo District Court issued a ruling against Japan MMO, which operates a free music exchange service called File Rogue. In granting a temporary injunction, the court ruled that Japan MMO must not provide File Rogue's users the option of downloading songs whose copyrights are held by any of the 19 Japanese record companies that filed the lawsuit.
But record companies and their representatives are far less pleased with a recent ruling by a Dutch appellate court. In that ruling, the court found that the people using a music exchange -- in this case, Kazaa -- were the ones violating copyright laws, not the Kazaa service itself.
In the Los Angeles case, scheduled for trial in October, the Recording Industry Association of America, which represents the major record companies, has sued StreamCast Networks, Grokster and Kazaa.
The record companies are hoping to rely on points they established in the Napster case. "They are doing exactly the same thing -- both from a consumer perspective and from a copyright-holder perspective," said Matt Oppenheim, senior vice president for business and legal affairs at the recording industry association.
But the defendants say they must be judged differently from Napster because, they say, the new exchanges have a fundamentally different technological underpinning.
On Napster, users exchanged songs that they kept on their own computers. But to find out what songs were available through the system, they filed a search request that went through Napster's computers.
Users of Morpheus, Grokster or Kazaa software trade music from their own computers, but they also use their own computers to search for the music they want. Specifically, the software looks around the network of users for those with the most powerful computers, turning those computers temporarily into hubs that other users can tap into to search the rest of the network.
Lawyers for the software makers say that once they introduce the software into the market, they not only cannot control how it is used but also cannot completely shut down their systems because those networks do not rely on the companies' computers. 
"The peer-to-peer systems in this case do not have central servers, like Napster," said Judy Jennison, a lawyer for Kazaa. She said that was the major difference in the cases, "drilled down to its finest point."
But the record companies say that the services have far more control than they let on. Lawyers for the music companies point out that the Morpheus system, for example, was taken offline in February for a software change. 
Justin Hughes, a visiting law professor at the University of California at Los Angeles who is an expert in intellectual property and Internet law, said the fact that Kazaa and Streamcast did not have centralized servers made this a more "complicated case."
But in his view, he added, such a system will not cause a court to rule in the online services' favor. "I expect a lot of people in the judiciary will look at this and say, 'This does not meet the smell test,' " he said.

HEADLINE: Independent Considers a Third Run for Governor 

BYLINE:  By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. 

DATELINE: ALBANY, April 16 

 BODY:
B. Thomas Golisano, the Rochester billionaire who has twice run for governor as an Independence Party candidate, said today that he was leaning heavily toward running a third time and would make a formal announcement in three weeks.
 Speaking at a fund-raiser in Albany, Mr. Golisano said the only development that could keep him out of the race would be the Independence Party's choosing a strong candidate not affiliated with a major party. A majority of the party's leaders have already decided to throw their line on the ballot to the Republican incumbent, Gov. George E. Pataki. 
 "To turn the nomination over to another major party today would be a huge mistake," he said.
Mr. Golisano, whose personal worth is more than $1.7 billion, said he would challenge Mr. Pataki in a primary for the Independence line if the party nominated the governor. If he lost the primary, he said, he would circulate petitions and run as an independent candidate in the general election. He would need at least 15,000 signatures to do that.
If he ran, Mr. Golisano could hurt Mr. Pataki among upstate conservatives and independents. He attracted about 4 percent of the vote in 1994 and twice that in 1998 with a message of lower taxes, limits on campaign contributions and better schools.
Mr. Pataki has wooed the Independence Party's leaders successfully, promising to support a constitutional amendment allowing citizens to put legislation on the ballot through petition drives. That proposal is critically important to the party rank and file.
"The party's going to nominate George Pataki this year," said Jeffrey E. Graham, a member of the executive committee and a former mayor of Watertown. "It's pretty much a lock."
But Mr. Golisano said he was disappointed in Mr. Pataki's record in helping the upstate economy and lowering taxes.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
 G.M.'s Profit Drops 3.8% But Exceeds Expectations
The revival of General Motors continued as it reported a slight decrease in earnings, well above analysts' expectations, despite financial difficulties at its European unit. G.M. reported net income of $228 million, or 57 cents a share, with sales of $46.3 billion. That was down 3.8 percent from a year earlier. The company also raised its 2002 earnings estimate to $5 a share from $3.50. G.M.'s shares rose almost 5 percent, to $64.05. Page C4.

Bristol's Financial Officer Resigns
Bristol-Myers Squibb, struggling to recover from a series of disappointments, said that Frederick S. Schiff, its chief financial officer, would leave. Harrison M. Bains, vice president for tax and treasury, will serve as acting chief financial officer. C2.

Adelphia May Restate Its Results
Adelphia Communications, the cable television company that surprised Wall Street by disclosing that it had guaranteed $2.3 billion in debts owed by entities controlled by its founding family, said that it might restate its past financial statements to reflect those debts. C4.

Tribune May Owe Back Taxes
The Tribune Company has disclosed that it could owe up to $880 million in back taxes and interest as a result of two 1998 Times Mirror transactions whose tax-free basis has been disallowed by an I.R.S. audit. C13.

Shares Rally on Earnings Reports
Stocks climbed in a broad-based rally on strong earnings reports and forecasts. The Nasdaq composite index jumped 63.01 points, or 3.6 percent, to 1,816.79. The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 207.65 points, or 2.1 percent, to 10,301.32. The broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 25.82 points, or 2.3 percent, to 1,128.37. C14.

Coke Reports $125 Million Loss
Despite a long-awaited resurgence in soda sales, Coca-Cola announced a $125 million loss for the first quarter, primarily because of required mandatory changes in its accounting methods and the dwindling value of its plants in ailing economies of Latin America. C4.

Ruling on Shredded Tobacco Data
A court ruling in Australia that British American Tobacco had carried out a systematic, worldwide program to destroy internal files that documented the health risks of smoking has ramifications in the United States. The Justice Department has asked for evidence of the corporate shredding. A10.

'Early Show' Producer to Step Down
Steve Friedman, left, executive producer of the CBS "Early Show" and a key figure in the history of morning television, said he would leave the program by June. CBS has chosen Michael Bass, a former producer for the top-rated "Today" show on NBC, to succeed him. The departure of Mr. Friedman brings to an end CBS's most aggressive -- and ultimately unsuccessful -- effort to make strides in morning television. Advertising. C13.

Vivendi Executive Is Forced Out
Jean-Marie Messier, chief executive of Vivendi Universal, fired Pierre Lescure, the head of the money-losing French pay-television unit Canal Plus. World Business, Section W.

Objections to Soldier Field Plan
A $606 million plan to renovate the historic Soldier Field in Chicago by constructing a seating bowl that will accommodate 123 new skyboxes and 8,500 premium club seats has drawn fire from architects and preservationists and has also led to a lawsuit by two civic groups. Commercial Real Estate. C10.

HEADLINE: Players and Owners Differ Over Balance 

BYLINE:  By Murray Chass 

 BODY:
The last time labor representatives of the owners and the players met, the players proposed a novel approach to the competitive balance problem that the owners say is hurting Major League Baseball. When talks resumed yesterday after a five-week hiatus, the owners didn't reject the proposal; they instead asked questions before preparing their rejection.
 "We did not substantively respond to the proposal other than to ask questions about the rationale for it," Bob DuPuy, baseball's chief operating officer, said. But he left no doubt that the players came up significantly short with their idea of moving players and draft choices around instead of 50 percent of the clubs' local revenue that Commissioner Bud Selig wants to move. 
 "The commissioner," DuPuy said in a telephone interview, "has made it clear there needs to be certain economic benchmarks achieved through bargaining, both in revenue sharing and salary restraint in the form of a competitive balance tax. He hasn't deviated from that. There are additional reforms he feels can help competitive balance, but he views those as enhancements rather than substitutes."
 In their March 13 proposal, the players indicated their willingness to accept a world draft of amateur players the owners want to create, though with some different elements, and they proposed a professional player draft, in which the weakest teams would select players from the strongest teams.
 They also proposed allowing teams to trade draft choices, negotiating rights to drafted players and newly signed draft choices, and they proposed changes in the June amateur draft and the December draft of minor league players, all weighted toward poorer clubs.
 But the players continued to reject a payroll, or competitive-balance, tax and they stuck to their revenue-sharing position, in which they would agree to having clubs share 22 percent of their local revenue, using a different method from Selig's plan that calls for 50 percent to be shared. The commissioner also wants to impose a 50 percent levy on portions of payrolls over $98 million.
 "Our questions today were designed to understand more completely their proposal so we can formulate responses to it," DuPuy said. "It was the start of what I hope will be a long series of working sessions designed to get us closer to a deal."
 Donald Fehr, the union leader, said the union would begin responding to the clubs' questions at today's session.
 The two newest members of the owners' negotiating team attended yesterday's meeting at the commissioner's office in New York. One person who attended the meeting said Peter Angelos, owner of the Baltimore Orioles, and Andy MacPhail, president of the Chicago Cubs, listened but did not speak. Murray Chass

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Broad-Based Rally Lifts Shares and Hopes for Recovery

BYLINE:  By SHERRI DAY 

 BODY:
Stocks climbed in a broad-based rally yesterday as several companies including Johnson & Johnson and General Motors reported better-than-expected financial results and reignited investors' hopes that an economic recovery is under way.
 Technology issues led the market's surge as positive forecasts from Novellus and Texas Instruments lifted the semiconductor sector. 
 "We got off to a good start with the Texas Instruments and the Novellus news, so it's making people focus on the recovery again," said John Forelli, senior vice president and portfolio manager at Independence Investment in Boston. "We've had a couple of days where people have been worried about corporate earnings" since General Electric reported weaker-than-expected results on Thursday. 
"The reality is the economy and earnings prospects are improving," he said, "and today is a day where investors are deciding to take advantage of that."
Bolstered by the gains in the technology sector, the Nasdaq composite index jumped 63.01 points, or 3.6 percent, to 1,816.79. The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 207.65 points, or 2.1 percent, to 10,301.32. The broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 25.82 points, or 2.3 percent, to 1,128.37.
The mood could turn, however, if a big company issues disappointing earnings. 
After the market closed, Intel reported first-quarter earnings that were largely in line with Wall Street's expectations, but investors initially reacted enthusiastically.
Excluding acquisition-related charges, the company posted a profit of $936 million, or 14 cents a share. Craig R. Barrett, the chief executive, said that demand in emerging markets remained strong but that weak spending continued to affect established markets like the United States and Europe.
Shares of Intel gained $1.40, to $29.51. Shares rose as high as $31.50 in after-hours trading. 
Shares of Texas Instruments rose $1.66, to $33.79. The company said late Monday that it had "turned the corner toward growth" and expected stronger sales and profits throughout the year, after posting a loss of $38 million, or 2 cents a share, in the first quarter.
Novellus, which also makes semiconductor equipment, gained $3.06, to $53.46, after it reported financial results on Monday that beat Wall Street's expectations and said it expected sales to improve. 
The upbeat forecasts from the two companies spilled over into the entire chip sector. Applied Materials gained $2.72, to $54.16; Linear Technology rose $2.56, to $43.88; and Xilinx picked up $1.37, to $42.56. 
The Philadelphia Stock Exchange's semiconductor index climbed 31.92 points, or 5.6 percent, to 603.54. 
Telecommunications stocks also recorded gains yesterday on the heels of an earnings report from Sprint, which reported earnings of $286 million, or 32 cents a share. Wall Street had expected Sprint, the nation's third-largest long-distance company, to earn 30 cents a share. Shares of Sprint surged $2.79, to $16.26.
Other long-distance companies rose on Sprint's announcement. WorldCom rose $1.16, to $6.23; AT&T gained $1.34, to $14.89; and the MCI Group climbed 83 cents, to $5.58.
Sprint's wireless unit, Sprint PCS, rose $2.58, to $12.60, after it reported a quarterly loss of 15 cents a share. Analysts had predicted that the company would lose 20 cents a share.
Other wireless stocks moved higher as well. Nextel rose $1.48, to $5.95, and Leap Wireless was up $1.02, to $10.68. 
Among the Dow industrials, General Motors gained $2.95, to $64.05. The company reported that its first-quarter earnings excluding special items rose to $791 million, or $1.39 a share, exceeding Wall Street's forecast of $1.14 a share. Company officials said strong sales in North America and cost reductions were largely responsible for the increase.
Johnson & Johnson rose $1.10, to $63.26, after it reported profit of $1.83 billion, or 59 cents a share, compared with $1.55 billion, or 50 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. The company said strong sales growth of drugs that treat anemia, arthritis and schizophrenia were responsible for the increase. --------------------

Treasury Prices Fall (By Reuters)
Treasuries fell yesterday as a surge in stocks prompted dealers to book profits after a two-week government bond rally fueled by increasing prospects the Federal Reserve would be slow to raise interest rates.
Stocks soared as Wall Street cheered higher sales forecasts from an array of top companies.
Data showing industrial output increased sharply in March, drawing funds out of Treasuries into stocks.
The market mostly shrugged off economic data for March showing tame core inflation pressure and a sharp drop in housing starts.
By late in the day, the price of the 10-year note dropped 13/32, to 97 20/32. The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 5.19 percent from 5.13 percent on Monday.
The 30-year bond fell 17/32, to 96 1/32. Its yield rose to 5.66 percent from 5.62 percent.

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
Economist Testifies For Microsoft

BYLINE:  By AMY HARMON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 16 

 BODY:
An economist testifying for the Microsoft Corporation told a federal judge today that the company's antitrust violations had not harmed consumers or significantly damaged competition in the market for PC operating systems.
 Kevin M. Murphy, an economist at the University of Chicago, said the court would be justified in imposing only a narrow set of restrictions on Microsoft, given the lack of evidence that the competitive landscape would look any different had the company not acted illegally to preserve its Windows monopoly. 
 "The goal of restoring competition," Dr. Murphy said, "is to restore the prospects for consumer welfare to what would have existed in the but-for world; that is, what those prospects would be but for the anticompetitive acts in question." 
A federal appeals court held last year that Microsoft illegally preserved its monopoly in a series of acts intended to sideline the Netscape Web browser and the Java programming language, which posed a potential threat to Windows.
Dr. Murphy is one of two expert economists scheduled to testify for Microsoft at a hearing on how to restore competition and prevent the company from repeating its unlawful behavior.
Netscape and Java failed to evolve into viable alternatives to Windows almost entirely because of factors unrelated to Microsoft's unlawful acts, Dr. Murphy argued.
Netscape, he said, suffered in part because it continued to charge for its browser after Microsoft released its rival program Internet Explorer free -- a perfectly lawful business practice, according to the appeals court.
Java depended on Netscape to achieve wide distribution on desktop computers, and as Netscape's share of the browser market plunged from 80 percent in 1996 to 15 percent today, Java's chances of success as a Windows challenger eroded, Dr. Murphy said in his written testimony.
Stephen Kuney, a lawyer for nine states that are seeking broad restrictions on Microsoft's business practices, suggested that Dr. Murphy's testimony flew in the face of facts already established by the appeals court. He pointed to several places in the court's decision that described a particular Microsoft act as having a "substantial effect" on protecting the company's market power, which Dr. Murphy described as having only a "small effect" or "virtually no effect" on the future of Netscape and Java.
But Dr. Murphy, who adopted a folksy manner on the witness stand, insisted there was no contradiction. He pointed to language in the appeals court decision indicating that the lower court should consider the degree to which Microsoft's illegal acts actually influenced competition in deciding what sort of penalty to impose on the company.
Much of Dr. Murphy's testimony was aimed at refuting that of Dr. Carl Shapiro, who testified earlier this week as the expert economist for the states. Dr. Shapiro argued that antitrust sanctions should account for the fact that the explosive growth of the Internet had provided a rare opportunity for competitors to challenge Microsoft's monopoly.
Dr. Murphy disagreed, arguing instead that the even wider use of the Internet today allowed for greater threats to Microsoft than when the medium was relatively new. The package of penalties proposed by the states who have dissented from a settlement proposal between Microsoft and the Justice Department, he said, "unduly restricts competition and will harm consumers."
Earlier today, W. Jerry Sanders III, the chairman of Advanced Micro Devices Inc., acknowledged that he had testified against the states' proposals on Microsoft's behalf as a favor to the company's chairman, Bill Gates, even though he had not read them. Mr. Sanders testified that the proposals would hurt the personal computer industry and A.M.D., the second-largest maker of microprocessors after the Intel Corporation. 
On cross-examination, Mr. Sanders acknowledged that after agreeing to Mr. Gates's request in a Feb. 8 telephone call, he sought Microsoft's public support for A.M.D.'s next generation of silicon chips. 
"We were hopeful Microsoft could support A.M.D. as the only remaining viable alternative to an Intel monopoly," Mr. Sanders testified.

HEADLINE: Enron Staff Is Biding Time At a CompanyThat Isn't There 

BYLINE:  By DAVID BARBOZA with JOHN SCHWARTZ 

DATELINE: HOUSTON, April 16 

 BODY:
Despite the turmoil and uncertainty at Enron headquarters here these days, there are executives who can now admit to arriving at the office late each morning and punching out at 5, something unheard-of in the heady days when the company dominated the energy business.
 Senior executives now find time to drive their children to school and leave work early to catch a daughter's soccer game. Calls to Enron employees at 4:45 on a weekday afternoon might find them headed to a high school baseball game in the Bellaire district of Houston. 
 "I see it every day," said Chris Schlaudraff, an administrator who now works part time at Enron because she is educating her three children at home. "Our group is pretty busy, but some areas are relaxed enough to let people go to dance recitals, soccer games, football." 
Bankruptcy and a number of federal investigations have changed everything at the Enron Corporation, which once aspired to be "The World's Leading Company." The sense of urgency is gone.
"It's a different kind of place," said Keith Couch, who works in the information technology division. "Our V.P. has encouraged us to do our jobs but also to take advantage of some quality time outside of work."
Enron is hardly relaxed, of course, as it struggles to survive bankruptcy under Stephen F. Cooper, its acting chief executive, who would like to take it back to its roots as a power and pipeline company.
Enron has 23,000 employees worldwide, down from about 32,000 a year ago. But having shed all its new-economy ambitions to trade everything from natural gas to electronic bandwidth, it is a very different company, one whose future shape is still being determined.
The people who have remained at Enron still receive most of their old salaries, starting at about $150,000 to $200,000 for vice presidents and higher-level executives. But most of a vast legion of energy traders went to UBS Warburg when the trading operation was sold, and there are no more generous bonuses, stock options and other perquisites that often doubled or tripled salaries.
Add in the uncertainty about what tomorrow holds and it is no surprise that working at Enron these days is difficult. While some employees wait for their divisions to be sold or liquidated, others fret about new rules that forbid some departments to discard any documents. Few know if they will be there long enough to see whether Enron will emerge from bankruptcy. Indeed, the company is still regularly laying people off as the need for employees at its headquarters continues to shrink. Few employees hide the fact that they are looking for something else, something better.
"People were told to get a resume ready," said one employee in his 30's who asked not to be identified because of his propensity for searching for jobs online. "Every morning I'm on Monster.com, and no one says anything about it."
To glimpse inside the shimmering 50-story Enron headquarters is to watch a corporation take its last breaths as a colossus. The turnaround specialists, headed by Mr. Cooper, prowl the corridors, doing their best to lift spirits and revive a fallen icon. But the people who have worked here for years know things will never be the same.
The $100 billion company that existed a year ago is all but gone. Though much of its success was an illusion (some experts estimate that the new Enron will generate at most $5 billion in revenue), the people of Enron were the truest of believers.
"It's a totally different place," one midlevel executive said. "It's like sludge compared to the speed-of-light-way things happened before."
From the inside, the headquarters even looks different. About 3,000 employees now work in the glass tower, far from the crush of 6,000 that made for cramped floors and long elevator lines some months ago.
Now, there are deserted floors, vacant offices, rooms stockpiled with unused computers and areas where construction was suddenly halted in December. In some conference rooms, presentation boards are still marked by grand plans that were being hatched on the eve of bankruptcy. The electronic ticker that used to broadcast the company's stock price to insiders has gone dark.
"My friend came into the building the other day," one longtime executive said. "She said, 'How do you go in there every day?' "
Many employees have grown cynical about working at Enron. And who can blame them? Even top executives talk publicly about the bleak mood.
"I don't have any motivation," said one employee, who asked not to be identified for fear she might be dismissed. "I work in the corporate tax department, and no one here is willing to work late. We're just kind of in la-la land right now."
Many here share the pain of former colleagues like the more than 4,000 around the world who were let go on one day in December with little severance pay. But those remaining face the almost daily reminder of hearing about one scandalous disclosure after another. It is as if a scarlet "E" were sewn onto their clothing, some say. 
"This cloud is never going to go away," said one midlevel executive who has worked at Enron for nearly a decade. "It's sort of intangible, but there's that Enron taint. You pick up the papers, and everything that happened here is bad. Everyone has been cast in a bad light; no matter what you did here, it was bad."
To soothe employees, Mr. Cooper has delivered peppy voice mail messages to the staff each week, a mix of straight talk about the prospects for survival and heartfelt encouragement for those willing to stay the course.
"Hi everybody. It's Steve Cooper," one message began. "I just wanted to give you an update as to where we are with the retention and severance plan."
Indeed, Mr. Cooper has tried to be the honest broker who has long been missing from the Enron arcade. Last Thursday, he held his first all-employee meeting at the Hyatt Regency hotel a few blocks away.
He showed up in his trademark attire: a yellow baseball cap, a rumpled jacket, khakis and a golf shirt. Inside, he told a group of about 1,000 employees that he was bullish on Enron's future and that they should be, too.
"This is a Chapter 11, which is a reorganization," he said. "It's not a Chapter 7, which is a liquidation.'
He also paid tribute to those employees who have stuck with the company. "I personally can't imagine how you remain committed to being here," he said. "The last six to nine months must have been hell."
Indeed, many here talk about a restructuring team that is charged with doing what amounts to open-heart surgery on the corporation.
One Wall Street analyst said it had become increasingly difficult to talk to friends on the inside.
"All conversations have ceased," the analyst said. "Their morale has to be somewhere between the 8th and the 12th circle of hell right now."
One bright spot, some employees say, is that television news crews no longer show up each morning. "It's settled down a lot," Mr. Couch of the information technology division said. "Before, we were in a media circus."
Still, employees say that the company feels hollow, that few feel committed to it.
Stephen Schwarz, a former employee in the broadband division, said his friends were just trying to wait out the storm.
"Everybody has that short-timer's kind of attitude," he said. "Ride it out till you find something better." 
So, why do employees stay at a company that is disappearing like the Cheshire cat? Because having survived the corporate equivalent of the Titanic, some feel wedded to Enron; others, happy at least to have a paycheck, use the time to search for a better opportunity.
"There's no future here for the vast majority of people," one high-level executive said. "I don't think about a long-term future at the new company, but I have some time to plot out a new life."
To keep good employees, Enron asked the bankruptcy court to approve a severance and retention package for employees over the next year. In New York today, United States Bankruptcy Judge Arthur J. Gonzalez granted Enron permission to give the bonuses and severance payments to more than 1,700 executives and managers. The bonuses will cost $47.4 million to $140 million, depending on how much is raised at asset sales, Enron said in court papers.
Employees would be eligible for a large retention bonus -- in some cases, maybe $1 million -- if they stayed at least a year. And they would be promised at least $4,500, or two months' salary, in case of dismissal.
"This is the uncertainty of bankruptcy," Mark Palmer, an Enron spokesman, said recently. "That's why we're working so hard to put together a severance and retention plan, to give people some kind of certainty about their future."
Rather than simply dismantle Enron with a fire sale, Mr. Cooper -- who has helped other corporations, like Polaroid and Federated Department Stores, out of bankruptcy -- says his goal is to create a stable company with pipelines and utilities that span North and South America.
The new Enron would look something like the old, pre-90's Enron, before all the talk about being "asset light" and creating a trading giant that dealt in everything from bandwidth to paper and pulp.
Some old-timers like the idea of the company's returning to its roots. "I don't plan on going anywhere till they run me out," said a 24-year veteran of the pipeline operation.
But most of the troops greet one another like survivors of a terrible battle.
"I get calls every day, 'Sue, I'm so glad you're still here,' " one employee said, masking her true name. "Can you help me?"
Before, she said, the attitude was: Get this done! Now, the requests sound more like: Please get it done, if you can.
"Sometimes, it seems like a ghost town here," the woman said wistfully. In the old days, there was the tendency to look to the future. "Now, people are getting a little nostalgic."
