HEADLINE: Cuomo Calls Pataki Record A Failure 

BYLINE:  By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

 BODY:
As his father watched intently from the front row, Andrew M. Cuomo yesterday offered a lacerating attack on George E. Pataki's record as governor, denouncing Mr. Pataki's handling of the upstate economy, the condition of the public school system, and what Mr. Cuomo described as the faltering effort to rebuild the devastated site of the World Trade Center.
 For nearly 30 minutes, as Mr. Cuomo began a three-day tour across New York to formally promote his candidacy for governor that took him from Long Island to Albany yesterday, he repeatedly belittled the man who ousted his father, Mario, from the governor's office in the 1994 election. And he presented a case for why New York voters should now replace Mr. Pataki with another Cuomo in this gubernatorial election. 
 Andrew Cuomo, the former federal housing secretary, described Mr. Pataki's seven years as governor as "a record of failure." He said Mr. Pataki had brought little energy or imagination to the job, and he charged that Mr. Pataki had not fulfilled his bedrock campaign promises of cutting taxes, saying tax cuts would be a central part of his own economic development program. 
Not incidentally, the Democratic gubernatorial candidate sought to deflect Republican efforts to use any lingering animosity that might exist against the father to derail the son as he makes his first attempt for elective office.
"You're going to hear a lot of excuses from George Pataki. He's going to talk about the past," Andrew Cuomo said in a morning speech in Brooklyn, as Mario Cuomo nodded attentively, his expression fixed and sober. "Why? Because he can't defend the present, and he has no vision for the future. That is why it is always about yesterday with George Pataki."
Mr. Cuomo made no direct mention of his opponent in the Democratic primary, H. Carl McCall, focusing his attention entirely on Mr. Pataki, who is seeking a third term and who is, in the view of many politicians, a formidable opponent no matter which Democrat wins the Sept. 10 primary. "It's not that George Pataki is a bad man.," Mr. Cuomo said. "It's just that he's not a good governor, and that is why I'm running for governor of the state of New York."
Mr. Cuomo, 44, portrayed yesterday's speech as his official entry in the race. In fact, there has been no doubt that he was running for office since he stated he was during a speech in New York City nearly 15 months ago; he has been campaigning nearly full-time since then. Aides to Mr. McCall promptly called reporters to denounce the day as an attempt to "revive a flagging campaign."
Nevertheless, whatever its real significance, the day was filled with what have become the trappings of a campaign announcement swing in New York. There was the appearance with Mr. Cuomo's family -- including his wife, Kerry, and three young daughters dressed in matching blue dresses with white trim who frolicked around the stage as Mr. Cuomo spoke. There was the campaign bus to take him across the state. There was even what appeared to be a campaign slogan -- "Ideas. Energy. Action." -- posted on the side of the bus and behind Mr. Cuomo as he spoke.
Most strikingly, though, it was a day about political dynasties and was filled with gentle reminders of the generational handoff that may be taking place in New York this year. 
Mario Cuomo attended his son's main speech, at a homeless shelter in Brooklyn that Andrew Cuomo created when he was running a private nonprofit homeless assistance corporation. The former governor did not speak (Bill Clinton also did not speak when his wife announced her own candidacy) but instead sat quietly in the front row next to his wife, Matilda Cuomo, and Ethel Kennedy, the widow of Robert and the mother of Andrew Cuomo's wife.
Mario Cuomo nodded and applauded as his son's voice filled the room with cadences and turns of phrase familiar to anyone who witnessed the first Cuomo campaign for governor in 1982. Andrew Cuomo, who was his father's campaign manager then, even used the same campaign theme song when he entered the room: the theme from the movie "Rocky."
Afterward, the former governor parried the questions about which Cuomo delivered the better speech with the answer that any father would give about a son who was about to take over the family business.
Aides to Mr. Pataki responded with their own attack, in particular challenging Mr. Cuomo's assertion that taxes have risen while Mr. Pataki has been in office. Lisa Dewald Stoll, the deputy campaign manager, noted that Mr. Cuomo had said total tax collections in New York increased to $44 billion from $34 billion over the last six years.
"We've replaced all the hundreds of thousands of jobs that Mario Cuomo drove out of the state: therefore, more people are paying more taxes, therefore the collective number would go up," she said. "That doesn't mean all these new people aren't having their taxes cut. They are."
She also challenged Mr. Cuomo's assertion that plans to rebuild the World Trade Center site were floundering under Mr. Pataki's leadership. "Ground zero is no place for partisan politics," she said. "I'm not going to comment on those unfortunate remarks."
Mr. Cuomo began his day on the courthouse steps of Nassau County, a reminder of how critical the suburbs will be in this election, before he headed upstate.
Most of his attention was focused on what he said would be the two main issues of the campaign: the upstate economy, a topic that Democratic statewide candidates have been using against Republicans with some success since Charles E. Schumer was elected to the Senate in 1998, and the condition of the state's public school system.
He reiterated his support for eliminating the Board of Education in New York City and putting the mayor in charge, and he said a comparable change should be made with the state system. "Who is responsible for education? The governor of New York. When I'm governor, the buck will stop on my desk."
Mr. Cuomo, who opposes the death penalty, invoked it in discussing how the state should deal with failing schools. "If you want to have a death penalty, let's have a death penalty for failing public schools," he said. "If a school doesn't work, two years and you're out."
On the economy, Andrew Cuomo sounded very much the way Mr. Pataki did in attacking Mario Cuomo eight years ago. "We're never going to be the empire state in terms of economic growth if we are the nation's tax capital," he declared. "We have to get taxes down. We have to lower taxes."
Mr. Cuomo argued that Mr. Pataki had created an illusion of cutting taxes by reducing state taxes and thus state support of local governments, which in turn had to raise property and other local taxes. The result, Mr. Cuomo argued, was that the overall tax load on New Yorkers was higher than ever.

HEADLINE: Senate Energy Bill 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Your April 10 editorial about the Senate energy bill, "The Missing Energy Strategy," reveals how much The New York Times has changed since endorsing responsible oil development on Alaska's coastal plain on three separate occasions in the 1980's. 
 Drastic new fuel economy standards would reduce gasoline use by forcing people into smaller, less safe four-cylinder vehicles. 
These same standards would raise the price of other commodities made from oil, including jet fuel, marine fuel and the feedstocks used to make plastics and other household products. 
Production from the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge would occur on 2,000 acres inside a 1.5 million-acre area that the Democratic Senators Henry M. Jackson and Paul E. Tsongas set aside for oil and gas exploration in 1980. 
That parcel abuts the rest of the 19 million-acre refuge, including the eight million acres of federally designated wilderness where environmental radicals take photographs used in newspaper ads against oil exploration on Alaska's coastal plain. 

TED STEVENS
U.S. Senator from Alaska
Washington, April 15, 2002

HEADLINE: Fed Is Expected to Hold Steady On Ratesfor Next Few Months 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 16 

 BODY:
With new statistics today providing further evidence that the economy is on the mend and that inflation remains under control, the Federal Reserve now seems likely to hold steady on the interest rates it controls for the next several months, economists said.
 Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, is expected to give investors some guidance about the schedule for any rate increases that may be coming when he testifies on Wednesday before the Joint Economic Committee of Congress. 
 Many Fed officials have indicated in recent weeks that they are not in a rush to raise the central bank's main rate, the federal funds target rate on overnight loans among banks. It is currently 1.75 percent, which is a 40-year low. 
Economic indicators released today appeared to confirm the officials' view that they could afford to be patient. The figures show an economy that is bouncing back from the recession, the first in a decade, without any sustained inflationary pressure other than a recent surge in oil prices. 
Industrial production in March rose 0.7 percent, its biggest gain in nearly two years, indicating that the worst may be over for the hard-hit manufacturing sector. The Consumer Price Index for March rose 0.3 percent, in large part because of the rise in oil prices; excluding food and energy costs, the index rose 0.1 percent.
Fed officials now appear all but certain to leave rates unchanged at their next meeting, on May 7. Investors in the interest rate futures markets are now betting that the Fed will not start tightening its policy until this summer, perhaps as soon as the meeting on June 25-26 but more likely at the session in early August.
Mr. Greenspan faces a choice in coming months, economists said. He can allow the bond market to begin pushing long-term rates higher in coming months in anticipation of a tighter policy from the Fed and a more robust economy, they said. Or he can get out in front of the bond market by raising the Fed's short-term rates to assure investors that he will keep inflation in check and try to keep long-term rates from going so high that the economy stalls again.
"Given that there is no immediate inflation risk, the Fed can afford to lead the market into higher rates gradually," said Ian Shepherdson, chief United States economist at High Frequency Economics, a consulting firm.
"We doubt there will be a rate hike in May," he added, "but we think the market is right to anticipate action in June."
But Fed officials face a particularly unsettled economic outlook, even beyond the usual questions associated with a cyclical rebound from a recession. The road ahead for the Fed could remain full of unexpected twists and turns even as it makes the transition from a period of aggressive rate cuts into what economists expect to be one of gradual rate increases.
The economy could well be subjected to further shocks as the Bush administration pursues its campaign against terrorism, especially if the United States tries to topple Saddam Hussein in Iraq. And the recent volatility in oil prices could slow the recovery. 
At home, the ramifications from Enron's collapse are still rippling through the corporate world. Internationally, the United States faces escalating trade tensions and the drag from Japan's economic paralysis. At its January meeting, the Fed even discussed how it would deal with a Japan-style crisis, in which official interest rates are already near zero but the economy needs more help from monetary policy.
Then there is the growing speculation that the Fed itself faces a significant transition. Mr. Greenspan, who has held his post since 1987, turned 76 last month, and although he has given no indication that he intends to retire anytime soon, there are persistent rumors in Washington and on Wall Street that he will step aside before his current four-year term ends in June 2004.
Whatever his own plans, Mr. Greenspan approaches the crossroads in Fed policy having won generally high marks for his handling of the recession. He continues to be criticized by some economists who say he raised rates too high in 2000 and was too slow to start cutting rates when the economy slowed late that year.
But his aggressive rate cutting -- starting early last year, before the extent of the downturn was clear -- delivered a powerful boost to the economy later in the year. And his willingness to flood the financial system with money after Sept. 11 to help stabilize Wall Street and the banking system helped minimize the economic damage from the terrorist attacks and keep the recession brief and shallow.
"I'd give them an A-minus, and the minus is only because of the inexplicable delay in acknowledging the slowdown in 2000," said John H. Makin, an economist at the American Enterprise Institute, a research organization. "When Greenspan became convinced they were behind the curve, they got started and moved very quickly in a way that was breathtaking, compared to other central banks. They made aggressive moves all year, and they had the right response to 9/11."
This business cycle largely confirmed Mr. Greenspan's judgment on two issues that will remain important. First, it validated his view that the improvement in the growth rate of productivity, or business efficiency, was more than a flash in the plan. Not only did productivity growth hold up through the downturn, but it accelerated at the end of last year.
Second, last year's experience has seemed to confirm that monetary policy has not lost its punch, a criticism voiced by some economists early in the downturn when the Fed's rate cuts did not seem to be packing much power. Although it took deeper rate cuts than expected to revive the economy -- no one at the beginning of 2001 predicted that the federal funds rate would drop 4.75 percentage points over the course of the year -- the Fed's actions did go a long way toward reviving the economy.
A report this month by Mickey D. Levy, chief economist at Bank of America, said the business cycle over the last year had disproved "the tired mantra that monetary policy had lost its power, that this recession was different and that a long downturn may be in prospect."
Mr. Greenspan did not get everything right. Some economists, for example, said that he had overemphasized the potential harm to the economy from the effect of falling stock prices on the willingness of consumers to spend and that he was slow to pick up on the seriousness of the downturn in business investment.
Not all economists are ready to credit Mr. Greenspan and the Fed with rescuing the economy. Some say growth may soon stall again, now that companies are completing the process of whittling down excess inventories.
"All the good things that happened in the economy after Sept. 11 were either one-shot deals or are likely to run out over time," said James K. Galbraith, an economics professor at the Lyndon B. Johnson School of Public Affairs at the University of Texas in Austin.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: LEGISLATION; 
A Move to Release Money To Pay Terrorism Victims

BYLINE:  By MATTHEW L. WALD 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 16 

 BODY:
Proposed legislation announced today would allow an American victim of state-sponsored terrorism who wins a civil judgment against another country -- Iran, Iraq or Libya, for example -- to collect money from assets of that country that have been frozen in the United States. 
 The measure, sponsored by a bipartisan group of five senators, is opposed by the Bush administration, which contends that the State Department needs to control frozen assets of foreign countries as a diplomatic tool. In fighting the bill, the Bush administration is adopting the same stance as the Clinton administration before it. 
 As a result of the opposition by both administrations, a 1996 law that allows victims to bring suits in American courts has been ineffective, advocates for victims say. 
"Current law allows American citizens to sue terrorist organizations for their losses, but they have been unable to collect, even though the United States Treasury Department lawfully controls at least $3.7 billion in assets of the seven state sponsors of terrorism," said Senator Tom Harkin, Democrat of Iowa, a sponsor of the bill. "Our own government has worked to keep these families from collecting. That's wrong and it needs to be corrected."
Sponsors of the measure are optimistic, noting that Congress has voted twice recently to help one group of victims, the American embassy staff who were held hostage in Iran from 1979 to 1981. A State Department spokeswoman declined to comment on the legislation.
One person with a judgment but no immediate prospect of collecting is Edwina Hegna, whose husband, Charles, was the United States Agency for International Development station chief in Pakistan. Mr. Hegna was on a Kuwaiti airliner that was hijacked in December 1984. He was beaten, and when the plane landed in Teheran, shot three times and dumped under the plane. 
Two days later, when the hijackers saw him move, they shot him three more times, Ms. Hegna said, and then allowed an ambulance to pick him up. He died on the way to the hospital, she said.
Ms. Hegna was awarded $42 million but has been unable to collect from Iran. She was one of several victims whose cases are in various stages who appeared at a news conference today to urge passage. Most said they were pursuing their cases not so much for money as for some measure of justice.
Stewart Dahl, a 22-year Navy veteran, was a petty officer in charge of a detachment of Navy divers when his plane was hijacked by Hezbollah militants and taken to Beirut; all the divers were beaten and one, Robert Dean Stethem, was killed. Their case is still in court here.
"We want to make terrorism costly; that's where it's going to hurt," Mr. Dahl said.
Also at the news conference were several Americans who were held hostage in Teheran after the fall of the Shah of Iran. Last year, they won a judgment against the Islamic Republic of Iran by default, but the State Department stepped in to argue that the agreement it made in 1980 with Iran to free them forbade suits against the Iranian government.
Another sponsor of the measure, Hillary Rodham Clinton, Democrat of New York, cited the case of Ira Weinstein, an American who was killed in the 1996 bombing of a bus in Jerusalem, with 23 others. The Hamas militant who detonated the bomb was trained by Iranian security personnel, she said; a judge awarded the family $183 million but it has been unable to collect.
"Crime does not pay," she said, "and neither should terrorism."
In addition to Iran, Iraq and Libya, the measure covers four other countries: Cuba, North Korea, the Sudan and Syria. Senator George F. Allen, a Republican of Virginia, another sponsor, said it was useless to hold on to the money as a negotiating tool when dealing with the "tyrants and despots" in the seven countries.
Iraq has over $2 billion in assets frozen; Libya over $1 billion; Cuba has about $90 million; and Iran about $350 million, plus $60 million in an account for military sales that were never completed, said Gary M. Shiffman, director of governmental affairs at Greenberg Traurig, a law firm. The other countries have minimal assets here, he said.

HEADLINE: Release of Budget Begins a Drama, Familiar, Yet Unscripted 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL COOPER and DIANE CARDWELL 

 BODY:
When Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg unveils his executive budget plan today, wrangling with the City Council will begin in earnest. For those involved in city government, it is the high season, the main event -- the time for lobbyists to lobby, advocates to advocate, and the city's executive and legislative branches to get down to some serious trading.
 The $40 billion question this year is how it will all play out with a new mayor and a new City Council trying to close a budget deficit of nearly $5 billion. There could be a reprise of what was likened in years past to a dance, in which the mayor proposed cuts with a wink and the Council restored them. Or Mr. Bloomberg may be able to bend the Council to his will, and get them to pass his plan. Then again, the Council could rise up and pass its own budget, as it did just once before, in 1998. And, of course, there is always the possibility that the two sides will amicably reach a compromise. 
 The mayor and the Council have already staked out wide areas of disagreement. The mayor is against all tax increases except one: an increase of $1.42 per pack for cigarettes, while the Council is pushing for a personal income tax surcharge that would pay for new schools and the restoration of a tax on commuters who work in the city but live elsewhere. But both sides say they expect to be able to negotiate an agreement by June 5, when the City Council is obligated by law to pass the budget.
"I'm confident that we are going to work with the mayor, as is our responsibility, to enact a budget that provides for the future of this city," Gifford Miller, the speaker of the City Council, said earlier this week. "I'm not at all worried about how things are going. I think it would be eerie if we all agreed in April." 
And although Mayor Bloomberg is expected to incorporate very few, if any, of the Council's proposals in his executive budget today, he said yesterday that he would look at some of its ideas, such as a call to sell more taxi medallions. 
The mayor is expected to say that the size of the deficit has grown to more than $4.9 billion, from his old projection of $4.76 billion, officials say. And he continues to prepare his contingency plan: deeper cuts that he would seek if the state and federal governments and the city's labor unions do not take the actions that he says are required to help the city save money. 
The size of the Police Department could drop further under the contingency plan. Officials said yesterday that the plan would call for pushing back the next class at the Police Academy from July until January, saving $63 million by delaying the hiring of 1,300 new officers to replace retiring officers. The backup plan would also scrap the mayor's previous plan to hire 800 civilians at the Police Department to replace officers who work at desks, freeing them for patrol duties. 
All told, officials said, the net effect of the contingency plan would be to reduce the targeted size of the force to 37,790, from the current target of 39,110. The department recently hit a peak strength of 40,710 officers, but it has found it difficult to maintain that size because officers are retiring faster than new cadets are recruited.
For those joining the city budget battles in the middle, here is a brief recap, in terms of a drama in five acts. The scene: the recession and the terrorist attack have driven down tax collections, and city spending has been rising in recent years, leaving New York with a $4 billion to $5 billion shortfall in the fiscal year that begins on July 1.
Act I came in February, when Mayor Bloomberg released a preliminary budget that called for closing the gap with $1.8 billion in cuts and savings at most agencies, including the Police and Fire Departments and the schools; $1.5 billion in borrowing, which he said was undesirable but necessary; and $1.3 billion in savings that would require action by the state and federal governments and the city's labor unions. His plan called for closing seven centers for the elderly, ending the recycling of bottles and cans, avoiding layoffs and raising only the cigarette tax.
Act II came earlier this month, when the City Council released its response to the mayor's budget. The Council called for restoring the cuts to education, keeping the recycling program and restoring services for the elderly. It proposed a surcharge on the personal income tax that would generate $400 million a year to build new schools, and called on the State Legislature to reinstate the commuter tax. The mayor responded that he opposed higher taxes, saying they drove away business. He added that it was unrealistic to expect Albany to approve higher taxes in an election year. 
Act III opens today, with Mr. Bloomberg's executive budget. Then comes Act IV: hearings, negotiations, protests. Act V, the grand finale, comes in June when, somehow, the City Council passes a budget for fiscal year 2003.
But no one is quite sure how the final acts will play out. Current and former officials and political analysts are still taking the measure of the new mayor and his administration. Many wonder how unified the new City Council is, and whether Mr. Miller, its speaker, will be able to negotiate on behalf of the whole body, as his predecessor, Peter F. Vallone, once did. With so many new officials and staff members, lobbyists find themselves unsure of whom to lobby.
For many years, budget negotiations in New York resembled a game, or a tug of war, or perhaps a stylized dance. Most years, the mayor proposed a series of budget cuts to social services, libraries and cultural institutions, and then the City Council restored them, leaving much of the mayor's plan alone, and claiming victory.
But with the city facing a giant budget gap, both sides agree that this year will be different from the games of the past. "We're not going to find that there are pockets of money hidden, where the City Council and the mayor play a game of one cuts and the other restores," Mr. Bloomberg said recently. "There isn't any money to restore."
Within the City Council, the question is how to push its agenda. So far, its signature issues have been calls to restore aid to education and the elderly, to save the recycling program, and to restore cuts to libraries and cultural institutions. Many of the Council's own proposals require state approval, which could be difficult to get, especially without the support of the mayor. The Council did not propose raising the one tax that it has control over, the property tax. So, if the budget is to be negotiated, the Council must set its priorities.
The alternative is that the Council passes its own budget. That happened in 1998, when Mr. Vallone, who was running for governor, and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani got into a heated battle over which taxes to cut, and whether the city should finance a new stadium for the Yankees. It grew into an all-out fiscal war: the Council passed its own budget, the mayor vetoed some items, the Council overrode the vetoes and the mayor refused to spend some of the money. The battle lasted nearly five months, until Mr. Vallone and Mr. Giuliani smoothed over their differences. 
It appears right now that the Council leadership wants to negotiate a solution. David Weprin, a Queens councilman who is the chairman of the Finance Committee, said yesterday that despite some early indications that some members wanted the Council to pass its own budget, there was now a strong consensus to reach an agreement with the administration. "I think a lot of people realize it's not a question of our proposal or his proposal," he said of the shift. 
But some council members have been taken aback by what they say are a series of slights from the mayor in recent days. Two council members who criticized the mayor said they had been barred from meeting with commissioners. Then Newsweek quoted the mayor as suggesting that the Council was not smart and did not understand the budget. 
Several council members said that rejecting the mayor's budget and passing their own was still a live option. "The Council clearly has the authority and the wherewithal to pass its own budget, and may have to undertake that strategy," said Councilman Bill Perkins, a Harlem Democrat. "The mayor will be the one to determine that, depending on how he negotiates."

HEADLINE: Bush and Daschle Set Terms For Their Battle on Budget 

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. SANGER and ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 16 

 BODY:
President Bush and the Senate majority leader, Tom Daschle, today staked out the battle over taxes, the budget and national defense that will probably define this year's Congressional elections. 
 Mr. Bush threatened to veto any spending that he thinks threatens the war on terrorism, and Mr. Daschle vowed never to allow a Senate vote that would make Mr. Bush's tax cuts permanent. 
 In a speech at the White House that sought to tie his budget to the nation's battle against terrorists, Mr. Bush invoked the lessons of Vietnam -- not the military battles but the budgetary lessons it left. 
"We must not repeat the mistakes in the 60's," he said, "when increased spending required by war was not balanced by slower spending in the rest of government." But he stopped short of declaring that Lyndon B. Johnson's Great Society program was a mistake, or suggesting that some of its provisions now be trimmed back.
Mr. Bush also hinted broadly that he had salted away money in the budget for a confrontation with Iraq and other countries accumulating weapons of mass destruction.
"I've got one country in mind," he said to nervous laughter in a brief speech to a group of business leaders calling themselves the Fiscal Responsibility Coalition. 
Raising the possibility that Iraq might seek to "team up with an al Qaeda organization," Mr. Bush said, "It's just not going to happen," and added "our budget reflects that." That was an apparent reference to the administration's budget request for a $10 billion military-action reserve fund that the president could draw on in case of an armed conflict.
Democrats have been enormously cautious about directly confronting the president on any spending for American troops or homeland defense. But Mr. Daschle today pointed out that the while the president was sharply increasing such defense spending, he was not making the same investment in domestic programs.
"We are also cutting taxes unlike anytime we have ever done since the early 1980's," Mr. Daschle said.
Those cuts expire in 2010, unless Congress acts to extend them, which Mr. Bush has urged it to do. Today Mr. Daschle vowed that Democrats would "never bring up the permanent tax cut the president has advocated."
"It is bad policy, it is wrong, and it compounds the budget disaster that our country currently faces," he said.
While it is early in the budget battles, both sides today seemed to be taking positions that could prove painful in the fall. Mr. Bush is likely to get all he asks for in defense, but the result may be that he must choose -- just before the elections -- between vetoing politically popular social spending programs or increasing the projected deficit. Mr. Bush said today that he now believed that deficit spending would end in 2004, but that estimate is based on projections that the American economy will strongly rebound.
Mr. Daschle is also playing with political fire: By refusing to bring to a vote proposals to make the tax cut permanent, he will be accused by Mr. Bush of favoring a tax increase. The president has already struck that chord many times in fund-raising speeches.
Mr. Daschle's declaration today was his strongest yet in response to Republican efforts to make the tax cut permanent.
The Republican-run House is planning to move this week to make the tax cut permanent and use the measure as an election-year campaign issue against the Democrats. The Democrats are saying in turn that the permanent extension of the tax cut risks the health of the Social Security system. 
"Keep in mind, every single dollar of this tax cut will be taken from the Social Security trust fund," Mr. Daschle told reporters after the weekly meeting of the Senate's party caucuses. 
The fight over the tax cut is part of a broader battle of competing agendas. Republicans today were once again accusing Mr. Daschle of being an obstructionist because he has blocked parts of Mr. Bush's agenda.
Mr. Daschle responded: "We're actually proud of the fact that we've stopped some bad legislation from becoming bad law. We stopped Enron from getting a $254 million bailout last fall." He was referring to tax cuts for corporations included in the Republican economic stimulus bill.
"We are going to stop ANWAR," he said, referring to the proposal for oil drilling in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge.
"We feel good about some of the things we've stopped," Mr. Daschle said, "because that's why we are here. We are the brakes to the administration at times when brakes are needed."
Mr. Bush's veto threat today was vague, but it was significant because it was the most direct he has uttered. "We don't have to get into needless partisan screeching over the budget," he said. "We've got to have some goals, and I've set the goals in terms of the war, and set the goals in terms of the homeland," he said, adding later, "and I've got a tool, and that's called a veto."
Mr. Daschle appeared unbowed by President Bush's threat.
"I think he needs to clarify what he is talking about," the senator said. "He is actually committed to spending at levels equal to, if not in excess, to anything we've seen in recent times. But mostly that spending has been in defense and homeland and security. 
"If he is keeping spending in check, I think it's only in those areas affecting education and health care and those issues directly affecting the people of this country and ways with which to ensure their strength and their ability to become citizens of this country in a way that give them the jobs and the future that they all want."

HEADLINE: NEW YORK/MILAN; 
Designers Turn Down The Volume

BYLINE:  By JOHN LELAND 

 BODY:
THE 30th annual Kips Bay Decorator Show House, which opens to the public on Tuesday, is intended to represent the state of the art in home decor. This year's show house is an 1871 limestone town house at 18 East 74th Street. All proceeds from the tickets (and a fifth-floor boutique) benefit the Kips Bay Boys and Girls Club in the Bronx. If you like what you see, the building is for sale. The asking price is $12.5 million. 
 Sixteen New York-area professionals, chosen in a competition, had 16 rooms to show off their best. For the sake of comparison, and to see how late-model home design is faring against the Great Escapists in Detroit, I added a 17th interior: a 2002 Cadillac Escalade sport utility vehicle. Car interiors have become increasingly homelike, adding luxe materials, elaborate entertainment systems and enough lounging room for a small cocktail party. 
 At the same time, home designers have resisted the ergonomic innovations of cars, like adjustable lumbar supports in sofa seats or split thermostats to cool one side of a bedroom without freezing the body on the other side. (The exception is the kitchen, for what is a Viking stove but a hot-rod engine with burners instead of wheels?) 
For a weekend, I bounced between the show house, a borrowed Escalade and my own not-ready-for-prime-time apartment. I sat in chairs, kicked tires and boomed the stereo. Let the games begin. 
Compared to past show houses, which have run to glorious excess, this year's rooms were quiet and restrained, short on big ideas and chintz, but long on soothe. Though several of the rooms would cost more than $1 million to replicate (the decorators get many of the furnishings and materials free in exchange for a mention in the program), there was little flaunting of wealth. "There's not so much glitter, glitz, gilding, over-the-top kind of things," said Harry Hinson, the event's honorary chairman, who has been involved with the show house for 30 years. 
Materials pulled back from conspicuous luxury. Gold and gold flake were almost absent, and the flashy electronics and giant plasma televisions that showed up in several rooms in past years, courtesy of a former sponsor, Philips, made only occasional cameos. Instead there were books on shelves and items from the designers' personal collections. Bright sorbet colors -- orange, turquoise, strawberry, lime, pale blue -- cast a warm glow over unpretentious and tasteful rooms. 
"I believe people want their homes to feel like a sanctuary or retreat," said Celeste Cooper, creative director of the design store Repertoire, who created a serene sitting room in off-whites and creams. Ms. Cooper's room was modernist with few sharp edges: club chairs in woven cotton, rayon, linen and goat-hair herringbone; a milky plexiglass mantle surrounding a marble flame; cool polished nickel coffee tables. All rested under a painted light box from Pucci that bathed everything in the color of flan. A marble bench by the artist Jenny Holzer, with the inscription, "You saw a way to survive and you were full of joy," threatened to push the mood past sanctuary toward final resting place.
Several decorators spoke about the restrained climate in response to Sept. 11 and the recession. "This room is about anonymity," Ms. Cooper said. "It's not about pedigree or provenance. The fabrics are luscious without being ostentatious. I think that's the zeitgeist."
Newcomers provided much of the energy. Katie Ridder, in her first year at Kips Bay, designed a small fourth-floor guest room in soft taupes and greens, creating a leafy retreat. She stenciled the walls in a white leaf pattern and designed a daybed with a back shaped like maple leaves. In a show house that was largely off-the-rack or out-of-the-atelier, this was an inspired bit of custom whimsy.
Ms. Ridder tried to do the room on what passes around here for a budget, reflecting a year in which some of her big-spender clients had either put off work or pulled back, replacing, say, an expensive Stark carpet with a cheaper sisal. The room would cost about $35,000 -- "but you could do it for $15,000 to $20,000 if you cut back on the materials," she said. 
T. Keller Donovan likewise trimmed the budget in his plum-and-white media room, done with a Miami theme. Amid more expensive items, like throw pillows in a custom fabric or a clever white butler's table with lots of storage, Mr. Donovan showed hanging shelves from Pottery Barn and a white shelf clock from Ikea. The Escalade, by contrast, was a showpiece of conspicuous consumption. Celebrated in songs like Missy Elliott's "Lick Shots," it is the S.U.V. of choice among rappers, N.B.A. players and other connoisseurs of the oversize ride. Unlike the show house rooms, the Cadillac aims to reflect the taste of its drivers more than its decorator, and that taste, like the stereo, runs to loud. The model I drove, including heated leather seats, power sunroof and an 11-speaker audio system, retails for $54,525, plus tax. 
Yet the Escalade design reflected a level of attention and accommodation toward its occupants that was missing at the show house. The S.U.V.'s seats adjusted every which way, with lumbar supports that both pushed and hugged my lower back, taking the cramps out of a long drive up the Hudson. Though they were not as seductive as the pristine white club chairs with cocoa leather piping in Michael Rosenberg and Leonard Kowalski's sixth-floor study in the show house, they were easier on the spine. 
This study, I should add, was one of the most successful rooms: soothing, uncluttered without being austere, with sea-green Ultrasuede draperies on the windows. This was their first time at the show house. 
Like many of the decorators, Mr. Rosenberg and Mr. Kowalski played stylistic Cuisinart, mixing Asian accessories with modernist lamps, a classic upholstered bench and carved mahogany demi-lune consoles. The effect was both impure and tranquil; it was balanced.
White linen mesh screens gave the room a diffuse glow. The subtle tan plaid wallpaper, by Art People Wall Coverings, created the effect of being in a well-lined drawer. 
After all that contemplative serenity, Jamie Drake's bright-orange third-floor landing added an infectious splash of clamor. "It's my kumquat smoothie," he said, seated at a blinding neo-Victorian sunflower-yellow sofa and surrounded by curved bright orange padded walls. Mr. Drake, also a newcomer here, made headlines recently as the decorator for Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, but if this landing was meant to reflect the new austerity of city hall, it overshot by several kilowatts. 
A self-portrait by Chuck Close stared intensely over the area, above twin benches in yellow lacquer that Mr. Drake used as coffee tables. He aimed for uplift rather than cool coddle. Even the jelly beans were orange. "I wanted to be upbeat and optimistic," Mr. Drake said. "I don't want to see anything depressing or dreary."
Mr. Drake, whose room is so extroverted, would not say what kind of car he drove. "That's getting too personal," he said.
Elsewhere, what was most striking about the house was what it lacked: no formal dining room, no decorator bath, no real living room. Instead there were studies, sitting rooms, drawing rooms and retreats -- modest, functional rooms for a year that called for modest statements and scaled-back ambitions. There were many sunburst mirrors, few grand arguments.
"We're moving away from the grand references and the celebrity of the decorator," said Greg Richardson, who worked on Albert Hadley's casually perfect sitting room. "It's more like being a psychiatrist, listening to what the client wants instead of telling them your vision."
As the show house rooms slouch toward sanctuary, they begin to function like the protective lozenge of an automobile. Do not expect to see cup holders in the living room just yet, but this year's house made this move for the most part in quiet good taste and an aura of comfort. Still pending is a concerted effort by furniture designers, outside the homely chairs of the home office, to deliver that comfort, high style and support to the spine. On Jamie Drake's sculptured sofa, I kept reaching for the four-way lumbar button, alas, to no avail.

The Kips Bay Decorator Show House is at 18 East 74th Street. Admission is $20. The house will be open Tuesday through May 19. Information: (212) 988-6991.

HEADLINE: ONLINE SHOPPER; 
And You Thought Eloise Was Fussy

BYLINE:  By Michelle Slatalla; E-mail: Slatalla@nytimes.com

 BODY:
MY most important preparation before traveling with children is to lie to myself.
 I love to travel with children. 
 (See how easy that was?)
I love to hear car-trip debates over whether we should listen to the first cassette tape from the second Harry Potter book for the third time before turning to the fourth book, which we already have heard five times. 
I love to discover, upon check-in, that we forgot to pack the stinky, shredded old rag known as Night-Night Blanket that my 4-year-old needs to fall asleep. 
Lies, lies, lies. Achieving that remarkable level of self-delusion would not be possible without some tiny basis in fact. So I am very, very picky when it comes to choosing a hotel. It must fit the image I conjure of The Check-In, a mental scene in which we tumble cheerfully from the car while the girls chatter (for some reason, in civil, quasi-British accents), "Why, Mummy, perhaps you should take a hot bath with the complimentary bath salts while we unpack."
My standards rival those of Eloise of the Plaza. That's why I never was able to complete a reservation online at any of the usual travel haunts, like Expedia.com, Travelocity.com and Orbitz, where I go for maps or airline tickets. Although I've been clicking on nonrefundable airline tickets for years, even the most tempting room rate raises questions I can only answer with follow-up phone calls to pester hotel clerks: What do you mean by "club room"? Is "pool" an indoor facility? Do the "bath amenities packs" include loofahs?
But last week, as I planned a weekend excursion with my three daughters to Cambridge, Mass., I figured it would make things easier if I just went online to a travel site, clicked on an available room, paid by credit card and printed out the confirmation number.
I started the search at Expedia (because I agree with Forrester Research's recent assessment that it is the most navigable of the major travel sites). My criteria were specific: I wanted a two-bed, nonsmoking room within easy walking distance of Harvard Square (to avoid having to get back into the car until it was time to go home).
Using an Expedia map that showed street locations, I narrowed the candidates to three: the Charles Hotel (intriguing, also, was the mention of a pool), the Inn at Harvard and the Sheraton Commander.
All sounded nice, but there were two problems: they were pricy (with rates from about $160 to more than $200 a night) and only the most expensive, the Sheraton Commander, was available for both nights.
I reserved the Sheraton Commander for $229 a night, figuring that if something better turned up later I could cancel without penalty since the Sheraton was not an Expedia Special Rate hotel (be warned: Suzi LeVine, an Expedia spokeswoman, said that canceling Special Rate hotels, a category that offers guaranteed low rates, will cost $25).
But I couldn't resist calling all three hotels, which is how I learned that the Charles Hotel also had a room available for $229 that had not been listed on Expedia. Under my relentless questioning ("How big is this pool?" "Indoor?" "Are fluffy towels available?"), the reservations clerk said that the pool actually belonged to a health club; hotel guests could only use it during limited hours. That's the kind of detail I would have been really irritated to learn after checking in.
Next I visited Farechase.com, a search site that looks for cheap rates listed on hotel chain sites, travel sites and hotel consolidator sites. The results listed only one hotel in Cambridge, the Holiday Inn Express Suites, for $339.90 a night. Among the dozens of results for Boston that I scrolled through, I also found the Salem, N.H., Holiday Inn ($158) and the Providence Airport Hotel in Rhode Island ($212). From either of those it would be a long walk to Harvard Square.
A search at other major sites, including Orbitz, Travelocity and Hoteldiscount.com, confirmed that rooms were scarce in the Boston area last weekend as visitors prepared to swarm into town for the Boston Marathon on Monday.
That night I tossed and turned over the high price of the Sheraton Commander. Maybe it was time to take a chance on a cheap room through Priceline.com, a site I always have avoided because you have to bid for a room without knowing which hotel the site might select for you (and an accepted bid is nonrefundable, even if you are not happy with the selection).
Two impulses were at war: my desire to micromanage my location and an equally strong desire to save money.
Cheapness won, at least temporarily, because the next morning I visited Priceline, where I learned I could narrow my geographic search only to the entire city of Cambridge, an area that according to the site's map extends approximately three miles.
A three-mile area was still a big gamble. On the other hand, what if I bid $70 and Priceline assigned me to the Sheraton Commander?
To remove some mystery from the blind bidding process, I visited BiddingForTravel.com, where Priceline bidders post messages describing their experiences. There I gleaned valuable intelligence about at least one Cambridge hotel that sells rooms over Priceline, from a post that described a successful $70 bid for a room at the University Park Hotel at M.I.T. I checked the map. Too far to walk.
By now it was Wednesday. I checked Expedia again and was shocked to see a Sheraton Commander rate of $189, $40 less than the rate posted two days earlier. I booked the lower rate. Minutes later it no longer was available.
"This feels like hotel roulette," I told Ms. LeVine of Expedia. "Why?"
"Usually hotel rates don't change like that," she said. "Unlike airfare, hotels don't have a predictable pattern for when they might open up new rates. But there may be a lot of strangeness in the system because of the Boston Marathon."
By then I figured I had a pretty good deal. But on a hunch, I checked the Sheraton Commander's own site again and saw the $189 rate available on an upgraded club room. Yes, I phoned and learned that a club room came with complimentary continental breakfast and "upgraded bath amenities."
"You mean lotions?" I asked. 
"Right," the clerk said. 
So I booked the club room directly through the hotel, canceled the Expedia reservation for the lesser-lotions-room and started to pack. My 11-year-old asked, "Will we be allowed to order room service?" 
"No," I said. 
"I love to travel with adults," she said.

HEADLINE: The Beige Box Fades to Black 

BYLINE:  By STEVE LOHR 

 BODY:
THE beige-box personal computer, the drab diehard of modern industrial design, became a visual standard without a lot of deep thought in 1981, when I.B.M. introduced its PC. It was functional, neutral, almost non-design, says Lee Green, the company's current director of design. Yet beige box it was, and bland proliferated for two decades, long after "it was obvious they were beyond boring," Mr. Green said. 
 Even earlier, the Apple II in 1977 was mostly beige, and the first cuddly Macintosh in 1984 was beige, though it was no conventional box. Irrefutably, however, it was I.B.M. that brought the personal computer into the mainstream, and the industry -- except for Apple -- followed its lead in industrial design, or the lack of it. The companies that rose in I.B.M.'s wake -- Compaq, Dell, Gateway and others -- were aptly termed clones. 
 But now the beige-box desktop PC seems headed toward extinction at last. The changeover has evolved gradually, along with the ways people think about their computers, but the pace is quickening as more and more PC makers abandon beige. 
Dell has moved from beige to black for all of its desktop machines. Hewlett-Packard had shifted to shades of gray by 1997 and has since settled on silver and dark gray. I.B.M. introduced its first black desktop PC in 1996 and completed its move to black in 2000. Last month Compaq announced that it was converting its consumer desktop PC's from beige, with some color panels, to black-and-silver designs. Next week, Gateway plans to introduce a series of desktop models with a non-beige color scheme. A safe bet: it will be dark gray or black. 
Beige desktops may be headed for the design dustbin, following the lead of notebook computers years ago, but dark gray and black are the new conformity. It scarcely qualifies as a deep insight that things often look better in black, thinking back at least to Coco Chanel's original little black dress of 1926, if not before. 
PC designers say that as black attire has became more commonplace beyond New York and Los Angeles, it has made black acceptable for mainstream PC's. Until recently, the designers say, market research had shown that many people regarded black as polarizing and extreme. 
Black is certainly an improvement over beige. Perhaps the shift is just the caboose in a trend of computers' following fashion. 
"The death of the beige box is really the tip of the iceberg," said Paul Saffo, a director at the Institute for the Future in Menlo Park, Calif., and a student of computer design. "Computers of all kinds -- desktops, notebooks, hand-helds, MP3 players and cellphones -- are embedding themselves deeper and deeper into our lives, and one of the things they have to do is dress better."
Manufacturers have come to realize that given the relentless pressure on PC prices, color and design might be a way to get noticed in a tough market. Besides, ignoring appearances could spell trouble when a rival has decided that design matters.
Sony entered the PC business with a consumer electronics mindset, adopting a purple-and-gray palette for its Vaio models. But the real innovator in computer design and the use of color has been Apple since Steven P. Jobs returned to the company in 1997. First came the one-piece iMac, introduced in 1998 in a translucent blue and white and released later in a selection of fruit colors. The rest of the industry derided the iMacs as "Life-Savers," but then several companies ineptly tried to echo Apple's design, mostly by slapping colored panels onto conventional desktop machines. 
That trend already seems spent. But this year Apple introduced another striking iMac desktop design: a flat-panel screen on a hinged silver strut connected to a white dome that houses the computer's processor and storage. Jonathan Ive, the company's director of design, minces no words in explaining why Macs look so different from other personal computers. "This industry generally has been creatively bankrupt," he said. 
For Mr. Ive and Mr. Jobs, that position is both a heartfelt belief and a marketing tactic. Not only design but also technology sets Apple apart from the rest of the industry, with its Macintosh operating system and Power PC microprocessor offering ramparts against the onslaught of Microsoft's Windows and Intel's microchip, known as Wintel. A recent Apple advertisement read: "If you're an accountant, you're most likely surrounded by beige Wintel boxes. But if you work in nearly every creative field, you most likely use a Mac." 
Industrial designers at other computer companies admire Apple's work. Yet they insist that its rarefied approach is a luxury that Apple can afford only because it is a niche company accounting for less than 5 percent of worldwide PC sales. 
In computing, the term "standard" is typically applied to a technology, in software or hardware. Those standards, particularly Intel's microchip, have become grist for economists and antitrust lawyers, who explain the dominance of such technologies with sophisticated language like "network effects," "path dependencies" and "increasing returns markets." 
Explaining an industrial design standard is more subjective. But the persistence of the beige-box PC standard, and its eventual decline, has its own logic of economics, habit and fashion. Beige PC's arrived in offices in the 1980's, when the management fashion was to scorn hierarchy and extol the virtues of teamwork and a more egalitarian workplace. Japan's teamlike corporate organizations appeared to be winning the economic footrace. Some Silicon Valley companies had abandoned private offices in favor of cubicles with shoulder-high beige partitions.
So beige PC's fit in. No matter that time and common sense would make such gestures toward democracy in the workplace the stuff of Dilbertesque satire. The beige-box PC was well entrenched and difficult to displace, if often bemoaned. Most PC's were used in business, and purchasing managers wanted office equipment to be standardized to reduce costs and limit employee complaints. "In business, they don't want the new thing looking different than the old thing," said Mike Stinson, a Gateway vice president. 
PC makers are mainly packagers of disk drives, chips and other parts from outside suppliers. Beige was the unshakable standard for the East Asian suppliers of "drive modules" for floppy disks, CD-ROM's and Zip drives. It was only in the last few years, said Steve Gluskoter, director of industrial design for Dell, that the company's market share was large enough that it would not have to pay a higher price for black housings on the drive modules. 
The most important force in the demise of beige has been a gradual shift among users toward perceiving these machines as personal computers. Well into the 1990's, according to marketing and focus-group research conducted by PC makers, most people still regarded a personal computer as another piece of office equipment, like a water cooler or a wastebasket. "It was not something people related their personality to," said Randall Martin, a designer at Compaq. 
The shift began with laptop and notebook computers, which people carried around with them and took home, even if a company bought them. Notebooks abandoned beige first, in part because the beige yellowed and became dirty with fingerprints. But the notebook crowd also preferred other colors. Home desktop users "want to get away from beige because it is associated with work," said Tom Anderson, a PC marketing executive at Hewlett-Packard. 
David Kelley, the founder of Ideo, recalled that his industrial design firm had created some colorful computers over the years, including sculptured purple-and-gray models for Silicon Graphics. "But it didn't make a difference," he said. "People weren't ready yet to consider it a personal thing." 
"But that is what is changing now," added Mr. Kelley, who is a professor at Stanford University. "As the computer moves into the personal space, then these subjective things like color and design begin to matter."

Historical Colors
Tying an Early PC To a Big Blue Star
When I.B.M. famously turned its attention to personal computers two decades ago, beige was not the only choice for a color scheme. 
The Altair, acknowledged as the first commercial personal computer, was blue. It was built in 1975 by a small company in Albuquerque, Micro Instrumentation Telemetry Systems, known as MITS. 
 Microsoft got its start at MITS, where Microsoft's co-founder, Paul Allen, was the director of software and his colleague Bill Gates was briefly a contract worker. 
Ed Roberts, former president of MITS and the father of the personal computer, said that the company chose blue because of the blue mainframe computers used by I.B.M., as if to suggest that the inexpensive, general-purpose Altair microcomputer was also a real computer. On a corner shelf in his office in Cochran, Ga., where he is now Dr. Roberts, a physician, rests an Altair 8800, a shade or two darker than a robin's egg. 
In the heyday of the mainframe, many engineers say, I.B.M. paid too much attention to marketing concerns like color and shape. The technical headaches created by I.B.M.'s machines -- which would be addressed by engineers, not business managers -- tended to be masked by a classy powder-blue exterior. The color -- starting with the 1401 system, introduced in 1959 -- earned I.B.M. the nickname Big Blue. Steve Lohr

HEADLINE: Form Follows Feeling 

BYLINE:  By JULIE V. IOVINE 

DATELINE: MILAN 

 BODY:
A RELENTLESS downpour last week set the mood for the Milan furniture fair, normally a giddy weeklong designfest that drapes this charmless industrial city in wall-to-wall design happenings.
 The galleries in palazzo courtyards and the slick installations in Boeing-size warehouses were clogged as usual with camera-ready displays of high-concept furnishings. But everywhere, as palpable as the rain dripping off the ubiquitous wisteria buds, was a sense of unrealized potential. 
 "It's all very stylish, very functional," said Ayse Birsel, a New York industrial designer. "The big companies are going for what they know will be successful. But I want to see design with more heart." 
The business of buying and selling modern furniture (with its rounded edges, Pantone-bright shades and layered laminates inspired by midcentury modern) has been disappointing, following three boom years. Italian furniture exports slipped 5.3 percent last fall, but ended the year slightly up at $5.8 million in export sales.
The mood at the fair was subdued. Wallpaper magazine and Droog, the Dutch design collaborative, which usually give two of the most raucous be-there bashes, issued no party invitations. "It got to be too many students drinking and damaging the prototypes," a Droog spokeswoman said.
Amid talk that Cappellini, famously devoted to upstart design, was negotiating a sale to the posh B&B Italia, Cappellini staged a baldly sensational display featuring male and female beauties in Pucci-patterned bikinis cavorting on matching Pucci-upholstered benches. The Italian paparazzi went wild, but visitors saw through the gimmick and noticed the absence of striking new designs. (A spokeswoman at B&B Italia did not return phone calls to comment on the potential deal.)
There were proficient designs from the usual suspects. For Kartell, Philippe Starck updated the phenomenally successful clear plastic Marie chair as the ghost of a Louis XV side chair. Anyone who wanted to sample Karim Rashid's hot-dogging beanbag sofa for Edra had to put on special booties to protect its upholstery. One observer called him "the Spice Girl of design."
Richard Garofalo, the owner of Repertoire, which has contemporary furniture stores in Boston and New York, has been scoping out new buys in Milan for the last 15 years. He said it was a year to consolidate, not to expand his collection. A buyer from the Midwest added that he would be cutting back his shopping list. "How many Cappellini chairs can Kansas City buy anyway?" he said.
Lackluster performances by the expected stars made the rare standouts all the more dazzling. In a concrete shed far from the fashionable shopping streets around Via Montenapoleone, Swarovski crystal chandeliers reinvented by young British and Dutch designers evoked smiles and gasps of appreciation. Hella Jongerius, a designer from Rotterdam known for coupling the artisanal and the industrial, made a ball-gown-shaped chandelier with a "bodice" of crystals and a skirt of patterned pink rubber letters spelling out epigrams like, "Can I only update?"
It was a relief from the ordinary, said Murray Moss of the Manhattan store Moss, who will be exhibiting the chandelier in May. "I thought that this year people would clutch onto practicality," he said. "It was nice to see the opposite happening."
Nigel Coates, a British designer, combined the silhouette of traditional swagged candelabra rendered in blue plastic with quivering crystals strung on a computer-generated grid of nylon thread, for kitsch-free glamour. "I wanted there to be some poetry," Mr. Coates said. "Design shouldn't always be as digestible as a car or a washing machine. Common sense is overrated."
The chandeliers were commissioned by Nadja Swarovski, an heir to the 107-year-old Swarovski company in Austria, makers of crystals for the world's shiniest chandeliers. 
The poignant lyricism of the chandeliers touched a nerve in those who feel that much of today's design is missing emotional weight. "I've had enough of rounded edges, orange upholstery and wood laminates," said Michael Maharem of the Maharem textile company in New York.
Visitors reacted in the same spirit to Boa, designed by the Campana brothers for Edra, a sofa made from about 300 feet of tree-trunk-thick ropes entwined in a pile. The massive apple-green velvet piece acted like a magnet for enervated visitors, who dropped like cluster flies onto the velvet coils. They wiggled into position, readjusting the thick loops into neck and arm rests. Humberto and Fernando Campana, magic realists from Brazil, imagined the piece as something that might have emerged, like a mythic beast, from a primal forest.
Even technology was about serving intangibles. The design renegades at Snowcrash, a Swedish design collaborative, managed to be both high-tech and evocative in a simple way with an inflatable room by Monica Forster, a designer from Stockholm. Her room, called Cloud, comes in a 26-pound golf-bag-size sack. Plug it in and a parachutelike material balloons within three minutes to conjure a space of 215 square feet, six and a half feet high. Ready for production, Cloud will cost about $2,200. "We're exposed to so many impressions all the time," Ms. Forster said. "It would be really good to have a quiet space for a timeout."
Roberto Cavalli, the Italian fashion designer with a Gypsy soul, understood better than most that, in these times of economic and political turmoil, furniture has to be more than functional. His over-the-top collection (and shag-rugadelic installation) featured a crystal vase with drooping petals and plates bursting with the image of one overblown rose. Visitors collapsed on a rolled futon with a Chanel-type tweed printed in red silk on one side and a zebra-hide pattern on the other. Sprawled on one of them was Yair Atias, a consultant for Tollman's, one of the largest furniture stores in Israel. He said he liked the gaudy red silk futon because "sometimes you have to find somewhere to rest, and it's nice if that somewhere is soft and the colors are very happy."

An article last Thursday about the Milan furniture fair misspelled the surname of a visitor who criticized some design trends there and also the name of his family's textile company in New York. He is Michael Maharam, not Maharem; the company is Maharam.

HEADLINE: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK; 
Rich Firms, Poor Ideas for Towers Site

BYLINE:  By HERBERT MUSCHAMP

 BODY:
Don't believe what you hear about the emergence of a consensus on the future of Lower Manhattan. To the extent that opinion has coalesced thus far around a particular set of options, the agreement represents a somewhat circumscribed point of view: that of New York's largest corporate architecture firms and the politically connected real estate-development industry they serve.
 This is the view presented in "Principles and Preliminary Blueprint for the Future of Lower Manhattan," a document issued last week by the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, the state agency created to supervise the rebuilding of New York's financial district. Why are we not surprised? In the era of privatization, it's been a long time since urban planning was driven by other than market considerations. Public-private development projects are the way things get done. 
 But please. Let's not kid ourselves that the public comes out ahead when things are done this way, or that corporate architecture firms specializing in large-scale urban projects for corporate clients are the best instruments we have for deriving the greatest benefit from the public-private partnership format. 
The blueprint lists 11 "Principles for Action" and recommends a traditional city street grid to replace the twin towers' large open plaza. The principles (edited for length), are:
*Make decisions based on an inclusive and open public process
*Create a memorial for those lost in the 9/11 attacks
*Assist the revitalization of Lower Manhattan without precluding future development
*Coordinate and encourage infrastructure improvements
*Support Lower Manhattan as the world financial capital with new office space
*Develop a diverse mixed-use magnet for the arts, tourism, education and recreation, with residential, commercial and neighborhood amenities
*Develop a comprehensive transportation plan with expanded regional and local connections
*Connect neighborhoods and improve streets for pedestrian use
*Expand and enhance public and open spaces
*Preserve the historic character of Lower Manhattan and its cityscape
*Promote sustainability and excellence in design, for environmentally sensitive development.
These goals will seem oddly familiar to some readers. Indeed, most of them have been lifted, with modifications, from a document issued some weeks ago by New York New Visions, a coalition of civic groups and professional organizations formed not long after the World Trade Center disaster. In defense of the development corporation, it might be said that its adoption of the earlier report shows a constructive openness to consensus. But in fact, this provenance casts some doubt on the process by which this particular consensus was built.
New York New Visions was spun off last fall from an earlier group, NYCRebuild, which was formed by an alliance between two business groups, the New York City Real Estate Board and the New York City Partnership, along with the New York Chapter of the American Institute of Architects. This group's executive committee consisted mainly of partners from the city's largest corporate architecture firms and its leading development companies.
Participants in New York New Visions have been telling themselves, and others, that the spinoff group represents an independent, public service coalition. No doubt they believe this to be the case. In the last seven months, they have indeed volunteered time for meetings and urban design workshops, and there's no reason to disbelieve that this service was offered in good faith.
The key players in both groups are the same, however, and the overall mission is the same. That mission is two-fold: to redefine the future of Lower Manhattan as a set of architectural problems, and to expand the zone of action beyond ground zero and its immediate surroundings to include most of Manhattan south of Chambers Street. It has never been clear why this mission should be considered either desirable or inevitable, except insofar as it enables the private sector to reap a windfall after an international tragedy.
It would be useful to go down the list of principles and unpack them one by one. Each represents a significant crisis in the way cities are made. A historical view of these crises could yield constructive results. What forces, for example, have diminished the capacity of New York's Department of City Planning to implement these worthy goals?
For that matter, it is not clear whether even the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation has the authority to implement them. Last week, the corporation was forced to withdraw a request for proposals for comprehensive master plans, issued to 24 architecture and planning firms, when the Port Authority determined that the state agency had no right to build on the 16-acre ground zero site. This conflict should be seen not just as the usual bureaucratic comedy of errors, but as a potential topic for cultural study and creative exploration.
We are, after all, dealing with a heavily contested site. History has different claims upon it, as well as organized special-interest groups, and little effort has been made thus far to sort out those claims, or even identify them. Until such an effort is made, I see scant reason to hope that a modern equivalent of Brunelleschi's dome will arise in Lower Manhattan. And to judge from the record of recent accomplishment, I see little evidence of historical awareness on the part of the city's corporate architecture firms. In fact, these firms have been alarmingly out of touch with the evolving needs of the contemporary city in the globalizing world.
This could change. The Lower Manhattan Development Corporation could be an instrument for such a change. The blueprint, however, does not go far in that direction. What it offers, instead, is a parade of platitudes entirely consistent with the world view of a rigid status quo. That status quo revolves around a single unstated assumption: it is ultimately not possible to discriminate good from bad.
One thing is just as valuable as another thing: that is the consensus. Everything is a matter of taste, opinion, stylistic preference or the roll of the dice: that is the world view. Every problem is a design problem, and all designers are equally capable of solving a design problem. What a wonderful world it would be if this were true. Things can be different, but not hierarchically ranked. Out of Coke? I'll take Pepsi. 
Lately, some good work has come out of corporate offices. The new Baruch College building, by Kohn Pedersen Fox, is a fine example. The proposed new Penn Station, by Skidmore Owings & Merrill, is also first rate. Historic restoration projects by Hardy Holzman Pfeiffer and Beyer Blinder Belle are also major blessings of our time. In general, there is a sense that postmodern relativism can no longer be a license for mindlessness. 
The projects, however, that have reinvigorated the public's interest in architecture are predominantly the work of smaller firms, like those of Tod Williams and Billie Tsien; Christian de Portzamparc; Raimund Abraham; Renzo Piano; Jean Nouvel; and Rem Koolhaas. What is it, apart from talent, that distinguishes these offices from their corporate counterparts?
None of them subscribe to the myth of the omnicompetent designer. They are makers of objects, but more than that, they are connectors -- humanistic thinkers who piece together areas of information that lie beyond the architect's actual expertise. They bring with them -- or invent -- the context of meaning in which their work should be judged.
The blueprint does not provide such a context, or encourage its creation. No cultural connections are forged. The principles could be used to describe an edge city anywhere on earth. There is no acknowledgment that other areas of expertise might be drawn upon before the design process begins: history, economics, philosophy, global politics -- the entire range of disciplines on which any plausible interpretation of the World Trade Center tragedy must depend. But without a credible reading of 9/11, constructed from a global perspective, we will have no means of discriminating the value of whatever designs are put forth.
