HEADLINE: America in Extremis 

BYLINE:  By Michael Paterniti; Michael Paterniti is the author of "Driving Mr. Albert: A Trip Across America With Einstein's Brain" and a writer at large for GQ magazine.

 BODY:
While visiting Florida one day last summer, I happened upon the following newspaper headline: "Sex-Plane Couple Remains Mystery." The ensuing Miami Herald article detailed an improbable incident featuring a Hispanic couple in their "50's or 60's" who in mid-August chartered a plane out of Key West, ostensibly with the desire to share connubial bliss at altitude. The pilot claimed that his company, Fly Key West (a company not listed in the Florida Division of Corporations), advertised such escapades and that because anonymity was guaranteed and the couple spoke only Spanish, he never knew the full names of those on board. 
 It became a case of coitus interruptus in the most cosmic sense. The plane ditched in 3,600 feet of shark-infested ocean, the couple apparently died (according to the pilot they remained in the plane, unmoving as it sank) and the pilot himself, 36-year-old Thomas Hayashi, was subsequently rescued. When interviewed by investigators, Hayashi claimed that the couple had tried to hijack the plane to Cuba, and in the ensuing scuffle, the throttle had broken. It was a stranger-than-fiction story that many found farfetched, questioning, among other things, whether a couple had actually been on board at all, though an F.B.I. spokesperson said there was nothing to suggest that the pilot was "not telling the truth." 
 The story had everything: sex, intrigue, missing bodies, risky behavior behind a veneer of normalcy, the humid specter of Cuba and capitalism operating at its tawdry finest. I happened to read it on the back porch of the cypress bungalow where Janet Reno lives. She has spent most of her life in Kendall, a satellite of Miami that was once sparsely populated but that today is very much a vision of America itself, all big-car traffic and strip malls. The sun was beating down on the gumbo limbo trees, the day was just turning to sauna and my host had given me a glass of lemonade to keep cool, as the house had no air-conditioning but for the bedroom. 
Reno, the former United States attorney general and the state's most infamous daughter, was soon to announce her candidacy for governor of Florida, and we had been talking about Waco, a subject that I brought up but that she seemed quite eager to discuss. Now she'd gone rummaging for a letter she wanted to show me. It was from John Danforth, the former Republican senator who led a Congressional investigation on how 75 people, including 25 children, had died in a conflagration set by the F.B.I. at David Koresh's Branch Davidian compound in 1993. The personal letter, written by Danforth in January 2001 after he left the Senate, commended Reno's controversial decision-making during the 51-day standoff -- a vindication Reno was quick to share with me. While she went for that letter, I picked up the paper and read the article. 
When she returned, I told her about the sex plane. She may not have wanted to appear too interested, but as the daughter of a crime-beat reporter and herself a former state attorney general who once knew where all the bodies were hidden in these parts, she wanted the details. And while it was just another bizarro mystery tale (one that, to date, hasn't been unraveled), it wasn't quite the stuff of a Versace murder or hanging chads, shark attacks or Elian, the stuff that has turned this state into a bellwether and bane, the national headline and tabloid heart of our nation over the last five years. Still, after absorbing it, Janet Reno smiled behind her glasses -- an enigmatic grin floating six feet in the air -- and with possibly a trace of admiration at the idea that her home still has the power to surprise her after 63 years, said, "Welcome to Florida!" 
Oh, Florida -- fabled land of shady real-estate deals and unclad hotties (the fine MTV youth of America!) bumping and grinding on spring break, of endangered manatees and Miami nightclubs, the ghost of Meyer Lansky and retirees sidling across white-sugar beaches at sunset . . . and how to forget O.J. Simpson, tucked away in his golf-green haven? Hasn't this always been the place where exiles and fugitives, ex-dictators and ex-astronauts -- ex-everyones -- come to erase the past and make themselves new again? 
In the weeks after Sept. 11, the nation began to ask questions of Florida. Television commentators spoke of a "Florida curse," as if the vapors from Atchalafaya Swamp now suddenly carried with them evil spirits and gnats intent on mucking up our democracy. By any measure, it has been perplexing, this bonanza of strange news emanating from that steamy underworld of alligators and mockingbirds. In fact, how can one explain or begin to quantify Florida's recent seismic impact on the news of this country? How does one account for a state in which everything now seems to happen first -- or somehow in the extreme, that as a microcosm of America, has come to reflect the psyche of America itself?
Of the three biggest news stories in the last three years, two of them -- the Elian Gonzalez case and the 2000 presidential election recount -- played out on Florida's pastel-and-neon stage, while the third, the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in New York and Washington, immediately had its own unsettling Florida synchronicities with tales of Mohamed Atta and his posse practicing takeoffs (but not landings) in flight simulators in Opa-Locka, receiving actual in-air flight training in Venice, inquiring about crop dusters at Belle Glade municipal airport and boozing at a Hollywood bar, where Atta posed as an airline pilot before embarking on his deadly journey. 
Then, of course, came the first reports of anthrax contamination at -- who scripted this? -- American Media Inc., publishers of The Star, National Enquirer and Weekly World News. Soon more anthrax was found in Boca Raton. As if this all weren't enough, there came a January echo of the tragedy when a teenager apparently sympathetic to Osama bin Laden re-created his own suicidal mise-en-scene by piling a Cessna 172 into a bank building in Tampa. In staging his addled attack, the ninth grader killed himself alone but gave weight -- with the image of the plane's tail fin suspended 28 stories aloft, framed by shattered glass and twisted metal -- to another senseless absurdity somehow implicating American culture at large.
Maybe the feng shui of the place is a little out of whack, recalling a time in the 60's and 70's when California was the site of our concern, with its odd crimes and laissez-faire lack of accountability. In that day, the Hollywood state gave us the assassination of Bobby Kennedy and antiwar foment, Patty Hearst and Charles Manson. It launched Jim Jones and his followers to Guyana and their liquid suicide, and also the actor who became governor who became president. Where Californians often seemed flummoxed by the next day's news, Floridians have come to expect the surreal. And with the first tolling bells of a new election season comes the prospect of more surrealities: a gubernatorial wrangle between the onetime Clintonian, Janet Reno, and the incumbent first brother, Jeb Bush, which could prove to be either Greek drama or an episode of "American Gladiators." In recent polls, Reno bests her Democratic challengers, including Bill McBride, a private-practice attorney and political novice though already a state party and labor union darling. (Of the group, McBride may in fact have the support to make it close.) Her name recognition alone is over 90 percent. And while she lags behind Jeb Bush by 10 to 20 percentage points, it's still early, with an election season as tangled as Spanish moss looming ahead.
For his part, Bush has been fund-raising -- collecting $500,000 at a recent $25,000-a-head country-club event featuring his brother, George W. -- and a large part of his campaign strategy will hinge on a television commercial blitz at election time. And since the presidential election controversy, 36 days that seemed to relegate him to an upstairs closet at the mansion, Jeb has been more and more willing to be seen with George W., whose approval ratings still float in the stratosphere. In Florida, Jeb's own recent approval rating is 58 percent, which leads Democratic state party leaders to believe he may be more vulnerable than he appears, especially since Democrats continue to outnumber Republicans in the state and high voter turnout may create the same element of surprise that it did in the 2000 election.
If a Reno-Bush showdown indeed transpires, and if Bush's numbers slide come November, it may make for grand theater: Reno, the somewhat less than charismatic though controversial native daughter, running to avenge the loss of the vanquished Al Gore, whose hapless fade from public view included the protest beard; and Jeb, oozing roguish wonkiness and piloting a finely honed political machine, whose fortunes now seem all the more inextricably linked with his brother's, running not just to win and lay the backbeat for his brother's own re-election bid in 2004, but to re-establish himself as a national political figure as well.
Recently, I stopped in on Jeb -- and Janet again. In between, I took myself on a 500-mile road trip from Tallahassee, the capital in the north, to Miami, the unofficial capital in the south. I found myself navigating a state that joined the union in 1845 as a mostly uninhabitable, mosquito-infested swamp; a state where, until recent times, "nothing ever really happened," says the poet Campbell McGrath, a transplanted Floridian with a new book about his adopted home titled "Florida Poems." No founding fathers, no presidents born here, only two Civil War battles worth mention, no gold or silver or fantastically arable soil -- no exceptionally famous natives. It is a state that, until the post-World War II advent of air-conditioning and Interstates, was more sleepy Southern colony than capitalist cornucopia. In fact, so transient is Florida's place in our history and landscape, its own founding fathers were real-estate speculators who didn't stick around for long, while an estimated 70 to 80 percent of voting Floridians today were not actually born in the state. 
"Florida ought to be more like Texas, but it isn't," McGrath says. "Texas has the Alamo, we have Alamo rental cars. While it has none of the burdens of history, Florida has no mythic identity, no sense of place or self. Florida is still a new world in the New World." 
Since the 1997 Gianni Versace murder in Miami Beach, a nation has increasingly looked to its fourth-largest state with a gawker's fascination and subdued parental confusion. So long the amorphous vacation spot with a floating population, Florida has emerged as a new prime-time sensation, defined more by the sum of its recent television cameos than by its natural beauty or multicultural panoply, its Disney World extravaganzas or business opportunities. So it has seemed recently: as Florida goes, so goes a nation.
"You could dismantle each of these news stories and say they're all coincidences, that they could have happened elsewhere," says McGrath, who lives in Miami Beach. "But then the anecdotal evidence piles up and you ask, Why here? Why psychopaths and terrorists, upside-down elections and general weirdness? Is it the unrootedness of people, the extraordinariness of the landscape, the lack of seasons that untether you from the past? You do begin to wonder, Is it something in the air?"
Striding into the dining room at the Governor's Mansion for a lunch with the state's Hispanic caucus, Jeb Bush seems very much at ease on this late-winter Tuesday, the halfway point in one of Tallahassee's most rancorous legislative sessions in years. Always boisterous, Florida politics has become what passes as extreme sport in the capital these days. The speaker of the House, Tom Feeney, is no longer talking to the president of the Senate, John McKay; the budget is moving toward complete impasse; and a lobbyist and dog-track owner ended up engaged in fisticuffs in the men's room at the rotunda. Twenty or so representatives, most of them Cuban-Americans from southern Florida, have been mingling with the lieutenant governor and resident cutup, Frank Brogan, awaiting the governor's arrival, and the room receives a palpable surge of electricity when he finally appears. "Boss is here," Brogan says.
Tanned and grinning, Bush, 49, wears a neatly tailored olive suit and a purple tie emblazoned with green elephants, a more psychedelic rendering of his party's traditional mascot. He is tall -- taller by a head than most in the room -- and though his baby-face features, ruddy cheeks and slight double chin leave the impression that he may enjoy dessert, he's surprisingly thin. 
Those close to Jeb Bush describe him as a private man who deeply enjoys the political process, however late he has come to the game, and many believe he may be the post-W. future of his party. Having married his teenage sweetheart, Columba, whom he met as a 16-year-old exchange student in Mexico, Bush moved to Miami in 1981 after attending the University of Texas, where he graduated, like his father, in only two and a half years. He got his start making real-estate cold calls and worked up to partner in the Codina Group, a Miami real-estate development firm, where he pocketed more than $1 million a year. 
In 1994, two years after his father lost the White House, Jeb Bush decided to run for governor, though he ultimately lost to the incumbent, Lawton Chiles. (In the same election year, his brother unseated the incumbent Ann Richards to become governor of Texas.) Jeb Bush's campaign was reportedly disorganized, and one comment in particular did little to endear him to undecided voters: when asked what he might do for black Floridians if elected, he responded testily, "Probably nothing." In 1998, having tried to make amends with black voters and casting himself as more moderate, Bush ran again, in more disciplined fashion, and won handily. 
As opposed to his brother the president, whose managerial style resembles that of a big-picture C.E.O., Jeb can be a hands-on administrator (the two reportedly have a well-honed sibling rivalry that leaves them close or distant, depending on the day and the issue). He is known to fire off e-mail messages in the middle of a Saturday night and fearlessly dive into the nuanced, jargon-filled territory that his brother tends to avoid like a reactor in meltdown. It may seem an unlikely comparison, but in manner, intellect and emotional availability, Jeb less resembles his brother, or even his father, than he does Bill Clinton. And as dazzling as Clinton could be in the living flesh, as much as he genuinely fed off people, he still left the impression of sizing up his company and plugging the world into a grid, each new acquaintance ranked by usefulness. Outwardly, Bush is less the striver, perhaps because he has had to strive less.
If Clinton's personal life fell prey to the tabloids, Bush's has, too. In May of last year at a bill signing, Bush took the unusual measure of addressing a rumor about an alleged affair with Cynthia Henderson, his appointed head of the Florida Department of Management Services. It came just before a supermarket tabloid was supposedly scheduled to break the story. (Ultimately the tabloid did not, but Vanity Fair did, referring to the affair as "a rumor.") Adding pepper to the sauce was the fact that Henderson worked for two years at a St. Petersburg Playboy Club in the 1980's to help pay her way through law school and that her past in government had included the controversial firing of 50 staffers, an accusation that she had assaulted a colleague and an ethically questionable trip to the Kentucky Derby, sponsored by Outback Steakhouse, one of the businesses she was charged to regulate. 
"I have been faithful," said a sullen Bush, his voice cracking. Behind him stood various state agency heads, including Henderson. "I love my wife," he said, labeling the rumor "an outright lie." Had he been the anonymous governor of an empty Western state, people may not have cared to look up from their ribeye. As a scion of the Bush family, he became front-page news.
Partly for this reason, Bush is loath to talk about his personal life, one that has included several noted incidents: in 1999, his wife was fined more than $4,000 for failing to pay duty fees on $19,000 worth of designer clothing bought in Paris; last year, his 16-year-old son was caught by the police having intimate relations with a female teenager in a Tallahassee public parking lot; and in January, his 24-year-old daughter was arrested at a pharmacy near the Governor's Mansion for prescription-drug fraud after posing as a doctor in order to issue herself the anti-anxiety drug Xanax, which led the governor to beg the media for privacy during "this difficult time."
As trying as these revelations have been for the family, they are indeed family matters, and the electorate is likely to ignore them at the polls. Still, his wariness of the press is evident. In turning down my request for a sit-down interview, Bush's communications director, Katie Muniz, said, "The governor doesn't do national media," pointing up the fact that there are few governors in office today who wouldn't die for a little. (Instead Muniz sent an e-mail message lavishing praise on his environmental and education initiatives. "He has led in addressing old problems in new ways," she enthused. "Ask state leaders around the country. Governor Bush's reforms are serving as models for the nation.")
In his comfy cone of silence, then, he'd prefer to let his record do the talking. At events around the state, he is quick to trumpet his achievements: a decreasing crime rate, in addition to the education and environmental programs. His One Florida initiative has ended affirmative action at Florida's public universities to much outcry. On the same page of The Miami Herald on which the "sex plane" article appeared last summer there was an article quoting an estimate that black first-year enrollment at the University of Florida has decreased by nearly half this year, from almost 12 percent of the class in 2000 to about 7 percent in 2001 -- disappointing," according to the university's provost, David Colburn. 
"The governor's policies are punitive as they relate to minorities," says State Senator Kendrick Meek, a Democrat from Miami. "At election time, he's going to run three commercials to every one of the Democrats', doing his Jerry Maguire 'I love black people.' But there's not a barbershop or beauty parlor in the black community where people like this governor." 
Where he may not have the black vote, there is no question about the Cuban vote. Will it be the difference against Reno or whoever emerges as Bush's Democratic challenger? And, after his brother, is he the future president of the United States? 
Seated in the dining room at the mansion now, with its Everglades motif on the wall, Bush is right where he seems to want to be. He switches easily between speaking English and Spanish (his is the first Hispanic family to live in the Governor's Mansion), catching up on the progress of this or that bill, joking with those at his table, then leaning back to take in someone else's punch line. Before the meal is served, before Bush passes off his piece of chocolate cake on an eager if well-fed state representative to his right, Lieutenant Governor Brogan stands up and welcomes everyone, then turns the floor over to the governor. Like the state he leads, Jeb Bush is partly the creation of news and rumor, misperception and exaggeration, and it is in moments like these that flickers of the real man show through.
Bush remains seated, reminds everyone that this is just a casual chance to catch up, so there'll be no formalities. Then he does something rare in politics. He shows emotion, unrehearsed emotion. Without a trace of irony in his voice, he says: "Welcome to your house. I love you." As if by setting the words on a warm Gulf breeze, they might go forth and pollinate Florida itself, this riven congregation, this new day rising.
Driving the state of Florida from north to south, one is barraged by a cacophony of images: a huge Confederate flag luffing high above the intersection of I-10 and I-75, anti-abortion billboards starring fetuses, other billboards for W.W.F. wrestling goons and, farther along, approaching Tampa, billboards advertising strip clubs and the tourist attractions of Old Florida: the mermaids of Weeki Watchee and the manatees of Homosassa Springs. Out here, too, in the murk around Ocala, is the skunk ape, Florida's own Bigfoot, eight feet of orange-haired, sulfur-smelling beast that roams the swampland like a bad nightmare.
What is unavoidable as you drive along the west coast of the state to Tampa, what you surrender to and grow accustomed to finally as the best beaches begin, are the condos, miles upon miles of them, in pink stucco and white cement, standing sentinel over spotless beaches, dappled with bright yellow sun umbrellas, and then, as far as the eye can gaze, the green Gulf waters of bonefish and tarpon. And where condos don't exist yet, it seems they're in the process of being built, a wall of plywood all the way to Miami.
If there is guilt to assess for this odd Xanadu, complete with its extravagances and attendant environmental degradation (satellite photographs of the Everglades show the ravaging effects of development here), then we all stand accused. Florida exists by the good graces of our patronage -- by those of us who live in the other 49. That is, it's a pure creation of our demand, of our retirees and relocated, cold-weary brethren, as well as of our families on vacation. And so we are equally the authors of Florida; it belongs to us as much as it belongs to itself.
How is this? Take, first of all, the fact that the state has no income tax, but is rather financed in large part by the $16.6 billion in sales tax it collected last fiscal year. Tourism infuses Florida's economy with $50 billion a year. To reduce it to its simplest formulation: if those Mickey Mouse ears aren't selling in Orlando, there's less chalk in the classrooms of Gainesville. And since Sept. 11, Florida hasn't had a run on mouse ears. As a result, the state is looking at a shortfall in the neighborhood of $300 million to $1 billion in its $50 billion budget for the coming year, depending on which party you believe. Belt-tightening is rampant. At a number of Florida's public universities, teachers have been prohibited from using copy machines since fall. And Florida now ranks 41st in per-pupil state financing for kindergarten through 12th grade. If it weren't for sustained low-interest rates that have buoyed the real-estate market (housing starts rose here by 2.2 percent in 2001), we might be talking about a Florida bust in the same dire way we were talking about the California energy disaster.
What contributes to this symbiotic relationship between Florida and the rest of America is a telling demographic dynamic. The north of Florida, sometimes derisively referred to by those in the lower climes of the state as the Redneck Riviera, resembles the Deep South, populated as it is by Southerners more kindred in their conservative ethos to the citizens of Alabama and Mississippi than to those of Miami. The middle of the state, which includes Orlando, Tampa and St. Petersburg (a city once known as God's Waiting Room for its preponderance of retirees) teems with transplanted Midwesterners. And then the south, and Miami in particular, is referred to, with a slightly patronizing nod by its northerly brethren, as the Sixth Borough -- as in the sixth borough of New York City -- a Democratic bastion, if one subtracts the roughly 700,000 Cubans who live in Dade County. 
Furthermore, the state offers a close reflection of the nation's ethnic breakdown. Where 75 percent of Americans today are white, in Florida 78 percent are white. Where nearly 13 percent are Hispanic, in Florida 17 percent are. And where 12 percent are black, in Florida more than 14 percent are. (The United States census numbers here include persons reporting themselves as multiple races.) That Florida's minority groups are represented in slightly higher numbers than the national average already augurs a trend identified by population experts, one that calls for the sustained growth of the country's minority population in the coming decades, especially among Hispanics -- offering yet more proof that the future has already arrived in Florida.
I was thinking about Florida, the great Gulf Stream shape-shifter, as I drove south through orange trees and swamp, and I began to wonder if all those television commentators were right after all, if Florida really was somehow cursed. I thought about the mysterious skunk ape and Ted Bundy and witch doctors throwing spells in Miami's Little Haiti. I thought about Dale Earnhardt, the great Nascar champion from North Carolina who drove his last race in Daytona, dying on the last lap; and the Missouri-born Payne Stewart, the golfer whose bizarre last flight originated from Orlando. Then there was perhaps the state's greatest hero, the Seminole leader Osceola, who was actually born in Georgia, the son of a British trader, and who fearlessly fought the Army in the Everglades and was duped by Gen. Thomas Jesup at St. Augustine in 1837, which led to his death in a South Carolina prison. And finally, before all of them came the Spanish explorer Juan Ponce de Leon, the first Floridian developer who tried to seek his fortune at the Fountain of Youth (rumored to sit atop a pile of silver and gold), instead took a poison arrow near Charlotte Harbor and later died in Cuba. Florida has always been a stage on which its visitors have preened and strutted, often briefly and unsuccessfully, perhaps at times hubristically, which may explain our feelings about the state as being somehow alien or even an altogether Otherworld. But cursed? 
Based on my conversations with a cross-section of Floridians -- including ministers and politicians, beat reporters and retirees, who as a group exhibited an equal eagerness to psychoanalyze their increasingly notorious home (most of them, as transplants, are still trying to figure it out as well) -- the state seems more cursed by a willingness to tear down and rebuild (in the name of the Almighty dollar) and a short-term memory that might rival that of a patient in an Oliver Sacks case study. Considering that Florida has packed nearly 25 percent more people onto its balmy peninsula in the last decade, bringing the current total of its residents to nearly 16 million, one can at least isolate a cause for Florida's increasing disorientation. If it's a state that hasn't really learned from its mistakes -- as any Carl Hiaasen novel will tell you -- that perhaps is because it doesn't really remember them in the first place. "The beauty of Florida is that we are a land of innocents," the poet McGrath says. "No one is to blame for anything. It's a pyramid scheme of ineptitude and sloth."
Hiaasen says: "We've always been a doormat for dirtbags -- and not just terrorists and criminals, but crooked doctors, lawyers, accountants and insider traders who all move to Boca Raton and build big houses because bankruptcy laws protect them here. They've all come with the herd. It's the end of the road, a transient place, like California, and the bar of weirdness is so high it would be almost impossible to be noticed unless you did something incredibly stupid or egregious."
And one other note from the road: as you move south through Florida, especially if you've abandoned a northern clime where people live under layers and layers of wool for half the year, you find bodies wearing less and less clothing. This is more important than it sounds, for it is not just a sartorial observation but a metaphor too, for a certain transparency, a lack of suspicion, perhaps a naivete, a general, open, Floridian disposition dictated in part by weather -- by benevolent days of wall-to-wall sunshine, a perpetual summer punctuated by the autumn roll of hurricanes. That disposition is reflected in a people who tend to be more trusting -- or, rather, simply more uninterested, for many Floridians learned long ago not to ask too many questions of their neighbors -- and it is reflected, too, in the state's political process.
"I think the national and foreign media were amazed when they came down here to cover the 2000 election," says Barbara Petersen, president of the First Amendment Foundation, a nonprofit watchdog group in the state. "To have this open televised recount, then to have this open televised debate about the recount, whatever the outcome. Afterward, Jeb, who prides himself as the e-governor, had to turn over thousands of e-mails. What sets Florida apart is its constitutional guarantee of access to all three branches of state government."
And if the nation was horrified to learn that the two hijackers who drove planes into Tower 1 and Tower 2 of the World Trade Center received their flight training in the state, it surprised Floridians a little less. 
In fact, a quick breakdown of the recent big news stories is not only a primer in global geography but also a case study in state schizophrenia. Rudi Dekkers, the man who ran the flight school at which Mohamed Atta and a Saudi friend trained, was Dutch. Versace was an Italian killed by a half-Filipino who hailed from San Diego. Elian was a Cuban affair, pitting first-generation Cuban-Americans against their own family back in Cuba. Even the election, if you are to believe certain urgent voices in the state, was decided by the blacks (for Gore) or the Cuban-Americans (for Bush), while the recount jetted in out-of-state visitors from the white power structure like James Baker and David Boies. For better or worse, Florida may be the truest melting pot we have -- and oddly, perhaps because memory is indeed so short here, it has more or less worked.
"I didn't know who they were," protests Dekkers today about the terrorists who trained under his guidance. And then sounding the perfect Floridian note, the Sunshine mantra, he adds, "But then, why should I have?"
Behind the windshield of her eyeglasses, wearing a sensible green dress, Janet Reno grips the wheel with big hands, her long body folded a bit uncomfortably in the front seat of a poky rental car, driving back to campaign headquarters after yet another plate of cold chicken, wild rice and the umpteenth speech of the last year, this time at a Broward County Chamber of Commerce luncheon. The speech was full of Reno touchstones -- memories of her hard-drinking, maverick mother, the unspoiled Florida of yore and an urgent if vague call to arms for a new, improved Florida -- but the biggest response came when a banner hanging on the wall behind her came undone and clattered loudly to the ground as if by voodoo. Reno turned slowly, turned back to the crowd and with perfect comic timing said, "Must be Jeb Bush!"
After eight years of being chauffeured in bulletproof vehicles as attorney general, Reno has been driving a lot lately -- and is about to head out on a 15-day road trip that will take her from Pensacola to Miami, this time in her red 1999 Ford Ranger; Reno's handlers have thus dubbed it the Red Truck Tour. It's a journey that will end in mid-March to mixed reviews: some will call it an anemic, cheesy attempt to highlight Reno's supposed folksiness; others will point to the 2,796 miles traveled as evidence of Reno's fitness for office. At the very least, it will serve up an image to counter the one of an old woman, momentarily out cold and sprawled on her back beneath the hot lights in January, her Wicked Witch of the West pumps poking out from the rostrum: in this case, a candidate moving forward, in the upright position, perhaps minus sizzle but nonetheless with the kind of dogged determination and physical stamina that others have underestimated in her before now.
If the odds-on favorite, Jeb Bush, is a wash-ashore from Texas bearing a marquee name and a lucrative past in the state's time-honored real-estate trade, Janet Reno is one of those wild macaws, born in Miami and bred at the edge of the Everglades in a cypress house, who has spent most of her life in public service of one kind or another, and as the first female state attorney in Florida presided over the most dangerous years of drug trade, fabulated by the 80's television show "Miami Vice."
And while it has been said that Jeb is New Florida and Janet is Old Florida, it's not clear what this means exactly besides their 14-year age difference and a sense that, by being born on local turf, Reno has never exactly had to reinvent herself, has always stubbornly been just Janet -- a bit gawky, competitive and in love with the Brooklyn Dodgers and the poet Samuel Taylor Coleridge. (It was actually her grandfather who reinvented his family, coming from Denmark via Wisconsin to Miami, changing his name from Rasmussen to Reno, allegedly by picking the name off a map.) She grew up during the post-World War II years when the state was still a sparsely populated American frontier. If she saw her family as homesteaders, carving out a life at the edge of the Everglades -- hand-building their house, riding horseback and working the land -- millions and millions have since arrived to a readymade land of condos and Art Deco hotels, bungalows and strip malls, with the idea that Florida is a virtual and psychic frontier.
For their differences, the candidates may be more similar than they'd like to believe. Both cast themselves as can-do achievers of unimpeachable integrity and say they want to protect the environment, one of the state's biggest issues. Both claim education as a top priority. From opposite sides, both are slowly creeping closer to the center to claim precious swing voters. And both are said to be stubborn and exacting, at times imperious and zealous. If Jeb Bush struggles against the news media to be taken on his own terms without the hype, private-life intrusions and "brother of" introductions, he might try being Janet Reno for a day. 
It's hard to imagine a brushstroke that hasn't already been slapped on the former attorney general -- or won't soon be. Her physical appearance and perceived androgyny, her inextricable link to Clinton, the plodding nature of her Justice press conferences -- all of these have been grist for barbs and criticism, sometimes in the nastiest of terms. And that's not even taking into account the right-wing extremists who read her resume as a rap sheet of government conspiracy: Waco, Oklahoma City, Elian. Somehow Reno, or the distortion of her, has become part of our cultural vernacular. She is the Other, the unfeeling automaton, kin to the mysterious skunk ape, materialized from the swamp. And yet she remains mostly impervious. "I don't really give a damn what people think of me," she says.
In person, Reno is nothing like that stiff, press-conference Reno. Her paradoxes abound. She's a loner who clearly needs and enjoys people; an outsider who's an insider with a mean Rolodex; a husbandless lover of family whose best friend is her younger sister, Maggy; a seemingly austere woman who is prone to laugh (and when she does, it's like a little outburst). She is a person both awkward and uninhibited (her awkwardness more assumed by others than evidenced by her) -- and someone who inspires deep loyalty in those closest to her. And she can be downright wacky, as when she appeared on "Saturday Night Live" just after leaving office in Washington, dancing like a stilted punk rocker.
"Once people get to know me, they often say, 'But you're such a gentle girl,"' she says one day at lunch at a Mediterranean restaurant near her home in Kendall. She has a plate of grilled lamb kebab and rice, some hummus and a glass of chardonnay. From time to time, her hand shakes from the Parkinson's disease that was diagnosed in October 1995, but she pays it -- and some errant rice on the table -- no mind. "Just like that," she says, with that delighted burst of laughter. "They always say 'girl,' as if I still am one."
To look at her family is to understand the clay from which Janet Reno springs. Her 62-year-old brother, Bob, is a longtime political columnist for Newsday. Her sister Maggy, 61, once served as a county commissioner and is an obsessive outdoorswoman, kayaking the rivers of the world. And her polymathic brother Mark, 60, is a former paratrooper who lives in a thatched hut behind Reno's house and splits his time between professionally trapping rodents and working as a court bailiff. It's not quite the Bushes of Kennebunkport, but a down-home Kendall dynasty of its own. Collectively, the Renos seem to know something about everything -- and they are consummate storytellers. When Janet is with her sister, as on the night I join them for dinner at Maggy's wooden bungalow in Stuart, two hours north of Miami, the two sisters spend hours in animated chatter. "We do this all the time," Reno says. "We tell each other the best things from our day."
Later she turns to her sister and says, "You won't believe who I saw the other day." 
"Who?" asks Maggy with her usual excitement.
"Katherine Harris," says Reno, smiling. 
"No . . . where?"
Harris, Florida's secretary of state and Congressional hopeful, became the face of the 2000 election when she ruled that the Florida vote would stand without a recount, a decision upheld by the United States Supreme Court. "I saw her in the airport," Reno says. "She came up to me and said, 'We have mutual acquaintances who think the world of you, and I just wanted to say hello."'
"Really? What'd you do, Janny?"
"Why, I said hello. But it was just so . . . so . . . strange. She's much shorter than I thought. Did you know that about her?"
Inevitably, dinner conversation comes around to their mother, Jane Wood Reno, who died three months before her daughter went to Washington. "Pop the pomp" was one of her mantras, and she spent her life doing just that, in the most colorful manner. Her children remember her wrestling alligators with the Seminole Indians, hitchhiking home on 18-wheelers after nights at the bar and her intense love for all things Florida. In fact, Reno and her mother once circumnavigated the state by motorboat. Of all things, she taught her children to speak their minds, something Reno has occasionally done with consequences. 
Still. She does not hide her frustration or disdain at the way the 2000 presidential election was handled in the state, claiming it reflected poorly on all Floridians. Though she says she will not run a campaign of personal attacks in hopes of restoring some dignity to the political process, she describes Jeb Bush as "more intelligent than his brother, but arrogant." 
About her former boss, who still seems to lurk behind her on the campaign trail, she admits she still has fondness for Bill Clinton, an admission for which she's occasionally criticized. 
Reno brushes aside claims by the former senator Bob Kerrey that, at a dinner party last year, Clinton listed her among his five least favorite people on his White House team (a story Clinton's office later denied in a phone call to Reno). Responding to an ill-kept secret that, at one point, Clinton had wanted a new attorney general, she says bluntly: "I think he would have liked me gone after those first four years, but then I didn't box him in. When I announced that I had Parkinson's" -- in November 1995 -- I just said I'd stay as long as the president wanted, and I told him. And he said he appreciated that."
About the former first lady, Reno is decidedly less charitable. "I was so impressed by her," she says, describing Hillary Clinton in action. And yet as Clinton was driven deeper into the traditional role of first lady -- after the setback of her health-care initiative, her father's death, then Vince Foster's suicide -- Reno says she feels Hillary Clinton eventually came to blame her for granting Kenneth Starr expanded powers that led from the special prosecutor's investigation of a 20-year-old real-estate deal to the most lurid details of the president's sex life. "She was brittle," Reno says. "And I've heard I'm not one of her favorite people because of the way I handled the Lewinsky affair." (Rumors that Hillary Clinton might try to undermine Reno's run for governor have also been categorically denied by the Clintons.)
Even in her fifth and what must be considered final act of a long political career, it seems Reno can't escape the aura of conspiracy. In a way, it's only fitting. One night at her house, she was out back with her brother at his thatched hut, the two of them having cooked fish over an open fire. Reno's hair was wet, matted to her head, her green dress was soaked and, when I inquired about what had happened, she told a story of walking in a state where no one walks, to the fish store just down the road. The clouds, which had gathered in paranoid piles, let loose in one of Florida's famous monsoons, flooding the streets and drenching her. Sitting there now with tousled hair, she couldn't have been happier for having been caught in the downpour. And I tried to imagine her moving in her own time, stopping traffic by the oddity of her presence at the side of the road with a bag of fish clutched in her hand -- Florida's most infamous daughter, its would-be governor and, for a fleeting moment, its only spectacle.
Alack, Florida -- I drove its highways and byways, stuck behind S.M.O.P.'s. (the local idiomatic acronym for "slow-moving old people") and out-Andrettied by pierced-and-pumped youth. At the statehouse in Tallahassee, I heard tell of more tabloid dramas. This time it was Representative J.D. Alexander, cousin of Katherine Harris, describing what it was like to tiptoe around your cousin's house, the cousin with whom you usually stay while the Legislature is in session, as you were now suing each other over your grandfather's $500 million estate. At Homosassa Springs, I communed in an underwater tank with your vegetarian manatees, possibly the galaxy's most innocent creatures, who are being gouged to extinction by the propellers of your pleasure craft and speedboats. 
In Miami Beach -- where all the men and women seemed as if they're front-runners in the casting call for "Temptation Island 3" -- I went to the Versace mansion to stand on the very spot where Versace was murdered. This was not consciously macabre, but rather a function of my blindly following the shutterbug masses -- and here we found his massive Pleasuredome, this epic, Floridian palazzo and ode to material consumption, covered in plastic tarps, being deloused. 
In Hollywood, I visited Shuckums, the bar where locals once brimmed with fury at the fact that Mohamed Atta and his companions rudely drank here, and where scribbled on the men's-room door was the righteous reminder "Terrorists not welcome." Now on this Friday night at the horseshoe counter, with raw oysters shuddering in their shells, inebriated men were trying to pick up less-inebriated women, and with the cavalcade of news cameras now safely established on a beachhead far away, no one remembered anything and eyed one another with the gaze of cuddly possibility. 
If Florida is America's future, it's going to be, Hiaasen says, "almost Toffleresque in its chaos," a place where dots do not connect and each new incident in its history is taken in isolation, as a television drama unto itself, to replace the forgotten one before it.
"It's at the point where we know we can't go six months without another big story down here," he says. "If you're a Floridian, there's a certain sort of rueful but good-natured pride in the state's notoriety. It's a camaraderie born of being part of the freak show. You gotta laugh, because what the hell else are you going to do?"
Finally, in the Little Havana section of Miami, I pulled up in front of Elian's house. His great-uncles, Lazaro (father of Elian's made-for-TV aunt, Marisleysis) and Delfin Gonzalez (who was shirtless and wore a watch with Elian's face on it), were both puttering around, tidying the grounds, as Lazaro's family had vacated the two-bedroom bungalow shortly after Elian was taken by I.N.S. agents in order that it might become a living museum. Among other miracles -- and these included the visitations of the singer Gloria Estefan and the actor Andy Garcia -- the Virgin Mary was alleged to have appeared in the bathroom mirror. But what had she come to say?
It was the end of the day, and the light was that big, orange-orange, four-dimensional light of Florida, belonging only to Florida, bathing everything in the felicity of good feeling, intensifying the color of each bungalow on the street, as well as the verdant greens of the palm trees that seemed to bleed more color in a warm breeze. The boy, the cameras and the crowds were long gone. All that remained was this empty house full of Elian's toys and Elian's race-car bed and newspaper clippings and paintings marking yet another surreal chapter in the Florida story. Pictures of Elian with the magician David Copperfield seemed to be everywhere. The beaten-up door to the back bedroom had been left just as it was, after it had been battered open by government agents bearing automatic weapons, and the famous closet in which Elian was hiding with Donato Dalrymple, the man who first fished him from the sea, was hung with the exact clothes from the predawn hours of that April morning two years ago.
"We pay taxes," Lazaro Gonzalez said wearily. "We love this country, but we hate the people who did this to us." Beneath the American and Cuban flags, as well as a heavy wooden crucifix that hung from the gutters, a couple of friends joined us on the front lawn, and the discussion careered from how Fidel Castro, Bill Clinton and Janet Reno had plotted together to steal Elian from them to how the Cuban community delivered the presidential election to George W. Bush. 
What struck me was just how convinced they were in their beliefs, how zealously American they were, standing on the front lawn of this relatively new landscape. If the country appeared on those election-night maps as a place divided by red and blue principalities, in Florida the various special-interest groups -- blacks, Cubans, other Hispanics, the elderly, the Jews and the hook-and-bullet N.R.A.'ers -- neutralized one another, blending the state purple. More likely than not, George W. Bush won because, of the ballots counted, he'd simply received 537 more than Al Gore. Those votes might have belonged to the Lhasa apso owners of the state, who knows? -- and it's possible that those Lhasa apso owners may decide the next election, for nothing, nothing at all, is certain here. 
One of the men on the lawn was short, burly and loquacious, with a cellphone holstered to his waist. He told the story of how his father, a political dissident, had been killed trying to escape from Cuba on a raft. "Fidel Castro shot him" is how he phrased it. He explained how he and his mother nearly didn't make the 90 miles from Havana to Miami, how his mother had been tricked and disgraced and then persevered, until later they were permitted to leave. He'd been a boy at his mother's side through it all, just like Elian. "I'm going to tell you something, brother," he said, thumping my chest. "We're living in the Promised Land, don't you forget it."
He went on. "That boy went back to prison -- Elian's living in Fidel Castro's prison. His future was right here in this house. Man, you've seen all the toys in there. One minute he was here, and then he was taken away. I think about it every day. My father was shot on a raft trying to get here, and here I am, breathing the air, free."
He stopped, and a strange lambency filled the yard, and, lo, by some odd trick of light, he seemed to have tears in his eyes. The American flag was over his head, faded and torn, and he was standing on the good earth of Florida. He was standing in Elian's front yard, waiting for the next hurricane. Yes, now that I think about it, we were waiting together for the next hurricane, and that man, it may have been a trick of light, but he had tears in his eyes, and whether they were for joy or sadness, I can't say.

CORRECTION-DATE: May 12, 2002

 CORRECTION:
An article on April 21 about Florida's place in the national culture referred incorrectly to the standoff between Branch Davidians and the F.B.I. in Waco, Tex., which occurred during the tenure of Janet Reno as attorney general of the United States and is getting new attention in light of her campaign for the Florida governorship. The investigation of the standoff led by former Senator John Danforth was independent, not Congressional. According to the Danforth report, the Branch Davidians were responsible for the fire inside their compound; it was not started by the F.B.I. The number of Branch Davidians who died was about 80, not 75, including more than 20 children, not 25. The previous office held by Reno was state attorney for Dade County, Fla., not state attorney general.
The article also misidentified the first family of Hispanic origin to live in the Florida governor's mansion. It was that of Bob Martinez, not Jeb Bush. The article also referred incorrectly to a swamp in Florida. It is Okefenokee; Atchafalaya (not Atchalafaya) is in Louisiana.

SECTION: Section 2; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk; Pg. 31

HEADLINE: ART/ARCHITECTURE; 
Russian Photographers Who Fell Out of History

BYLINE:  By VICKI GOLDBERG 

DATELINE: HOUSTON 

 BODY:
GLOBALIZATION may be a new economic phenomenon, but networks of international influence have been around a long time. In art, the first International Style began around 1400 in Western Europe, when the world was not yet a globe. The second International Style did not come along until the 1920's, but that's just a matter of labels. Once the railroad, the steamship and the modern press expanded travel and communication, it would be hard to think of a major artistic style that did not travel everywhere.
 But styles do change as they move about the globe, and sometimes their subjects and meanings change, too. "Russian Pictorialism," a show last month at Fotofest, the biennial Houston photography festival, made clear that this late-19th- and early-20th-century photographic style had certain goals and achievements quite unlike those of Pictorialism in other countries. There are certainly enough similarities to identify the work with the International Pictorialist style, which was characterized by its determined effort to look like any art other than photography, but the differences are so basic that they raise questions about the usefulness of general definitions. 
 With more than 130 pictures by 16 photographers from the 1880's to the 1930's, this was the largest show of Russian Pictorialism seen abroad since a 1928 exhibition in Italy, and it was the first time most Americans had the chance to see any of it. Still, that puts us way ahead of most Russians, for Pictorialism was outlawed by the Soviets in the mid-1930's and was effectively invisible until it began to emerge from obscurity in the 1990's.
After the death of the Pictorialist Aleksandr Grinberg in 1979, a friend stopped by his communal apartment in Moscow and found a neighbor using an exhibition print as a dustpan. Yet Grinberg had exhibited in more than 50 shows in Europe, Asia and the United States and won many gold medals in the 1920's before being silenced. (Honk if you've ever heard of him.) He was only one among many to show successfully around the world.
The exhibition's curators, Yevgeny Berezner and Irina Chmyreva from the State Center for Museums and Exhibitions of the Ministry of Culture of the Russian Federation, say in a brief but illuminating essay in the Fotofest catalog that the history of Russian Pictorialism has yet to be written. And right now, it's not just history but news.
The Russian Pictorialists clearly shared their international contemporaries' fervent desire to make photography an art as well as their predilection for Impressionism and Symbolism. Like other Pictorialists, they favored landscapes, portraits and nudes, mastered such "artistic" techniques as bromoil and gum bichromate, made photographs that could be mistaken for the products of other graphic techniques and courted blur, color and texture. Nikolai Andreyev's landscapes emerge from the romantic hours of dawn and twilight or the moments before a storm; Grinberg's are suffused with calm. Vasily Ulitin, in 1929, turned a factory into a mood poem composed of dark silhouettes, plumes of smoke and a pale glimmer of moon. Portraits are equally romantic: Nikolai Svishchyov-Paola titled one "Demon, the Portrait of a Young Man," and Miron Sherling's images of the opera singer Fyodor Chaliapin in costume are over the top even for opera.
Occasionally these artists committed remarkable excesses that took the style beyond the decorous territory it occupied elsewhere. In 1903, Aleksei Mazurin put a sepia photograph of a nun into the trapezoidal opening of a Spanish frame ornately carved like an arch with fake, painted tiles, creating an elaborate religious icon. Andreyev liked to paint and draw with crayons on his bromide-print landscapes, inserting a startling, faintly orange moon in one, infusing another so thoroughly with muted color that it became a miniature painting.
Even more striking is the loving attention paid to peasants, who symbolized the ideal harmony of humanity, nature and God. Pictorialism in other countries largely ignored workers and farmers. It was an art-for-art's-sake movement, an attempt to elevate photography and prove there was more to it than what the man in the street could produce with a Kodak. Pictorialism has also been said to represent a reaction against the cold materialism of science and applied technology and an attempt, as in Symbolism, to plumb the imagination. It was nostalgic and essentially elitist. In Europe, its placid vision momentarily reassured a bourgeoisie threatened by the unrest of the lower classes; in America, Alfred Stieglitz, who loudly championed Pictorialism, totally ignored Jacob Riis's pictures of tenement dwellers and Lewis Hine's of child labor.
In Russia, however, Ms. Chmyreva and Mr. Bereznov write, from the early 19th century on artists considered it their duty to deal with pervasive ethical problems and to improve public morality. The situation of the peasants was a primary concern. Though the serfs were freed in 1861, they gained little, as their land could barely support them and they remained illiterate. Photographers like Sergei Lobovikov, who tenderly photographed barefoot mothers and peasants in the field, created bucolic scenes and idealized Russian types while also performing what they saw as a civic duty. Presumably, such pictures could help soothe the guilt of a liberal audience, who, the curators say, saw the Pictorialist style itself as a mode of ethical, even spiritual, self-improvement -- an unlikely attitude in the West.
Russian photographers had one enormous advantage over their counterparts in the West: at the end of the 19th century, the Russian Academy of Fine Arts officially recognized photography, putting it on a par with other arts, while elsewhere it had to continue its strenuous social climbing. What's more, the progressive intelligentsia regarded photography as a sure sign of cultural modernity, and they valued photographs of landscape as evidence of the inherent spirituality of nature. For progressives, owning photographs was a vital element of self-definition. And photography was widely seen across the country in magazines and traveling exhibitions in the early 20th century. In America, by contrast, Camera Work, Stieglitz's splendid magazine, had just under 1,000 subscribers at its peak. 
The curators say that Pictorialist photography was so pervasive in Russia that it influenced the appearance of characters in novels as well as the appearances of actual people. Ms. Chmyreva and Mr. Berezner even suggest that Pictorialism served for a time as a kind of "metalanguage" that could speak to and unite the different classes, generations and geographic regions of Russia. After the Revolution, the Soviets endorsed both the avant-garde photography of people like Aleksandr Rodchenko and Gustav Klutsis and the derriere-garde work of the Pictorialists, whose photographs represented the Soviet Union in most foreign exhibitions in the 1920's.
By the late 1920's, both photographic styles were subject to criticism; they would soon be suffocated by Socialist Realism. In 1935, Grinberg, who had earlier been accused of "deviation from Soviet ideology" and criticized as a "filthy survival of the capitalist generation," dared to exhibit 20 nudes. Excoriated for "catering to the taste of pre-Revolutionary provincial hairdressers," he was arrested on charges of pornography and condemned to five years of labor. (A book on Grinberg, with many useful though rather poorly reproduced illustrations, was published by Carre Noir in 1996.)
The core of the collection shown at Fotofest was assembled by Mikhail Golosovsky, a photographer and optical engineer who patiently ferreted out work wherever it lay hiding. The show enlarged the history of Pictorialism, not only by adding photographers and images, but also by pointing out how ethical and spiritual meanings could inhere in photographs that would have been considered secular elsewhere. Negotiations are under way to mount this show in Russia, taking the exiled work home again.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Rediscovering Russian Pictorialism: Nikolai Svishchyov-Paola's landscape "Stone Lions," circa 1924, left, and a 1923 study by Aleksandr Grinberg. (Photographs courtesy of Mikhail Golosovsky/Rosizo State Center, Russia)

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/New Jersey; 
A Site Near the Mall Is Now a Plus for Offices

BYLINE:  By ANTOINETTE MARTIN

DATELINE: ROCKAWAY, N.J. 

 BODY:
IT is a most unprepossessing building that has been singled out for star treatment here in the shadow of Town Square Mall and the new Hilton Gardens Hotel. But that last part is the point, developers say: it is next to the mall and hotel.
 Previously occupied by the ITT Hartford Insurance Companies and vacant for five years, 333 Mount Hope Avenue off Route 80 in Morris County is loaded with potential, according to its current owners, WP Commercial. They have stripped the boxy 95,000-square-foot structure down to bare bones and are giving it a multimillion-dollar, full-body makeover -- from facade to mechanical systems. 
 Within 90 days or so, it will re-emerge as Rockaway Executive Center, a spiffed-up office space with surefire allure, according to WP Commercial, because of proximity to "suburban amenities." 
"It will be a Class A office site next to a large regional mall providing a wonderful amenity base for employees," said WP Commercial's chief operating officer, Mark Schaevitz. "After working a long day or on lunch hours, office workers can shop, go to the dry cleaner, the bank, the supermarket, or pick up a video.
"Business clients can stay at the Hilton Gardens, which is directly contiguous to the building, which is located next to a four-highway interchange.
"What's not to like?" asked Mr. Schaevitz about the 20-year-old building, acquired last year for $5.2 million. Mr. Schaevitz said his company had found a niche in refurbishing buildings that might otherwise have faded into the commercial-office-market woodwork, but which are close to shops, hotels, and major traffic arteries. 
Even in the current office market, where vacancy rates have risen for six straight quarters, WP Commercial -- a company that was acquired by Goldman Sachs in the late 1990's -- -- feels bullish about the makeover tactic, Mr. Schaevitz said.
"The development strategy works in both ascending and descending markets," he asserted, "because it always offers value to tenants, both in terms of employee retention -- always a big issue in New Jersey -- and amenities for clients, those with whom a tenant does business."
Steven M. Frank, the CB Richard Ellis broker who is marketing the Rockaway property, said the trend to consolidation and downsizing among state businesses enhances the value of an amenity-rich site.
"Employee attraction and retention are important factors to look at -- what I call the frictional costs -- resulting from property turnover," Mr. Frank said.
"A few years ago, all you had to do was provide an attractive options package to get and keep employees," Mr. Frank observed. "The stock went up, and everybody was happy.
"Today, the options are uncertain, and today what's on the minds of many employees is quality of life. The rise of the two-income family has made access to a place to do errands and chores during long workdays a major plus that companies can offer."
For most of the service industries that now dominate New Jersey's economy, employee compensation is already the top expense, Mr. Frank noted. He said providing employees with a good commute to an office near amenities is a way to add no-cost benefits that can be more valuable than a raise.
So, why isn't everyone doing this? Because it's not possible, Mr. Frank said.
"We think of New Jersey as being filled with malls, but the major ones aren't really that numerous, he said. "So the sites -- and opportunities to develop around them -- are relatively rare, and they're sought after."
THERE are several current examples of developers taking this approach -- a project going on next to Willowbrook Mall in Wayne, for one. At that site, Mack-Cali is at work on the 178,000-square-foot space that formerly served as headquarters for the now-bankrupt Grand Union stores.
"We're modernizing," said Michael Grossman, a vice president at Mack-Cali. "We are redoing the common areas, constructing a new lobby and repositioning the building to attract quality tenants." 
The Grand Union building's style had been "basic institutional" with a side entrance and no real lobby area, Mr. Grossman said. The renovated building will have a glass-and-aluminum lobby finished with wood panels and limestone floor tiles, and it is to be cosmetically upgraded throughout.
"We have 90,000 square feet on the market," Mr. Grossman said, "and the Willowbrook location is a great selling point, we think. It's a proven fact that once tenants move into a property that has the luxury of nearby amenities, they tend not to want to leave, because employees are happier."
In Bridgewater, there is the example of commercial space being constructed with proximity to amenities in mind.
Hines has almost finished building a 600,000-square-foot office complex called Bridgewater Crossing, adjacent to the Bridgewater Commons Mall and also a 350-room Marriott Hotel.
"Siting next to amenities -- that's what this project is all about," said Hines's project manager, Michael Pride. "The Hines U.S. Development Fund, which built this project, built 10 others around the country at what are referred to as suburban core locations. That was a prerequisite for buying this site and all the others.
"Hines considered the Bridgewater site very, very attractive because it is becoming so difficult to find an office site in New Jersey next to retail and a hotel."
Mr. Pride said his company believed the mindset of large commercial tenants had completely shifted from the 1980's, when the trend was to set up headquarters at secluded campuses. 
"Then, the idea was to be out in the woods, literally," he said. "Now, companies want to provide employees with a little stimulation and sense of community: pedestrian access to retail and a hotel, a place to go when they walk outside building."
Bridgewater Commons was built 20 years ago to create a downtown for Bridgewater, which, like the corporate town of Parsippany, 10 miles east, had no retail center. Now, the mall functions as a Main Street, Mr. Pride said, flanked by development.
"This little node is effectively a community," in Mr. Pride's view, "and employees at our buildings become a part of it."
The pharmaceutical company Aventis moved in February to the first of the two Bridgewater Crossing buildings to open. Aventis's facilities manager, Burt Horner, said the office workers were pleased with the move.
FOR the moving-in transition, Hines set up a golf cart ferry service to introduce employees to the mall. Now that spring weather has arrived, employees are out there "getting some exercise," Mr. Pride said. "Nobody has to get into their car. Given the car culture in New Jersey, that's a very special amenity."
The buildings are equipped with a helipad that Aventis uses several times a day to ferry people from Newark International Airport and other transit centers, Mr. Pride said. "When people are in town on business, they can walk too -- maybe go over to the mall after hours and take in a movie."
The second Bridgewater Crossing building is to open soon and is being marketed by Insignia/ESG.
Mr. Frank, the marketing broker in Rockaway, said he likes to use an "everybody wins" approach to selling space. "Let's face it, as often as not when businesses have to move, nobody's happy," he said.
"But this setup can serve the need of a company to reduce its costs and serve the need of the administrative group that oversees the needs of employees. It's certainly a benefit to the large malls, which get more customers.
"In the end, I really do think everybody wins."

HEADLINE: Cables Across the Sound Leave Hartford Divided 

BYLINE:  By CHRISTINE WOODSIDE 

 BODY:
LEGISLATORS from both parties have joined to oppose Gov. John G. Rowland, who last week promised to veto legislation that would stop the installation of utility lines under Long Island Sound for one year. 
 Last week, after promising a veto, the governor issued an executive order to stop pending cable projects for six months. He called for a task force to study cable crossings and report by next January. 
 His order exempts a project to repair a leaky electrical cable between Norwalk and Port Jefferson, N.Y., and does not apply to the installation of an electrical and fiber-optic cable between New Haven Harbor and the former Shoreham nuclear power plant on Long Island. That project received permits from the Connecticut Siting Council earlier this year and could be completed this spring, although the state attorney general is challenging it in court.
The legislators said their version of a moratorium is better. If legislators vote as they did for the moratorium, they will easily override any veto. The Senate approved a one-year moratorium for all the projects, by a vote of 31-2 on April 10, following the House's April 3 approval, 138-11.
"The bill says 'let's slow down, let's take a look at something the Siting Council has not addressed, the cumulative effect of these projects,' " said Senator Donald Williams, a Democrat from Danielson who is co-chairman of the legislature's Environment Committee.
"We can't ignore the economy of Long Island Sound," Senator Williams said. "We've been concerned in recent years with the drastically dropping lobster population and the shellfish beds." 
The New Haven Harbor project, proposed by Trans-Energie U.S. Ltd., an affiliate of a Canadian company, moved its cable to avoid some shellfish beds in New Haven Harbor and reached deals with shellfishermen to compensate them for losses.
"We've spent hundreds of millions of dollars cleaning up Long Island Sound," said Senator William Aniskovich, a Republican from Branford. "Why would we place the investment we've made in jeopardy, just so that a handful of companies try to win a race?" Senator Aniskovich said the third pending cable project, the Islander East natural gas pipeline (for which the Siting Council was holding public hearings last week) would go through his neighborhood before hitting the water to cross the Sound.
"Look, I'm a Republican," Mr. Aniskovich said. "The environmentalists really shied away from Republicans, thinking Republicans would line up behind the president, the governor and the utility crossings. I think that was a miscalculation. The more I learned, the easier this issue was to speak out on. All we're saying is: slow down." 
Environmental groups who met with legislators said their votes to stop the utility projects were atypical. "It was very unusual," said Donald Strait, executive director of the Connecticut Fund for the Environment, based in New Haven. "We feel it's quite historic. It's not in response to one project." 
Leah Lopez, staff lawyer for Save the Sound, a South Norwalk-based environmental group, said: "The whole moratorium was pretty unusual. First of all, they don't usually go for a moratorium; second of all, it was bipartisan, and third, to stop a project that has already been granted approvals was a pretty gutsy move." 
Mr. Strait and other environmental advocates said there were as many as a dozen utility lines planned for the Sound.
"I see no evidence of anything like that kind of number," said S. Derek Phelps, executive director of the Connecticut Siting Council. 
The Long Island Power Authority said it needed more sources of electricity, but that Connecticut should realize that power could flow in the other direction, to Connecticut, if Long Island did not need it. If the New Haven-Shoreham cable is not laid this year, the authority hopes that other plants and connections will get the island through the summer. Ten back-up gas turbines and a repaired connection from Westchester County all should be working by the summer, said Michael Lowndes, a spokesman for LIPA.
"I don't want to mislead you to say that with these other things everything's going to be hunky-dory here on Long Island," Mr. Lowndes said. And he said that even with the Sound cable, conservation is essential. "We still need our customers to change the ways they think about power and to use it more efficiently and effectively," he said.

HEADLINE: LONG ISLAND VINES; 
Small Winery's Red

BYLINE:  By HOWARD G. GOLDBERG 

 BODY:
When Harold Watts, a retired professor of economics at Columbia University, isn't tending his five-acre Wesley Hall Vineyard in Cutchogue, he nurtures his wines in barrel at Ternhaven Cellars.
 And once the daily underpinnings of his boutique business are shipshape, he carries out his duties as president of the Long Island Wine Council, the producers' trade association. 
 Bordeaux -- more precisely, wine with a Bordeaux inflection -- is the low-key Mr. Watts's passion. With a wit as dry as his reds, he announces his homage in his Bordeaux-type blend, called Claret d'Alvah. 
Claret, of course, is a British term for red Bordeaux. Alvah's Lane in Cutchogue is home to Mr. Watts's cabernet sauvignon, cabernet franc and merlot vines.
Not that you would confuse the grandeur of Mr. Watts's chai (the Bordelais word for a chateau's barrel hall) with, say, Chateau Lafite's. His eight-year-old winery is a converted gasoline station at 331 Front Street in Greenport. 
If that is not distinction enough, Ternhaven, the East End's tiniest winery, is also the easternmost on the North Fork. Just think, after you store Claret d'Alvah in your car trunk, you can catch Greenport's evening ferry to France. 
The 600 to 800 cases that Mr. Watts makes yearly don't pit him against big boys like Pindar and Duck Walk. But don't underestimate the quality of his wines.
Ternhaven's '98 Claret d'Alvah ($18) -- smoky, somber, smooth, intensely flavored (berries and black currant), prettily oaked -- can hold its own against Bordeaux blends from better-capitalized local competitors.
Mr. Watts will be pouring his wines, as will 21 other producers, at the council's 12th annual Windows on Long Island tasting in Manhattan, to be held April 29 at Guastavino's restaurant, on the East Side.
Previously, the wine festivity, catered by Long Island and New York City restaurants, was held at Windows on the World, at the World Trade Center, destroyed Sept. 11.
Proceeds will benefit the Windows of Hope Family Relief Fund and the Earth Pledge Foundation, a nonprofit organization that promotes sustainable agriculture. For tickets and information: (212) 725-6611, extension 225, and www.earthpledge.org. HOWARD G. GOLDBERG
