HEADLINE: L.I. @ WORK; 
Regionwide Planning Moves Closer to Reality

BYLINE:  By WARREN STRUGATCH 

 BODY:
LAST month, at the scholarship fund-raising breakfast Long Island planners hold annually, something happened that was apparently unprecedented: the county executives of Nassau and Suffolk both showed up, ready to share the limelight.
 Thomas R. Suozzi, Nassau's county executive, was ready to speak off the cuff, as is his fashion. Robert J. Gaffney, his counterpart from Suffolk, came with a prepared text, which is his style. Both were ready to deliver a keynote speech. 
 In the end, both did just that; Mr. Suozzi spoke first.
So rarely have the county executives met, in public or in private, that decisions on important regional issues -- housing, transportation, preservation of natural resources and economic development -- have generally been made on the town and village level, rather than Islandwide. Long Island has developed as a patchwork of regulations and incentives, rules and restrictions that reflect local needs rather than regional concerns. And thus it has never had a unified economic policy.
Because many residents originally came from New York City, so the thinking goes, Long Islanders express a strong preference for low-density housing, mainly separate single-family homes. As a consequence, there are few mixed-use developments that reduce the dependence on the automobile by allowing people to move easily from home, office and shopping. 
"It's difficult to call Long Island a well-planned place when you look at the transportation system here, which really doesn't work," said Sheldon Sackstein, an accountant in Melville and the chairman of Action Long Island, a business and civic organization that recommends solutions to transportation and other problems. "We don't have a single train station to serve the largest business corridor on Long Island, Route 110."
The Long Island Rail Road "shut down the one we had, at Republic Airport, in 1986," he added.
In the absence of a bicounty governing body, the Long Island Regional Planning Board, formed in 1965 by an act of State Legislature, has at least partly filled the vacuum. The 14-member board, a mix of government officials and local leaders, has examined hundreds of issues, ranging from protecting water purity to developing affordable housing, and has issued reports by the shelf-load. A number of its recommendations, including its proposal of an islandwide economic development and job creation plan in the early 90's, have been adapted by the Long Island Association, the region's largest business group.
There are signs that a more integrated and modern approach to planning, at least on the government level, is on the horizon. By dint of their joint appearance before the region's planners last month, the county executives sent a signal that they intend to communicate on regional issues more than their predecessors did.
"A few years ago, I wouldn't have expected either county executive to say much that might challenge the status quo," said Michael Levine, the section director of the local chapter of the American Planning Association and a planner at Allee, King, Rosen & Fleming, an environmental consulting and planning firm in Smithtown. "Things are different these days."
Mr. Levine said he was pleased with the content of the county executives' talks. Mr. Suozzi talked in detail about Nassau's need to clean up contaminated or otherwise neglected spaces, preparing them for new uses. Mr. Gaffney spoke in favor of "smart growth," the voguish concept that seeks to involve local groups more deeply, and earlier, in the planning process. 
"We call this kind of planning 'bottom up,' rather than 'top down,' " said Shellie Williams, the director of development at Sustainable Long Island, a Huntington nonprofit group prominent among local smart-growth advocates. "But there's a roadblock on Long Island to achieving it. There is a shortage of people with vision." 
A number of veteran planners, including Lee E. Koppelman, the executive director of the regional planning board since 1965, welcomed the onset of cooperation between the two heads of county governments.
"If the two county executives are really going to work together, it augurs well not just for good governance but for good planning," Dr. Koppelman said. "It raises the possibility that we will be able to tear down that imaginary Berlin Wall that divides the island at Route 110."
The boundaries of the Island's multitude of towns and villages are equally imaginary, but their effects are real. Depending on the local government in authority, businesses at opposite ends of the same street can face different regulations, taxes and bureaucratic processes. While some businesses view these inconsistencies as an irritation, others turn them to their advantage.
"Often, in Nassau County, we'd be dealing with businesses that knew we were competing with Suffolk County in terms of keeping companies here," said David Salten, who retired last year after 17 years as the chairman of the Nassau County Industrial Development Agency. "We'd even be competing with villages within Nassau County. Sometimes they'd play off one against the other."
Many planners, business leaders and community organizers give the regional planning board credit for the quality of its research and suggestions, and express admiration for Dr. Koppelman as a theorist and environmentalist. In Suffolk County, where he headed the planning department for over two decades, he is widely praised for making conservation and land preservation a priority. But many of his recommendations have failed to sway town and village officials, and ended up being discarded in favor of more parochial responses. 
"Dr. Koppelman has been influential among scholars and regional thinkers but has often not been able to get individual towns and villages to subordinate their views to the big picture," said Mr. Levine, the planner at Allee, King. "Nobody is obligated to listen to the regional planning board. And often, Dr. Koppelman's ideas have been perceived as too ivory tower and not been implemented.
Some planners, including Mr. Levine, believe that as smart-growth policies continue to take root, planners who cannot communicate their ideas effectively will find their influence waning. "As an individual, Dr. Koppelman may be more in the background today, but some of his ideas have caught up," Mr. Levine said. "There's more of an awareness of environmentalism and respect for the importance of thinking about the entire region. Everybody is starting to catch up to where he has always been."
Dr. Koppelman, 74, disagreed mildly with Mr. Levine's assessment. Since retiring as Suffolk's planning director in 1988, he immediately began a second career in academia, as the dean of the Center for Regional Policy Studies, a master's program at the State University at Stony Brook. He continues to direct the regional planning board, and he remains in demand as a consultant. He is currently advising the Towns of Brookhaven and East Hampton as they rewrite their master plans.
"I feel I'm as active as ever, and I have no plans to retire," Dr. Koppelman said. "Maybe in 20 years, I'll decide what I want to do when I grow up."

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: Site in Valhalla, in Westchester; 
Research Park Is Planned

 BODY:
Westchester County has announced a plan to turn a vacant 60-acre county-owned site in Valhalla into a privately financed biotechnology and medical research park. Under the plan, up to one million square feet of laboratory and incubator space would be built on the property, next to Westchester Medical Center and New York Medical College. 
 The proposed research park is part of Westchester development efforts that include expansion of biotechnology and research. That sector has about 8,000 employees, the county said, giving it the state's largest concentration of biotechnology and pharmaceutical firms, including Regeneron Pharmaceuticals in Tarrytown and Acorda Therapeutics in Hawthorne. 
 Salvatore J. Carrera, the county's director of economic development and real estate, said that more than 30 private developers had expressed interest in the park. The county said that the list included Tishman Construction of New York City, Simone Development of New Rochelle, the Starrett Corporation of New York City and the Louis Dreyfus Property Group in Wilton and Stamford, Conn. 
Three to five finalists will be invited to prepare formal proposals, and a final developer will be selected by late fall, Mr. Carrera said. Those interested can contact the Office of Economic Development at (914) 995-2926.

LENGTH: 1970 words

HEADLINE: The Wait For Breast X-Rays Grows Longer 

BYLINE:  By JOAN SWIRSKY 

 BODY:
SIXTEEN years ago, when Geri Barish, a Baldwin resident, was 41, she scheduled her first mammogram. The radiologist's office gave her an appointment that same week. 
 The routine test -- which is given to many thousands of women on Long Island every year -- detected breast cancer. Less than a year later, Mrs. Barish found another cancer through a self-examination. And last month, her yearly mammogram picked up yet a third cancer. 
 "It was the early detection that saved my life," said Mrs. Barish, the president of 1 in 9, a Long Island advocacy group for breast cancer treatment and research. "All anyone knows is that early detection gives women like me the best chance for survival. Two of my mammograms found cancers that couldn't be felt and had no symptoms." 
But for many Long Island women, the early detection that mammograms can provide is now harder to come by. An increasing number of radiologists are no longer offering the test, and this means that women are having to wait six weeks to five months for appointments. Radiologists make the distinction between screening mammograms, for women with no symptoms, and diagnostic mammograms, for women with symptoms like breast pain or lumps. The diagostic tests can usually be scheduled in a week or at most, two.
"Screening mammograms are not cost-effective, so many radiologists are getting out of the field," said Dr. David A. Fisher, the chief of radiology at ProHealth Care Associates in Lake Success. In his own office, which employs six radiologists who do about 5,000 mammograms a year, the wait is about six weeks.
"We don't make any money on mammograms," he said. "We lose money." 
Despite some recent studies that call conventional wisdom about annual mammograms into question, the American medical establishment, including the American Cancer Society and the National Institutes of Health, recommends that women age 40 to 69 be screened at least every two years. 
After lung cancer, breast cancer is the most common cancer among women in the United States and the leading cause of death among women age 15 to 40. The cancer society estimates that one woman in eight will develop breast cancer sometime during her life. Last year, nearly 200,000 women -- and 1,500 men -- were diagnosed with breast cancer, and 41,000 women died from the disease. 
In Nassau County, state Health Department figures show that breast cancer is diagnosed in about 1,000 women each year, and the same number in Suffolk. In both counties, breast cancer occurs more often than in other parts of the state. Statewide, there are 104.1 cases per 100,000 women, but in Nassau, the rate is 115.6 cases per 100,000 women, and in Suffolk, 118.2 cases per 100,000 women. The state's mortality rate from breast cancer is 26.7 deaths per 100,000 women each year; in Nassau, 27.4 deaths per 100,000 women and in Suffolk, 28.6 deaths per 100,000 women.
Last year, Congress raised the Medicare reimbursement base rate for mammography from $69 to $81.81, but that is less than it costs a doctor to do the test, generally $100 to $150. 
"Out of the reimbursement we receive," Dr. Fisher said, "our expenses include paying the doctor, the nurse, the technician, the front-desk person and the person who bills the patients and collects the reimbursement. Then there's the cost of leasing the mammography equipment, developing and storing the films and file-room personnel. Most doctors aren't in it for the money, but they still have to survive."
Although Mrs. Barish credits mammograms with detecting her cancers early, she is realistic about the difficulties in making the test available and in scheduling appointments. "It's a supply-and-demand problem," she said. "Our population is aging, and there's a greater demand from women who are 40 and older to have screening mammograms, but the supply of doctors who provide them is decreasing."
Precise numbers are hard to pin down. Charles K. Showalter, senior director of government relations at the American College of Radiology, which represents 30,000 radiologists and radiation oncologists, said that his organization "keeps track of facilities but not of individual radiologists who leave the field."
"The problems of access for women is going to continue," he added, "unless we can increase the supply of radiologists and mammography becomes more economically viable."
According to the Food and Drug Administration, the number of certified imaging centers New York State dropped from 725 in 2001 to 690 in April. On Long Island, health officials said that 5 of 58 imaging centers have closed in Nassau County this year alone. But in Suffolk County, for reasons that are not clear, the number increased from 44 to 49 last year.
Dr. Robin Ehrenpreis's office, Northern Imaging in Great Neck, is open six days a week and handles about 50 mammograms a day. Even so, the wait is two months to see a radiologist (there are two), and five months to see Dr. Ehrenpreis herself. "The waits are very anxiety-provoking for women who are not accustomed to planning six months in advance for a routine X-ray," she said. "It's a big concern."
Dr. Ehrenpreis is also a partner in the five offices of the Nassau Radiologic Group, where the waits are shorter, generally one to three weeks.
The reasons for the shrinking pool of radiologists who do mammograms are many, Dr. Ehrenpreis said: "Mammograms are very difficult to read, they offer the lowest reimbursement, they involve among the most stringent federal regulations and quality controls, and the patients who get them are the most litigious."
Mammograms are difficult to interpret, which is why problems arise. "Mammographies comprise less than 5 percent of what radiologists do, but more than 50 percent of the lawsuits," said Dr. Paul A. Fisher, an assistant professor of radiology and surgery at Stony Brook Medical Center and the chief of imaging at the Carol M. Baldwin Breast Care Center in Setauket, which screens 11,000 women each year. "Reading and interpreting a mammogram is absolutely a judgment call. Even the very best radiologists in the world only see 85 percent of cancers. It's not a perfect test, and people are human. They miss things."
Many radiologists admit that interpreting what they see on mammography films is tricky. "It's an art based on science," said Dr. Stephen A. Feig, the director of breast imaging at Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan. "There's a variability in interpretive skills, but if there's a question, patients should always get a second opinion."
Recently, Dr. Feig and a colleague at the University of California at Los Angeles conducted a survey of 211 senior radiology residents. Sixty-five percent said they would not consider a fellowship in breast imaging, and 63 percent said they did not want to interpret mammograms in their future practices. Fear of lawsuits and inadequate pay were the chief reasons, Dr. Feig said.
At the Breast Care Center, Dr. Fisher said, women have to wait up to two months for an appointment. "So many for-profit breast imaging centers are closing that there's a net transfer from smaller to larger facilities," he said. "But even so, we lost over $200,000 last year. Ideally, women should never to have to wait for a screening, because that's when a woman's life flashes before her eyes." 
Although radiologists may complain about the litigious bent of their patients, several medical insurers on Long Island said that radiologists pay less for malpractice insurance than some other medical specialists: $47,000 a year for radiologists, by one estimate, compared with $124,000 for obstetricians and gynecologists, and $166,000 for neurosurgeons. 
With mammograms, most lawsuits stem from misread results. Dr. Harvey F. Wachsman, a former neurosurgeon who has been a malpractice lawyer in Great Neck for 20 years, said, "A false positive means there's a lot of mental anguish but no cancer, but a false negative means there's a cancer that wasn't detected or treated."
The problem is that some radiologists should not be handling mammograms at all, in Dr. Wachsman's view, and others should be more careful. "Not all radiologists are qualified to read mammograms," he said. "Some just glance at them and miss a cancer. And that missed cancer is usually found in a relatively young married woman with children whose mammogram was misread."
"I say that every suspicious mammogram -- no matter how small the suspicion -- should be aggressively addressed by a biopsy," Dr. Wachsman added. "When you compare the minimal discomfort of a biopsy to possibly death, the risk-benefit analysis should always err on the side of caution." 
New technologies -- digital mammography and magnetic resonance imaging -- offer the prospect of making mammograms more accurate and easier to get. In digital mammography, X-ray images of the breast are transmitted to a computer screen. Doctors get clearer images of dense tissue and can make more precise diagnoses. They can also transmit the images quickly to other doctors for consultations.
Magnetic resonance imaging takes cross-section images of the human body using a strong magnetic field and radio waves instead of X-rays.
"As doctors start doing more digital mammograms and screenings with M.R.I.'s, where the reimbursement is greater, fewer of them will leave the field," said Dr. Ehrenpreis, the radiologist.
An exception to the long waits on Long Island is the Breast Imaging Center at Nassau University Medical Center in East Meadow, its two vans and four satellite clinics: Freeport/Roosevelt, Elmont, Westbury/New Cassel and Hempstead. Together they handled 7,765 screening mammograms last year, at no cost to county residents. 
"We do screening and diagnostic mammograms within a week of a woman's making an appointment," said Christine D. Mancuso, the nurse who serves as the program's coordinator. 
Although popular wisdom says that screening mammograms save lives, two recent studies call that contention into question. A Canadian study of 40,000 women, published in The Journal of the National Cancer Institute in September 2000, reported that for women in their 50's, yearly mammograms combined with physical breast examinations by trained clinicians did not reduce death rates any more than physical exams alone. And an article in The Lancet, published last October, said that Danish researchers had concluded there was no reliable evidence that regular mammograms reduce the risk of dying of breast cancer for any age group.
Barbara Brenner, the executive director of Breast Cancer Action, an advocacy group in San Francisco, agrees. "Mammography is a flawed test that misses an average of 10 percent of all tumors, and as many as 25 percent of tumors in women younger than 50," she said.
On the other side of the fence, several legislators are pushing to make mammograms easier to get. Senators Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York, and Tom Harkin, Democrat of Iowa, sponsored a bill last year "to increase mammography reimbursement rates, increase accessibility and decrease the waits for women," Senator Schumer said.
The closing of breast screening centers, he added, "is especially alarming for women in Nassau and Suffolk Counties, where breast cancer incidence is, respectively, 11 and 13 percent higher than incidence statewide."
A co-sponsor of the House version of the bill is Representative Peter King, Republican of Seaford. "There is not a family on Long Island that hasn't been impacted by breast cancer," Mr. King said. "It's important that women get screened early because this is one disease where early detection works. We're trying to do everything to remove the long waits for women and the roadblocks and disincentives for doctors."
Mr. King said that although the timetable for the bill was uncertain, "I think we have a better than 50-50 chance of pushing it through."

HEADLINE: Nassau Police Budget Fight Hears an Echo of Sept. 11 

BYLINE:  By PHILLIP LUTZ 

 BODY:
LAST September, in the hours and days after the terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center, Long Island police officers in the hundreds rushed to help out in New York City. Many of the officers who stayed on the Island were reassigned to guard places deemed vulnerable to terrorists or otherwise went on high alert.
 During that month, while the antiterror mobilization was at its peak, the number of reported crimes and arrests for major crimes dipped in both Nassau and Suffolk. But the following month, as the terror threat began to ease and the police started to return to their normal duties, the number of arrests and reported crimes in both counties jumped. 
 Those are the statistics, and no one is disputing them. But there's plenty of disagreement over what they mean, and that argument has entered the debate between the Nassau County police union and the new county executive, Thomas R. Suozzi. In a package of proposed tax increases and spending cuts intended to close a projected $428 million gap in the county budget, Mr. Suozzi wants to wring $30 million in concessions from the union, in part by cutting some 300 officers from the 2,800-member force. 
All sides are using Nassau's low crime rate -- the lowest among counties its size in the country -- to justify their positions on staffing and other issues. Mr. Suozzi has said the crime rate in Nassau has remained low despite previous reductions in the force. Gary DelaRaba, the president of the Nassau County Police Benevolent Association, has said the crime rate shows that the size of Nassau's police force produces good results.
Siding with Mr. DelaRaba, some crime experts said the increase in arrests in October may have reflected a surge in activity by criminals who thought that the police were either distracted or too few in number to be able to do their duties. That, especially in light of the potential for another terrorist attack, would argue against cuts in police staffing, they said.
"After 9/11, Nassau and Suffolk sent a significant number of officers to New York City," said Harvey W. Kushner, the chairman of the criminal justice department at the C. W. Post Campus of Long Island University in Brookville. "The bad guys probably knew that and took something of an advantage." If so, he added, it would "absolutely, 100 percent" argue for a correlation between the size of the police force and the crime rate. The implication is that if Mr. Suozzi allows the Nassau police force to shrink, crime in the county will rise.
But Anthony Cancellieri, Nassau's deputy county executive, said, "I don't think you can connect any increase in arrests post-9/11 to anything that happened on 9/11." Told that Professor Kushner had suggested that would-be criminals might have been taking advantage of the situation, Mr. Cancellieri said, "Obviously, a lot of them got caught."
According to the Nassau County Police Department, its officers and other police forces in the county made 407 arrests on charges of murder, rape, robbery, burglary, aggravated assault or larceny in September 2001. That figure, down 17 percent from the month before, was the lowest for the 26 months in the reporting period, which was January 2000 to February 2002. In October 2001, the Nassau police made 540 arrests, up 133, a 33 percent increase from the month before.
The Suffolk County Police Department, which covers most of the county aside from the East End, made 398 major-crime arrests in September, down 11 percent from the previous month. In October, the number jumped to 513, up 115, a 29 percent increase.
In both counties, the increases were the biggest month-to-month gains in the 26 months, both in absolute and percentage terms.
Like arrests, reported criminal activity surged in October after dropping the month before. Reported crimes in Suffolk, which dropped by 7 percent in September, rose by 12 percent the next month, to 2,996. That was the highest figure in the 26-month period. Reported crimes in Nassau, which dropped by 11 percent in September, rose by 15 percent the next month, to 1,654. The reports of crimes in Nassau, unlike the arrest statistics, do not include its two cities and about 10 incorporated villages, out of 64 in the county, that have their own forces.
An August-to-September drop-off in total arrests and reported crimes in both counties in 2000 raises the possibility that seasonal factors played a part in the declines during the same period in 2001. But Officer Michael Irise, a Nassau police spokesman, said "criminals went on a moratorium" in September 2001.
Nora V. Demleitner, a law professor at Hofstra University in Hempstead, suggested that even would-be criminals might have been stunned after the attacks. "Everybody was so shocked," she said. "Petty crimes seemed so irrelevant at a time of national crisis."
Professor Demleitner said that a sharp, across-the-board increase in larceny statistics in October 2001 strongly suggested that conditions specific to the climate after Sept. 11 were the major factor driving the overall increases.
Larceny, she said, is a type of crime that might be especially encouraged by a real or perceived absence of police. Thus, while the police may have been unusually energetic on returning to activities after the period of intense duty in September, she said, the increases in arrests in October were more likely a proportionate response to increased thievery. "People thought the police were otherwise occupied," she said. 
Or as Officer Irise put it: "The moratorium was over." Criminals, he said, "made up for lost time."
J. Leonard Samansky, who was the emergency management chief under Thomas S. Gulotta, Nassau's county executive at the time of the attacks, said that by Sept. 12, some 400 Nassau police officers were directly involved in the response to the disaster, aiding in communications, searching for bombs, guarding federal buildings, patrolling New York Harbor and manning a roadblock set up on the Long Island Expressway near the Queens-Nassau border to keep people from going into New York City. He said the Nassau County police maintained a major presence in the city for 18 days and continued to provide services for several weeks afterward.
Like the Nassau police, officers from the Suffolk County Police Department began to mobilize within hours after the terrorist attacks, said Philip Robilotto, the Suffolk police chief. About 200 officers were sent into the city for about five days, after which the force was cut back to about two dozen, maintaining a Suffolk police presence in the city until early 2002.
Meanwhile, in the immediate aftermath of the terrorist attacks, the Suffolk police secured Brookhaven Airport, Republic Airport and Long Island MacArthur Airport. Patrols were stepped up at smaller airports around the county. 
Nassau officers earned about $6.5 million in overtime for their work, said Michael Kornfeld, communications director in the county comptroller's office. The costs pushed the number of officers in Nassau who earned more than $100,000 in 2001 to 1,300, up from 900 in 2000. Suffolk police earned almost $1.8 million in overtime after the attacks, about a quarter of which paid for the initial securing of the county's airports, Chief Robilotto said. Both counties have applied to federal and state agencies for reimbursement, most of which is expected to come from the Federal Emergency Management Agency.
Chief Robilotto said the commitment strained his department's resources. "I only have 2,700 cops, and I still had a county to run," he said. But officials in both counties said that officers who normally performed other duties were called on to fill in for street officers sent to the city. "There was no period when Nassau County was underprotected," Mr. Samansky said. Chief Robilotto said, "We didn't strip ourselves."
Professor Kushner said that in the event of similar emergency, a smaller police force might put the public at risk. He said the Nassau police should hire 175 new officers from a civil service list that will expire in October. Estimates of the first-year costs for the new officers range from $7 million to $11 million.
The force has already lost more than 300 officers in the last two years as a result of attrition. So far this year, 84 officers have retired and none have been hired, said Officer Wayne Hartmann, the Police Benevolent Association's sergeant at arms. 
Mr. Suozzi plans to save money and ease the impact of force reductions on public safety by moving officers now on desk and clerical duty into street patrols, replacing them with civilians who earn less. Since May 2000, 40 civilians have been hired to replace retiring Nassau County officers, said Detective Thomas Mazur, a spokesman for the department. In Suffolk, 60 positions were "civilianized" last year, Chief Robilotto said.
In the past, Nassau police officers have expressed strong reservations about civilians' taking jobs that police had handled. They still do, especially when it comes to certain station house positions. Still, at least some seemed resigned to the likelihood that the practice will grow. "It may be the wave of the future," Officer Hartmann said.
Professor Kushner noted that while demographic factors like the aging of the population have also contributed to the low crime rate, the department had provided "unmatched" service. "If it's not broke," he said, "why fix it?"
But despite critics' concerns, Mr. Cancellieri said: "There will probably be a hit to the police budget somewhere down the road. I just don't know how big or where." 
Whether Nassau voters will endorse such cuts is still an open question. While some Nassau taxpayers have expressed anger over police salaries, which now average more than $100,000, surveys show the public remains very concerned about terrorism and crime. In a recent survey by RoperASW, a polling company in New York, those two topics ranked first and second on a list of Americans' personal concerns, eclipsing economic issues.
"People don't like people playing politics with public safety," said Anthony Santino, the press secretary for the Nassau Republican leader, Joseph Mondello. As for the political impact of Mr. Suozzi's plan, "it's a situation where the jury is still out," Mr. Santino said.

HEADLINE: Habitats/Hastings-on-Hudson, Westchester; 
Opening Up Their House To Let the River Views In

BYLINE:  By TRISH HALL

 BODY:
ALTHOUGH the house didn't exactly turn its back to the river, it didn't embrace it either. But Gavin Macrae-Gibson and Dr. Nonnie Balcer were attracted to it anyway. Built in the 1930's, the house stood on a hill in Hastings-on-Hudson in a neighborhood where the winding roads follow paths originally laid out by Frederick Law Olmsted and Calvert Vaux, who designed Central Park. 
 The house was in such poor condition that "the real estate broker didn't even want to show it to us," said Mr. Macrae-Gibson, 46, an architect with his own practice in Manhattan. But he and his wife, at the time a banker with J. P. Morgan, could imagine its potential, and they liked Hastings, a half-hour train ride north of Manhattan in Westchester County. A liberal town where people hide their SUV's in the garage, it has long been known as a hospitable place for artists, writers and intellectuals. 
 So 10 years ago, Mr. Macrae-Gibson and Dr. Balcer bought the house, leaving their home in Jersey City "just as the last screw was being put in the kitchen," she said. They moved in with their two young sons and embarked on a decade-long renovation that they have only recently finished.
The most drastic changes came in the first month of owning the house, when they ripped down walls and added large windows to let in the light and the river views. They eliminated the separate living room, dining room and sun room and created one long flowing space parallel with the Hudson River. 
THEY brought the river into their house, too, by cutting down some of the trees that stood in front. "You couldn't see the river out of the window at all," Mr. Macrae-Gibson said. "Now you can see it from every window, which is the unifying point."
Their passion for the river is evident throughout the house. Over the mantel in their book-filled living room is an abstract landscape of the Hudson River by Ellen Hopkins Fountain, a contemporary Westchester artist. "We're very interested in the notion of a new Hudson River School," Mr. Macrae-Gibson said. Other paintings in their house were also inspired by the river, which reminds Dr. Balcer, 48, of her childhood home in Montreal and the St. Lawrence River. About six years ago, Dr. Balcer, who has a Ph.D. in economics from Cambridge University in England, retired from banking and is now a vice president of the local historical society.
At the same time they opened up the ground floor, they took the roof off of the house and enlarged the top floor, turning an attic into a light-filled master bedroom suite with a bedroom as well as an exercise room, a walk-in closet and a bathroom, complete with a laundry chute. "I love laundry chutes," Mr. Macrae-Gibson said. "They're like secret passages."
The creation of the top floor was a revelation. "It was amazing to rip off the roof and see this," he said, pointing to the expanse of the Hudson.
That first year, they were so excited about their house that even before the top floor was closed in "we had an Easter dinner up here, open to the elements," she said. It still provides the best place for viewing the river, which seems to envelop the house. In front of it, at a small table on a laptop computer, Mr. Macrae-Gibson, who grew up in England and came to this country to go to Yale, is working on a book about architecture in Manhattan, including some of his own projects.
After almost two years of renovating the house, they took a break. "It was pretty brutal," Mr. Macrae-Gibson said. "Now in all honesty I can say to my clients, 'I feel your pain.' "
But after a few years they dived in once again, restoring the brick porch in the back of the house and doing the decorating that they had never had time for. They finished the basement and made it hospitable for their sons, Rory, now 14, and Malcolm, now 11. They also built a room for Dr. Balcer's loom and all of her yarns. 
"It was something I always wanted to do," she said, but there was never time to weave and be a banker and a mother. Now she makes fabric for herself and her friends, and her mother told her something she never knew before. "My two great-grandmothers were famous weavers," she said. "My genetic makeup was calling me."
Finally she and her husband worked their way to the kitchen, now a bright compact space with a peninsula and a natural flooring like the one Mr. Macrae-Gibson chose for the Ottendorfer branch of the New York Public Library in the East Village, which his firm restored. 
The renovation, which cost about $275,000, did not of course have to take 10 years. But Mr. Macrae-Gibson said that he is so busy finishing work for his clients on residential, commercial and institutional projects that it was hard to find the time to do his own home.
"We're like the shoemaker's family," Dr. Balcer said cheerfully and without a hint of reproach. And indeed, her husband may have preferred not to rush things. 
"It takes years," he said, "to make a good pair of shoes."

HEADLINE: For Developers, Brownfields Look Less Risky 

BYLINE:  By JOHN HOLUSHA

 BODY:
BY the end of the decade, if the developer's plan follows schedule, a dreary 1.87-square-mile stretch of closed municipal dumps that litter the New Jersey Meadowlands in the towns of Lyndhurst and Rutherford is to be transformed into a parklike setting with golf courses, hotels, housing and offices. The upgrading is being done largely with private capital, rather than government expenditure, reflecting changes in recent years that have made redevelopment of polluted lands more attractive to developers. 
 The Meadowlands have been an eyesore for generations, but efforts by government to force landowners to clean up their property using litigation and regulation have often been ineffective, in part because of difficulties in identifying and pursuing legally responsible owners of sites that might have changed hands, and uses, many times. 
 But recently the private sector has been finding ways to make money cleaning up the lightly contaminated properties called brownfields. A key part of the new attention to contaminated lands is the comfort level afforded by increased experience with the cleanup process. Another is the increasing availability of insurance to cover various risks in such projects. And underlying the activity is a characteristic shared by many of the polluted sites: they are convenient to both transportation and to urban areas that were once the source of workers for vanished factories and are now the source of prospective shoppers and home buyers. 
The Meadowlands project is being undertaken by EnCap Golf Holdings, a company backed by Cherokee Investment Partners, a large venture capital fund that has specialized in brownfield projects for the last decade. Other companies have raised capital to invest in environmental projects, promising investors high returns.
Recent actions by the federal government has made brownfield cleanup predictable and attractive as a business option, according to real estate specialists. President George W. Bush signed the Small Business Liability Relief and Brownfield Revitalization Act earlier this year, a law that recognized that lightly contaminated brownfields are in a different category than the badly polluted sites covered by the law commonly known as Superfund. 
The brownfield act doubles, to $200 million, the federal assistance to states and communities to help clean the 500,000 to 1 million brownfields that the Environmental Protection Agency estimates are scattered across the land. The act also increases the liability protection for landowners who participate in the voluntary cleanup programs now established in more than 40 states. Under Superfund, a landowner can be held liable for the entire cost of a cleanup, regardless of who was responsible for the contamination or whether an owner made good efforts to control damage.
"The new federal law provides a more realistic assessment of risk," said Charles Bartsh, a senior policy analyst with the Northeast-Midwest Institute, a Washington-based research organization. "When these things become a line item, not a black hole, is when things can really take off."
Previously, the virtually unlimited liability inhibited development of brownfields, in part because lenders have been reluctant to get involved in sites that they might wind up owning if the developer goes out of business. However, some states have taken measures to limit the exposure of people participating in the voluntary cleanups. Some have also recognized that sites to be used for industrial or commercial uses do not have to be as clean as those used for residences, playgrounds or schools.
In recent years, insurance companies have developed policies that provide a cap on a developer's financial risk. And pools of private capital have been assembled to invest in brownfield development, with the promise of high returns.
Meanwhile, cleanup technology has been developed to a point that assessments of the extent of contamination can be made and the cost of cleanup reduced to a number.
With these tools in hand, developers can evaluate whether a given project makes economic sense. "You have to look at each site as a real estate deal," said Charles Kramer, the president of Brookhill Group, a New York company specializing in brownfield redevelopment. "The fact that a site is contaminated is an issue and a cost component to be added in. In the end it is another line item."
Thomas Darden, the chief executive of Cherokee, which is based in Raleigh, N.C., stresses another basic consideration. "The real driver in this business is land use issues," he said. "There is an increasing interest in communities to have development in the urban core." Not only is Cherokee backing the ambitious $1 billion, 1,200 acre Meadowlands project, but another affiliate, OENJ Cherokee, is managing a project to turn the old city dump in Bayonne into a golf course and an effort to convert a contaminated waterfront site in nearby Woodbridge Township into an auto importing center to relieve some of the pressure on the Port Authority's docks in Newark and Elizabeth.
National statistics about brownfield development are notoriously difficult to come by because definitions vary and there is little uniformity among state reporting systems. Nevertheless, the National Brownfields Association, a trade organization, has reported that, based on environmental insurance policies purchased, the total spending for goods and services by companies cleaning up brownfields totals $1 billion to $1.5 billion a year and is growing at a rate of 15 to 20 percent annually. However, this does not account for the value of the properties involved.
"No one defines a brownfield and no one wants their property on a list of brownfields, so hard data is hard to find," said Robert V. Colangelo, publisher of Brownfield News, the publication of the association. But he said some corporations that in the past simply sat on property rather than recognize environmental liability are beginning to seek ways of unlocking the value of those holdings.
"There has been a shift of philosophy regarding brownfields," Mr. Colangelo said. "Superfund was a stick program. Now people are looking at the end use of a property once it has been cleaned up. That is a sustainable approach."
Corporate real estate is the largest potential market for brownfield remediation, said Jack Thomas, president of the Brownfields Recovery Corporation of Boston. He said business should grow "as corporations warm to the concept that liability can be transferred and that they can walk away with a strong sense of comfort. But it is slow."
Mr. Thomas's company is involved in a project to develop Admiral's Wharf, a 40-acre site on the West Branch of Stamford Harbor in Connecticut. The site, contaminated by petroleum products left by a coal gasification plant decades ago, is to be developed into a complex of 620 living units, 275,000 square feet of office space, a ferry terminal and a 275 to 300 slip marina.
CLEANUP costs of $10 million to $15 million were included the sale price of $40 million negotiated between the developers and the previous owner, Northeast Utilities.
Mr. Thomas said he and some partners got into the brownfield business in the mid-1990's and initially focused on industrial properties. "One of our first projects was a manufacturing-warehouse building that had a big spill that was the economic downfall of its owner," he said. "We bought it, addressed the environmental problems, put on a new roof and new mechanical systems. We got environmental insurance, which satisfied a Wall Street lender, got our cash out and went on the next project."
He said the company was currently involved in a 1,160 acre waterfront site in St. Croix in the United States Virgin Islands that was formerly an alumina smelter. He said the intention was to redevelop the site with a waste-to-energy power plant, a water desalinization plant and port facilities.
Mr. Thomas said some investors had been willing to participate in these projects because of the promise of high returns and the availability of environmental insurance. "As we have grown, our access to capital has grown," he said. He asserted that the availability of capital and insurance have been far more important in the development of the brownfield business than greater flexibility in state regulations.
Joseph Cotter, the president of the National RE/sources Company of Greenwich, Conn., said he was able to raise $100 million in 1996 to do brownfields and other redevelopment projects and has been applying the funds since then.
"Our company does business with large corporations," he said. "We buy the site and take title." One example, he said, was the Home Depot store in Derby, Conn., which is built on the site of an old ironworks. "A Home Depot store is basically a warehouse," Mr. Cotter said, "and it can live with a different cleanup than a residential development."
Since big box stores require 10 acres of land for their format, they are often forced to deal with contaminated industrial properties to find suitable locations in crowded metropolitan areas like New York. 
Mr. Cotter said his company was also involved in the planned reuse of the old Otis Elevator site in Yonkers and the Sperry-Rand site in Lake Success.
Joseph L. Boren is president of American International Group's environmental unit, which has become one of the largest providers of insurance for brownfield projects in recent years. He said the business had "grown substantially over the last five years."
When brownfield projects were first proposed in the late 1980's and early 1990's, he said, insurance was not available because insurance companies did not have enough experience with them. "Environmental insurance was the great unknown," he said. "It was not commonly known that you could control risks."
But with experience has come knowledge, and companies like American International Group now offer policies with considerable confidence in their pricing. "We now have insurance products that do two things that make the brownfields business go," said Kenneth Cornell, an executive vice president of AIG Environmental.
The first, he said, is insurance that puts a cap on cleanup costs. This helps to protect a developer from financial disaster if the actual cost of a cleanup is a lot higher than the company had estimated.
The other is to cover the cost of dealing with the situation if more pollution is found after the supposedly clean land has been sold. "The seller has to give indemnification to buyers," Mr. Cornell said. "So this protects against things you don't know about."
As with others in the field, the insurance executives say that success in brownfield redevelopment lies with the underlying real estate transaction. "A brownfield is a real estate transaction on contaminated property," Mr. Cornell said. "The environmental uncertainty is removed because of the insurance."
Mr. Darden said Cherokee bought insurance to cover its projects because even with the experience of treating more than 300 properties, the company might still make mistakes. "It is very unusual for us to buy a property without drilling a lot of holes in it, but we still get surprised," he said. 
"And we have found when we do find a lot more pollution than we expected, the costs are usually 100 percent greater than the estimate."
He said that the insurance helps cover the cost of the overrun but that the insurance companies require sizable deductibles. 
The project that Cherokee is backing in the Meadowlands is based on the site's proximity to the golf hungry New York metro area and the hills -- some as much as 120 feet high -- created by generations of dumping municipal and industrial refuse, which has been covered with soil. The project, originally planned as a 99-year lease, was delayed as state officials decided to sell the land to EnCap. 
William Gauger, president of EnCap, which is based in Tampa, Fla., said the first phase of the Meadowlands project is scheduled to commence on Sept. 1 of this year and is expected to take six to eight years to complete. The plan is to reshape the land to make it suitable for golf courses and to bury the garbage even more deeply, possibly using soil dredged from New York harbor as part of the channel deepening program for the seaport.
The additional capping is intended to reduce the amount of rainfall seeping through the old landfills, which leaches toxic materials out of the dumps and carries it to nearby waterways. The water that does seep through is to be treated and reused. The site will be encircled by a 20-foot-deep buried wall to prevent uncontrolled seepage.
The project is being designed by Robert A. M. Stern Architects of New York and Torti Gallas & Partners of Silver Spring, Md. They are working with EDAW Inc. of San Francisco, which specializes in environmental planning and landscape architecture.
Mr. Gauger said treating the site to make it suitable for construction was expected to take three and a half years. The actual building could take an additional three to five years, he said. 
The company has taken control of most of the land already, although some remains tied up in litigation. Officials of the Hackensack Meadowlands Development Commission, which controls planning in the area, have said they would prefer to collect rental fees from developed property rather than continue operating dumps.
Phase 1 of the Meadowlands project is to include 27 to 36 holes of golf on both sides of the western spur of the New Jersey Turnpike. Renderings of the project show a Kingsland Golf Course, named for one of the old dumps on the site. Another course is named for Berry's Creek, an unlovely stream that flows through the area.
Each of the golf courses would have its own clubhouse, and the developers say at least 18 holes would be reserved for public play. The project will be about 60 to 65 percent in the town of Lyndhurst, with the rest in Rutherford.
Plans call for the project to be connected to a new station on New Jersey Transit's Bergen rail line, which would provide access to the site from the New Jersey suburbs and New York. The plans also include two hotels. One is to be a business hotel with 400 rooms near the rail link, and the other would be a 350 room resort hotel with a conference center.
Six office buildings with a total of 1.2 million square feet of space are included, along with 100,000 square feet of retail space. About 1,500 units of housing are to be built, with 50 percent reserved for people 55 years or older and the balance to be open market housing.
Other details include a senior citizen clubhouse, a golf academy and four athletic fields: three for baseball and one for soccer.
The first stage of development is scheduled to cover 700 acres of land. The second phase would cover the remaining 500 acres and would include more golf and related developments. About 200 acres of the area would remain as wetlands; where wetlands have to be filled, an equal amount of new wetlands are to be built, developers say.
Mr. Darden of Cherokee said the Meadowlands' proximity to Manhattan gives the land value, despite the environmental problems. Mr. Gauger said EnCap acquired the property for about $12 million, which he characterized as a low price that recognizes the additional costs of cleanup and capping.
"There is a notion that developers and communities are only interested in sprawl," Mr. Darden said. "That has changed. People are interested in downtowns, they want to live downtown." Since most older areas come with pollution problems from past industrial times, these properties must be treated before they can be reused, he said.
The business of cleaning and reusing brownfield properties may have moved from a voyage into the unknown to a fairly normal real estate business, but it still has some unusual challenges.
Irving Cohen, president of OENJ Cherokee, said development of the golf course in Bayonne had been slowed by a lack of dredge material to bury the old garbage. Federal officials have been slow to issue contracts to deepen the port and until that happens, the Bayonne site will remain more brown than green.

HEADLINE: In Florida, Prime Site Thrives After Cleanup 

BYLINE:  By JOHN HOLUSHA

DATELINE: SARASOTA, Fla. 

 BODY:
EVER since he moved his Harley-Davidson dealership from downtown last December to a site near an exit from Interstate 75, the main north-south route in the western part of the state, sales of motorcycles and accessories have surged, said Rick Rossiter, the dealer.
 The attractively located site was not available for development until recently because the soil and water in the area were contaminated by solvents discharged from a nearby military electronics plant, creating a brownfield. 
 But years of processing by on-site treatment plants have reduced the underground plume of solvent contamination, which had spread from the plant to most of the 40 acres of vacant land nearby; now the pollution is limited to the plant itself and a few isolated patches. 
The Brookhill Group, which bought the land and arranged for the cleanup sold three acres to Mr. Rossiter so he could have a bigger parking lot for visiting bikers, a larger showroom and repair area. Indeed, he is negotiating for adjacent land to establish a used-motorcycle business.
Other parcels closer to the highway have been sold so a bank branch, a restaurant and a hotel can be constructed, although the latter will probably be delayed. 
"It cost approximately $3 million to clean up the site," said Charles Kramer, president of Brookhill, which specializes in finding contaminated land and redeveloping it for other uses. But it has to be the right land, he notes. "If I-75 was not here, the economics would not work," he said.
"This was all agricultural in the past," said Leon DiLieto, a broker with Michael Saunders & Company. But, he said, as land values have increased, offices are taking the place of feed stores and industrial plants. 
"There are offices going up north to Tampa and south to Naples," he said, concentrated near I-75 exits.
This kind of development is good for the region's economy, said Nora Patterson, a Sarasota County commissioner. "This is an opportunity to bring jobs to the area via I-75," she said. "Around here we have wealthy retirees and low-paid people who serve the retirees, and not much vitality in between." JOHN HOLUSHA

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW; 
Ivy League Or Also-Ran? Does It Matter?

BYLINE:  By TOM REDBURN

 BODY:
THE long march is almost over. This week, my daughter, like countless other high school seniors, will choose which college she will attend in the fall. Does it make a difference where she goes?
 It does to us, of course. But within the economics profession, there is a vigorous debate over whether highly selective and highly expensive colleges -- like most of those to which our daughter, Emily, applied -- confer any real benefit in later life. 
 Recent research by Alan B. Krueger, an economics professor at Princeton University (can't get much more selective than that) and Stacey B. Dale, a senior researcher at Mathematica Policy Research, a consulting firm, suggests that it does not. They found that students who chose a school with lower admissions standards over a more competitive school earned incomes just as high as those who attended the elite college.
A fat paycheck isn't everything -- far from it. But what that means, Mr. Krueger explained, is that a student accepted at the University of Pennsylvania, a prestigious member of the Ivy League, would be just as well off going to Penn State, which some people know more for its football team than its academics. Most intriguing, the research found that even students rejected by a highly selective college did as well as those who attended it.
"The best school that turned you down," Mr. Krueger said, "is a better predictor of your future income than the school you actually attended." It's the person, not the place, that matters: students who apply to schools for the ambitious are ambitious enough to do well just about anywhere.
So what does this mean for parents? First, it's supposed to be comforting; you can console your child that the rejection letter from Brown doesn't really hurt.
And it suggests a cunning strategy: Apply to Harvard or Yale but then go to the college that offers the best deal. That's partly a joke, but I wouldn't be surprised to see a lot of second-tier colleges -- the kind that offer generous merit aid to talented students -- using Mr. Krueger's theory to persuade high-school graduates to choose, say, Denison or Lewis & Clark, over Williams or Stanford. No doubt there's some truth to that argument for some students.
Now, like most fathers, I think I know what's best for my daughter. Funny how she has her own ideas, though.
As she culled through the acceptance letters, I thought Wellesley, the most prestigious name on the list, would push her the hardest to succeed.
"All girls," she replied. Exactly. No boys to distract her.
What about Pomona College in Southern California, where my wife and I met?
"It never snows," I told her.
"Too far away," she said. "I'd never see you."
What parent can argue with that?
For her, the choice has come down to two colleges. The well-known and nearby Wesleyan University, in Middletown, Conn., is a classic New England liberal arts college that prides itself on its diversity. It usually attracts several students every year from her high school; one of her best friends already goes there. Carleton College, a hidden jewel in the Midwest, is more obscure, but it has a better program in math, which she loves, and is close to Minneapolis, where her favorite aunt lives with her family.
WE'RE fortunate that she has such good colleges to choose from and that we can afford to send her anywhere she wants to go. But this also makes clear that the choice of a college is about a lot more than how much money our children will earn in their future careers.
For one thing, what about those who choose a lower-paying but socially valuable career like teaching over something like public relations or investment banking? Are they to be treated as less successful than the class goof-off who mostly drinks and parties but ends up making a lot of money after taking over a car dealership?
Beyond that, many parents care a lot about the academic atmosphere fostered at the colleges their children attend. We want bright faculty members who will challenge them to think harder, and we hope that they will meet interesting people and develop richly satisfying lifelong friendships.
And other academic research, somewhat counter to Mr. Krueger's, still suggests that having lots of smart, motivated fellow students in a concentrated place provides something immensely valuable.
"We're coming up with hard evidence," said Gordon Winston, an economist at Williams College, "that being surrounded by other bright, demanding students has a real effect on academic performance."
In the end, both sides of this economic debate point to one common conclusion: find a challenging college that's a good fit. As a parent, I want what's best for my children. But the decision should be up to them.

PERSON: Michael Buckley 

HEADLINE: Private Sector; 
An Unflappable Banker Is Tested

BYLINE:  By BRIAN LAVERY

DATELINE: DUBLIN 

 BODY:
ROUND 9 p.m. on Feb. 4, Michael Buckley, the chief executive of Allied Irish Banks, received a long-distance telephone call, the kind that bankers dread.
 A currency trader named John M. Rusnak at Allfirst Financial, Allied Irish's subsidiary in Baltimore, had run up hundreds of millions of dollars in losses over five years, in trades that presumably should have been detected much earlier. 
 The news hit Mr. Buckley, on the job for only nine months, as he was about to announce record 2001 profits for Allied Irish, the biggest bank in Ireland. Those profits were now slashed in half by one of the biggest scandals since the rogue trader Nicholas W. Leeson brought down Barings Bank in 1995. 
"The degree of shock that I was affected by was on the same scale as a family bereavement," Mr. Buckley said in a recent interview, his first since results of a formal investigation were released on March 15.
Mr. Buckley, 57, had offered to resign, but the bank's directors convinced him to stay. He has since been in crisis-management mode from the scandal, which caused $691.2 million to disappear from the bank's books. He has traveled to Washington, Baltimore and New York to meet with regulators, oversee a reorganization at Allfirst and calm nervous investors, some of whom think Allied Irish should not only sell Allfirst but also get out of the American market.
Mr. Rusnak, who was fired, is cooperating with prosecutors in the United States. No criminal charges have been filed, and it remains unclear whether others at Allfirst or Allied Irish, or other banks, might have been involved.
Despite the distraction of the scandal, Mr. Buckley said: "I have a lot of energy; I'm blessed for my age. It hasn't been getting me down." 
Friends said Mr. Buckley was no stranger to handling stress. He spent two years in the 1960's training to be a Roman Catholic priest before switching to get a master's degree in philosophy at the National University of Ireland. He landed a position in the Finance Ministry, helping to write national budgets, and for 10 years taught political philosophy on the side at University College Dublin.
He does not attribute his reserved demeanor to his time in the seminary -- a period he remembers with some amusement.
"It took me about two years to discover women -- and what they might do to you," he said during a radio interview last year with RTE, Ireland's state broadcaster, in explaining why he quit the seminary. "There was a fundamental crevice between being a priest and having any sort of relationship with women." (Mr. Buckley is now married with two daughters and a son.)
At the news conference here to present the investigative report about the scandal, Allied Irish's chairman, Lochlann Quinn, became red-faced and flustered under intense questioning and eventually evicted all television cameras. Mr. Buckley responded to questions in measured and deliberate tones.
"He gives the wrong impression of being one of these slow, country men," said Padraic Fallon, an Allied Irish board member and a London-based publisher. "He's a strange man to see in 2002. He's more the kind of man you would see in 1955."
Dermot O'Brien, a former Finance Ministry colleague of Mr. Buckley and now chief economist at NCB Stockbrokers in Dublin, called him "the most unflappable guy I ever saw in that job."
Mr. Buckley moved to NCB in 1986, rose to managing director and helped convince the government to build the International Financial Services Center, a 27-acre office complex in Dublin's derelict docklands. With tax breaks and other incentives, it attracted companies like Merrill Lynch and Deutsche Bank and became an important contributor to a turnaround of Ireland's economy. But when the center was still a blueprint, he said, "Nobody ever believed that you could do something like this in Ireland."
Now he is facing similar skepticism about the American business of Allied Irish. Banking industry analysts in Dublin and London say a relatively small European institution like Allied Irish has no place in the highly competitive American retail banking business. Yet Mr. Buckley has said that Allied Irish will keep Allfirst, which it has owned for nearly 20 years.
He expressed admiration for regional American banks, like Fifth Third Bancorp of Cincinnati and M&T Bank of Buffalo, saying "the intensity of your franchise is what matters, not the size." 
Mr. Buckley said he wanted to expand Allfirst through acquisitions. But for now he is still dealing with the aftermath of the scandal. Six Allfirst executives were fired, while two others -- Frank Bramble, the Allfirst chairman, and Pat Ryan, Allied's group treasurer -- resigned. Risk management and foreign exchange trading procedures are now centralized through Dublin.
After news of the scandal first broke, there was some expectation that Mr. Buckley would resign himself. He had been told of possibly suspicious trading by Mr. Rusnak last May, but Allfirst executives had assured Mr. Buckley that nothing was wrong.
"It took a bit of persuading" by Allied Irish's board to convince him to stay on the job, he said. "I tendered it on a belief that, when you look at accountability, that you can't stop at any particular level in a company. The buck, as far as I was concerned, stopped with me."
But losing Mr. Buckley would have left the bank leaderless at a time when it was considered particularly vulnerable to a takeover by its acquisitive British neighbors, Royal Bank of Scotland and Barclays Bank. And the Bank of Ireland, Allied Irish's main domestic rival, has expressed interest in a merger.
"At the end of the day, the whole thing was a mess, and it was very difficult to apportion blame," Mr. Fallon, the board member, said. "There wasn't anyone at a senior position in the group whom we could fire, that was the really frustrating thing."
Although the final chapter on the scandal is far from closed, Mr. Buckley says Allied Irish's employees have "a fantastic sense of ownership" in the company. He said many had expressed support for him. "They see this, very much as I do, as the defining challenge of their lives."

HEADLINE: Investing; 
Fidelity SetsIts Sights On New Worlds Abroad

BYLINE:  By CONRAD DE AENLLE

 BODY:
FIDELITY INVESTMENTS has more than $1 trillion under management, so its $22 billion in funds focusing on foreign markets is relatively small change. Too small, in the opinion of Fidelity, the nation's largest portfolio manager, which is trying to raise its profile in international investing.
 The company has improved the performance of its international funds relative to that of its peers. In the three years through March, according to Morningstar Inc., Fidelity's international funds fared better, on average, than two-thirds of all international funds; in the three years ended in March 2000, Fidelity was beating fewer than 60 percent. 
 Fidelity executives attribute the improvement to technological enhancements and strengthened research capabilities. Outside commentators agree that these have been big factors, but they also say Fidelity has been helped by a conservative management style that is better suited to the difficult global market conditions of the last two years than to the preceding bull run. 
Philip Bullen, who oversees Fidelity's international funds, prefers to focus on the benefits the company gains from "scale and size and having resources," including more than 200 analysts worldwide.
"On the buy side, we don't think anyone else has that scale," Mr. Bullen said. "Because of the philosophy we have of recruiting analysts from top schools, we have an incredibly strong and in-depth pipeline of people." The best ones, he said, go on to manage Fidelity portfolios.
Mr. Bullen also pointed to technology systems that allow better communication among far-flung offices. The international funds that Fidelity sells to Americans are managed from its Boston headquarters, but many analysts are based abroad to be near the companies they follow. Fidelity also offers funds to foreign investors, but they are run by a separate entity in Britain.
Emily Hall, a Morningstar analyst who follows Fidelity's international funds, agreed that the company's size, and the research expertise and scope it could buy, provided an advantage. But she said its international funds had also benefited from missteps in the 1990's that led Fidelity to become a low-risk manager.
"In the early to mid-90's Fidelity got burned by big bets on individual countries or sectors," Ms. Hall recalled. "The funds calmed down as a result; a lot of them are much more aware of whatever benchmark they have. The funds as a whole have become somewhat more conservative and are not taking wild risks anymore. They are not turning in barn-burning performances but have turned into steady offerings."
Bill Blevins, managing director of Blevins Franks International, a financial advisory firm in London, also said the cautious approach could hurt performance if investors found a new appetite for risk. "Fidelity seemed to go into a more conservative phase, and of course this has been rewarded in the last couple of years," he said. "It remains to be seen if this approach will reward investors as markets recover and a more dynamic approach becomes necessary."
Still, so far, so good. In the three years through March, according to Morningstar, Fidelity's international equity funds rose 4.9 percent, on average, versus 0.7 percent for all international equity funds. Fidelity's two international bond funds have been more impressive, up 17.8 percent a year, on average, over three years, while the average international bond fund was up 2.8 percent.
Fidelity's $22 billion in funds investing outside the United States is less than what some of its rivals manage abroad. American Funds, for instance, has $93 billion in funds that invest overseas and Janus has $30 billion, according to Standard & Poor's. Franklin Templeton has about the same amount as Fidelity in international funds and the Vanguard Group has $19 billion.
Fidelity's large number of funds results in a variety of recommendations from analysts and advisers. Eric M. Kobren, executive editor of Fidelity Insight, an independent advisory newsletter, likes Fidelity's Europe Capital Appreciation and Europe funds. "I think Fidelity has some great international funds," he said. "Europe Cap and Europe should benefit from a rebound in the global economy."
James Stack, editor of InvesTech Market Analyst, likes two other Fidelity funds, Japan and Japan Smaller Companies.
Ms. Hall recommends Fidelity Diversified International, its flagship foreign fund and a solid performer for many years. Its longtime manager left a year ago to start his own money-management firm, but his replacement, William Bower, has maintained the fund's strength, keeping it in the top 10 percent of international funds.
Mr. Bower relies less on the quantitative methods -- using data screens to select stocks with desired characteristics or to eliminate those with undesirable ones -- favored by his predecessor, Gregory Fraser and more on Fidelity's researchers. When he took over, Mr. Bower expanded the fund's inventory of small and midsize stocks, as well as technology and media stocks. Recently, however, he has been lightening up on technology.
MS. HALL was less enthusiastic about other funds. "I think Fidelity runs some decent international funds," she said. "Not all of them are stellar. A lot of them are segmented, like the individual country funds. Why do they even have them? Does anybody really need Fidelity Canada?"
She described funds run by one manager, Richard R. Mace Jr., including Overseas and Global Balanced, as "lackluster," saying they "don't take a lot of risks and as a result have not turned into shining stars." The funds have done slightly better than average for their peer groups over the last one and three years. His Worldwide fund has beaten close to 90 percent of its peers in the last year, and three-fourths of them over three years. 
Mr. Mace said that "what some people misunderstand is I maximize risk-adjusted performance."
"I consider the relevant index as a baseline and take bets against the index when prudent," he added.
Difficulty in emerging markets has eroded many portfolios, and Fidelity's have not been immune. Fidelity Emerging Markets has had seven managers in 11 years. It ranks in the bottom 1 percent among international funds over five years, largely because it was heavily invested in Asia when the region's economy collapsed in 1997.
"It has kind of been a problem child for them," Ms. Hall said. But under its new manager, John H. Carlson, a veteran of Fidelity emerging-markets bond funds since 1995, the fund "has found religion and become somewhat conservative," Ms. Hall added.
While managers of other Fidelity international funds usually pick stocks and then consider what macroeconomic factors might affect performance, Mr. Carlson looks first at countries, in an effort to avoid the upheavals that take down even the best investments in emerging economies. Only then does he pick stocks.
"The first rule of thumb is: Don't blow up," Mr. Carlson said. In the debt funds, he added, "that has allowed us to handily outperform the index over long periods." He is trying to apply that rule to the stock fund, whose returns have been roughly average over one and three years.
Is Fidelity correct to start crowing about its international funds? Taken together, Ms. Hall said, the funds deserve middling grades. "They're doing a good job, but not anything unusual or extraordinary, beyond the number of funds they offer," she said.
She said several firms -- American Funds, William Blair, Julius Baer and Tweedy, Browne -- "all run international funds as good as or better than Fidelity's."
"Any fund shop is not a monolith," she added. "It can have some good ones and some rotten ones. Fidelity has more better ones than ones that are not good."

HEADLINE: Investing; 
In a Large Family, Many Views on Investing

BYLINE:  By CONRAD DE AENLLE

 BODY:
FUND managers at Fidelity Investments say they are given great freedom to pick stocks. While they all have access to the same research, there is no house view that compels any of them to own shares in certain industries or countries.
 As a result, William Bower, who runs the Fidelity Diversified International fund, has been selling technology stocks, and Richard R. Mace Jr., who manages three smaller funds, has been buying technology shares. 
 Owning such stocks "worked out well over the last nine months of last year, but we have been catching our breath lately and have pared down the fund's aggressiveness," Mr. Bower said. With expectations running high for improvement in technology sectors, he said, "the risk-reward in these names has gotten a bit dicey." 
"I'm just not convinced the recovery is going to be as strong as the market is telling us," he added. "Looking out two or three years, I'm cautious on technology."
Mr. Mace, by contrast, noted that "some of my largest bets have been in tech," notably semiconductor makers like Samsung Electronics in Korea and two in Taiwan: Taiwan Semiconductor and United Microelectronics. 
Producers of copper and aluminum also have prominent places in his three funds -- Fidelity Overseas, Fidelity Global Balanced and Fidelity Worldwide. He expects the metals companies to benefit as an economic recovery takes hold. Two companies he mentioned are Rio Tinto, the British mining company, and Alcan of Canada. 
Mr. Bower has been using the proceeds from his tech-stock sales to "nibble on energy and health care."
When the global economy sputtered last year, drug stocks were favorites because of their steady earnings streams. Lately, however, "people are giving up on them, saying they are cyclical, but they are not," he said.
"Over the last four years I was underweight Big Pharma," he added. "I'm buying now because everyone is starting to hate them. I think it's going to be the same story: Good companies with good pipelines are going to deliver the numbers and people will say, 'What a great business opportunity they are now.' "
Among his choices are GlaxoSmithKline of Britain and Aventis of France. Smaller health care companies he likes include Altana, a German drug maker, and Nobel Biocare, a Swedish maker of dental implants.
Mr. Mace said he likes another large drug maker, AstraZeneca of Britain, on the strength of a new cholesterol drug, Crestor, which could become "the most effective drug at improving cholesterol of any on the market." The company is seeking approval for the drug in the United States.
The energy stocks owned by Mr. Bower tend to be out of the mainstream. They include Suncor Energy, a Canadian business that extracts crude oil from sand. He likes Canadian energy companies because they would have no risk of disruptions if the Middle East conflict escalated. But they would reap the full benefit if the conflict drove oil prices higher. He does not own giants like the Royal Dutch/Shell Group and BP.
Mr. Mace, who is neutral on energy, nevertheless owns one of the industry leaders, TotalFinaElf of France, which he says has had "good production growth, consistent cost-cutting over the years and a discount on valuation." CONRAD DE AENLLE
