HEADLINE: Business; 
Looking Far From 7th Ave. to Revive Leslie Fay

BYLINE:  By LYNNLEY BROWNING

 BODY:
AT the American Image Awards last month in New York, a glittering gathering of the fashion retailing world, John Pomerantz received honors for his nearly three decades at the helm of the Leslie Fay Company, one of the country's oldest and, at one time, most popular dressmakers. 
 But on Seventh Avenue in Manhattan, in the heart of the fashion industry, the spotlight is on John Short, Leslie Fay's little-known new chief executive. Mr. Short, a former banker and onetime underwear and sunglasses executive, spent eight years in Europe and Asia with Esprit, the trendy clothing maker, but has no experience in the women's apparel industry in the United States. 
 Mr. Short has a tall order at Leslie Fay, where sales of dresses for work and social occasions have shrunk amid the casual revolution of recent years. The American dress market peaked in 1997 at $8.9 billion in sales, but by last year it had contracted by a third, to $6 billion, as consumers turned to informal pants, skirts, jackets and blouses, said Marshal Cohen, president of NPD Fashionworld, a fashion research company in Port Washington, N.Y. 
Mr. Short recalled that before he took the job, someone told him, "You'd really better be sure you want to do this, because the dress business is in a death spiral."
Leslie Fay, which sells through national department and specialty stores and off-price outlets, is also being buffeted by its outdated, polyester styles, the growth of private-label brands and the rise of "cheap chic" separates at stores like Target and H&M, the fast-growing Swedish chain. 
Founded in 1947 by Mr. Pomerantz's legendary father, Fred, who named the company after his daughter, Leslie Fay had sales of more than $859 million at its peak in 1991. Then, Leslie Fay, a recognized name among career women for its no-nonsense, affordable dresses and other outfits, towered over the rival Liz Claiborne. But Claiborne has since eclipsed it in sales and prestige. Other competitors include Jones New York, which is part of the Jones Apparel Group, as well as Sag Harbor and private labels like Kathie Lee, sold through Wal-Mart.
In 1993, accounting fraud at Leslie Fay forced it to restate its profits for 1991 and 1992. The company spent 1993 through 1997 in Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. Its former chief financial officer, Paul Polishan, was sentenced in January this year to nine years in prison for fraud. 
BY last year, sales at the reorganized company, which was forced by creditors to sell Sassco Fashions, its most profitable division, in 1997, had declined to around $170 million, according to Three Cities Research, a private-equity firm in New York that owns about 75 percent of Leslie Fay. That was down from $197 million in 2000, Three Cities said, and far below Leslie Fay's target last year of around $230 million. Leslie Fay was publicly traded until November.
The company still makes moderately priced dresses under its own label and higher-priced dresses under the David Warren, Rimini and Trio New York names. Under its Leslie Fay Haberdashery and Joan Leslie labels, it also makes sportswear, coordinated ensembles of dresses, pants, jackets, blouses and skirts. It does most of its manufacturing overseas.
After the fraud scandal, the company expanded its sportswear business, acquiring Cynthia Steffe, a women's casual sportswear line, two years ago. But dresses still account for about 70 percent of Leslie Fay's revenue, said Mr. Pomerantz, who remains the chairman. In 2001, the company picked up the license to manufacture higher-end dresses for Liz Claiborne and its Elisabeth plus-size line.
Last year, as many apparel makers cut prices, Leslie Fay raised its average price 10 percent, Mr. Cohen of NPD said. The move hurt sales and forced markdowns that led to a 39 percent plunge in revenue from sales through department stores like Dillard's, Macy's and Lord & Taylor, among Leslie Fay's top distributors, NPD said. The stores shifted unsold inventory to discount retailers like T.J. Maxx and Marshall's. 
Not all has unraveled. Retailers' orders have been brisk for Leslie Fay Sportswear, a line of moderately priced knitted ensembles that replaces a brand once known as Outlander, said Roseanne Cumella, a merchandising manager at the Doneger Group, a fashion industry consulting firm.
Leslie Fay may be seen as frumpy and slow to change. But in Mr. Short, 53, it has a leader who is irreverent about dress codes and quick-paced in temperament.
Belying his past as a button-down corporate banker for Citibank in Venezuela, Ecuador and Hong Kong in the late 1970's and early 80's, he had his trademark ponytail and wore no tie at the black-tie awards ceremony last month.
Still, Mr. Short is hardly laid back. "He is manic and driven and determined," said John Botts, chairman of Botts & Company, an investment management firm in London, who has known him for more than a decade.
Mr. Short has a master's degree from Thunderbird, a graduate school of international management in Glendale, Ariz., and majored in economics and Spanish at Dartmouth. His financial experience and ability to analyze a company's numbers make him a rare -- and valuable -- creature in the fashion world, Mr. Botts said.
Mr. Short declined to be specific about what he had done at Leslie Fay since assuming the job on March 20. He said only that he faced "a huge learning curve" and was reviewing all business lines with Mr. Pomerantz, who was president or chief executive from 1972 to 1999.
Mr. Short "is better in growth situations, not in structured environments," Mr. Botts said.
Willem de Vogel, president of Three Cities, said that Mr. Short would trim production costs by improving forecasting for orders from retailers and that he would tighten internal management procedures to produce better-quality garments, faster and at lower cost. Mr. Short has been pushing Leslie Fay's new president, Linda Larsen German, who created the successful Elisabeth line at Liz Claiborne, to spiff up Leslie Fay's designs quickly, Mr. Vogel said. 
Mr. Short may be envisioning a future in which dresses are no longer Leslie Fay's mainstay business. "If you go into a dress department today, there are dresses and then there are a lot of two- and three-piece garment combinations, like a pant with a soft jacket," he said in a brief interview. Such sportswear, he said, "is the way the market has evolved, and the consumer is telling us she likes that."
Mr. Short is also a big investor in Leslie Fay, having bought a stake of at least 10 percent -- he declined to be more specific -- after the previous chief executive and president, John Ward, resigned in January. Leslie Fay's other shareholders are Constable Partners, an investment firm, and other senior executives. 
Before joining Leslie Fay, Mr. Short was chief executive, president and chief operating officer of Joe Boxer, the whimsical underwear maker. There, he sold excess inventory to prepare the financially troubled company for sale to private investors. Before that, he was executive vice president of the American and Canadian operations of Sunglass Hut International. 
At Esprit's Asian headquarters in Hong Kong in the late 1980's, he pared the list of suppliers, organized licensing brands and helped the company go public on the local stock exchange. Later, as head of Esprit Europe and Esprit's global licensing operations, he pushed to integrate the licensing companies and the American arm of the company, but he clashed with one of Esprit's founders, who deemed the moves too brisk and too bold, said Richard Baker, the chief executive of Ocean Pacific, the surf wear-inspired clothing company.
Birgit Kelley, a retail consultant and former colleague of Mr. Short's at Esprit, recalled: "A lot of his ideas were implemented only in pieces. He's sometimes a little too fast for his own good."
He quit Esprit to move to Paradise Valley, Ariz., near Scottsdale, where his two children and their mother, from whom he was getting a divorce at the time, had settled. He commuted by plane to Joe Boxer in San Francisco and to Sunglass Hut in Cincinnati. He is still commuting about twice a month between Arizona and New York City and plans to buy a country house in upstate New York.
At Leslie Fay, Mr. Short "will get that first pass as not of Seventh Avenue and not having the right skill set," Mr. Baker said. Mr. Short reportedly was not among the dozen or so candidates whom recruiters originally vetted for Leslie Fay. "But he's a quick study," Mr. Baker said. "This is a very unique choice to run a brand like this on Seventh Avenue."

HEADLINE: MONEY & MEDICINE; 
Birth Control Is Changing, and Its Price Is Rising

BYLINE:  By MICHELLE ANDREWS; Michelle Andrews is a freelance writer in Manhattan specializing in health care. Her column on its economics appears the third Sunday of each month. E-mail: moneymeds@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
FOR decades, the main weapons for preventing pregnancy have been condoms, birth control pills and sterilization. Sure, other methods are available, and there have been innovations from time to time, but none have quite caught on to the same extent.
 That may soon change. Two contraceptives will be introduced this summer that will significantly enhance women's options. And if the new methods are as popular as many family planners say they will be, they might even make a dent in the 49 percent rate of unplanned pregnancy in the United States. 
 But there are problems already. The new contraceptives -- a skin patch that is replaced weekly and a vaginal ring that is used for three weeks at a time, each releasing contraceptive hormones -- may not be readily available to poor women. Public clinics, like those operated by health departments and Planned Parenthood, may not be able to afford these new methods for the 6.5 million women, mostly poor and young, that they serve.
The National Family Planning and Reproductive Health Association, which represents many of the 7,000 public clinics, says that so far the best rate it can get from Ortho-McNeil Pharmaceutical, the Johnson & Johnson unit that makes the Ortho Evra patch, is about $15 for a monthly supply. While that is far less than the retail price of $30 to $40 a month, it is still substantially higher than what public clinics pay for oral contraceptives. (Negotiations on the vaginal ring, called the NuvaRing and made by Organon, haven't begun. The retail price, however, is also expected to be $30 to $40.)
With so many kinds of birth control pills on the market, competition has helped to keep a lid on their prices, and manufacturers have given deep discounts to clinics. A one-month supply of pills, which normally goes for $30 elsewhere, may cost a clinic just $1.50. Of course, there is no such price competition for the patch or the ring.
But family planning organizations don't begrudge the drug companies their rates. "Ortho-McNeil has just spent hundreds of millions developing the patch," said Judith DeSarno, chief executive of the National Family Planning and Reproductive Health Association. "They're doing their best to figure out how to give us a bigger discount."
Ms. DeSarno says public clinics have felt especially squeezed lately -- they're seeing more patients who are uninsured or not enrolled in Medicaid, while spending more on screening and treating diseases. At the same time, she said, financing for Title X, the only federal program dedicated to family planning, has been flat. In fact, when adjusted for inflation, it declined 57 percent from 1979 to 2001.
It wasn't always this way. "Contraception for all" may not be the phrase most associated with the presidency of Richard M. Nixon, but in 1969 he asserted that "no American woman should be denied access to family planning assistance because of her economic condition." He called for more money for flexible family-planning programs, and Title X followed a year later.
Title X is still the backbone of the system, though it doesn't appear to be a priority for President Bush. For the fiscal year that begins this October, the president has proposed $265 million for the program, about the same as this year. Education programs on teenage abstinence, however, would get a $33 million increase, to $135 million.
In the long run, though, the president's Title X budget may cost the government more than it saves. According to the Alan Guttmacher Institute, a nonprofit group that focuses on reproductive health research, for every public dollar spent on family planning services, $3 is saved in Medicaid spending on pregnancy and care for newborns.
Researchers say Ortho Evra and the Organon NuvaRing are nearly 100 percent effective in preventing pregnancies, a rate similar to that for birth control pills. But they may be more effective than oral contraceptives in one crucial way: women don't have to remember to take a pill every day, and forgetfulness is one reason that 7.5 percent of women who are on the pill become pregnant during their first year.
DOROTHY MANN, executive director of the Family Planning Council, which oversees 85 publicly financed clinics in the Philadelphia area, sees the patch and ring as good birth-control options, but she worries that she won't be able to afford them for her clinics.
Eighty-four percent of the clinics' 120,000 clients receive contraceptive services. This year, her budget for contraception is $1.32 million, or a little more than a dollar a month for each patient, before insurance and Medicaid reimbursements. If, as expected, the patch or the ring end up costing more than what she essentially allocates for each patient, she may have to severely ration the devices.
"You have to make horrible choices," she said. "It has always been our practice to provide all birth control methods to all women, regardless of income. But I don't think I can do that anymore."

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: WEST VILLAGE; 
Will the PATH Train Stop Here? Concerned Nonriders Hope Not

BYLINE:  By DENNY LEE 

 BODY:
It's nothing personal, New Jersey. It's just that residents of Greenwich Village are sensitive about preserving their hamlet.
 To ease crowding at the city's southernmost PATH stations, the Port Authority plans to add second entrances to the stops at Christopher Street and Ninth Street. Ever since the PATH station at the World Trade Center was destroyed on Sept. 11, ridership at those two stops has doubled, and there is sometimes a 15-minute wait just to get to the turnstiles. 
 Under the plan, two new staircases would open onto Christopher Street: one at the southeast corner of Bedford Street, where P.S. 3 is situated, and the other at the southeast corner of Waverly Place for the Ninth Street stop. To accommodate the new entrances, the street would be narrowed by four feet.
But Village residents say the plan will tarnish landmark streetscapes, create a traffic bottleneck, and invite twice as many loiterers and petty criminals. 
"You couldn't pick a worse place," said Scott Schindler, a graphic designer who lives on Bedford Street. "You've got a school there, a very narrow street, and it's just thick with cars." 
Preservationists are especially concerned about the Waverly entrance, which would fall inside the Stonewall Historic District, the only gay-related site in the nation named as a National Historic Landmark. 
"The stairs could have the impact of turning a historic side street into a major transit way," said Andrew Berman, executive director of the Greenwich Village Society for Historic Preservation.
Residents want the Port Authority to put the new entrances on two busier thoroughfares, Hudson Street and Avenue of the Americas. But authority officials say that their plan is more economical and less disruptive. "This is the simplest and most direct means of getting people in and out of the system," said William Fellini, manager of the PATH Capital Program. 
He also said community opposition must be balanced against safety concerns. With only one entrance at each station, Mr. Fellini said, it now takes more than 18 minutes to evacuate riders in an emergency. With a second entrance, the time would be shaved to seven minutes. 
No timetable for construction has been set, but for PATH riders, the new entrances could not come too soon. 
"The residents are being a little high-strung, and definitely selfish," said Ann Walsh, a bookkeeper from Jersey City, who was displaced from the World Trade Center station. "There's always this confrontation with people from Jersey." DENNY LEE

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH; 
Telecom May Have Bargains, After All

BYLINE:  By GRETCHEN MORGENSON

 BODY:
INVESTORS are famous for loving stocks when they should be leaving them and bailing out when they should be buying with both hands. Many top Wall Street analysts encourage such behavior by downgrading stocks just as they hit bottom.
 With that in mind, it seems a good time to survey the slag heap that is the telecom stock sector. Surely, some jewels lie buried there, cast off in recent months by dispirited investors. 
 The telecom train wreck, of course, has been one of the messiest ever for investors. Many companies were brought public by Wall Street in the late 1990's, and billions of dollars in capital was raised for them. Now, a good many of these start-ups have filed for bankruptcy. Telecommunications equipment shipments plummeted 26 percent last year. And telecom shares turned in the poorest performance of the top 10 industry sectors in the Standard & Poor's 500 in the first quarter of 2002. By one estimate, investors have lost $1.4 trillion since telecom stocks peaked in 2000.
Two years later, the sector contains some compelling values, according to some astute fund managers picking through the wreckage. 
Martin J. Whitman, manager of the Third Avenue Funds and a veteran value investor, says he is buying shares of telecom equipment manufacturers. Mr. Whitman is worth listening to: the underappreciated stocks he provided to this column last Sept. 23 have risen, on average, 31 percent.
He is careful to examine companies' balance sheets before he buys, and he limits his purchases to companies with cash positions that significantly exceed their total debt. An analyst at Third Avenue Funds, Ian Lapey, contends that while the industry is depressed now, demand for voice, data and video transmission will grow in coming years. So telecom equipment makers that can weather the storm today will be the beneficiaries tomorrow.
Mr. Whitman's picks may not rise immediately. Earnings in the sector are expected to be dismal this year and may never again reach the heights seen during the telecom bubble. 
Nevertheless, the companies he favors are not overpriced: they either trade below 10 times their peak earnings or at less than two times their book value. 
Given the speculative nature of these companies, Mr. Lapey and Mr. Whitman have bought a group of them. One or two of them may flame out, but there is some safety in numbers. 
The Third Avenue Funds basket of telecom stocks consists of ADC Telecommunications, Ciena, Comverse Technology, Corvis, JDS Uniphase, Sycamore Networks, Tellium and Tellabs. All but one of the stocks trade at less than $10 a share.
A final recommendation in the distressed telecom sector comes from Marlowe Burke, an analyst at JHC Capital, a value investing firm in Greenwich, Conn. Ms. Burke is a believer in Allegiance Telecom, a provider of telecom services to businesses. "Allegiance was not attractive to us when analysts were pushing it at around $100 a share," she said. "But at $2.25, the valuation is out of step with reality."
Fearing that the company will not achieve the revenue target it needs under the terms of its bank loans, investors have dumped Allegiance shares. But Ms. Burke thinks the company will hit the number. "We think there's great value in the company in terms of their growth in data services," she said, "and they are picking up assets from distressed companies very inexpensively, which will help them manage their costs effectively." 
Unlike the Internet highfliers that crashed, some telecom companies that are still standing have paying customers and real earnings potential. Because they can no longer raise fresh capital from investors, Wall Street has abandoned them. But shrewd investors need not follow suit.

CORRECTION-DATE: April 28, 2002

 CORRECTION:
The Market Watch column last Sunday, about possible bargains among telecommunications stocks, misstated the investment position of the Third Avenue Funds in a basket of eight issues that it found attractive. The company owns one of the stocks, Tellabs, not all of them; it is studying the others further for possible purchase.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: UPPER EAST SIDE; 
European Taste Lured to New York by American Money

BYLINE:  By ERIKA KINETZ 

 BODY:
Last month three Frenchmen -- two alumni of Christie's and a great-grandson of the painter Camille Pissarro -- set up an art gallery on East 70th Street. 
 "All of our clients live around the neighborhood," explained Franck Giraud, one of the three. "As simple as that." The gallery, Giraud Pissarro Segalot, is a one-room showroom on the second floor of a 19th-century townhouse, with furniture by Jean Prouve and Le Corbusier. 
 New York has long attracted European art dealers, and the reason is clear. "Americans have more money than anyone else," said Dominique Surh, director of a gallery on East 73rd Street that Salomon Lilian, an Amsterdam dealer, opened in October.
Now, however, the attraction is growing much stronger.
Last year for the first time, the United States captured a larger share of the $23.5 billion global art market than did Europe, according to David Kusin, an economist and the founder of Kusin & Company, a Dallas research firm. In a recent study for the European Fine Art Federation, Mr. Kusin found that European gallery and auction sales totaled $10.6 billion last year, while American sales hit $11 billion. From 1998 to 2001, Europe's share of the art market fell by more than 6 percent, while America's grew by nearly 7 percent.
These numbers may be global, but it is New York that is at their center. Mr. Kusin estimates that two-thirds to three-quarters of the American sales take place in New York.
There is widespread agreement that the appetites and pocketbooks of American collectors are the main forces drawing European dealers to New York. But Anthony Browne, chairman of the British Art Market Federation, says that regulatory issues also play a role. By setting up shop in New York, some European dealers can avoid penalties under certain European tax and property laws. 
The Upper East Side has been the beachhead for these new immigrants. 
"It's the place that gets the press," Mr. Kusin said. "People in Paris live on the Avenue Foch, and they assume that if they lived in New York they'd live on Fifth Avenue or Park Avenue."
If current trends persist, establishing a foothold in New York may become de rigueur for European art dealers.
"There is a realization in Europe that the axis of the art market has shifted to New York," said Michael Goedhuis, a British dealer. In January, Mr. Goedhuis shifted the headquarters of his contemporary Chinese art business to East 76th Street from London.
Another newcomer is Patrick Derom, a Belgian dealer who opened a gallery in Brussels in 1986 and merged with a gallery on East 79th Street in 1999.
"People would not give me important paintings unless they knew I had a permanent presence in a very important art city," he said.
But while the business of art thrives here, at least some dealers suggest that the hotbeds of artistic creativity lie elsewhere, such as Germany, Japan, Belgium, England and China.
In New York, "a lot of young artists decide to be artists, but they also think of the dollar behind the work," said Christophe Van de Weghe, a Belgian dealer who opened a gallery on the Upper East Side in 2000 and recently moved to Chelsea. "I think people are more able to focus on their creativeness in Berlin."
Mr. Goedhuis added: "Here artists are groping for a theme. In China, artists and writers and poets are grappling with deadly problems, problems of life and death of real concrete relevance to their spiritual lives." ERIKA KINETZ

HEADLINE: PRELUDES; 
Suddenly, 67 Looks a Lot Closer

BYLINE:  By ABBY ELLIN; Abby Ellin is a Manhattan writer. Her column on starting out in the world of money appears the third Sunday of each month. E-mail: preludes@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
I HAVE a confession: Until recently, I gave Social Security and its possible reform about 7.4 minutes of thought.
 I'm not proud to say that, but retirement just seems so distant. It's hard enough thinking about what I'll do next weekend, let alone when I'm 67, the estimated age when people born after 1960 can retire with full benefits. There are a million things to contemplate -- deadlines, children, marriage, houses -- before worrying about the golden years. 
 Is it psychologically sound, after all, to prepare for the last years of your life when you're still undecided about its current direction?
"I'm too busy to think about it," said Vanessa Lundborg, 31, a fashion designer and owner of Miracle on St. Marks, a clothing boutique in Manhattan's East Village. "Anyway, the propaganda is that by owning my own business I'll come out ahead. I have enough faith in myself."
Faith in yourself is one thing; faith in the system is quite another. Whether we will even have Social Security when we're older is a good -- and scary -- question.
It's especially important for women, who typically earn less than men and often take time off from work to raise their children, thus diminishing the Social Security money they can get back later in life. (Another consideration: The average life expectancy for men is around 74; it's 80 for women.)
Certainly, the numbers indicate that not all is rosy on the retirement front. When Social Security began in 1935, there were about 40 workers for every retiree. Today, the ratio is just three to one, and in 20 years it will be down to two.
A study by Laurence J. Kotlikoff, an economics professor at Boston University, and Willi Leibfritz, an economist in Munich, found that a 25-year-old worker can expect to pay $175,000 more in Social Security taxes over his lifetime than he can expect to receive in Social Security benefits. A 55-year-old, however, would pay only $4,000 more. 
Nearly every pollster north of Tijuana has conducted some kind of Social Security survey, and the results are contradictory and confusing. So are the "expert"analyses. 
A March poll, for instance, found that 71 percent of people 18 to 34 years old supported change in the current system. "Younger people are generally antigovernment, so it doesn't surprise me that they're in favor of reform," said Anna Greenberg, 33, vice president of Greenberg Quinlan Rosner Research in Washington, co-sponsor of the poll with National Public Radio. 
But the outlook becomes more puzzling when you consider a 1999 poll conducted by Peter D. Hart Research Associates in Washington, which found that 81 percent of people 18 to 34 supported Social Security in its current form. It also found that more people thought that "making sure that people receive a decent, guaranteed monthly retirement benefit" was a higher priority for Social Security than "making sure that people receive a better rate of return."
Jeff Mandell, 26, the director of the 2030 Center in Washington, a public policy organization for young adults, says a secure fund will benefit everyone, and in more ways than one. "Social Security guarantees young people that their parents and grandparents aren't going to knock on their door and say, 'Surprise! We're moving in!' " he said. "When you talk to young people about it that way, all of a sudden they think it's more important."
Contrary to popular rhetoric, he noted, there's still plenty of money left in the till. In an annual report to Congress last month, the trustees of the Social Security trust fund said the program in its current state would remain solvent until 2041, after which it could meet about three-quarters of its benefit obligations. "That's not nothing," Mr. Mandell said.
While that is somewhat encouraging, it still doesn't mean that my generation will get back what it paid into the system.
"The whole Social Security system is a sham," said Morris L. Reid, 31, a principal with the Dewey Square Group, a government affairs consulting firm in Washington. "We need to look at its performance from top to bottom, and I don't have a lot of confidence that it will be there when I'm ready for it, or that anyone in Washington has a credible plan."
Then there's the Third Millennium, an organization in New York that also represents Generation X. The group favors the ideas outlined by President Bush and his Commission to Strengthen Social Security, including the establishment of personal retirement accounts.
"The issue is whether you're in favor of maintaining the present system or carving out a small portion from the current FICA tax and allowing workers to invest that in a personal account," said Richard Thau, 37, the organization's president, who believes in partial privatization. "If you let every American worker ages 20 to 39 set aside 2 or 3 percent of their gross annual income for retirement investing, and let that money grow over the course of 40 or 50 years, by the time they reach 70 or 75 they will have nice size nest egg to complement Social Security."
That makes sense in theory, although it doesn't help the people who aren't well versed in the intricacies of the stock market. The rich will get richer, and the poor will suffer. 
AS for me, I basically view Social Security the way I view washboard abs: something to aspire to, but something that I'll most likely have to live without. Part of me hopes that a random benefactor will swoop down from the heavens and voluntarily sponsor my retirement, but I realize that this is unlikely. So I've set myself up with an Individual Retirement Account and other savings plans.
The real issue is what will become of those less fortunate, less educated and less prepared financially. And what of Franklin D. Roosevelt's words when he signed the Social Security Act, to "take care of human needs" and to "provide for the United States an economic structure of vastly greater soundness"? Will the changes proposed today support or undermine his vision?
I am finally starting to think about all that. And, frankly, I'm worried.

HEADLINE: STRATEGIES; 
Is It Free Fall, or Just a Blip?

BYLINE:  By MARK HULBERT; Mark Hulbert is editor of The Hulbert Financial Digest, a newsletter based in Annandale, Va. His column on investment strategies appears every other week. E-mail: strategy@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
IF the stock market's plunge last September had been an earthquake, it might have measured 2.1 in magnitude -- jarring, yes, but not nearly as severe as many previous tumbles.
 Market measurements of this kind are now possible because of recent research that applies the concepts of geophysics to investing. The study, titled "How Deep Was the September Stock Exchange Crisis?" and conducted by Bertrand Maillet, a lecturer in economics at the University of Paris (Sorbonne) and Thierry Michel of the Paris Bourse, is at papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers .cfm?abstract-id=300923. 
 To appreciate the utility of the new scale, which was intended to be analogous to the Richter scale once used to measure earthquakes, consider the question that investors faced as stocks plunged last September: Was this a once-in-a-lifetime market blowout, one from which it would take several years to recover? 
Seven months later, of course, we know that it was not. But how much of this could have been surmised at the time?
In September, those who tried to interpret history could do little more than review the market's reactions to previous crises. Because the stock market, on average, was higher six months after those crises, a similar outcome was predicted after Sept. 11, too.
That view has proved correct in the last several months, but it was largely a lucky guess. After other past plunges, such expectations have proved wrong: six months after the 1987 crash, for example, the market was still 25 percent lower than it was before the crash.
In short, there has been no way to differentiate relatively mild tumbles from genuinely severe ones like the one in 1987. Many people have long assumed that sharp market downturns were exceptional events that suspended the statistical relationships of relatively normal times.
The new study, however, relies on the idea that the biggest market downturns, though infrequent, are still subject to ordinary statistical analysis -- in other words, that they are not that exceptional. For years, researchers could not see this relationship because they tried to force the markets into the template of a bell curve-- known in statistics as a normal distribution. Because huge market downturns occurred more often than could be expected if markets followed the bell-curve pattern of events, many people concluded that big disruptions were entirely unpredictable.
Bell curves, of course, aren't the only statistical patterns. Some patterns account for a greater frequency of seemingly rare events. In the language of statistics, such a pattern has a "fat tail" -- a relatively large number of apparently unusual occurrences. Other recent research has found that the markets closely follow one particular fat-tail pattern, known as a lognormal distribution. This new insight shows that sharp downturns are not exceptions to the historical rule, but rather extreme instances of what occurs all the time.
This seemingly subtle change in perspective has enabled Mr. Maillet and Mr. Michel to construct their magnitude scale. To be sure, there is no perfect financial analog to the physical movement measured in earthquakes, but the researchers think they come close by focusing on a comprehensive measure of volatility. Rather than zeroing in on volatility over just one time horizon -- daily, for example -- they constructed their measure to encompass many different periods, from a few minutes to several months.
It is on this scale that Mr. Maillet and Mr. Michel measured last September's drop as a 2.1, merely the ninth worst since 1896. On their logarithmic scale, that decline was 400 more times likely to occur than the 1987 crash, which earned the highest rating, 4.7 -- higher than even the 1929 crash, at 4.0.
More research is needed, of course, but the results are promising so far. The new measure does a decent job of forecasting volatility after a plunge -- the market is more volatile after higher readings than it is after lower ones.
To be sure, the new scale's daunting mathematics mean that most people will have to rely on others to calculate it, and it may take some time for it to become widely used. But I know of at least one research group in Zurich that has already started to do so. Will Wall Street take up the challenge?

HEADLINE: The World: Oil Crises; 
Which One Is Worse?

BYLINE:  By MATTHEW L. WALD 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
THE old oil crisis: You drive the family car, a Ford Country Squire station wagon, to the new Exxon station (changed from Esso in 1973). But you've got an odd-numbered license plate and it's an even-numbered day. You can always drive less, but that means staying home, and heating oil is going to get expensive this winter, the experts say.
 The next oil crisis: You go down to the Texaco station, which still has gas, partly because Texaco's eastern states marketing operations are 50 percent owned by Saudi Arabia. But the price has doubled and your S.U.V. takes 20 gallons to fill. And you begin to regret retiring the '86 Camry, which got roughly 28 miles per gallon, in favor of the '2001 Taurus, which gets 22 miles. 
 But at least your house is heated with natural gas, not oil. Your supply is locked in at a constant cost, thanks to weather-based hedging strategies of companies like Enron. In energy crises of the 1970's, natural gas was a regulated industry and costs were kept low but supplies sometimes ran short; now it is available, at a price. Taking inflation into account, the cost of natural gas is double what it was in 1973. Similarly, gasoline price controls are over -- meaning fuel is available, but the price is variable.
Which is worse, the energy crises of 1973-74 and 1979-80, or the one that could be triggered by civil unrest in Saudi Arabia or any other crisis among exporters?
This is worth asking, as tensions rise in the Middle East, and Americans have to pay attention to political developments in places many of them can't even pronounce, the nation has a new complication: A big South American exporter has a coup and a counter-coup in a single week-end.
America has worried for years about a new oil crisis. During the Arab oil embargo, Richard M. Nixon promised energy independence. Six years later, when the shah fell and prices skyrocketed, Jimmy Carter promised a ceiling on imports. George Bush had a plan to wean cars from gasoline, and run them on natural gas, ethanol, electricity and other alternatives. All came to naught.
There are some improvements. Energy consumption per dollar of gross domestic product is down to 10,400 B.T.U.'s, from 18,400 B.T.U.'s. Even if consumers don't know what a B.T.U. is, this is good news. Better yet, B.T.U.'s of oil and gas per dollar are down by more than half, because the share of energy from coal and nuclear is up.
But demand is up, especially for oil. The number of miles driven per vehicle is up about 20 percent since 1973, and the number of vehicles is way up, by more than 50 percent since 1970. Miles per gallon was 11.9 in 1973, when the Arab oil embargo began; it was at 16.9 in the early 90's and is still there.
By 2000, America was were supposed to have millions of cars running on natural gas, ethanol, methanol and who knows what else. But the share of all transportation energy that came from alternate fuels in 2001 was less than 3 percent, down from 4.2 percent in 1973. To be fair, the total amount of other fuels rose over the period. But gasoline and diesel use rose faster. 
And the American oil patch has been bled nearly dry. Oil imports, 34 percent in the oil embargo, are now 54 percent. Persian Gulf imports, less than 5 percent of American consumption in 1973, are now 14 percent.
With more cars to drive -- about 220 million -- Americans are driving more and more. Total vehicle miles traveled was about 1 trillion in 1970, but was nearly 2.7 trillion last year.
Suggest a car pool in the station wagon and half the people you talk to will say, "What's a station wagon?" The other half will say, "What's a car pool?"

HEADLINE: DataBank; 
Wall Street Breaks a Long Losing Streak

BYLINE:  By SHERRI DAY

 BODY:
Although a handful of large companies reported weak first-quarter earnings last week, the major indexes rose for the first time in five weeks on the strength of results that generally beat Wall Street's expectations. 
 The big decliners included I.B.M., Pfizer and airlines like Delta. 
 But General Motors and American Express rose sharply after both companies reported earnings that exceeded Wall Street's estimates.
 Technology stocks were responsible for much of the market's gains. Novellus and Texas Instruments touched off a broad rally on Tuesday after they forecast improving sales. Better-than-expected earnings from Sprint lifted the telecommunications sector.
 Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, gave an upbeat assessment of the American economy and said the Fed would not raise interest rates until it was sure the economy was stable. 
 For the week, the technology-weighted Nasdaq composite index rose 40.64 points, or 2.3 percent, to 1,796.83. The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 66.29 points, or 0.7 percent, to 10,257.11, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 14.16 points, or 1.3 percent, to 1,125.17.
 SHERRI DAY

HEADLINE: INVESTING: DIARY; 
MarketsOvervalued, Survey Says

BYLINE:  Compiled by Jeff Sommer

 BODY:
Fund managers around the world say stock markets are overvalued, but the managers have not increased the proportion of cash in their portfolios, according to a monthly survey by Merrill Lynch. 
 The survey, involving 305 managers, was conducted during the first two weeks of April. 
 They believed that markets were trading 2 percent above "fair value" but were priced fairly a month earlier, the survey said. Sixty-two percent said companies in the United States were the most overvalued.

HEADLINE: PERSONAL BUSINESS: DIARY; 
Wyoming's Tax Bite Is Mildest

BYLINE:  By Vivian Marino

 BODY:
Residents of Wyoming are undoubtedly drawn to the state's abundance of national parks and wide-open terrain, but there's another benefit to living there: tax relief.
 In 2001, for the fifth consecutive year, Wyoming was found to be the most tax-friendly state for families and retirees, according to survey results released last week by Bloomberg Personal Finance magazine. 
The survey ranked the 50 states and the District of Columbia based on taxes on income, sales, real estate and other assets for four hypothetical families. 
 After Wyoming, the other states earning high marks for "wealth friendliness" for families were Tennessee, Nevada, Alaska and Washington. For retirees, Delaware, Hawaii, Louisiana, and Colorado were in the top five.
The least friendly tax states for families were Maine, Wisconsin, New York, Rhode Island and Montana. The least friendly for retirees were Vermont, Nebraska, Montana, Wisconsin and Rhode Island. Vivian Marino

HEADLINE: Mothers Without Doubts 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
My family story may be different from Nichole Christian's, but I hear the same words from aunts and friends. My parents fled their native land, Ukraine, in World War II, lived on the Lower East Side and saved every penny to move to New Haven. 
 The minute I finished grad school, I was in a car on my way to New York to take a job, find an apartment, make friends and fall in love. My husband and I have a beautiful 14-month-old daughter, whom we are raising in a safe, supportive community on the Upper West Side. 
 I cannot imagine doing it any other way, certainly not in the suburbs. I meet other mothers for coffee and trips to the swings, and my daughter and I take the most wonderful class. 
We will never move from here, despite terrorism, the economy and the price of a "classic six" apartment.

NATALIE SILVERSTEIN
Upper West Side

HEADLINE: BackTalk; 
N.F.L.'s Newest Owner Seeks the Middle Ground

BYLINE:  By THOMAS GEORGE 

 BODY:
The face of ownership in the National Football League has been changing at a persistent and sweeping pace. The league's new owners are schooled in a new economics and in a new image; simply blending into the background is seldom a chosen path.
 The new owners prefer the sideline action to sitting in luxury boxes. New owners have a wider range of businesses than many of their peers. New owners get involved more with the coaching and the acquisition of personnel. New owners care less about sharing revenue than about their own team's financial growth. New owners want more control of their local marketing. New owners are less interested in building strong camaraderie with their peers. 
 New owners want to win -- and win now.
The pace of change among the 32 owners is startling.
Eighteen have joined the league since 1984. Fourteen have joined since 1991. Eleven have joined in the last eight years. Five have joined in the last three years. More change is scheduled: Steve Bisciotti has an option to buy the Baltimore Ravens from Art Modell in 2004.
The current group -- from the familiar presence of the Giants' Wellington Mara to the swashbuckling style of Dallas's Jerry Jones to the mild manner of the Jets' Robert Wood Johnson IV to the frenetic presence of Washington's Dan Snyder -- is more disjointed than it is a unit.
"We used to gather at our league meetings and the number of teams was small and manageable enough that everybody knew everybody and their families and it was much more cordial and family-like," said Ralph Wilson, the Buffalo Bills' owner for the past 43 years. "Now we just have meetings. And more meetings. There isn't much camaraderie. The relationships aren't as personal. There is a lot more 'me, me, me.' It's the times."
It's the league. But it has worked as the N.F.L. continues to prosper.
Now comes an owner who appears to be a cross between new and old ownership, a consensus builder, a man who has brought pro football back to Houston and says he has a plan to win with grace and style, to make money and still make friends.
That man is Bob McNair. His Houston Texans will complete their first collegiate draft today and will play their first exhibition game Aug. 5, against the Giants in the Hall of Fame Game in Canton, Ohio. Soon after is their opener Sept. 8 against -- who else? -- Dallas in Houston's new Reliant Stadium, which features the league's first retractable dome.
Using part of the wealth he gained primarily in the electric power industry, McNair, 65, bought the team for $700 million, a record for an expansion team.
Bud Adams, the Tennessee owner, is his Houston neighbor. In 1992 Adams asked McNair to get involved with the N.F.L. by purchasing the Miami Dolphins. (McNair chuckles now when recalling that he considered the asking price, $142 million, far too much.) Soon after that, N.F.L. Commissioner Paul Tagliabue asked McNair to get involved with a fledgling expansion group's bid to put a team in St. Louis. McNair waited. The league has had its eyes on McNair for a while. His heart, however, was set on Houston.
He was awarded his franchise on Oct. 6, 1999.
"The world doesn't come to an end if you don't have an N.F.L. team, but I do think that sports are a vibrant part of a community," McNair said. "I'm doing it for Houston. If we manage this properly, this can be a tool to bring people together. We have a very diverse community, and this opportunity crosses all lines and ages with a sports team that people have an affinity for.
"You win with the organization. It has to be the stable element, because players come and go. You have to have a clear vision and a plan of action. We want to do everything in our power to strengthen our relationship with our fans. I want this to be the most valuable and highly respected franchise in the world. My goal is to provide our people with the resources to get that done."
And find middle ground.
Step on the sidelines -- "I'm part of the team like everyone else," he said -- but not control them. Give his players support but insist that they exhibit strong character. "In the 60's it was, 'I'm O.K., you're O.K.,' and you felt like what people did on their own was their business," he said. "We're finding that's not the case. The player's private life is his private life, but all of them are very public people. I won't embarrass them. They won't embarrass the Texans, or somebody's leaving."
He supports the idea of teams' controlling more of their local marketing but said, "Maybe we will find that the league does a better job; we can always go back to that."
And check out his blunt view on the Texans' making money.
"If you don't make money you're only a partial success," he said. "Making money is a measure of efficiency. If you're not making money, you're not doing a good job -- even if you're winning Super Bowls."
He said his team should be competitive with the other 31 teams in three years, yet he is counting on some surprises.
His persona appears to be patient yet demanding. In the harsh, competitive climate he enters, can it last?
"The unique thing about sports is it builds camaraderie," McNair said. "Some of my old-time, best friends are guys I played ball with. You don't have that kind of camaraderie in regular business. And I love being around young people."
Here is a switch among N.F.L. owners: They genuinely like being around him.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Bob McNair spent $700 million for the Houston franchise in 1999, a record amount for an expansion team. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: As the Drivers of the 18-Wheelers See It, the Economy Is on the Road to Recovery 

BYLINE:  By PETER T. KILBORN 

DATELINE: OKLAHOMA CITY, April 18 

 BODY:
Judging from the number of 18-wheelers rumbling in and out of the Flying J truck stop here on Interstate 40, the economy has left the recession in the dust. For a couple of weeks, a "Now Hiring" banner has been fluttering out front; business is up and the place needs two more cashiers and a midlevel manager.
 Drivers still balk at buying trinkets and gifts in the Flying J's store, and waitresses say drivers are still watching their tips. But they are buying more fuel, and few sit around anymore waiting for loads to fill their empty trailers. 
 "I don't have as much downtime," said Ron Jones, 40, stopping on his way to Lawton, Okla., for a shipment of Goodyear tires to haul to DeKalb, Ill. Danny Hamby, the stop's general manager, said, "I don't think we're in a rut anymore."
Economists and Wall Street analysts mix and mold all kinds of statistics -- on employment, inventories, industrial production, lending and borrowing, consumer and capital spending, imports and exports, profits and losses -- to assess the economy's pulse. A year after they declared the start of the recession, some have lately been drawing the economy's course in the shape of a "W," showing it slipping again after falling and bouncing a bit. Optimists see it scaling the valley of a "V." Pessimists are drawing an "L."
But truck drivers, who can offer what is perhaps a more tangible assessment of the economy, say they believe growth, at least in terms of the goods they carry, has begun inching up the eastern slope of a "U." 
"Around Christmas, I'd be ready to go, and they wouldn't have a load for me," Mr. Jones said, digging into a Flying J breakfast burrito as big as his foot. He was on his way to pick up a load of Goodyear tires, having just brought a shipment of automotive oil from Mississippi to Oklahoma City. "I could be sitting for six or seven days, and they wouldn't have a load for me. I don't sit much at all now." 
There is good reason to trust in the accuracy of the 18-wheel economy. "We haul the raw materials that products are made of," explained Don Weaver, 60, who was in the middle of a trip carrying cedar mulch from Paris, Tex., to Wichita. "We haul the product after it's finished."
According to the American Trucking Association, truck drivers carry 67 percent of the nation's domestic freight as measured by weight and 87 percent as measured by value. In weight, truck freight reached a peak in December 1999, the trucking association's chief economist, Bob Costello, said. It plunged 17 percent by July 2000, presaging the recession, and the events of Sept. 11 kept it down through last year. But by February, Mr. Costello said, traffic had climbed about 5 percent from the trough. 
That has also been the experience of David McCorkle, the association's chairman and owner of a truck company that runs 85 tractor-trailers. Mr. McCorkle said his trucks, which haul cement, gypsum, lime and sand for builders, factories and oil companies, were busy again after the post-Sept. 11 slowdown. For the industry, he said, "the prospects seem to be pretty good." 
Jim Baertschi, 54, detects all the signs of an incipient boom. He owns a Peterbilt truck, layered with polished chrome, and leases his services to the Allied Automotive Group, a car-hauling company. On this trip, he was taking four Chevrolet truck cabs and chassis to New Mexico. 
"I haul from the General Motors plant in Janesville, Wis.," Mr. Baertschi said, adding that he was one of 160 owner-operators normally leased to Allied. "For the last two years, we had 50 laid off. They've all been called back. In fact, they want to hire more."
A few Flying J customers have yet to feel much recovery. Gene Griffey, for example, went deep into debt to acquire eight trucks over the last decade. He hired drivers and started running the trucks from his home in Asheville, N.C. 
But Mr. Griffey, 52, is using just one truck now, and he is driving it himself. He lost a major customer, a window manufacturer in Texas that went bankrupt. Customers in the North Carolina furniture industry, crippled by the recession, shut down. 
"I'm working out of my yard now," he said. "I've sold five trucks. I still have three, and they're for sale. I laid the last driver off in January." 
Another owner-operator, Earl Gillespie, 50, said the investments in capital goods that he sees as a sign of recovery -- loads of assembly-line machinery, factory air-conditioning systems, I-beams -- had yet to appear. His loads have fallen 30 percent in less than a year. 
Steven Toth, 45, who forms a driving team with his wife, Debra, 48, has seen better times, too. As drivers for the U.S. Xpress Enterprises truck line, the Toths were carrying Compaq computers from Carson, Calif., to Indianapolis. 
They are getting some decent loads, allowing them together to earn $110,000 a year. But they are not back to normal. "In the late 90's we would normally run between 5,300 and 6,300 miles a week," Mr. Toth said. "Now it's a struggle to make 5,000."
Many drivers at the Flying J wondered about the fate of just-in-time delivery, the innovation that helped sustain the trucking boom in the 1990's. Rather than pack warehouses with goods that would be used in weeks or months, factories and store chains turned to trucks to deliver the goods when they needed them. 
The ability to provide this sort of service stalled after Sept. 11. Many companies had to halt production because the airplanes and ships that brought foreign components and materials ground to a halt. It was not long before the slowed-down trucking business slowed even further. 
But some drivers, like Ronald Doan of El Paso, are beginning to feel the just-in-time heat again. "I've got a load of plastic drinking cups I'm taking from Shreveport, La., and making three stops, the last one in Chino, Calif.," said Mr. Doan, 61. Each stop had to hit a warehouse early enough in the morning so that local distributors could then transfer the cups to restaurants in the area.
The deliveries are "nerve-racking," Mr. Doan said. But they also mean "we're getting busy."

GRAPHIC: Photos: The drivers who eat at the Flying J truck stop in Oklahoma City are generally upbeat about the economy these days. Jim Baertschi, above, who hauls vehicles, says his business has been improving lately. Ron Jones, on his way to pick up a load of tires, said, "I don't have as much downtime." (Photographs by Jerry Laizure for The New York Times) Map of Oklahoma highlighting Oklahoma City: Truckers passing through Oklahoma City are sounding hopeful.

HEADLINE: Police in Belarus Detain 40 As a Protest Ends Violently 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, April 20 

 BODY:
At least 40 demonstrators remained in a Minsk jail today, after truncheon-wielding police officers in Belarus on Friday violently broke up a downtown march protesting living conditions and inadequate salaries.
 At least 15 other protesters, most of them under age, were released overnight, said Andrei Sannikov, the leader of a Belarus human rights organization, Charter 97. Several protesters were reported hospitalized with injuries. 
 The Belarussian police said today that they had arrested about 85 protesters and released nearly 50.
Mr. Sannikov said the police action against what had been a peaceful march was meant to intimidate potential participants in what is usually Belarus's largest anti-government demonstration, an annual march marking the anniversary of the Chernobyl nuclear disaster.
That protest is to be held next Friday. The 1986 explosion at the Chernobyl reactor, just across the Ukrainian border, left a fifth of Belarus contaminated by fallout.
The demonstrators' target is the government of President Aleksandr Lukashenko, Belarus's leader since 1994. His Communist-style government controls most aspects of Belarus's laggard economy and permits only limited political opposition.
Friday's demonstration was staged on Minsk's main avenue by several hundred protesters, some carrying the banned red-and-white flag that Belarus used in its first years after declaring independence from the Soviet Union.
The protesters marched under a banner that declared, "We can't live like this anymore." But some also carried signs accusing the government of providing illegal military assistance to Iraq, an allegation raised by American officials who visited Minsk in February.
Mr. Sannikov said the protest had been peaceful until several buses carrying black-helmeted riot police officers pulled alongside the marchers, and the police formed a line in front of them. "When the marchers met the first line of the special police force, they turned around and went back," Mr. Sannikov said, "and then they were beaten."
News agency reports said the protesters were hit with truncheons as they sat in the street and on sidewalks, then herded to jail.
The Charter 97 Web site, www.charter97.org, stated that six protesters were hospitalized with head injuries. News reports said one was in serious condition.
Among those arrested were a prominent Belarussian filmmaker, Yuri Khaschevatsky. One of the organizers of the march, a 60-year-old journalist named Valery Shchukin, was beaten unconscious, according to the Charter 97 Web site. 
The police said that Mr. Shchukin suffered injuries to his lower back and pelvis.
Mr. Lukashenko has long been ostracized by most Western governments because of his government's human rights record. Two of Mr. Lukashenko's leading political opponents have vanished in recent years, and a former member of Belarus's special services charged late last year that one had been executed and buried near a government base.
Belarus has met the criticism with growing irritation. On Monday, the government threw out the leader of the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe, a principal human rights monitor, and refused a diplomatic visa to his successor.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The police in Minsk, Belarus, subdued a protester on Friday as they stopped a peaceful demonstration. At least 40 people were jailed. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: Many Made the Move From the Industry to the Administration 

BYLINE:  By DON VAN NATTA Jr. with NEELA BANERJEE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 20 

 BODY:
Crucial White House positions and the upper ranks of several agencies, including the Interior Department and the Environmental Protection Agency, are held by appointees who, for years, worked in the energy industry, lobbied for it or defended its interests in the nation's courts.
 The better known are the most visible: Secretary of Commerce Donald L. Evans, for example, who for 25 years worked for Tom Brown Inc., a Denver oil and gas company, and Andrew H. Card Jr., the White House chief of staff, who as president of the American Automobile Manufacturers Association lobbied against improving fuel efficiency and emission standards. Interior Secretary Gale A. Norton received $285,630 from the energy and natural resources industries when she ran for the Senate in Colorado in 1996. 
 Energy industry alumni and supporters also hold less visible jobs in the administration and agencies that allow them to make far-reaching policy and regulatory changes. 
Philip Cooney is the chief of staff for the Council on Environmental Quality, a White House advisory group that develops policies on environmental and economic issues. The council has played a crucial role in forming a White House policy that played down the effect of carbon dioxide emissions on global warming. Earlier, Mr. Cooney was a lawyer for the American Petroleum Institute, the main lobbying arm of the oil industry, and was a prominent critic of global warming theories.
James E. Cason holds a new high-level position in the Interior Department, associate deputy secretary. He was an assistant interior secretary under James A. Watt in the Reagan era and, critics say, tried to stop limits on drilling for oil and gas in national forests. The Interior Department denied that, underscoring instead Mr. Cason's recent tenure at a company that specializes in manufacturing energy-saving insulation.
As deputy secretary of the interior, the second in command at the department, J. Steven Griles oversees more than 500 million acres of federally protected land. Mr. Griles was the assistant secretary at the department from 1984 to 1989. He left the government to work for the mining industry, most recently with National Environmental Strategies, a Washington firm that represents the National Mining Association and utilities that use a lot of coal.
In March 2001, the spokesman for the National Mining Association at the time, John Grasser, called Mr. Griles "an ally to the industry."
Mark Pfeifle, an Interior Department spokesman, noted that Mr. Griles worked with Democrats in the 1980's to close loopholes that allowed the coal industry to pollute heavily. He also said Mr. Griles's firm represented Caithness Energy, which specializes in renewable energy.
The number of people in the Interior Department who once worked in the energy industry is only a small slice of a much larger picture, said Mr. Pfeifle, who added that other officials had experience on the state level working "with local citizens to find compromise and consensus."
He added, "The real hands on deck are ready to implement what the secretary calls the four C's: communication, cooperation, consultation -- all in the service of conservation."
John. D. Graham is the administrator of the Office of Information and Regulatory Affairs at the Office of Management and Budget, a powerful department that advises the president on regulatory change, particularly on environmental and public health issues. Mr. Graham is the founding director of the Harvard Center for Risk Analysis, a nonprofit organization financed by some of the country's largest energy and chemical companies, including ExxonMobil and Dow Chemical. The center's benefactors include the nation's biggest producers of dioxins, a substance widely thought to be carcinogenic, environmental groups said.
Senior White House officials argued that the backgrounds of some of the top staff members matter much less than the policies they develop. 
"Look at the agenda, and look at the result of the policy," said Scott McClellan, deputy White House press secretary. "Any independent look at the president's agenda underscores his commitment to achieving results for the American people."

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times; 
Justice Byron White: A Friend and a Mentor

BYLINE:  By IRA BERKOW 

 BODY:
Nick Lowery was having a tough time of it. He had been a fine place-kicker in college, at Dartmouth, and expected a career booting balls in the National Football League. 
 Not so quick. Lowery was cut 11 times from eight N.F.L. teams before catching on with the Kansas City Chiefs in 1980. He beat out, of all people, Jan Stenerud, who to this day is the only place-kicker in the Pro Football Hall of Fame. 
 And things hardly got better for Lowery in his first training camp with the Chiefs. He was the butt of numerous pranks; he was not only a rookie but a rookie from the Ivy League, which carried with it a special kind of contempt in that bruising environment. One evening in training camp, for example, he found fresh cow manure in his bed.
He tried to talk to his new teammates, to be one of the guys, but he encountered resistance. Shortly after that, he went home to McLean, Va., and sought out his next-door neighbor on Hampshire Road, who had become a friend and mentor.
The neighbor was Justice Byron R. White of the United States Supreme Court. White had also been a football player, a 6-foot-1, 195-pound all-purpose all-American back at Colorado. He picked up the nickname Whizzer while leading the nation in rushing, in scoring and in total offense. He was also a star basketball player, and led Colorado to a National Invitation Tournament final at Madison Square Garden. And he was a standout baseball player and the valedictorian of his graduating class.
He went to Yale Law School and to Oxford as a Rhodes scholar. In between he played football for one season with the Pittsburgh Pirates (later the Steelers), in 1938, and two seasons with the Detroit Lions, in 1939 and 1940. He led the N.F.L. in rushing in 1938 and 1940. Then he joined the Navy and went off to fight in World War II.
So not only did Justice White know something of the athletic world, he knew something of the world.
"Nick," Lowery said White told him, his strong bearing carrying a sense of gentle strength, "the only way you are going to get respect from those fellows is not by anything you say, but what you can deliver, how you perform on the field."
 It was a simple piece of advice, but when you are foundering, when emotions cloud your perspective, it is such advice, and coming from someone like Justice White, that will make an impact. It did make one on Nick Lowery.
That and other thoughts about Justice White came back to Lowery upon learning of the death Monday of his neighbor of 40 years. White, who served 31 years on the Supreme Court, was 84.
Lowery recalled the first full year he spent with Kansas City. He had a string of 11 field goals in 12 attempts, then kicked a game-winning field goal against the Lions. The guys who had been most vicious in riding him hugged him with tears in their eyes, he recalled.
"It was exactly what Justice White had been talking about," Lowery said.
Lowery said Justice White was reluctant to talk about his athletic career -- "He would always change the subject" -- and was perhaps happiest discussing history and people like Abraham Lincoln and Chief Justice John Marshall.
"I was curious to see what kind of football player he was," Lowery said, "and I was able to get a film of a game he played against Utah, my father's alma mater. It was amazing. There was this one kickoff return in which he almost ran backward in the end zone, then cut straight upfield -- he cut like a knife -- and broke about three tackles and completely faked out four or five other players and raced in for a touchdown. He was so fast, it looked like the other players were moving in slow motion."
He remembers Justice White talking about Bill Bradley a few years after Bradley became a senator. He said he admired Bradley because it was important to have balance in life, and not enough athletes do. Bradley had achieved balance as a student and an athlete, and he taught English in a Harlem school before getting involved in public service in government.
Lowery, now 45 and retired from football since 1997 after a superb 17-year career that included seasons with the Jets and the Patriots, has taken that advice from White to heart, too. He is a research fellow at the Harvard Project on American Indian Economic Development, and the first professional athlete to graduate from the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard.
On occasion, Lowery saw glimpses of the competitiveness that made White such a great athlete. About 1977 Lowery was playing basketball in the driveway with his two brothers -- all of the Lowerys are over 6 feet -- and White's daughter, Nancy, who was a field hockey star at Stanford.
"Justice White came by and we asked him to play," Lowery said. "He said O.K. He took off his tie and rolled up the sleeves of his white shirt and played in his black dress shoes. He was about 60 years old. We played for over an hour, the justice and me against the three of them. He was tough, and we killed 'em. But we all had fun. The next morning I saw Justice White go to his car on crutches.
"I went over to him. What happened? He said, 'Oh, I hurt my feet a little bit, but I'll be all right.' And he was. A few days later I saw him out in his yard mowing his lawn in his shorts."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Supreme Court Justice Byron R. White, who died Monday, was a neighbor of the former N.F.L. place-kicker Nick Lowery. (Associated Press; Steve Berman/The New York Times right )

HEADLINE: PRO BASKETBALL: INSIDE THE N.B.A.; 
Stunned by Their Swoon, Bucks Look Inward

BYLINE:  By MIKE WISE 

 BODY:
George Karl blamed himself for one of the worst collapses in N.B.A. history. Anthony Mason grumbled for many months about not getting the ball inside, but even Mason, the team's prized off-season acquisition, acknowledged last week: "Maybe it's me. I'm the new guy and I haven't fit in." 
 Ernie Grunfeld, the general manager, preached calm amid the storm swirling around the moribund and lottery-bound Milwaukee Bucks. 
 "We're going to look for ways to improve, but probably right now is not the best time to evaluate where we are," Grunfeld said in a telephone interview on Friday, two days after the Bucks failed to qualify for the playoffs. 
One Eastern Conference official, speaking on the condition of anonymity, said last week that he would not be surprised if the Bucks and the Knicks began talking about a trade in the next few weeks. Any deal would probably not be completed until after the draft in June, especially if the Knicks meet some of their big-man needs in the lottery.
Grunfeld shot down the notion that any of Milwaukee's key players -- Ray Allen, Glenn Robinson and Sam Cassell -- would be a part of a deal involving the Knicks.
"Nobody is on the block," Grunfeld said. "Would it be conceivable that we would speak? Yes, of course. But that would be irresponsible to throw names out there right now."
If anything ever did come of a conversation between the clubs, the Bucks would most likely be more interested in Latrell Sprewell, who is from Milwaukee, and Marcus Camby, whom Grunfeld has always liked, instead of Allan Houston. In return, the Knicks would want Allen.
Whether or not a deal is struck, two teams with two of the top five payrolls in pro basketball -- teams that were supposed to make the playoffs -- will soon shake up their rosters.
The Bucks' free fall the last two months of the season was more devastating than the dismal 30-52 season by the Knicks, if for no other reason than Milwaukee was among the favorites to win the Eastern Conference. Only two months ago, the Bucks were on top of the Central Division. They then lost 17 of 23 games, including their last 12 on the road.
On the last night of the regular season, in a game they needed to win to get in, the Bucks were routed by Detroit, 123-89.
"I think it falls on me for changing the formula and trying to get it fitted," Karl said last week.
With $14 million coming to him the next two years through a contract extension, Karl is staying put.
As for Allen, Cassell and Robinson, they have a much greater chance of moving to another team, though Grunfeld does not seem publicly committed to shaking up the roster.
"We had a lot of injuries in the second half of the season to four of our top five guys," he said. "We lost six overtime games after Jan. 1, and that affected our confidence. There were a lot of reasons. We had high expectations, but the bottom line is, we didn't get it done."
Like Sprewell, Camby and Houston, the Bucks stars' hopes of meshing, staying healthy and playing for a title faded in two short months.
The Bucks seemed such a sure-fire bet to make a run, Allen was included in a television playoff promotion. In a recent commercial, he is shown with the Lawrence O'Brien championship trophy, with other All-Stars on playoff-bound teams.
Allen probably never figured that was as close to the playoffs as he would come this season.

Speculation Over Brown
When the Philadelphia 76ers visited Denver in late December, Larry Brown casually said how much he enjoyed his time in Denver and how nice it would be to finish his career there.
The way Brown has moved around in his coaching career, the rumor mill began to churn. Last week it went into overdrive. Two general managers said they had heard that Brown was headed to Denver, where he would be joined by Bob Hill, his former Kansas assistant, who is now the Fordham coach. Brown would coach under the eye of his former student at U.C.L.A., Nuggets General Manager Kiki Vandeweghe. 
The general managers also said they had heard that Kentucky Coach Tubby Smith would succeed Brown as the 76ers' coach. 
Out of left field, right? 
"Larry Brown is our coach," Billy King, the 76ers' general manager, said Friday from Philadelphia. "I don't want to get into speculation. He hasn't given me any indication he's leaving."
A Nuggets official said there had not been one substantive conversation between the team and Brown regarding a move to Denver, where the interim coach, Mike Evans, is without a contract.
Brown has reiterated several times that if he is healthy, he will continue coaching. And that if he coaches anywhere in the N.B.A. next season, it will be in Philadelphia.
"I've been with Larry for nine years and I always hear the same rumors coming up," King said. "I guess if you keep writing it, after a while people will think it's true."
The speculation keeps arising because Brown is the Kevin Bacon of the N.B.A, within six degrees of any job because of his extensive travels. On paper, the Nuggets look like his typical rebuilding project: a young team looking for leadership and direction from an old-school teacher. Throw in that Brown looks perpetually worn down by Allen Iverson's inability to grasp his role as an off-the-floor leader, and it begins to make sense. Smith's leaving Kentucky is not even that preposterous, even with a recent contract extension.
But Hill, the former N.B.A. coach, has seven years left on his contract with Fordham.
"That's been out there for a while," Hill said Friday. "It resurfaced a couple of days ago. I haven't talked to any N.B.A. teams. There's nothing to it. Makes for a good rumor, though."

Webber Wanted to Be a Knick
From the Now-It-Can-Be-Told File: Chris Webber is happy with the way things worked out. But last June he wanted to play in New York. Allan Houston's $100 million deal all but secured his staying in Sacramento, Webber said recently.
Webber said his desire to go to the Knicks was not just because he wanted to play with Latrell Sprewell again. He said the uncertainty in the Kings' organization at the time (Sacramento had just traded Webber's friend and teammate Jason Williams for Mike Bibby), coupled with watching the draft in New York, swayed him.
"Draft night was the weirdest night," he said. "I saw us get Gerald Wallace, and I didn't know who Gerald was. I called Jason and he said: 'Oh, he can play. I'll call you right back.' He called me right back and said, 'I've been traded.' I'm like, 'What?' 
"So at this point, I'm in New York, guys at the draft are chanting my name, holding up signs. We're in the room, me and my friends, just laughing. New York sent me a miniature Madison Square Garden replica, where you take the lid off and see everything inside. My father went crazy. I really thought I had a chance.
"I loved the way New York embraced Spree after everything. Then I thought, there's not many real power forwards in the East. I could play center and let Camby play the power forward. I was very serious. At that time, that's what I wanted.
"But when they signed Allan, it kind of numbed me. I knew there was no way."
Houston's contract meant there was no way the Knicks would dangle Houston in front of Sacramento as part of a deal for Webber. The Knicks would also have had to give up Camby and perhaps another player. And the biggest part of the package, Houston, would have had to agree to play in Sacramento -- a long shot.
Still, Webber had already worked out a handshake agreement with Rob Pelinka, his former Michigan teammate and an agent for SFX. Pelinka, he said, would have advised him in the event of a trade from Sacramento.
"In no way am I trying to point the finger at Allan, because I saw him the other day and I felt kind of funny," Webber said. "It was just economics."
As it is, Webber gets to play with Peja Stojakovic, the All-Star swingman, on a team that won 61 games. 
"Allan is a great player," Webber added. "I wanted to play with both of them. That would have been like having two Pejas out there. But if I was Sacramento, I wouldn't sign and trade me to New York. I just looked at the common sense of it. Looking back, I'm glad things worked out the way they did."
