HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; 
New chairman of trade group calls for improving the value of the product that agencies sell.

BYLINE:  By Stuart Elliott 

DATELINE: DANA POINT, Calif. 

 BODY:
MADISON AVENUE heard more tough talk, challenging the industry to remake itself to reach higher, as the 2002 Management Conference of the American Association of Advertising Agencies concluded.
 The speeches at the conference, which was the 84th annual meeting of the association, were virtually free of the frothy self-congratulation and back-patting that frequently takes place at industry gatherings. Rather, the top executives who addressed the general sessions before the conference ended Saturday spoke plainly and directly about the problems that confront agencies as they grapple with the continued downturn in advertising spending by clients. 
 "The pressure is on us as agency leaders," said Ken Kaess, whose term as the 2002-3 chairman of the association, known as the Four A's, began with the conference. "Are we ready to -- dare I say it -- take the lead?" he asked. "Or have we grown so comfortable with our position in the back seat of the marketing partnership that we've forgotten how to drive?" 
Mr. Kaess, who is also the president and chief executive at DDB Worldwide in New York, part of the Omnicom Group, warned: "I know one course of action we can't afford to consider. We can't just sit back and wait for the sky to fall on us."
Mr. Kaess, whose agency works for advertisers like Anheuser-Busch, Hershey Foods, Clorox, the New York Lottery and State Farm Insurance, urged in his speech on Friday that his colleagues, counterparts and competitors unite in a sustained effort to reverse a long-term trend that has resulted in "clients paying us even less for the very marketing and consumer insights they need more than ever."
"Talk about flunking Advertising/Marketing 101," he added with some scorn and frustration. "We can't sell a product clients desperately need and ostensibly want."
One answer, Mr. Kaess suggested, would be for the association to depart significantly from its tradition of allowing each chairman or chairwoman during the usual one-year term in office to advocate an issue of his or her own choosing. Those issues have ranged in recent years from reforming political advertising to championing creative excellence to exploring how to make advertising more effective.
"Should we be stepping back and looking at our industry and doing, say, a three-year strategic plan?" Mr. Kaess asked. "Isn't taking the long view what we would counsel our clients to do?"
The issue that Mr. Kaess recommended concentrating on for the next three years is "improving the value of the product we sell" by reminding marketers of "the transformational quality of great brand-building ideas and brand-communication programs."
That could be accomplished, Mr. Kaess said, by taking steps that would include "funding a major research study that helps quantify the value of what we do" and surveying advertisers annually, perhaps in conjunction with a major media company, to determine "where we are falling short" in meeting their needs.
"If we could achieve this one goal, increasing the value of our product, wouldn't clients be willing to pay more for a product they valued more?" Mr. Kaess asked. "We have research that says consumers do.
"Wouldn't more young people flock to our business if they knew the world appreciated its value?" he added, referring to the struggle most agencies are having recruiting entry-level employees, even in a soft economy. "Wouldn't it be more fun to walk into meetings and have clients awaiting our exciting new ideas and campaigns because they actually believed our product had the power to energize their brands?"
When Mr. Kaess finished his speech, he received loud, sustained applause, about as much as was heard Thursday after the frank, provocative remarks from Brendan Ryan, the 2001-2 chairman of the association.
As if that one-two punch was not sufficient, another top executive who spoke Friday echoed the proposal of Mr. Kaess to lift the industry by rethinking its emphasis.
"We're in the idea business," said John J. Dooner Jr., chairman, president and chief executive at the Interpublic Group of Companies in New York, the world's second-largest agency company with holdings like the McCann-Erickson World Group and Initiative Media Worldwide. "Our sole purpose is to build value for clients' businesses and their brands."
One crucial element, Mr. Dooner said, will be the ability of the giant agency companies like Interpublic, Omnicom and the WPP Group to effectively offer their disparate advertising and marketing services in cohesive, coordinated fashion. "We're a long way from doing it in the manner it requires," he said.
"This is where the game is going," he said, adding that "the one that gets this right wins the game."
"What we have to do during this economically challenged time is very vital -- focusing and refocusing and refocusing on the fundamentals," Mr. Dooner said, which, he added, comes down to "doing good work and getting fairly paid for it."

HEADLINE: Poor Showing For Oxygen In Ratings 

BYLINE:  By JIM RUTENBERG 

 BODY:
Executives at Oxygen, the cable network that promised to revolutionize television for women when it made its debut two years ago, have taken issue with smart-alecky assessments that it is "gasping for air."
 But the network -- whose founders include the Nickelodeon pioneer Geraldine Laybourne and Oprah Winfrey -- does seem to be gasping for ratings. And if the revolution is indeed being televised, very few people are watching. 
 Monthly data available from Nielsen Media Research for the first time in Oxygen's history show results far below what its executives -- and industry analysts -- expected when the network began in early 2000. 
According to March Nielsen figures, Oxygen is watched each day in an average of only 26,000 households, less than 0.1 percent of the nearly 40 million households that receive it nationwide.
In the evenings, its ratings are slightly better, and an average of 52,000 households tune in. But Oxygen still ranks among the lowest of the regularly monitored television networks, far below cable outlets like the Travel Channel and Country Music Television.
Oxygen's troubled start has by now been fairly well documented. Its initial program schedule, which included an amateurish "Pajama Party" talk show and an au courant (some said forced) afternoon show for teenagers, "Trackers," was widely panned.
Getting distribution on cable systems took longer than expected, particularly in New York. And the pricey gambit of fully integrating its television programming with the Internet all but fizzled when Oxygen was forced to close several sites and backtrack from its ambitious e-commerce goals.
But the Nielsen figures provide the first official scorecard of how audiences are taking to its programming. The miniscule audience numbers were surprising to long-time television industry analysts. "Barely a heartbeat -- if it was any lower it would be a hash mark," said one; Another said the network's viewership "hardly registers a ripple in the pond."
The ratings struggles of Oxygen, they said, underscore the difficulty that new cable networks face in breaking through to audiences -- especially without the promotional backing of a major media parent like Viacom or AOL Time Warner. But they also raise questions about whether there is room for another women's cable network in a field dominated by Lifetime, a joint venture of the Walt Disney Company and the Hearst Corporation.
Oxygen's wobbly start comes as such a surprise because so much was expected of the network. Promising to offer intelligent and thoughtful programming for professional women, in contrast to the more breathless Lifetime, its parent company, Oxygen Media, attracted financing of a reported $300 million from backers like AOL, Paul Allen, the co-founder of Microsoft, and the Carsey-Werner-Mandabach production house. The network went so far as to demand that cable operators pay to carry it, in an industry where most newcomers have to pay for carriage.
Oxygen executives acknowledged that they were disappointed with the ratings.
"We certainly had hoped we'd do better," said Laura Nelson, a network spokeswoman. But, she said, network executives were not discouraged. "We're absolutely right on track."
Ms. Nelson blamed the network's growth spurt in distribution for much of the problem. Oxygen was available in 14 million homes at the beginning of 2001. It now reaches nearly 40 million households, too many to continue without signing up for Nielsen ratings, which it did before the network's promotional campaign had shown results. "There's just a lag time between when you hit someone's dial and when they find you," Ms. Nelson said.
In two of the markets that have carried Oxygen the longest, Atlanta and Dallas, it is doing much better, Ms. Nelson said. It was recently added to Time Warner Cable's basic cable lineup in New York and the network hopes that the increased exposure will help increase the network's profile in the media. 
Ms. Nelson said the network saw no reason to change from its newly revamped programming schedule, which has moved away some from in-studio seemingly Oprah-inspired shows toward more humor and mainstream entertainment in the form of reruns of "Xena, Warrior Princess," and original new programs including a talk show about fashion with the comedian Tracey Ullman as host ("Pajama Party" has been dropped). "I think we're pretty confident in the quality of programming that's on the air," Ms. Nelson. "We're beginning to hit our stride."
Oxygen certainly has a way to go. According to the Nielsen data, its household ratings during prime time translate into just 63,000 people, only 19,000 of whom were women 18 to 49, Oxygen's key demographic.
Lifetime, on the other hand, was watched in prime time in March by 2.4 million people, 713,000 of them women 18 to 49. Lifetime is a much more established network, available in more than 85 million homes. It ranks No. 1 in prime time among all basic cable networks.
Yet Oxygen is not doing quite as well as Disney's SoapNet, which shows reruns of soap operas; it started about the same time as Oxygen. It is available in slightly more than half as many homes as is Oxygen, but is watched in a much higher percentage of them. Still, it did not receive anywhere near the amount of media attention that Oxygen did at its start.
Analysts said Oxygen, unlike SoapNet, is trying something much more ambitious by creating its own programming, which takes time. And despite its troubled start, they were not nearly ready to count it out.
"I think they're putting pretty good stuff on the air," said Christopher Geraci, director of national television buying for the OMD USA, a media services division of Omnicom. "This is just a testament to how hard it is to get noticed."
Mr. Geraci said that while he had expected a higher number of viewers, he believed sponsors would continue to stick with the network. "Most of the folks who have bought them have done so to be there at the beginning, so if it does turn out to be successful they will have laid a base with them," he said.
Jack Myers, editor of the Jack Myers Report, a television industry newsletter, said Oxygen was headed in the right direction by retooling its programming. And, he said, once it gets better notices it should do fine.
He disagreed with assessments that the women's television genre was overcrowded and said there seemed to be room for Lifetime and its spinoffs, the Lifetime Movie Network and Real Women, SoapNet, Rainbow Media Holding's WE Women's Entertainment and Oxygen.
"The real issue is going to be once they launch their new season and new schedule in September," he said. If Oxygen's ratings do not improve within a year, he said, "Then there's real concern. But I think that critics need to give them the next year before judgments start being finalized."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Andersen Said to Have Had Hint of Problems in August
A former Arthur Andersen partner has told government investigators that officials with the firm became concerned about the possibility of a federal inquiry regarding Enron as far back as August after a whistle-blower at the company made accusations of accounting fraud, people involved in the case said.
 The statements by the former partner, David B. Duncan, are the first indication that the seeds of the obstruction of justice scandal that has crippled Andersen may have been planted earlier than once thought. Page A1. 

Hollywood Thrust Into Uncertainty
In the wake of a defeat of a Screen Actors Guild proposal, talent agents go to work this week for the first time without any oversight or restrictions by the guild, thrusting agents and actors into a period of uncertainty not experienced in more than 60 years. C2.

Japan Slow to Accept New Phones
Nearly 60 percent of the Japanese own cellphones, but they are not rushing to embrace the so-called third-generation service. The economy is at a standstill, and the number of new mobile-phone subscribers has fallen for seven consecutive months. Carriers are signing up fewer than half a million new customers a month, one-third as many as a year ago. Cellphone users like Yukiko Asaoka, an office worker, like the new features but are unwilling to buy new handsets that cost twice as much as older phones that provide many of the same functions. C4.

Celera Shifts Marketing of Database
Celera Genomics is moving out of the business of selling the database it developed by sequencing the human genome, people close to the company said. The main job of marketing and distributing the database will be shifted to a sister company, Applied Biosystems, which makes equipment used to study genes and proteins, these people said. C2.

Yiddish Project Draws Hate Mail
The Yiddish Radio Project, a 10-week series on National Public Radio about the radio programs broadcast for immigrant Jews in America during the first part of the 20th century, has become a lightning rod for listener criticism, some of it anti-Semitic. C8.

Pay Features Gather Steam on Web
All across the Web, consumers are buying newly offered information and services, including dating tips, weather alerts, college classes, financial advice and diet counseling. Executives of some large media companies are now trying to gauge how successful these initiatives will be in the long term, and whether it makes sense to adopt similar efforts. Bob Tedeschi: E-Commerce Report. C7.

New Life for Washington Monthly
A lone investor, Markos Kounalakis, a journalist, businessman and author, has taken control of The Washington Monthly, which has provided a neoliberal point of view in the national political debate. The magazine has teetered on the edge of financial ruin since it began in 1969. Most of the original shareholders mailed back their stock certificates so the magazine could be reorganized into a nonprofit. C8.

Google Runs Into Copyright Dispute
Legal experts say a complaint filed by the Church of Scientology against Google, the company behind the Web search engine, highlights problems with a copyright law that can make companies liable for linking to sites they do not control. New Economy. C4.

Agreement on Computer Recycling
Responding to a growing problem of waste computer equipment, manufacturers and local governments have agreed in principle to set up a nationwide recycling program. C6.

HEADLINE: Actors Guild Vote on Agents Leaves Old System in Chaos 

BYLINE:  By ANITA M. BUSCH 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, April 21 

 BODY:
The defeat on Friday of a Screen Actors Guild proposal that would have eased restrictions on talent agencies has thrust agents and actors into a period of uncertainty not experienced in Hollywood in more than 60 years.
 The referendum, backed by a majority of the union's board but rejected by 54.5 percent of the members who voted, would have allowed production companies -- but not the major studios or networks -- to buy as much as 20 percent of talent agencies. The referendum also would have permitted a talent agency to own up to 20 percent of a production company, including advertising agencies. In addition, the deal would have allowed agents to take commissions on residual payments for home video and DVD releases. 
 As a result of the vote, agents go to work this week for the first time since 1939 without any oversight or restrictions from the guild.
Minutes after the deal was rejected, the Association of Talent Agents seized the opportunity to send a letter threatening legal action if the union tried "to create chaos by interfering with the relationship between agents and actors."
The letter also accused the guild of violating its own rules by allowing actors to use managers, who do not adhere to union rules, to negotiate deals. In California, managers are prohibited both by law and the actors union from negotiating deals, but many do so.
In response, the guild's national board suspended its own rule requiring that actors deal only with "franchised agents," meaning that actors can keep working with their agents while the union continues "a variety of options to ensure protection for performers."
At the same time, however, the board advised actors not to sign individual representation deals if the terms provide less protection than the guild rules and regulations that had been in effect. In addition, it will urge agents to re-sign the old franchise agreement, which agents today said they would not do.
The union's leaders were addressing the members today, and the Association of Talent Agents gathered for an impromptu meeting.
The controversial referendum divided an already splintered union, with actors like Jason Alexander, Rob Schneider and Elliott Gould opposing the proposal and Annette Bening, Kevin Spacey and many others supporting it. Even the guild's past leadership was split, with a pair of former presidents, Patty Duke and Richard Masur, supporting the deal while Charlton Heston and William Daniels rallied against it. The current president, Melissa Gilbert, voted for the referendum.
Proponents of the referendum said it was needed to keep peace between actors and their agents who feel economically stifled. Opponents of the plan contended it would create conflicts of interest, arguing that if a talent agency was owned by a production company, an actor's agent could also, in effect, be an employer.
The defeat of the proposal has frustrated and angered agents, who have tried for more than two years to reach an agreement with the fractious union. The threat of legal action after the defeat of the vote has only added to the ill will. One commercial actor called it "a bullying tactic."
Agents began talking about changing the guild's rules and restrictions, known as the "master franchise agreement," in 1999, saying that they needed parity with managers.
While both represent actors, talent agencies' business practices are much more restricted. Management companies reap lucrative producing fees and can own -- and be owned -- by production companies. Managers, in their defense, note that while talent agents cannot collect producing fees, they can take lucrative packaging fees for pulling together projects for studios. Managers cannot take such fees.
Last fall, in testimony before the California Legislature, talent agents surprisingly changed their focus and said that they did not care about managers. Instead, they argued that the union's restrictions were antiquated and thwarted their efforts to expand. The master franchise agreement has not changed significantly in more than 50 years.
In the last few years, several major advertising agency companies have held talks with talent agencies about investments and acquisitions, but backed off because of the restrictive union rules. In 1997, Interpublic agreed to buy a majority stake in Addis/Weschler, a management and production company now called Industry Entertainment, in a deal worth about $25 million.
That deal made agents realize the worth of their own agencies. Agents have told actors repeatedly that they do not want to be producers, they just want access to capital to expand their businesses, which in turn would create more jobs for their clients.
"They really don't have a desire to produce," said Gavin Polone, a producer who has been an agent, a manager, holds a Screen Actors Guild card and voted for the referendum. "The real issue is that a lot of the value of an agency is its assets and they want to find a way to cash out those receivables and sell their agency so they can get a long-term capital gain for tax purposes, which means selling an interest in their agency to another company." Ad agency executives agreed with that assessment.
Agents contend that while some talent firms may want to sell, the real reason to make the change is to build strategic relationships that would benefit their clients. They also argue that selling a stake of 20 percent is not the same as cashing out.
A deal negotiated, and approved, by the board of the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists is expected to be endorsed by the agents on Tuesday. If approved, all agents and some Screen Actors Guild members will be bound by a three-year contract that allows up to a 20 percent investment by production companies. A little less than half of the 98,000 guild members are also members of the federation, which covers only a small fraction of film and television work. 
"The fact that these agents will be adhering to our restrictions will help prevent conflict of interests," said Greg Hessinger, national executive director of the federation. 
Norm Aladjem, the chairman and chief executive of Writers and Artists Agency, said: "All of us have to find a way out. It's like the Middle East. As Benjamin Franklin once said, 'We must all hang together, or assuredly we shall all hang separately.' "

HEADLINE: World Bank Aims to Help Poor Receive Elementary Education 

BYLINE:  By DAVID LEONHARDT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 21 

 BODY:
Calling education crucial to the reduction of global poverty, international finance ministers approved a World Bank plan today aimed at enrolling all young children in elementary school.
 As a start, 10 poor nations that have been making progress on education recently could receive about $1 billion in combined aid to carry out strategies they devise. Bangladesh and Tanzania are considered likely recipients. 
 Even as World Bank officials praised wealthy nations for saying they would finance the plan, the officials acknowledged that they were unlikely to reach their goal of providing schooling for all children between 5 and 11 by the year 2015. 
About 125 million children in that age group, or about one of five in poor nations, do not attend school. More than three-quarters live in Africa or South Asia, the bank said.
Education occupied much of the discussion of the final day of the meetings of the bank and the International Monetary Fund in Washington this week.
On a rainy day, the meetings were not much affected by the protesters who have made it a routine to disrupt them. James D. Wolfensohn, the World Bank president, said he was pleased that this year most of the demonstrators were focusing on political issues that had little to do with the bank. He added that the bank had become more open and more responsive to its critics in the last five years and that he had met with some of those critics in the last week.
As they had throughout the weekend, ministers and development officials continued to criticize the Bush administration's recent decision to levy new tariffs on imported steel to protect the American steel industry.
Many economists believe that tariffs and subsidies in the United States and Europe and in other wealthy countries are hampering developing countries and raising prices for businesses and consumers around the world.
"Openness of trade is a necessity if you're going to deal with the question of development," said Mr. Wolfensohn. American and European officials also continued to disagree over whether loans or grants are a better way to deliver foreign aid. Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill has said that grants are a more honest way to give aid, because many loans to poor countries are never repaid. Some Europeans are concerned that a shift to grants will lead to smaller amounts of aid from wealthy countries.
Trevor Manuel, the finance minister of South Africa and the chairman of the World Bank's development committee, said today that the wealthy countries should broaden the discussion to include the countries that receive the aid. The debate so far "has tended to be a North Atlantic discussion," he said.
The ministers' endorsement of the World Bank's education plan is only the latest such effort, and some ministers acknowledged today that earlier efforts had fallen short.
"We need action now," said Eveline Herfkens, the Netherlands' minister of development cooperation. "We don't want to have another generation lost because they don't see the inside of a classroom." 
In the next three months, the World Bank will chose 10 countries that it thinks have developed strong reform plans but lack the money to put them in place. 
The World Bank eventually plans to give grants to all 88 developing countries it says have a large number of unschooled children.
In a report it issued this weekend, the bank said that at least one-quarter of the countries in both sub-Saharan Africa and South Asia, and a significant percentage of countries in Latin America and the Middle East, are unlikely to reach the goal of full enrollment.

HEADLINE: Council Support Grows For a 'Living Wage' Bill 

BYLINE:  By STEVEN GREENHOUSE

 BODY:
For years, community groups and labor unions have complained that New York City's government underwrites poverty by awarding contracts to companies that pay many of their workers $6 or $7 an hour. 
 This year, these groups are pushing hard for legislation that would force companies that receive city contracts and subsidies to raise their wages, and that effort has received a welcome response from the City Council. 
 Forty-five of the Council's 51 members are sponsoring a bill that would require many such companies to pay their workers at least $8.10 an hour with health benefits, or $9.60 an hour without benefits.
The bill's backers say it is a smart way to lift thousands of New York workers above the poverty line at little cost to the city. They estimate that the bill, called a living-wage bill, will raise wages for more than 70,000 workers and cost the city less than $10 million a year in increased contract costs. 
In an interview on Friday, Gifford Miller, the City Council speaker, said, "I believe it's the right thing for the city to do both from a moral and economic point of view, because when the city is making certain types of investments it should make sure the jobs created by those investments are lifting people out of poverty."
But the Bloomberg administration and many business groups warn that the city cannot afford the bill. They estimate that it would cost the city at least $100 million a year at a time when the city is struggling with a projected $4.9 billion deficit. Some business groups say it would pressure employers to eliminate thousands of low-wage jobs. 
City Hall officials are not openly threatening a veto, but they say they are uncomfortable with the proposal.
"We approach this with great trepidation," said Bill Cunningham, the communications director for Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg. "It's safe to say that if the living-wage bill is passed, the budget numbers we put out will be out of whack by another $125 million to $150 million."
The bill could be the focus of a major battle between the Council and Mr. Bloomberg partly because it is backed vigorously by many groups, including the Community Service Society, the New York City Central Labor Council, the Working Families Party and 1199/S.E.I.U., the giant health care workers' union.
The Council has scheduled a hearing on the bill tomorrow, and some Council members say they plan to vote on it in May. 
More than 80 other government bodies across the nation, including Suffolk County, have enacted these so-called living wage laws, sometimes mandating more than $12 an hour, prompted in part by the reluctance of the federal government to raise the $5.15 an hour minimum wage. (Suffolk's law, to take effect July 1, requires at least $9 an hour for people who work for agencies under contract to the county.)
The Community Service Society, a charitable group, completed a recent study showing that the New York City bill would enable many welfare recipients who had taken jobs to climb out of poverty.
David R. Jones, the society's president, said: "If we want to be serious about lifting people out of poverty, we have to be serious about the adequacy of wages. For good or for ill, welfare reform has forced a lot of people to depend on low-wage jobs."
The bill would cover employees of companies that have city contracts to provide home health care, day care and services to people with cerebral palsy. In addition, the bill would cover city contractors that provide building, food or temporary-help services as well as companies that receive subsidies to operate or renovate office buildings. And the bill would cover workers employed by the city's business improvement districts and by large buildings in which city agencies rent several floors. 
Under the bill, workers for these companies are to get at least $8.10 an hour this year, with the minimum rising by 50 cents a year, finally reaching $10 an hour in 2006.
Perhaps the most powerful lobbyist for the bill is Dennis Rivera, the president of 1199. Having persuaded Albany's lawmakers to enact a $1.8 billion package to finance raises for health care workers, he wants the City Council to pass the living-wage bill because it would lift wages for 50,000 home health care workers, most of them 1199 members.
Mr. Rivera said it would cost the city just $5 million to raise the wages of home care workers to $8.10, but because of a matching formula, Albany and Washington would pay another $45 million, he said, helping spur the city's ailing economy.
A powerful business group, the New York City Partnership and Chamber of Commerce, is opposing the bill because of its cost and the record-keeping burden it would place on companies to show they are in compliance.
Kathryn S. Wylde, the partnership's chief executive, said, "Given the current fiscal crisis the city faces and the fact that our unemployment rate has gone above 7 percent and we're higher than the rest of the country, at this point putting additional impositions on business just seems totally the wrong direction to be going."
The Business Council of New York State has also attacked the proposal, saying it would pressure companies to eliminate 9,000 low-wage jobs.
The bill's sponsors say they hope to avoid a confrontation with Mr. Bloomberg over the issue. They say that they want to hear City Hall's objections and will consider some changes to make it less objectionable to the mayor.
Bill Perkins, a council member from Harlem and one of the bill's earliest sponsors, said: "If the mayor wants to negotiate, we're prepared to negotiate. This is a bill that will have an economic impact that is positive, not negative."

HEADLINE: The Youngest Workers 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Organization Sells a Legacy of Hine Photos" (Arts pages, April 16):
 The National Child Labor Committee has not lost its "original mission." 
The problem of child labor is still a major problem in the United States (not just internationally), with hundreds of thousands of children exploited in agriculture, in sweatshops and in retail and manufacturing jobs from New York to California. 
 We have added to that mission a focus on jobless and underprepared young people trying to enter the labor market, and on teaching children about the world of work. But we have never lost sight of child labor.
We are struggling to survive, but there should be no mistaking the need for our work and for our organization. 

JEFFREY NEWMAN
President and Executive Director
National Child Labor Committee

HEADLINE: Some in Reno Say Do Not Put Asunder Artifacts of Divorce 

BYLINE:  By PATRICIA LEIGH BROWN 

DATELINE: RENO, Nev. 

 BODY:
Back before the divorce was as common as the cold, there was Reno.
 It was here, along the Truckee River in what was then the biggest city in the state, that those seeking to untie the knot flocked to "take the cure," as a Reno divorce was known. 
 The mythology of divorce still hovers over the Virginia Street Bridge, where newly divorced women were said to fling their wedding bands into the roiling waters of the Truckee, having kissed the white columns of the Washoe County Courthouse, the stately dispensator of divorce, with red lipstick.
The Reno divorce -- Walter Winchell called it "Reno-vation" -- became a national institution in the 1930's, largely because of a 1931 law that allowed a person to obtain a divorce after residing in the state for six weeks. With divorces in most other states requiring long waiting periods and often proof or admission of adultery, Reno became what postcards described as "the divorce capital of the world" even as Las Vegas was little more than a desert outpost. 
But as Vegas gambling ascended, the Reno divorce receded. Now, a fledgling divorce preservation movement is seeking to protect the state's divorce landmarks. Two of the 11 historic sites listed this month as endangered by the group Preserve Nevada are related to divorce. 
One is the Virginia Street Bridge, Reno's Bridge of Sighs, which is threatened with removal in a flood-control plan. The other is the Silver State Lodge, the vintage log motel.
Hundreds of hotels, motels and boarding houses flourished in the back alleys and sagebrush of Reno, where about 32,000 marriages were dissolved from 1929 through 1939.
By the 1960's, no-fault divorce and more liberal social attitudes had killed the migratory divorce trade in Reno. Commercial development, urban sprawl, fire and neglect have since taken their toll, and few traces of the divorce industry survive.
Of all the institutions that have ridden off into the sunset, perhaps none was more romantic than the divorce ranch, where the combination of lonely women and handsome cowboys proved a lucrative mix.
"Some guests were drawn and tired, like life had dealt them a bad hand," said Joe Page, 79, a former wrangler at one of the ranches, the Flying ME, who had a room with a private bath and fireplace in the mid-1950's. "The whole tempo of the ranch was to get them introduced to life again." 
Sitting in his restored Victorian parlor in Virginia City, Mr. Page, who married four times, wistfully recalled a 19-year-old divorced woman named Holly from Corning, N.Y., who got away. "Her family convinced her not to associate with me," Mr. Page said. "They wrote the finishing chapter." The loss was still evident in his eyes. 
Guests from the Social Register hardly ever went to Reno because they wanted to avoid the press. 
"Back then, Reno had an international reputation," said Mella Rothwell Harmon, a historian with the state preservation office in Carson City, who recently wrote "Design for Divorce," to be published by Balcony Press. "We're beginning to recognize divorce as an important theme in our history."
Reno's notoriety as "an island in the sea of matrimony" began in 1906, when William Corey, president of the United States Steel Corporation, came here for a much-publicized divorce. It continued with Barbara Hutton and Clare Boothe Luce (then Brokaw), whose play "The Women" takes place at a hotel resembling the Riverside in Reno, now artists' lofts.
Mary Pickford divorced the actor Owen Moore here before rushing back to California to marry Douglas Fairbanks Sr. Arthur Miller wrote "The Misfits" while awaiting a divorce here, then married Marilyn Monroe, who plays a vulnerable Reno divorcee in the 1961 film.
"Not all of our history is pretty," said Andria S. Daley-Taylor, an adviser to the National Trust for Historic Preservation in Reno. "But it tells the story of the West."
Ms. Harmon spent years combing through 1930's divorce records to determine where the divorcing couples came from and the extent of local participation, which buoyed the Reno economy during the Depression. 
Sixty percent of the pilgrims were women. The euphemism for pregnancy was "the Reno worry."
"They were away from their families in a remote place with wide open spaces, gambling and men who made it their job to make sure they had a pleasant time," Ms. Harmon said. "Nature took its course pretty frequently."
Boarding houses, hotels with kitchenettes and about 36 divorce ranches sprang up to take advantage of Nevada's 1931 law, enacted to compete with Idaho, Florida and Arkansas. The less affluent created tent cities along the Truckee River, and even the Y.W.C.A. catered to divorce.
A plaintiff simply had to declare an intention to make Nevada his or her permanent home (most had a return ticket in their pockets) and offer testimony from a person, usually a landlady, that he or she had been a continuous resident for six weeks. If the divorce was uncontested, it was granted immediately on any number of grounds, some slight.
One of the handful of remaining divorce-oriented residences is Estelle Nystrom's Guest House, built in 1895 and now run as a regular boarding house by her daughter Sonia Martin. At its height, the house was home to two dozen women seeking divorces, and Ms. Martin, now 59, remembers playing in the courthouse rotunda almost daily as a girl while her mother testified.
"I thought I had a normal childhood," said Ms. Martin, now a graduate student in marriage and family therapy.
Pat Ferraro Klos grew up yearning to live in "a proper neighborhood," as she put it, instead of the Silver State Lodge, the second site on the endangered list.
Most of the ranches are gone now, including the TH, once owned by Cornelius Vanderbilt Jr. Vanderbilt offered a package divorce deal -- $795 a week for room and board, a horse, two trips to Reno, a bottle of liquor and a daily pack of cigarettes.
One of the few divorce ranches still standing is Washoe Pines, where Myrna Loy stayed. Believed to be the inspiration for the film version of "The Women," it was purchased by Maya Miller, now 86, who turned it into a private residence in 1960. "I wasn't equipped to take care of all those women," she said.
The setting remains intoxicatingly idyllic. "You can imagine what effect it would have on a housewife from Schenectady," said Ms. Harmon, the historian.
The fate of the city's most beloved divorce icon, the Virginia Street Bridge, built in 1905, remains in doubt. In a 1997 flood, the bridge's low arches were believed to have constricted the flow of water with a logjam of debris. The flood did $500 million to $700 million in damage.
A community coalition has been working with the Army Corps of Engineers on possible solutions, including tearing it down and building a new one. The prospect does not amuse preservationists. 
"Whether folklore, fakelore or what really happened, the bridge is symbolic of a rite of passage," said Guy Rocha, the Nevada state archivist.
Down the block, the Washoe County Courthouse and Historical Preservation Society is trying to raise $100,000 to restore Courtroom No. 1, once the divorce seeker's promised land. One morning recently, Judge Peter I. Breen, who presides over the courtroom, recalled "the fancy divorce decrees, backed in blue with red ribbons and a big gold seal."
In retrospect, Judge Breen said of the state's divorce legacy, "it shows how enlightened we were out here," adding, "It's valuable to remember the unnatural restrictions we've placed on human relations, and the position women have been in."
On the columns outside the courthouse the red lipstick smudges are gone, but perhaps not the moral. "We've come a long way," Judge Breen said. "To preserve and remember provides continuity."

HEADLINE: New Economy; 
A copyright dispute with the Church of Scientology is forcing Google to do some creative linking.

BYLINE:  By David F. Gallagher 

 BODY:
GOOGLE, the company behind the popular Web search engine, has been playing a complicated game recently that involves the Church of Scientology and a controversial copyright law. 
 Legal experts say the episode highlights problems with the law that can make companies or individuals liable for linking to sites they do not control. And it has turned Google, whose business is built around a database of two billion Web pages, into a quiet campaigner for the freedom to link. 
 The church sent a complaint to Google last month, saying that its search results for "Scientology" included links to copyrighted church material that appears on a Web site critical of the church. Under the Digital Millennium Copyright Act of 1998, which was intended to make it easier for copyright holders to fight piracy, the complaint meant that Google was required to remove those links quickly or risk being sued for contributing to copyright infringement. 
The site in question, Operation Clambake (www.xenu.net), is based in Norway, beyond the reach of the United States copyright act. The site portrays the church as a greedy cult that exploits its members and harasses critics. Andreas Heldal-Lund, the site's owner, says the posting of church materials, including some internal documents and pictures of church leaders, is allowable under the "fair use" provisions of internationally recognized copyright law. 
When Google responded to the church's complaint by removing the links to the Scientology material, techies and free-speech advocates accused Google of censoring its search results. Google also briefly removed the link to Operation Clambake's home page but soon restored it, saying the removal had been a mistake. 
At that point, according to Matthew Cutts, a software engineer at Google, it started developing a better way to handle such complaints. "We respond very quickly to challenges, and not just technical challenges but also these sort of interesting, delicate situations, as well," Mr. Cutts said. 
Under Google's new policy, when it receives a complaint that causes it to remove links from its index, it will give a copy of the complaint to the Chilling Effects Clearinghouse (chillingeffects.org). Chilling Effects is a project of a civil liberties advocacy group called the Electronic Frontier Foundation and several law schools. It it offers information about Internet rights issues. 
In the new procedure, Google informs its users when a link has been removed from a set of search results and directs them to the Chilling Effects site. For example, a search for the word "helatrobus," which appears in some Scientology texts, brings up a page of results with this notice at the bottom: "In response to a complaint we received under the Digital Millennium Copyright Act, we have removed one result(s) from this page. If you wish, you may read the D.M.C.A. complaint for these removed results."
The notice includes a link to Scientology's complaint on chillingeffects.org, which lists the Web addresses of the material to which Google no longer links. The result is that a complaint could end up drawing more attention to the very pages it is trying to block. 
Mr. Cutts said Google started linking to chillingeffects.org early this month but made no announcement, so it took a while for word to go around online. Meanwhile, Scientology sent Google two more complaints, citing pages within copies of the Operation Clambake site on other servers. All three complaints are now on the Chilling Effects site. 
Don Marti, the technical editor of Linux Journal, first wrote about Google's move on the magazine's site. He said he had been so upset about the company's initial response to the Scientologists that he organized a small group of protesters who visited Google's headquarters in Mountain View, Calif., where he also lives. Mr. Marti says he now applauds Google's efforts to make the process more transparent. If a letter of complaint simply makes a site more popular, "only a fool would send one," he said. 
Helena Kobrin, a lawyer representing Scientology at the law firm of Moxon & Kobrin in Los Angeles, said that Google's use of the letters of complaint would not discourage the church from pursuing further complaints if necessary and that there was nothing in the letters that needed to be hidden. "I think they show very graphically to people that the only thing we're trying to do is protect copyrights," she said. 
As part of its new process for handling complaints, Mr. Cutts said, Google added more information on its site explaining how site owners could have their links restored by filing a countercomplaint with Google. (The required forms can be downloaded from chillingeffects.org.) If site owners take this step, he said, they accept responsibility for the contents of their pages. 
Mr. Heldal-Lund, a Norwegian citizen, said he would not file a countercomplaint because it would put him under the jurisdiction of United States law. He said that he regretted making so much trouble for Google but was glad that the incident had highlighted the church's pursuit of its critics. 
The church, which has beliefs based on the idea that people need to release themselves from trauma suffered in past lives, has taken a keen interest in the Internet since 1994, when someone posted secret church teachings on an online discussion group. Critics say the church guards its teachings closely because it wants its followers to pay for access to higher levels of instruction. The church says that these payments are donations and that it is simply seeking to protect its rights online.
With its Chilling Effects partnership, Google is subtly making the point that the right to link is important to its business and to the health of the Web, said David G. Post, a law professor at Temple University who specializes in Internet issues. 
"This is an example where copyright law is being used in conflict with free connectivity and free expression on the Net," he said. Dr. Post said Google's situation highlighted the need for more awareness of copyright issues, including pending legislation that is more restrictive than the 1998 law. The measure is backed by entertainment giants like Walt Disney, but technology companies like Intel have come out against it, saying it would hurt consumers and slow innovation. 
Mr. Cutts said that the links to the complaints were not a political statement, just a way to "make sure our users get all of the information that they need." He said that Google had no official position on the copyright act and that so far it had not been involved in political activity or lobbying. But he said it "might take an interest in more of those issues." 
The copyright controversy has had an interesting side effect for Operation Clambake. The Google software judges the importance of a page in part by looking at how many other pages link to it. Scientology's complaint set off a flurry of linking to the critics' site, pushing it up two spots to No. 2 in the search results for "Scientology" -- just below the church's official site.

HEADLINE: The Washington Budget Box 

 BODY:
President Bush has been asserting lately that the budget is so tight there is barely enough money to pay for anything new besides the war on terrorism. He has begun issuing veto threats if Congress tries to defy his spending priorities. How bizarre it is, then, for him to contend at the same time that the nation needs another tax cut. Last week, the House went along, making permanent the ill-advised 10-year, $1.35 trillion tax reduction enacted last year. The Bush proposal would drain nearly $400 billion more over the next 10 years and cost at least $4 trillion in the decade after that. A more irresponsible position would be hard to imagine. 
 The sad truth about budget politics this year is that Congress and the Bush administration have gotten themselves into such a box that irresponsible posturing becomes the easiest recourse. The tax cut of last year, along with the recent mild economic downturn, vaporized the revenues needed to deal with anything outside military and homeland defenses. Yet the Democrats who would like to spend more money on education, health and other areas are too nervous to repeal the tax cut in an election year. As a result, the Senate, which is controlled by Democrats, may be unable to pass any budget resolution this year. 
 The reason for the Democrats' failure is simple. Earlier this year, the Senate Budget Committee approved a sensible resolution calling for some restraint on military spending, no new tax cuts and more paying down of the federal debt. But conservative Democrats want less domestic spending and more tax cuts, and some liberals want more domestic spending. Republicans are not ready to supply the votes for the Democratic budget resolution.
When it comes to facing up to reality, the Republicans are being no less irresponsible. The House, where the Republicans are in control, is unable to pass a vital measure sought by the Bush administration to increase the federal debt limit. Most Republicans don't want to admit that their own policies have returned the nation to the days of racking up more deficits and debts.
Budget resolutions were designed to place ceilings on overall spending and force Congress to write appropriations bills that live with them. There was no resolution in 1998 because at that time the House and Senate could not agree on one. Still, the resolutions are often useful because they can help control Congress's tendency to embark on pork-barrel spending. Without any specific spending limits, Congress needs to exercise some discipline while making sure that essential needs are met -- an unlikely scenario in an election year.
Mr. Bush needs to get off his veto-threat strategy and work with the lawmakers on finding money to sustain investments in the right areas. If the nation is to meet its domestic needs, and protect the next generation of retirees, the tax cut should not be made permanent. Instead, large parts of it, especially those benefiting the wealthiest, should be rescinded -- the sooner the better.

HEADLINE: President to Use Earth Day To Sell Environmental Plan 

BYLINE:  By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: NASHVILLE, April 21 

 BODY:
Monday is Earth Day, an annual rite of spring for the last 32 years. But this Earth Day will sound less like a love-in for Mother Earth than like an October rally in a presidential election year.
 George W. Bush, a former oil executive, is not normally identified with Earth Day rituals but like any president feels the need to flash some green credentials. Earth Day will find him in the acid-rain-besotted Adirondacks in upstate New York with Christie Whitman, the administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency. 
 With Whiteface Mountain as his backdrop, Mr. Bush is to help restore a hiking trail and promote his "Clear Skies" initiative, a proposal that the administration says will yield cleaner air than the Clean Air Act signed by his father in 1990. Protesters will be on hand to assert that his proposal would only make things worse and to complain about Mr. Bush's inaction on global warming, a phenomenon some say can be seen when, among other things, fewer of the big lakes in the Adirondacks are freezing over in the winter.
 At the same time, Al Gore, derided by Mr. Bush's father as Ozone Man, is planning to give a blistering speech in Nashville about what he calls Mr. Bush's environmental failures. His setting is an academic forum in his home state, where he is trying to make amends for past inattention.
 Whether a rerun of campaign 2000 or a harbinger of campaign 2004, the dueling events will showcase what Democrats believe is one of their most potent political issues, one that stands out as a rare piece of terra firma in a world dominated by the military imperatives of a popular Republican commander in chief.
 Republicans play down the environment as an electoral issue. They say that they were simply outgunned by the environmental lobby on last week's vote on whether to drill for oil in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge, partly because the big oil companies cared less about it than about staving off automotive fuel-efficiency standards.
Glen Bolger, a Republican pollster with Public Opinion Strategies, said a national survey that he completed last week showed the environment ranking ninth on a list of nine priorities for voters, after terrorism, the economy, education and health care.
 "The public is pro-environment, make no mistake about that," Mr. Bolger said. "But they're not as anti-Republican or pro-environment as the Sierra Club would have you believe. Where environmental issues are hot are when it's a local issue that impacts people near their homes."
 Environmentalists have come to similar conclusions but frame them a little differently. A recent poll conducted for the League of Conservation Voters shows that while voters approve overwhelmingly of Mr. Bush's handling of the war on terrorism, the economy and education, they do not approve of his record on the environment.
 If these issues do not motivate those who have already decided about candidates, they can motivate important swing voters.
 "The environment consistently ranks as a voting issue for independent voters, women and suburban voters, all of whom are the battleground in November," said Phil Clapp, president of the National Environmental Trust.
 The vote on drilling last week might be followed this week by another rebuff to Mr. Bush's energy policy when the Senate takes up a package of measures related to global warming. Bipartisan compromises being worked out now would reject the president's approaches to international and domestic climate-change policy and, Democrats hope, further put the president on the defensive.
 Polls a year ago showed Mr. Bush weighed down by the environment. The catastrophe of Sept. 11 quieted environmentalists for a time and then forced them to redirect their criticisms of the president to criticisms of his policies.
 But with the approach of the 2002 Congressional elections, and the difficulty Democrats face in gaining traction on other fronts, that is changing.
 The Natural Resources Defense Council is running an advertisement on Earth Day mocking what it suggests is the president's one-day-a-year homage to things green.
 "The ad marks a significant departure from our post-attack posture of talking more about the wishes of big, polluting corporations than about President Bush's own involvement in an unprecedented attack on 30 years of successful environmental protections," said Alan Metrick, the group's spokesman.
 Deb Callahan, president of the League of Conservation Voters, said the president's own policies in favor of the extractive industries of oil, gas and coal had helped regenerate the environmental movement.
 "Before 9/11, it was evident to anyone in politics that the environment was genuinely shaping up to be a top-tier issue in electoral politics in a way it had not been," she said.
When Mr. Gore previewed his speech on the Op-Ed page of The New York Times today, the White House said it was politics as usual. "The president has a strong record on the environment, and the environment is one of the reasons he defeated Al Gore in the election of 2000, among other issues," the president's spokesman, Ari Fleischer, said. "Even in a time of peace and prosperity, Al Gore made the same charges and still lost the election." 
 For accomplishments, the administration points chiefly to helping clean up brownfields in urban areas and to bringing about legal changes in the Superfund program that had been deadlocked in Congress for years.
"We realize that some people may not give us credit for things we do right, but we're determined to make those right environmental policies anyway," one administration official said.
 Mr. Bolger, the Republican pollster, also dismissed issues like those that Mr. Gore was raising as a priority only for hard-core Democrats. 
"The environment resonates most strongly with the beats, the backpackers and the bangles crowd," he said. "And they are pretty well on the far left of the Democratic party."

HEADLINE: The Calm Before The Cuts 

BYLINE:  By BOB HERBERT; E-mail: bobherb@nytimes.com

 BODY:
New Yorkers are, to some extent, in a period of denial now. Which is understandable. It's a relatively quiet time, between the terrible events of last year and the all but inevitable decline in the quality of life that will result from the service cuts that are being readied to help close a staggering $5 billion gap in the city's budget.
 Last week, with temperatures ridiculously hot -- the mid-90's in mid-April -- you could walk around parts of Manhattan and convince yourself that the happy and prosperous times had returned, that the worst was over, that it was O.K., finally, to exhale. 
 Relaxed and smiling faces were everywhere. You could see them if you strolled among the vast expanses of bodies sprawled lazily on the grass of Central Park or Bryant Park, or among the sunbathers at Coney Island, or the throngs turning out for the hit Broadway shows, or the shoppers surging through Midtown, or the elegant patrons waiting to be seated at the most exclusive restaurants.
You could almost feel that New York was back.
But my best guess is that this is just a timeout. There's more trouble ahead. The background noise that catches your attention if you listen very closely is very disturbing.
Two weeks ago a 66-year-old woman on her way home from church was shot and killed when she was caught in the crossfire of a gunfight in Brooklyn. A few days later, a young man on a date was shot and critically wounded in an attempted robbery on a street in Greenwich Village. 
The city's government is desperately short of money and officials are preparing a budget that will mean fewer police officers, fewer garbage collections and even fewer resources for a public school system that is already being bled dry.
Mayor Michael Bloomberg, who is presiding over this potentially drastic rollback in services, was asked on Thursday just how frightened New Yorkers should be if he is unable to get the help he says he needs from the federal and state governments and the municipal unions. "We have to come up with the money, or we have to reduce the services, or some balance between," he said. "It is a matter of great concern. If you want to use the word fear, I certainly am worried about it."
At the moment there is no evidence of a creative collective effort to maneuver the city through this looming crisis in ways that would avoid the infliction of serious wounds and, perhaps, permanent scars.
Consider, for example, the perennial problem of policing. The Giuliani administration spent enormous sums of money in its ultimately successful fight against crime. A special dedicated tax, enacted when David Dinkins was mayor, was used to expand the department to 41,000 officers. And many millions of dollars in overtime were expended year after year.
Now, for a variety of reasons, the police force has contracted. And budgetary considerations are forcing further contractions. This is occurring at a time when the department has the additional responsibility of coping with the threat of terrorism.
Rudolph Giuliani did more with more. Is it reasonable to expect that Mr. Bloomberg can do more with less?
On Thursday, the same day the mayor was expressing his own concern, hundreds of advocates, protesters, teachers, parents and students showed up outside City Hall to voice their dismay over the harsh cuts.
They had a point. While the mayor has ruled out tax increases (with the exception of a cigarette-tax hike), he has been more than willing to impose severe cuts in essential services like police and fire protection, garbage collection, public education and other important services for children, the elderly and the poor.
The feeling among those who gathered outside City Hall was that the burden of sacrifice in these tough times was not being shared and, in particular, that too many of the sacrifices were being borne by children.
"There has not been an honest public conversation about how this budget is going to affect the lives of children," said Gail Nayowith, who heads the Citizens Committee for Children.
She and others urged Mr. Bloomberg to sit down with City Council members and others to explore ways to raise additional revenues and to ease some of the proposed cuts.
I would expand that conversation to others -- to the university and business communities, and religious leaders, and anyone else who may have some good ideas about maintaining safety and a reasonable quality of life in tough economic times.

PERSON: Willis J. Winn 

HEADLINE: Willis J. Winn, 84, Ex-Dean of Wharton And Official of Fed 

BYLINE:  By WOLFGANG SAXON 

 BODY:
Willis J. Winn, a former Federal Reserve Bank official and Wharton School dean who helped shape the country's economic policies in the 1960's and 1970's, died on April 11 at a hospital in Kansas City, Mo. He was 84 and lived in Trimble, Mo.
 He suffered a stroke, his family said. 
 Dr. Winn was dean of the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania in the 1960's. Under his guidance, the school promoted public service and sought to instill a social awareness in its graduates. Its graduate and undergraduate programs expanded to prepare students for a wider range of professions in banking and accounting, as well as occupations like theater or hospital management.
From 1961 to 1970, Dr. Winn was a director of the Philadelphia Federal Reserve Bank, and he was its board chairman from 1966 to 1970. After leaving Wharton and the University of Pennsylvania in 1971, he was elected president of the Federal Reserve Bank in Cleveland, where he served until 1982.
He sat on the Fed's influential Open Market Committee during some volatile economic times under Arthur F. Burns and Paul A. Volcker, the chairmen of the Fed from 1970 to 1987. His tenure coincided with Mr. Volcker's efforts to lower the inflation rate through painful increases in interest rates, a policy that Dr. Winn supported.
Willis Jay Winn was born in Plattsburg, Mo., and graduated from Central College in Fayette, Mo. He received a master's in 1940 and a Ph.D. in 1951 in finance at the University of Pennsylvania, where he began his academic career in 1946.
He served as dean at the Wharton School from 1958 to 1971, as well as vice provost of the university.
Dr. Winn is survived by his wife of 59 years, Lois Gengelbach Willis; a daughter, Judith Ann, of Shorewood, Wis.; a son, Steven J., of San Francisco; and one granddaughter.

HEADLINE: The Southward Journey of American Detritus 

BYLINE:  By JIM YARDLEY 

DATELINE: LOS INDIOS, Tex., April 18 

 BODY:
"Used" does not describe the royal blue 1986 Toyota pickup idling at the bridge into Mexico. Rust has chewed into the doors. The odometer reads 189,589 miles. Someone in Utah was surely thrilled when a smiling Guatemalan named Billy Pineda paid $1,000 for it.
 Yet the life, or second life, of that Toyota has only begun. Mr. Pineda, 27, having just driven 1,301 miles from Salt Lake City to the border, is about to drive 1,000 miles to Guatemala. He has filled the Toyota with stuffed animals, a used television, a set of socket wrenches, a used tire and an air-conditioner. A Barbie Car is strapped to the roof, and he is towing a second pickup, loaded with old bicycles. 
 He plans to spend the next three days driving down the Atlantic coast of Mexico, sleeping in the Toyota, until he arrives in Guatemala, where he will sell everything. If he is lucky, he says, he will net $1,000. He will visit his wife and three children, then fly back to Utah, where he has relatives, and start the process again. He makes more than 25 trips a year.
"For the local people, it's something normal," he said of his occupation. "There are a lot of people who do this for a living."
Here at the southernmost tip of the Mexican border, men like Mr. Pineda are known as transmigrantes, and their rusted, rolling caravans of junk are a common sight along Military Highway, just north of the Rio Grande. They operate in the shadows of the bustling Nafta economy, buying junker cars and throwaway goods in the United States, then driving to Central America, where people are so poor that a battered 1986 Toyota can seem like a dream car.
Dusty towns like Los Indios serve as border checkpoints for the transmigrantes, and Military Highway is dotted with hand-painted signs advertising the brokers who can expedite the paperwork with customs officials in Mexico and the United States. Though the occasional junker turns out to be stolen, statistics show that legitimate business has been brisk: in the last two weeks, transmigrantes have transported more than 350 used cars a day over bridges here in Cameron County. At that rate, they would be taking more than 127,000 vehicles a year into Central America from these crossings alone.
Parked in the gravel parking lot outside a broker's office, the Volvo flatbed truck driven by Ramiro Rivas is a motorized pack mule. Mr. Rivas, 51, took to the road after he lost his government job in El Salvador a decade ago. On this trip, he bought the old Volvo at an auction in Maryland and loaded onto it a junked Isuzu pickup with 300,000 miles that he had bought for $300.
He also bought a horse trailer and stuffed it with old stereo speakers and appliances, and is pulling it behind the Volvo. Nothing he is carrying would pass muster even at a yard sale in the United States. But those who buy from him in El Salvador, he says, cannot afford anything else. 
"Over there," he said through a translator, "you would not be able to purchase a vehicle, even a used vehicle, with the money you earn. Here in the United States, buying a used vehicle is like buying a used TV." 
Pete Sepulveda Jr., director of the international bridge system in Cameron County, says transmigrantes are skilled at automotive innovation. He has seen them take the seats out of school buses, he says, and stuff a couple of compact cars inside. "It's all in an effort to make a living," he said. "What might be a junk vehicle for us is a gold mine for them." 
Many of the transmigrantes start out from auctions as distant as Connecticut. Mr. Pineda's own routine, from Salt Lake City to Guatemala, often means six days of steady driving, with the most perilous part in Mexico. Mexican law prohibits leaving foreign used vehicles in the country, and the Mexican police have been known to keep a watchful eye on transmigrantes and to demand bribes.
The country's roads can also be treacherous. The new toll roads are too expensive for the transmigrantes, and that leaves the narrow mountainous routes along the Atlantic coast. Mr. Rivas said some stretches were so bad that it could take two hours to advance 50 miles.
The other concern is security. Many of the drivers prefer to travel in caravans, some with as many as 50 vehicles, to discourage holdup men. Mr. Rivas says he has never been robbed, though he insists on driving only in the daytime, staying in cheap hotels at night. Mr. Pineda, younger and more carefree, drives night and day, sleeping inside his vehicle du jour. Once, he says, he was robbed of his entire load at gunpoint as he neared the Guatemalan border.
The busiest seasons are Christmas and Easter, when the lines of transmigrantes can stretch for hundreds of yards every day as they await passage over the bridge here. For Mr. Rivas, who has a wife and two children in El Salvador, the job is no different from that of a long-haul trucker. For Mr. Pineda, who has a green card and has driven for nearly six years, the hope is to continue until he can become a United States citizen and bring his family here.
"America," he said, his crumbling pickup groaning under the weight of so much secondhand treasure, "it's marvelous."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Billy Pineda is one of the transmigrantes: Latin Americans who buy vehicles and other used goods in the United States and haul them home for sale. (Brad Doherty for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: CHARITIES; 
Narrowly Drawn Rules Freeze Out Tens of Thousands of Indirect Victims, Report Says

BYLINE:  By STEPHANIE STROM 

 BODY:
Tens of thousands of indirect victims of the terrorist attack on the World Trade Center are struggling to obtain services because of narrowly drawn eligibility requirements for federal money and for the charities set up after Sept. 11, according to a study to be released today by the United Way of New York City.
 These victims, who lost livelihoods rather than loved ones as a result of the attack, even though they did not work in the immediate area, fail to qualify for help and are losing homes, health insurance and peace of mind, the study says. This has put further strains on the city's nonprofit service providers. 
 "The ripple effect on the economy has been much greater than just south of Canal Street," said Lawrence Mandell, executive vice president of the United Way of New York City. 
The increased demand for charitable services from those who fail to meet the eligibility guidelines established by the federal government and various charitable funds set up since the attack comes at a time when city and state financing for nonprofit programs is falling.
"Food pantries are reporting huge increases in the number of people coming in," said Lilliam Barrios-Paoli, chief executive for agency services at the United Way. "Evictions are on the rise, and so is the demand for shelter."
About $2 billion flowed into the various charities set up to address the immediate victims -- or those who lost a relative or who worked in the area below Canal Street and lost jobs -- and roughly half the money has been disbursed.
Using that money for anyone other than those directly affected is difficult because it would run counter to the intentions of the donors.
The American Red Cross was widely criticized for saying it would hold back some of the donations it received for Sept. 11 victims as a reserve fund for future disasters. Although that is standard procedure among disaster relief agencies, the fuss made other charities cautious about the way they disbursed funds earmarked for Sept. 11.
"The Sept. 11 charities, including our own Sept. 11 Fund, are focused on the area below Canal Street, where the victims were most directly affected," Mr. Mandell said, referring to the fund the United Way administers jointly with the New York Community Trust. "Those funds need to be very concerned about donor intent."
The report, compiled by Appleseed, a consulting firm that specializes in nonprofits, public agencies and corporations, estimates that the attacks eliminated 110,000 jobs, either directly in the area around the World Trade Center or indirectly as a result of a drop in tourism that affected workers in hotels, restaurants, garages and the airline industry.
For instance, about 9,000 people in aviation lost jobs last fall, but because most of them worked in Queens, they are not eligible for assistance. 
Similarly, people who lost jobs in hotels below Canal Street can receive assistance, but hotel workers who lost jobs in Midtown when tourism dropped after the attacks cannot.
Reductions in work hours have reduced wages for an even greater number of people since the attacks, and those cutbacks can mean the difference between being able to pay rent and becoming homeless.
A worker making $400 a week whose income drops to $200, whether because of unemployment or because his hours were cut, is not likely to be able to pay his rent. 
Many organizations, like the Brooklyn Bureau of Community Services and the UJA-Federation, have stepped in with short-term assistance, using money provided by foundations and other donors.
Workers who lose jobs can also apply for unemployment insurance.
In many cases, those short-term programs are already running out, the report found. "Unemployment is running out, and we can see it," Ms. Barrios-Paoli said. "Now people are having to turn to the traditional sources people go to when they are in dire straits, and we may very well see a spike in the number of people going to welfare for the first time."
Finding money to address the needs of indirect victims of the attacks will not be easy. Government budgets are under pressure, donors have already contributed vast amounts of money for those directly hit by the attacks, and many traditional donors, be they institutions or individuals, have themselves been hit by the weak economy.
The United Way is hoping, however, that it can help its various affiliated agencies to help their clients tap existing programs more effectively. By one estimate, for instance, some 900,000 New Yorkers are eligible for food stamps but are not enrolled in the program, and only 3 percent of the low-income families eligible for the earned income tax credit actually take it.
"We don't fully utilize all of the funding streams that are available," Ms. Barrios-Paoli said. "Just figuring out ways to help people tap those would make a huge difference."

HEADLINE: Heard on the Fairway: The Whisper of Shorter Hems 

BYLINE:  By GINIA BELLAFANTE 

 BODY:
Six months ago, Dara O'Hara, a sales associate at Sotheby's, decided she wanted to go to golf school. She had in mind the intensive three-day clinic offered by the P.G.A. National academy in Palm Beach Gardens, Fla., and she sent e-mails to a few friends, also serious golfers, to see who might want to join her. Before long, she found herself spearheading a trip for a group of 19 -- all women and most of them an enviable distance from middle age. 
 The friends made their pilgrimage to Florida last weekend, dividing into threes for instruction with different pros. "There were two high-profile Wall Street executives among us," Melissa Barrett Rhodes, one of the participants, said. "At one point, there were two conference calls going on at once." So Ms. Barrett Rhodes, a former editor at Harper's Bazaar who now works at the Fabien Baron design firm, was stunned when an older pro announced that he was glad so many women have picked up the game because, he said, "it has showed their husbands they can really do something." 
 No other game, as John Updike once wrote, is as thoroughly associated with capitalism and its oppression as golf. Five million women are playing golf in the United States today, and it is fair to say that many bump up against a fairway culture that at times still seems under the influence of a very patrician Archie Bunker. It is also fair to suggest that golf's sex wars are being fought most visibly through fashion.
Whether a delayed reaction to the glamour-positive thinking of postfeminism or merely a concession to the fact that sex sells, some women on the pro tour are turning up dressed in a manner one does not equate with a sport that has typically encouraged women to look like home economics teachers. Just last week, Sports Illustrated profiled Natalie Gulbis, who, in her first year on the tour, has shown up in skirts not much longer than those worn by figure skaters. Her excursions in style have brought her a good deal of attention and led the magazine to dub her golf's It Girl, and the sport's potential Anna Kournikova. Ms. Gulbis also signed with William Morris and specifically with Norman Brokaw, the agent who once represented Marilyn Monroe.
Last year, the Swedish golfer Catrin Nilsmark, who is outfitted by the designer Johan Lindeberg, sparked considerable debate when she arrived to compete in tight-fitting shorts about the size of a compact disc.
The attention does not come as unwelcome for Ty Votaw, the commissioner of the L.P.G.A., who last month held a three-day summit in which he laid out his plan for elevating the celebrity level of women golfers. He came under some criticism in the sports press for suggesting that players consider looking better. 
"I want our players to be fashion forward," Mr. Votaw said. "I want the fans to find our players aspirational. No one seems to remember that Nancy Lopez was wearing pretty short shorts." He was referring, of course, to the most popular player in L.P.G.A. history.
Mr. Votaw said that the L.P.G.A. regularly receives e-mail from golfers habituated to the rules of private clubs who disapprove of what some pros have been wearing. But as Mr. Votaw put it, "we're not looking at halter tops here."
He certainly has a point. What is understood as risque in the world of the long iron might easily pass for churchwear by stylistic disciples of Britney Spears. But one must consider the typically stringent dress codes to which many elite clubs still subject members of both sexes. At Winged Foot, the fabled golf club in Westchester County, N.Y., for example, men are still prohibited from wearing shorts. "I remember saying to Sylvester Stallone or George Stephanopoulos," Colin Burns, the club's golf director, recalled, " 'maybe your host didn't tell you, but shirts have to be tucked in here.' "
Generally, women at private clubs are prohibited from wearing shirts that are both collarless and sleeveless, a rule intended to discourage the tank top. Shorts and skirts must rest no higher than four inches above the knee, but often they are worn just at the knee. Of course, such a look is dramatically less rigid than the ankle-length skirts and twin sets worn by women in the 50's and 60's, and interpreted memorably by Katharine Hepburn in "Pat and Mike."
"Club pros are supposed to emulate the guys on the tour," Kim Grahn, the assistant pro at John's Island, an old guard country club in Vero Beach, Fla., observed. "But we can't emulate the girls on the tour because if I did, I couldn't work here."
At the same time, what is available to women golfers, fashionwise, has never been so expansive. Armani, Prada, Tommy Hilfiger, Burberry and Escada have all begun to offer golf clothes that veer from the formula of pleated shorts that are roomy enough for two. Ralph Lauren has had a successful line for more than 10 years. Two months ago, because of the growth in the business, a company spokeswoman said, Ralph Lauren signed its first L.P.G.A. pro to a sponsorship, Carin Koch of Sweden. Last year, Patty Woo, a young woman who gave up a banking career at Goldman Sachs, entered the fray with a line of flat-front shorts and tops that to some eyes might seem provocatively well-fitting.
And the magazine Golf for Women recently hired a fashion director. The fashion spreads have women cavorting about in gingham wrap dresses and cotton miniskirts. "I was down at the Masters," Susan K. Reed, the editor in chief, said, "and some women were telling me how much they appreciate the fashion in the magazine and love the clothes. But they said, 'We could never wear that at our clubs,' and I said, 'Well, petition them!' "
Analogous to going braless in 1967, it may not be, but some women are beginning to break the rules. Ms. Barrett Rhodes said that a few of the friends with whom she attended golf school alighted on the green in tiny Lilly Pulitzer shorts or skirts equally rebellious. "It's the same idea as wearing a stiletto," she explained. "In the right context, it's empowering."
