HEADLINE: THE FRENCH SURPRISE: THE SHOCK; 
French Political Leaders Rally Around Chirac

BYLINE:  By SUZANNE DALEY 

DATELINE: PARIS, April 22 

 BODY:
French political leaders buried their differences today in a bid to present a united front against Jean-Marie Le Pen, the rightist leader whose qualification for the second round of the presidential election has convulsed the country.
 Dominique Strauss-Kahn, a Socialist and former finance minister, said he would support the conservative president, Jacques Chirac, in the second round because "It is the honor of our country that is at stake." 
 But Mr. Le Pen immediately demonstrated a shrewd appreciation of the forces that brought him success. He declared that he was "the candidate of the French people against the candidate of the system." He added, "We are witnessing the toppling of a decadent, corrupt and ossified political system." 
French politics have proved extraordinarily static in recent years even as the country has changed. There is little question that the prospect of more of the same led the French electorate to vote for Mr. Le Pen and relegate Lionel Jospin, the Socialist prime minister, to third place and elimination.
"This vote is the first to sanction the political class for not listening," said Laurence Parisot, of the IFOP polling institute.
Mr. Le Pen's success pointed to significant shifts in the French and European political scenes that suggest it would be wrong to dismiss his qualification for the second round as a mere anomaly, analysts and pollsters said.
Across Europe, several trends have buoyed candidates of the right: a strong reaction to rising crime in the form of a call for more "law and order," a growing uneasiness over high immigration, and a thirst for a different message among voters who feel that traditional parties have moved toward an indistinguishable center. "Anyone who speaks out against excessive and uncontrolled immigration or the abuse of asylum laws in the context of center-right politics is immediately branded an extremist," said Jorg Haider, the Austrian politician whose success provoked French ire two years ago. "But as time goes on, citizens are not putting up with this anymore."
Mr. Le Pen, a former paratrooper who has run for president three times before and has always been popular with the elderly, gained support across the country and with all age groups, particularly among low-income voters who had supported the Communist Party in the past.
He carried several regions in the industrial north, eastern parts of the country where unemployment is relatively high and the southern region of Languedoc-Roussillon. Mr. Chirac carried the center and west of the country, including Paris. Signs of shame were everywhere in France today. "NO" was the headline on the front page of the leftist newspaper Liberation, a terse summary of the widespread incredulity that a man whose politics have been consistently marked by anti-immigrant bigotry could do so so well.
Like the United States, France feels that its values hold a universal message for mankind. It has been quick in recent years to hand out moral lessons to other European nations, like Austria, that have voted heavily for rightist candidates, making its sense of humiliation today that much harder to bear.
Le Monde published a column entitled simply "The Wound." Written by its publisher, Jean-Marie Colombani, it said: "France is wounded. And, for many of the French, humiliated."
High school students marched out of classrooms in Lyon, Strasbourg, Reims, Rouen, Angers and Besancon to hold rallies against Mr. Le Pen, chanting slogans equating him with Hitler and calling his National Front a fascist organization. Tonight, police officers fired tear gas at anti-Le Pen protesters throwing homemade gasoline bombs in central Paris. 
Absolute strangers debated the results in the subways and around newspaper kiosks, stunned that the Socialist Party, which had governed the country for nearly five years, had been eliminated from the presidential race for the first time in decades.
Mr. Le Pen's supporters pledged today to hold a rally on May 1. Unimpressed by the breadth of the opposition lining up against him and snap polls that showed Jacques Chirac, the center-right president, likely to win by a landslide, Mr. Le Pen, 73, went to his Paris headquarters today, cheerfully telling reporters that he was just getting started.
He called on voters who abstained in the first round to vote for him on May 5. "The people of France have decided to use their power to shake up the current system," Mr. Le Pen said. "If you are disheartened, you have the chance to say what you think by voting for me, with your head high and hands clean. 
Bruno Jeanbart, a director at the C.S.A. polling institute, said there was a certain logic to the result because the French did not want to see another race between Mr. Chirac and Mr. Jospin, the Socialist leader, who have ruled for seven and five years respectively as president and prime minister. The two men contested the final round of the 1995 presidential election.
"Overall, the Sunday vote was a protest vote by people who have felt overlooked and forgotten by the system," Mr. Jeanbart said.
Final results of the vote showed that Mr. Le Pen had benefited from a large field of candidates that splintered the vote. With many of the center-left believing that Mr. Jospin's qualification was assured, they voted instead for ecologists or other candidates only to discover that they had contributed to the total eclipse of the French left.
Today, more than one French citizen who decided to skip the voting booth and go for a walk on a warm spring day rued his decision. "The weather was nice" said Benoit Marc, 19, who never got around to casting his ballot. "But yes, I will vote in the second round. The National Front in power? No!"
Some who voted for Mr. Le Pen said they had made their point and would now vote for Mr. Chirac. Camille de Barmon, 20, who sells expensive children's clothes on the Rue de la Paix, said she had voted for Mr. Le Pen to signal her concern about crime. But she never imagined he would beat out Mr. Jospin. 
She said she would not vote for the National Front again. "Le Pen is too excessive and I don't know his policies well," she said. 
With the highest rate of abstention France has ever seen, Mr. Chirac got 19.67 percent of the vote, Mr. Le Pen 17.02 percent and Mr. Jospin trailed with 16.07 percent. 
France's political establishment, so often criticized as slow to change and out of touch, seemed suddenly in the process of being remade. Everywhere there was a sense that the first round vote had catapulted France into a new political era. After months of total indifference to the presidential elections, it was the subject of almost every conversation.
"Even if there is no doubt about the outcome of the run off, and it is already clear that Mr. Chirac will be returned to the Elysee, " said Pierre-Luc Seguillon, an editorialist at the 24-hour news channel LCI, "it is nevertheless also clear that an era of great uncertainty, turbulence, deep political upheaval and institutional change is ahead."
Most immediately, that turbulence will affect the French left. Mr. Jospin announced Sunday night that he would retire as Socialist Party leader and prime minister after second round of voting next month. Today, the Socialists chose the party's secretary, Francois Hollande, to lead its efforts in the legislative elections in June.
The Socialists are in an awkward position. They have now pledged to support Mr. Chirac for the presidency in order to defeat the extreme right. But then within a few weeks they will try to defeat his Gaullist party in the legislative elections.
A lot is at stake in those elections. A French president with the backing of the legislature is extremely powerful. But if the legislature is in the control of another party, the president's powers are severely compromised, as the Gaullist Mr. Chirac has found in trying to govern with Mr. Jospin.
Mr. Chirac huddled today with defeated candidates from other center-right parties to discuss how his campaign should go forward from here. His aides appeared to back away from an earlier suggestion that Mr. Chirac would debate Mr. Le Pen, who is a fiery and sometimes unpredictable orator.
In a debate, Mr. Chirac, 69, who has faced several charges of corruption relating to his time in office as the mayor of Paris, could be exposed to accusations of dishonesty. On the other hand, a decision to refuse to debate Mr. Le Pen in the two weeks before the May 5 runoff could look like weakness.
In the last few years, France has been changing rapidly. After years of high unemployment, the late 1990's brought a a more successful economy and high-flying French executives with global outlooks to go with it. 
But in recent months, unemployment started creeping up again after a long period of decline, providing Mr. Le Pen with more ammunition for his anti-immigrant message.
In almost every sector of society, the French embraced new ideas. But the political establishment remained virtually unchanged. Both Mr. Chirac and Mr. Jospin had been in the forefront of French politics for three decades.
Polls showed that the French were bored and increasingly alienated from their politicians, most of whom are graduates from the same elite schools. In breaking into the race, it appears that Mr. Le Pen will have a powerful effect on the political scene whether he wins or not.
The message seems clear: France does not want an unchanging political class.

What Le Pen Wants to Do
These are changes that Jean-Marie Le Pen would seek to make if elected president of France, according to his campaign web site, www.lepen.tv: 
Outlaw abortion and end official recognition of same-sex unions.
Develop programs to increase the birth rate and pay benefits to women who stay at home with their children.
End legal immigration.
Deport illegal immigrants and eliminate dual nationality. 
Give French citizens priority for all jobs and public housing; create a separate medical benefits system for foreigners working in France, so that French tax money would not be used for foreigners' care.
Allow only French citizens to teach in French schools.
Reinstitute morality classes; require student participation in patriotic events and holidays.
Outlaw the wearing of yarmulkes and Muslim headscarves in schools.
Create 200,000 new prison beds.
Expand and give new rights to the police force.

HEADLINE: Even After Tremors of Sept. 11, Ambitious Building Plans Proceed 

BYLINE:  By BARBARA WHITAKER

 BODY:
IN the wake of Sept. 11, the Los Angeles County Museum of Art set aside plans to announce a sweeping expansion of its space. The Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, did the same.
 But fears were allayed that such postponements might signal a slowdown in what is one of the most ambitious building booms ever at museums nationwide. Both the Los Angeles and Boston museums have since unveiled architecturally significant projects. 
"A museum like ours isn't about a single time in an economic cycle -- it's about collections that represent all time," said Andrea Rich, the president and director at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art, explaining the decision to move forward with a design for essentially a new building by the Dutch architect Rem Koolhaas (despite its $200 million estimated cost and another $100 million to be raised for an endowment). "At any point you could be in an economic boom or bust."
Attendance dropped at museums with heavy tourist traffic in the months after Sept. 11. Cutbacks in public financing led to layoffs at numerous museums, many in New York. Nonetheless, building projects are showing resilience. Dozens of proposed museum expansions, from San Francisco to Kansas City to Tampa, Fla., are going ahead. 
A January survey by the Association of Art Museum Directors examining the status of these projects found that only about a third of the museums were slowing down or scaling back their plans; only one museum dropped an expansion project.
"It only surprised me because one read such dire predictions after Sept. 11," said James Cuno, the president of the association and the director of the Harvard University Art Museums. "But when one thought about it for a while, it wasn't surprising because building projects are always very long-term projects."
It is not uncommon for a project -- from the planning and analysis through the construction -- to span a decade.
"In a sense, there isn't a wrong time," said Malcolm Rogers, the director of the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, where officials are embarking on a $425 million capital campaign. "Just as in the stock market, you can't time the market. A campaign has to begin somewhere."
The lengthy time frame also benefits projects like the one at the Peabody Essex Museum in Salem, Mass., which before Sept. 11 had raised $90 million to finance an expansion project. After Sept. 11, the museum went into a planning phase for its fund-raising push this spring, so the timing helped it avoid having to contend with the poor economy.
Still, the current situation calls for caution and rethinking of plans. The most precarious projects are possibly ones that rely heavily on public financing. Budget cuts by the Department of Cultural Affairs in New York might play havoc with projects at a number of museums, including the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Queens Museum of Art. The picture is more complicated for projects that rely on private giving. Donations are healthy, but revenues from, say, sales subscriptions and services are suffering at some museums.
"I think there is a concern about protecting the normal operating budget and the normal side of the museum's life," said H. King McGlaughon, the director of the Merrill Lynch Center for Philanthropy and Nonprofit Management.
While capital campaigns are separate from operating budgets, they do affect each other, said Mr. McGlaughon, whose center works with about 35,000 nonprofit organizations, about 3,500 of which are museums. 
Harry S. Parker III, the director of the Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco, the city's largest public art institution, acknowledged that strain in discussing plans to build the M. H. de Young Memorial Museum in Golden Gate Park.
"We really are trying very hard not to let the two get entwined, but it's difficult," said Mr. Parker, whose group has made 15 percent budget cuts, mainly through attrition. "It's challenging; you have staff saying, 'How can we afford to start a construction project if we can't replace my secretary when she goes on maternity leave?' "
Yet private donors are enthusiastic about the $165 million de Young project. Of the $154 million raised so far, $100 million has come from 35 individual donors. "I would say if you go out to raise private funds, you need to have some very rich friends," Mr. Parker said.
Rich benefactors are behind many of the proposed expansions. At the Denver Art Museum, a $62.5 million bond initiative will finance construction of an addition that will almost double the museum's space. But an additional $50 million for the museum's endowment was raised by 36 members of the board of trustees.
"I think it's the commitment that these individuals have to the community," said Lewis Sharp, the director of the Denver Art Museum. "When you have something as horrific as Sept. 11, it causes some people to go back and look at core values and what is important to the community."
Cities are increasingly turning to their museums to bolster civic pride. The Milwaukee Art Museum recently opened a new addition designed by Santiago Calatrava, an architect, featuring a 200-foot sunscreen. The Nelson-Atkins Museum of Art in Kansas City, Mo., broke ground last year for an addition aiming to, as the museum said in a statement, "expand and enhance every facet of its programming in the next decade."
In Boston, officials at the Museum of Fine Arts would not say how much money they have raised, but Mr. Rogers, the museum's director, said that the museum was "on track." He anticipated some delays, he said, between the time when financial pledges are made and when money was made available.
"In general, people will be making pledges to a campaign but will want to see some of their stocks increase before they hand over the cash," he said.
But as Ms. Rich in Los Angeles said: "There are good times and bad times. You just begin to plan for a sort of essentially normal future and you just keep putting one foot in front of the other."

HEADLINE: Pooling Their Resources For a Place in the Sun 

BYLINE:  By ANDREA ADELSON

DATELINE: LAGUNA BEACH, Calif. 

 BODY:
HOLLYWOOD, Disneyland, the sun and the surf. With all this, how can museums in Southern California compete for the public's attention? 
 The answer is, they must work together. Twenty museums, large and small, like the J. Paul Getty Museum and the Laguna Art Museum, have set aside their rivalries and, for the last year, have cooperated in marketing their exhibitions and institutions. 
 "We're in competition with movies, TV, the beach and amusement parks for leisure dollars," said Mark A. Thie, the marketing manager for the Los Angeles County Museum of Art, which is near downtown Los Angeles. "We need to promote ourselves like any business."
The group has sponsored newspaper advertisements -- which the nine smaller institutions could not have afforded individually -- that celebrate the museums' role in the region's cultural landscape. For instance, a full-page ad on Oct. 24 in The Los Angeles Times read, "We share a vision to inspire and, at times like these, heal and fortify the human spirit." 
"Together, we make more of an impact," said Evelyn C. Davis, the marketing director of the Autry Museum of Western Heritage, which is near the Burbank-Glendale city limits. "There's more culture here than we're given credit for."
Traditionally, Los Angeles and Orange County museums have been reluctant to share resources or advertise together; they have always viewed their collections as specialized and their audiences as distinctive. But research by the Los Angeles County Museum of Art found that museumgoers were not institutionally loyal, that they avidly sampled many different kinds of collections.
"We realize we are all seeking the same things and the same audience," said Susan M. Metcalf, the communications manager for the Bowers Museum of Cultural Art in Santa Ana. "Why not share this audience and inspire it to go to museums in general, rather than divide it?"
The marketing campaign has yielded some unexpected alliances. The Autry Museum, established by the singing-cowboy Gene Autry, is promoting an exhibition at the Museum of Latin American Art in Long Beach on silver-hammered tack used by Mexico's show cowboys, the charrerias.
To promote its June exhibition of Jewish life in the American West, the Autry is considering granting reciprocal membership to members of the Skirball Cultural Center in Los Angeles, which specializes in Jewish culture. The center has also decided to supplement the Autry show by arranging its own exhibition on Jewish pioneer women. 
Such alliances would have been unthinkable a year ago.
While museum financial officers and bookstore operators in Los Angeles and Orange County have long had their own networking groups, there was no established group for museum marketers.
The group's leader is Carol Komatsuka, the marketing vice president of the Japanese American National Museum in downtown Los Angeles. Like most of her peers, Ms. Komatsuka worked in corporate marketing before shifting to the nonprofit sector. But she found that museums were not adequately addressing Southern California's particular cultural challenges, like urban sprawl and a surging immigrant population. The first round table, held last May, included marketing directors from 15 museums. It met with such collegial enthusiasm that she realized there were other museum marketing professionals who, like her, also wanted to share and gain experiences.
Museums elsewhere in the United States may soon be forced to create similar networks. With reduced government financing and declining income from endowments, many museums are squeezing their budgets. The American Association of Museums has urged its members to form alliances, but only a few have done so.
In 1992, nine cultural institutions in Chicago created a consortium called Museums in the Park. The group has hired a lobbyist, Jacqueline Atkins, to emphasize with local lawmakers the museums' economic value to the region. (Government financing to the museums amounts to 18 percent of their budgets.) "It sounds so logical, but it hasn't been part of the museum world," Ms. Atkins said, referring to the lobbying. In 1998, seven institutions in Richmond, Va., established Museums on the Boulevard; one project is to press city officials to redesign an unattractive freeway exit that acts as a gateway to the museum district.
Museums in Los Angeles are busy thinking of new ways to work together. They are granting free admission to employees of other museums, and plan to link Web sites.
All this sharing and collaborating is eroding the stereotype that Southern California is a cultural wasteland. The area's nine most popular visual arts sites drew 4.2 million visitors in 2000, according to the American Association of Museums' fact book. That figure exceeds attendance at the Dodgers home games that year, which was about three million, according to a Dodgers spokeswoman.
Banding together has made the museums stronger, marketing directors say, especially when the marketing resources of one competitor -- Hollywood -- are considered.
"What a studio spends on one movie," Mr. Thie said, "we spend in six years."

HEADLINE: COLLABORATION; 
Getting Liberace And Jimi in Tune

BYLINE:  By BEN SISARIO 

 BODY:
IN the beginning there was country music. The Country Music Hall of Fame, that is, founded in 1967. It is one of the first museums ever devoted to American music, and to the proud culture of personalities and artifacts surrounding it. Long before eBay, the Country Music Hall of Fame was busy acquiring guitars, costumes and Willie Nelson's sneakers. (They're New Balance, displayed proudly in a glass case.)
 Then came the Rock 'n' Roll Hall of Fame, which began inducting members in 1986 and opened to the public nine years later in a gleaming $26 million I. M. Pei pyramid on the shores of Lake Erie in Cleveland. 
 Since then, dozens of music museums have been founded, following their predecessors' lead in canonizing American music. The Experience Music Project, a high-tech museum and archive founded by the Microsoft billionaire Paul Allen, opened in Seattle in 2000 at an expense of $240 million. In Memphis, Soulsville Inc., broke ground on the $20 million Stax Museum of American Soul Music in 1999. The Country Music Hall of Fame itself spent $37 million on a new home in downtown Nashville. It opened in 2001.
The United States has not experienced a museum boom like this since the growth of fine art museums at the turn of the last century. 
"Now the same thing is happening for popular music," said Robert Santelli, the director of the Experience Music Project and a former manager of education and public programs at the Rock 'n' Roll Hall of Fame. "America has come to grips with its rich popular music legacy. Now is the time to preserve it."
As a movement though, the museums are struggling to define themselves. Three years ago, while still in Cleveland, Mr. Santelli started an informal meeting with the representatives of other music museums, to share information and ideas. 
Art museums have long had an extensive connecting network, including groups like the Association of Art Museum Directors and the Association of American Art Museums, an umbrella group that includes history museums and natural history sites as well as art museums. Now, the music museums are trying to organize a similar network. Next month the Experience Music Project plans to announce the Music Museum Alliance, a consortium of more than 40 institutions in the United States and Canada that will meet regularly and have a formal mission statement to share exhibitions and materials, seek strategies for financing and attracting visitors and promote the group's common cause. 
The alliance is a motley assortment of museums, including big institutions like the Experience Music Project, the Library of Congress and the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts, and an array of small, specific museums and shrines that read like the random assortment of posters at a record store: the Buddy Holly Center, the Grateful Dead Museum, the Liberace Museum, the International Bluegrass Music Museum and the Monterey Jazz Museum. There are also music industry organizations like the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences.
Some of the museums in the alliance, like the Folk Music Museum in Greenwich Village, do not yet exist. It was conceived in 2000 by a group of folk music veterans in New York City and is still searching for a home and adequate funds.
Art D'Lugoff, who owned the Village Gate club in New York and is the president of the Folk Music Museum, said the alliance was needed both as a source for mutual support and as an informal lobbying group. "It's a chance to communicate with one another," he said. "If something important happens in the government agencies, we have a chance to lobby and fight for what we think is in our best interest."
Mr. Santelli and his associates say that all the museums, large and small, face common problems of attracting audiences and money and presenting their collections.
One very current problem has been the drop in revenue that most music museums, like other museums, have faced since the economic boom ended. Even the richest museums have tightened their belts -- the Experience Music Project laid off 124 employees in January to counteract a 35 percent drop in attendance.
But some issues are more specific to the field, like the rapidly changing nature of popular music, the focus of most of the newer music museums. "We're dealing with extremely current subject matter," said Diana Johnson, a senior vice president for museum services at the Country Music Hall of Fame. "In this business, history is made yesterday."
Bill Ivey, a former chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts and director of the Country Music Foundation who is the current Branscomb Scholar at Vanderbilt University in Nashville, thinks that the preservers of popular culture could benefit by making their scope even broader. 
"The same issues cut across broad range of cultural institutions, outside of just music," he said. "The Museum of Television and Radio in New York, the American Film Institute in Los Angeles -- they should all be brought into the mix. They are the caretakers of American popular culture heritage, and it's important for them to start talking to each other."

HEADLINE: BEHIND THE SCENES; 
Independent Curators: Have Art, Will Travel

BYLINE:  By MELISSA MILGROM 

 BODY:
FOR Jade Dellinger, working as an independent curator -- without formal ties to a single institution -- is a matter of freedom. "I'm interested in creating the most appropriate context" for a particular artist, he said, "without any particular allegiance to a museum or regard for the way institutions usually do things."
 When Peter Doroshenko became the founding director of the Institute of Visual Arts in Milwaukee, working with independent curators was a matter of necessity. How else could he attract -- or afford -- to bring in curators with their fingers on the pulse of the global contemporary art scene? 
 For Harold Koda, the director of the Costume Institute of the Metropolitan Museum of Art in Manhattan, independent curators are a strategy. To curate, for example, a future exhibition on the Hollywood designer Gilbert Adrian, Mr. Koda chose Jane Trapnell Marino, a costume designer for films and television whose singular passion for Mr. Adrian's work has made her an authority on the subject. "It would be hubris for me to say I know more about Adrian than she does," Mr. Koda said. "I'd just be citing her work. Why don't I go to the expert?" 
These reasons and more -- including, not insignificantly, that this expertise comes at fairly low rates -- have whittled away at the notion that curators fit within museums as cozily as tenured professors fit into universities. In fact, Paul Schimmel, the chief curator at the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles, said at a symposium that recent developments had "blown apart" the standard American definition of what a curator is.
"The most important change in curatorial practice today," he said, is "the role of the independent curator -- a kind of journeyman curator or wandering global nomad" who does not have the shell of a museum for protection.
According to Amada Cruz, the director of the Center for Curatorial Studies at Bard College, curators often function like producers these days. As the mix of talents that are required to make a successful show have changed, curators are no longer judged solely by their scholarly background. Possibilities have opened for movement between fields. 
In Europe, the practice of hiring curators who are not contractually bound to an institution has been common for a while.
In the last decade or so, big American museums have begun to hire consultants to organize shows. The Museum of Modern Art's exhibition "High and Low" was co-curated by Adam Gopnik, a New Yorker magazine writer. "Jacqueline Kennedy: The White House Years" was curated by Hamish Bowles, an editor at Vogue, and the Brooklyn Art Museum's "Hip-Hop Nation: Roots, Rhymes and Rage" was curated by Kevin Powell, an authority on contemporary music.
WITHIN the top levels of museums, exhibitions by celebrity curators generate a buzz that keeps their profile high. Across the country, especially as the economic downturn has hit home, many smaller and midsize museums have found independently curated shows, many of them traveling exhibitions, increasingly attractive.
These factors have prompted big concerns over the rise of independent curators -- whether museums are opening up for the wrong reasons. After all, the backbone of every museum is its program and collection, critics say.
"Curators who are attached to institutions are the defenders of their mission," said Kirk Varnedoe, the former chief curator at the Museum of Modern Art, who has organized shows independently and as a staff member. "If they are relegated to doing grunt work because their institution has bought into these big coteries of floating art stars who go from biennial to art fair, that's an unhealthy sign." 
Mr. Doroshenko, the director of the Visual Arts Institute at the University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee, shares some of these concerns, which is why he sought to combine the fresh views of outsiders with continuity. In lieu of a full-time staff, he hired an international team of floating adjuncts from Paris, Mexico City, Tijuana, Munich and San Juan, P.R. Their work will be folded into the institute's continuing mix rather than be engaged for a single show.
There is a danger to the approach, Mr. Doroshenko said. "A lot of my colleagues have noticed the success of my model and have begun hiring freelancers without benefits only to reduce costs," he said, "which I think is the biggest mistake in the world."
Other museums are taking half-steps into the independent-curating world. The Los Angeles Museum of Contemporary Art, for instance, established a permanent, revolving position solely for outside curators, artists and scholars; the museum also built a warehouse annex that artists can freely dismantle to accommodate their work. Chicago's Museum of Contemporary Art has allowed its senior curator, Francesco Bonami, to organize outside shows independently. He was just appointed the 2003 director of the Venice Biennale, a title that will bring cachet and, hopefully, adventurous new ideas to the Chicago museum without the inherent risk and cost of staging an experimental show itself.
Another way museums fill in gaps is by renting traveling shows. Enter Independent Curators International, a nonprofit organization that for 26 years has sold entire exhibitions -- research, execution, shipping, catalog -- to leading museums. The shows are selected from proposals (most pitched by independent curators) and are chosen based on the ideas presented, regardless of financing. 
The organization recently staged "Lee Krasner" at the Brooklyn Museum of Art and "Beyond Preconceptions" at the National Gallery in Prague, a show that rents for 10 weeks for $15,000. The shows range from $7,500 to $30,000. 
Although the organization provides access to challenging or avant-garde work that a staff curator might not have known about, the surge in demand for traveling shows is more directly related to the state of the economy -- museums need inexpensive, provocative exhibitions. Traveling shows, in general, are far less expensive to stage than exhibitions that are organized in-house, said Carin Kuoni, the director of exhibitions at Independent Curators. While the company provides a complete package, she said, it encourages a museum's own curators to reshape the show by adding new works or by changing the context to suit their local community.
The attraction of being an independent curator depends on which end of the field is discussed. Hou Hanru, a leading independent curator from China, lives in Paris, is an adviser to the Rijksakademie van Beeldende Kunsten in Amsterdam and has curated more than 30 shows throughout the world. Okwui Enwezor, a Nigerian-born critic and poet based in New York, is this year's artistic director of Documenta, a show in Kassel, Germany, that has always signaled important changes in the art world.
TO prepare for Documenta, Mr. Enwezor traveled to the far-flung corners of the world -- Senegal, Malaysia, Mali, Nigeria, China, Jamaica, Mexico and elsewhere. And Hans-Ulrich Obrist, the curator for Musee d'Art Moderne de la Ville de Paris, uses the museum as a base for collaborations with scientists, architects and other nonmuseum professionals that result in traveling exhibitions in places like airplanes and opera houses. A maverick with feet in both camps, he regards a museum as a time capsule and as a laboratory. "For me it's always working on the inside and the outside," he says. "If you are only flying in and flying out, the continuity doesn't develop." 
At the other end of the independent-curating field are people like David Pagel, a freelance art critic who writes for The Los Angeles Times. He works on a handful of shows each year. "The most I've ever gotten from a show is $5,000; it probably came out to 50 cents an hour," he said. "It's very seat-of-your-pants living." 
For Mr. Dellinger, another independent curator, the real payoff is freedom. With no desk to tend, he can travel in search of new artists. And with no fixed point of view to represent, he can "be more responsive to the needs and desires of artists with whom I choose to work," he said.
Mr. Dellinger thinks that it is helpful for museums to let in outsiders. "I strongly believe cross-pollination is critical for the survival of museums," he said. 
Not surprisingly, some of the greatest apprehension about the trend emanates from staff curators. Because they get a chance to stage only one show every two or three years, they may be understandably reluctant to give their slots away. "I don't bring in outside curators because I have so many ideas and so little time and space on the schedule," says Paola Antonelli, the curator for design and architecture at the Museum of Modern Art. "Frankly, I want to do it all.
"I collaborate a lot," Ms. Antonelli said, "but I like to be the director of the movie."

HEADLINE: After Years of Vamping, a Jazz Museum Gets Ready for Harlem 

BYLINE:  By LEONARD GARMENT; Leonard Garment, counsel to President Richard M. Nixon, is president of the National Jazz Museum. His memoir, "Crazy Rhythm," was recently released in paperback.

 BODY:
WATCH a jazz group gather on a bandstand. The pianist plays some introductory chords, then repeats them. The other musicians talk, joke, trade suggestions about tunes and tempo and play seemingly random riffs. Finally, to the relief of the audience, they begin. "Vamp till ready" is music-business jargon for this Zen-like ritual of marking time until performance overtakes preparation. The phrase applies just as well to the founding of a museum like the one in whose birth I am involved, the National Jazz Museum in Harlem.
 In 1995, Art D'Lugoff, who was closing the Village Gate, his historic Greenwich Village jazz club, suggested the idea of a jazz museum to his friend David Levy, who is director of the Corcoran Gallery of Art in Washington, a sometime saxophonist and a lifelong jazz enthusiast. The two of them enlisted me. Before entering the practice of law, I had spent some time as a jazz musician; my performing career was brief, but my love of jazz proved permanent. Daryl Libow, a Washington lawyer and amateur jazz historian, joined us. We had lots of enthusiasm and no financing. We soon discovered the limitations of the former and the importance of the latter. 
 Some of our early decisions were easy. The most appropriate place for the museum was clearly Harlem, reflecting African-Americans' dominant contribution to the art form. The music in Harlem's clubs and theaters, during and after the Harlem Renaissance, indelibly shaped how jazz entered and informed virtually all American culture. A jazz museum in Harlem would be a companion to the jazz performance space being developed at Lincoln Center.
In those early days we also received some indispensable financial support. Through friends of mine who are involved in antipoverty efforts in Harlem, I met Deborah Wright, who was then the president of the Upper Manhattan Empowerment Zone, Harlem's main development organization. The empowerment zone provided the jazz museum its first funds, a grant of $125,000. That money was matched by the Scheuer Foundation and by Abraham Sofaer, a State Department legal adviser, federal judge and jazz fan.
We had enough money to hire an executive director, who struggled for a year to assemble an organization. We gathered a distinguished board. Jazz historians, archivists, educators and musicians advised on museum structure, themes and exhibitions. We were assured access to the vast jazz collections of the Smithsonian Institution and the Library of Congress. We acquired the help of Wendy Evans Joseph, the architect of the new Women's Museum in Dallas. Design work began for a small experimental building, modeled on the Geffen Contemporary in Los Angeles, where we could test relationships among historic text, live music and technology.
But our inadequacies soon overtook us. To begin with, we were all part timers; our meetings were sporadic and our communications mainly by remote means. We groped to answer basic questions: Who would do preliminary organizing? How would we raise more money? Where would the museum be sited? More important, what was the museum's mission? How could it display and illuminate music, an invisible art form? We properly identified these issues but did not have the expertise to resolve them.
We flailed around for several years, and while we did, the money ran out. We had been awarded a $20,000 grant from the National Endowment for the Arts to be used for planning conferences; but first we needed several hundred thousand dollars to refine and develop our primitive planning. We did not have it. Our executive director departed, sensibly enough, for employment elsewhere. Work came to a halt.
Then in December 2000, Congress produced what it occasionally does: an act of creative generosity. I had tried to interest senators and representatives in the museum, and some responded -- notably, Senators Daniel P. Moynihan of New York and John Warner of Virginia and Representatives Charles B. Rangel of New York and John Conyers Jr. of Michigan. Most unexpected was the crucial concurrence of Senator Ted Stevens of Alaska, at that time the chairman of the Appropriations Committee. It turned out that Mr. Stevens was a jazz fan who, during his years at Harvard, had spent many weekends in the jazz clubs of Manhattan. You never know.
Congress provided $1 million for development of the museum. This kind of largess is not exactly drive-by financing. The money is earmarked within the budget of a federal agency -- in our case, the Small Business Administration -- whose standards the grantee must meet in exacting detail before the money is disbursed. The process pursued by Daryl Libow, with a litigator's tenacity, took us almost a year to complete. 
That is how the museum stayed alive. But the idea gained major impetus from another event, the accelerating momentum of change in Harlem. For years, a new Harlem Renaissance had struggled to be born; it was finally happening.
ON Feb. 10, The New York Times reported on "The Changing Look of the New Harlem." Parcel by parcel, it said, Harlem was finally being remade. The principal actors in this development drama were the empowerment zone and the state Metropolitan Economic Revitalization Fund. Though the organizations' names are less than poetic, the transformation they wrought was dramatic. Indeed, Harlem now faces a new problem: the displacement of small businesses through gentrification.
In this changed urban setting, the jazz museum returned to life like a rim shot. The president of the empowerment zone, Terry C. Lane, is supporting the jazz museum as a natural addition to Harlem's landmark Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture, the expanding Studio Museum, the rebuilt Apollo Theater, a new Museum for African Art and other major cultural establishments. 
Discussions have begun that will allow the museum to have access to major jazz archives, like the Rutgers University archive administered by Dan Morgenstern, the director of the Institute of Jazz Studies there. The museum is also the natural home for a collection of which I am executor, Willis Conover's spectacular Voice of America collection of jazz music and history, which has 6,500 hours of performances and audiotaped interviews with the likes of Duke Ellington, Dizzy Gillespie, Louis Armstrong, Billie Holiday and Ella Fitzgerald. The National Endowment for the Arts has confirmed its planning grant to us; now we have the ability to use it.
Most important, we have a new executive director for the National Jazz Museum, Loren Schoenberg. Mr. Schoenberg has spent a quarter-century playing and conducting jazz, and he has had close associations with eminent musicians ranging from Benny Goodman to Wynton Marsalis. Mr. Marsalis, the artistic director of Jazz at Lincoln Center, has become a friend and supporter of the jazz museum. Mr. Schoenberg's extraordinary range is what we hope to see in the museum: an illumination of jazz as an art form, a teaching instrument, a model of combined discipline and improvisation and a supreme narrative, literary and musical, that has flowed through virtually every capillary of the nation's culture and set the mood for what we Americans think and feel about ourselves.
Much has been done, and more remains to be done, but we have finally reached the end of the beginning. We started with a big idea and no money, and the Harlem community was not ready for a jazz museum. These conditions have changed. So why, after seven years of vamping, is all this suddenly happening? Because, in the words of the 1945 breakthrough modern jazz recording by Charlie Parker and Dizzy Gillespie, "Now's the time!"

HEADLINE: CALIFORNIA; 
San Francisco's Modern: In Search of Stability After a Storm

BYLINE:  By TESSA DeCARLO

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO 

 BODY:
WHAT does it take to make a museum great? In recent years, the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art seemed to have all the right answers.
 Its glamorous new building was a favorite destination as soon as it opened in 1995. Exhibitions won critical raves and visitor numbers soared. Super-rich donors were happy to pay top dollar for acquisitions. David A. Ross, hired away from the Whitney Museum of American Art in New York to become director in 1998, further fanned local excitement and international buzz. 
 But more recently, question marks began to replace exclamation points. The collapse of California's high-technology boom put a squeeze on contributions. Morale sagged and staff members left. Last August, Mr. Ross suddenly resigned. 
Then came Sept. 11. Contributions shrank even further and the number of visitors -- heavily dependent on tourism -- dropped 15 percent. The museum appeared to be searching not only for a director but also for its way.
In many respects, its troubles are like those of art institutions around the country. "Museums fell into a trap in the 1990's, a very pleasant and comfortable trap," said Kent Logan. He and his wife, Vicki, have given some 300 works to the San Francisco museum, where she is a trustee.
"Times were good, benefactors felt generous, and name me one museum that didn't build a new building," Mr. Logan said. "Museums turned into big businesses, but they weren't managed like big businesses."
These days, however, benefactors are not willing to carry institutions that cannot stand on their own. "Museums have to break even," Mr. Logan said, "or close enough to satisfy their boards of trustees."
Locally, the museum's problems not only reflect those of smaller institutions but also affect them directly. "We're seeing a huge retrenchment in exhibition support," said John R. Killacky, the executive director of the publicly financed Yerba Buena Center for the Arts, across from the Museum of Modern Art on Third Street. "SFMOMA has to somehow keep its ambition going with fewer resources. But SFMOMA is the flagship. It's key to the vitality of the arts in San Francisco."
Which is why last month's announcement naming Neal Benezra as the museum's new director was greeted with relief by the arts community here. Currently a curator and deputy director at the Art Institute of Chicago, Mr. Benezra appears to offer everything the San Francisco museum needs: an outstanding art-world reputation, solid managerial skills and plenty of ambition.
"It's great news all around," said Kenneth Baker, the art critic of The San Francisco Chronicle. "There's an impression of rudderlessness one gets from that museum in the last year or more. Neal Benezra will quickly turn that around."
Elaine McKeon, the museum board's chairwoman, was almost giddy in her enthusiasm. "I've never had so many people phone me, send e-mails, even stop me on the street, all to say, 'It's a wonderful decision!' " she said.
While the good times lasted, the San Francisco Modern's rise was spectacular. The museum was founded in 1935 as the first on the West Coast devoted to modern art, but for more than 60 years it was a small-time venue housed in rented quarters on the fourth floor of the War Memorial Veterans Building.
John R. Lane, who became director in 1987, persuaded the museum's trustees to raise $63 million for a new building by the Swiss architect Mario Botta -- at 225,000 square feet one of the largest new art museums in the country. It was a gamble that paid off: the red-brick structure punctuated by a tower with black and white stripes became an instant landmark and inspired plans to take the less-than-stellar permanent collection to the same level of ambition.
The determination to become one of the world's top museums was likewise reflected in the board's decision to hire Mr. Ross after Mr. Lane left in 1997 to become head of the Dallas Museum of Art.
At the Whitney, Mr. Ross was known as a big spender who knew how to inspire art-world excitement, news media interest and generous gifts from the ultrarich. To locals and the global arts community, his arrival in San Francisco signaled that the San Francisco Modern had made it to the big time.
High-tech was pumping money into the Bay Area economy, and wealthy benefactors gladly helped the museum become one of the art world's biggest spenders, acquiring $140 million in art, most of it during Mr. Ross's tenure, ranging from modernist masterpieces to Web projects. 
As curator of painting and sculpture from 1993 to 2000, Gary Garrels helped arrange many of those acquisitions. "Most of the momentum had been building before David Ross arrived," said Mr. Garrels, who left to become chief curator of drawings at the Museum of Modern Art in New York. "He was the lucky surfer who grabbed onto this big wave, but it wasn't a wave that he created."
That wave soon crashed. In August, barely three years after he became director, Mr. Ross resigned. The museum's official statement said only that Mr. Ross's "priorities diverge from those of the museum."
The museum appeared to be doing well. Its 1998 Calder exhibition and the Magritte show in 2000 drew record crowds. In fiscal 2000, the museum welcomed 713,000 visitors, almost three times the number at the old building.
BUT the dot-com collapse brought the recession to the Bay Area early. Insiders said that trustees who were at first thrilled by Mr. Ross's spare-no-expense aggressiveness began to question his management style when the economy cooled. An internal "strategic plan" warned of "burnout and turnover of staff." 
"My approach was, and probably remains, too aggressive for this moment," Mr. Ross said in an interview. "With no apologies, that's who I am. It was a three-year honeymoon followed by a very quick divorce." 
Although The Chronicle called Mr. Ross's resignation 2001's "most unmourned departure," his absence left a vacuum. For example, the museum's current Eva Hesse retrospective, planned during Mr. Ross's tenure, is not receiving as much attention as many people had hoped. "The Hesse show is amazing," said Glen Helfand, a freelance critic. "But the energy around it is much more low-key. David Ross was a money drain, but he was also an energizer, and that loss is very apparent."
After the museum announced more than a dozen layoffs this spring, some feared that the trustees might pick an anti-Ross as their new leader, a bean counter whose only goal would be increasing revenue.
"The museum has to thrive financially," said Jeffrey Fraenkel, who owns a gallery in the city. "But if the director makes the bottom line the primary determinant of the exhibition schedule, that's when the institution suffers."
By appointing Mr. Benezra, the museum signaled that it was sticking to its high-art guns. Along with administrative experience, he has a strong academic record (a doctorate in art history from Stanford) and has been the curator for numerous shows, including retrospectives of Bruce Nauman, Martin Puryear and William Kentridge, favoring critical opinion over mass appeal.
"He knows how to balance art priorities against the bottom line," Mr. Fraenkel said.
Mr. Benezra, who grew up in the Bay Area and first learned about art in the cramped galleries of the old museum, acknowledges that popular shows have to be part of successful programming. But he also relishes the museum's loftier aspirations. "The fact that the museum has such strong ambitions for itself is one of the things that makes it so attractive," he said.
Despite the museum's recent troubles, Mr. Benezra will have plenty to work with when it comes to realizing those ambitions. Within the next five years, the museum plans to expand -- the building was designed to allow construction of nearly 100,000 square feet of additional gallery space -- and add a large sculpture garden on top of its parking garage next door. It is moving ahead with a 7,000-square-foot education center next to the permanent-collection galleries, to serve school groups and adult visitors, as well as expansion of its store.
The museum's endowment is a healthy $63 million, raised from within the museum's board, with an additional $12 million pledged so far. Then there's the trove of top-tier modern and contemporary art being stockpiled by local art lovers -- a rich source of possible future gifts. "I don't know if there's another community in the country, outside of New York, where you have the depth and commitment of the group in San Francisco," Mr. Garrels said. "And a lot of significant things have still gone into the Bay Area in the last 12 months."
Pam Kramlich, a museum trustee who, with her husband, Richard, is a leading collector of video art, agreed. "If everybody continues to support the museum -- and I think they will -- it will be in a very good position," she said.
The museum has also shown a knack for balancing crowd-pleasing shows with more challenging exhibitions. The recent Ansel Adams retrospective offered many little-known early works but still drew 375,000 visitors, Sept. 11 notwithstanding, and the Hesse retrospective has won raves while making the artist's often difficult work surprisingly accessible.
The audience has responded with real loyalty. The museum's membership, which is 42,000 -- 2,000 more than the Modern in New York -- has remained steady even during the last few difficult months.
"This museum wants to be great, and the community wants it to be great," Mr. Benezra said. "It has a wonderful future, a future I want to be part of."

The museum's main entrance, above, and a rope sculpture by Eva Hesse, top left. (Photographs by Dan Krauss for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: NEW YORK; 
New York's Showcases Are Facing Shortfalls

BYLINE:  By BERNARD STAMLER

 BODY:
VISITORS may not have noticed the signs of hard times at New York's two largest museums this last winter: a few more locked entrances at the American Museum of Natural History, a few more closed rooms at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
 Small measures like these were enough for the two museums -- strong institutions with big endowments and broad appeal -- to cope with a plunge in attendance of 50 percent or more in the months after the Sept. 11 attacks. 
 Attendance has risen since the winter, as fears of terrorism fade and the economy shows signs of new life. Weekends are often crowded at the museums, thanks primarily to local and suburban patrons and other day-trippers. 
But even as the museums seem to have escaped the worst, they have started to confront what they considered to be potentially more difficult choices posed by longer-term uncertainties. 
The long-distance tourists -- some of the museums' most ardent fans -- are still not back in town, at least not to the extent that they used to be. Overall attendance remains down at both museums by roughly 20 percent, officials say. The cash-short city -- which owns both museum buildings and is a major source of funds for both -- has already cut its financing by about $1.5 million apiece, with more cuts likely. Private donations have not returned to earlier levels.
In short, although "the trajectory and trends are in the right direction," the museums are still "a long way from home," said Ellen V. Futter, the president of the American Museum of Natural History.
After enjoying roughly five million annual visitors apiece in recent years, the museums are now welcoming around one million fewer visitors. That decrease, of course, has a direct impact on admission receipts, as well as on income from sources like restaurant and gift shop sales.
At the Museum of Natural History, those losses have translated into a decline in revenues of about $8.5 million as of March, said Ann Canty, a spokeswoman, who added that the shortfall might even go as high as $14 million or $15 million by June 30, the end of the museum's fiscal year. The museum has already cut its annual budget, to $119 million from an original figure of more than $130 million, and may have to do so again.
At the Met, which was running a slight deficit during its last fiscal year, the original budget of about $140 million has been cut by roughly $11 million; nevertheless, it still expects a possible deficit of $6 million to $9 million for its current fiscal year, which also ends in June, said Harold Holzer, a spokesman.
As a result of these shortfalls, cost-reducing measures have been imposed at both museums. At the Natural History museum, a number of entrances have been closed. The museum has also reduced opening hours, shutting down completely on Saturday nights and partly on Friday nights, according to Ms. Futter. There is also a freeze on hiring and on wages.
At the Met, Philippe de Montebello, the museum's director, ticked off similar measures that have been taken, though an official hiring freeze had not been imposed. Still, many positions that became vacant by attrition were not being filled. Galleries are occasionally closed when guards are sick or on vacation. Moreover, some large capital undertakings, like new designs for the Greek and Roman galleries, have been postponed six months to a year, he said.
NEW YORK's other museums were also hit hard after Sept. 11. But the degree of suffering has varied. At the Brooklyn Museum of Art, attendance is "pretty much back to normal" said Sally Williams, a spokeswoman. Such is the case for the New Museum for Contemporary Art in SoHo, according to its director, Lisa Phillips. At the Museum of Modern Art, attendance is actually exceeding expectations for the current fiscal year.
What explains the discrepancies? In Brooklyn, Ms. Williams explained, a new traveling Star Wars exhibition is garnering strong numbers; the museum is also "far less dependent on tourists" than its Manhattan counterparts, she said. The New Museum for Contemporary Art received what Ms. Phillips called an "extraordinary shot in the arm" from private donors, as well as from the Andrew Mellon Foundation, which donated $650,000, and the Carnegie Corporation of New York, which provided a grant of $100,000. (Reports have been circulating that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg anonymously donated $10 million for grants to New York City arts organizations that were distributed by Carnegie in February, though Carnegie officials will not confirm or deny this account.)
At the Modern, which is partly closed for renovations and which will shut down next month and move its operations to Queens in June for three years, three "very strong" shows are on display, said the director, Glenn D. Lowry, explaining the relatively good attendance. The strong shows include a retrospective by the German artist Gerhard Richter. 
Still, Mr. Lowry said, the number of visitors to the Modern, while above predictions, is actually lower than the number last year, when the entire museum was open.
But many other museums are still hurting. While that has resulted in big budget cuts, including layoffs and major exhibition cancelations and postponements at institutions like the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum and the Whitney Museum of American Art, officials at the Met and the Museum of Natural History have decided, in the words of Mr. de Montebello, "to weather the storm."
At the Museum of Natural History, that philosophy has meant that a new show at the Rose Center, "The Search for Life: Are We Alone?" opened as scheduled last month. And "Baseball As America," a traveling show from the Baseball Hall of Fame in Cooperstown, N.Y., also opened in March.
At the Met, weathering the storm has meant continuing with its admissions policy -- pay what you want, so long as you pay something -- and forging ahead with its strong spring and summer exhibition schedule. This includes "Surrealism: Desire Unbound," "Orazio and Artemisia Gentileschi: Father and Daughter Painters in Baroque Italy" and the Thomas Eakins show, organized by the Philadelphia Museum of Art, which will arrive in June from the Musee d'Orsay in Paris.
Mr. de Montebello explained the rationale. "You may save money directly if you cancel an exhibition," he said. "But if you do, and all of a sudden you become a less dynamic institution, are you costing yourself what you save? Or are you shooting yourself in the foot?" After all, he added, "rivers flow to the sea and not to the desert."
For now, the strategy seems to be working, Mr. de Montebello said. But the Met's ability to hold the line in the long run will depend on New York's return to normalcy. 
Domestic and foreign travel to New York both remain down, according to figures compiled by NYC & Company, the city's tourism board. In 2000, 30.6 million domestic visitors arrived; the preliminary figure for 2001 is about 26.3 million. Domestic travel to the city is not expected to rise this year in any significant way.
Nor is tourism from overseas particularly encouraging. During 2000, 6.8 million people came to New York from abroad; during 2001, that number fell to about 5.7 million, according to tourism board estimates. The number of foreign tourists in New York this year is expected to increase only marginally, by fewer than 1 percent.
"There is a perception among some that ground zero is bigger than it is," said Christyne L. Nicholas, the president of NYC & Company, who has been traveling across the country to promote New York. Among others, like Japanese tourists, "there is also a belief that it is disrespectful to come to New York in a time of mourning," she added. "In the long term we are going to have to continue to be aggressive to get these travelers."
And while Sept. 11 looms large, there are other reasons for the shortage of visitors to New York City. The economy is still soft, and luring big conventions to the Javits Convention Center has gotten harder. The Javits center ranks only 19th in size in the nation, Ms. Nichols said.
Sooner or later, everyone expects things to return to normal. And in the meantime?
"You can generally last through one bad year," said Mr. de Montebello, adding that he was "cautiously optimistic."
"After that," he said, "if attendance is still down 20 percent, we'll be facing a lot of tough decisions."
Likewise at the Museum of Natural History. "We are watching this spring and looking at this summer very hard," Ms. Futter said. "We hope we won't have to cut anything more this year. But nothing has been declared exempt."

HEADLINE: Across the Nation, Galleries Refill 

BYLINE:  By BERNARD STAMLER

 BODY:
THE economic slowdown and the Sept. 11 attacks hurt museum attendance nationwide. But in most places, spring seems to be ushering in a return to normalcy.
 In Washington, tourism dropped sharply after the attack on the Pentagon, as it did in New York after the World Trade Center attacks. Attendance at the museums of the Smithsonian Institution in Washington, including the National Air and Space Museum and the National Museum of Natural History, fell 35 to 45 percent in the months after the attack, said a museum spokeswoman, Linda St. Thomas. 
 The Smithsonian is financed largely by the federal government but it relies on operations like its museum stores, restaurants and theaters to cover various operating expenses. In February, estimating a shortfall of $8.6 million in its $60 million budget for the fiscal year ending in June, the Smithsonian laid off 45 employees.
Nevertheless, Ms. St. Thomas said, attendance appears to have returned to near normal.
That sentiment was echoed at the National Gallery of Art in Washington, which is also financed mostly by the government. The National Gallery also had a drop in attendance and a drop in income from its gift shop and restaurant. But, beginning in March, the galleries appeared to be full again, a spokeswoman, Deborah Ziska, said. Attendance, she added, now "appears to be back to normal." 
So it is in Boston, too, said Malcolm Rogers, the director of the Museum of Fine Arts, which owns its building and receives no financing from the city. The museum lost revenue when it dropped its admission charge during the last two weeks of September. ("It seemed like the right thing to do," Mr. Rogers said, as a way of offering solace to the public.) But now, he said, it is "fundamentally business as usual." Attendance this year will probably be about 1.2 million, on par with the last few years.
At the Art Institute of Chicago, "we were in a very unique position on Sept. 11," said Eileen Harakal, a museum spokeswoman. It was the members' opening for 'Van Gogh and Gauguin: The Studio of the South,' a blockbuster exhibition for which Chicago was the only United States showing. She said that although the show probably would have drawn more visitors had the terrorist attacks not occurred, nearly 700,000 people still came to see it from September to January, when it closed. As a result, museum attendance for this fiscal year, ending in June, will probably be about 1.7 million, Ms. Harakal said, compared with 1.3 million last fiscal year. 
The Los Angeles County Museum of Art has also recovered, a spokesman, Keith McKeown, said. "For about the first two weeks after Sept. 11, we saw a big drop-off," he said, "but then we were back to our usual level of admissions." 
The museum, which generally has 500,000 to 600,000 visitors annually, has been focusing its marketing eye on regions close to home to make up for a loss of tourists from Asia and other distant places. 
"Our admissions have not really dropped," Mr. McKeown said. "But they have changed in character." BERNARD STAMLER

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: WINE TALK; 
A Bright Note in South Africa

BYLINE:  By Frank J. Prial

DATELINE: STELLENBOSCH, South Africa 

 BODY:
COMING back here after an absence of nine years is like meeting an old friend grown younger. The deep verdant valleys, the improbably beautiful mountains rising from the sea, the plants and flowers found nowhere else -- all rest immutable. But in and around them, one senses a new spirit, an eagerness to meet the world, not with defiance and resentment but with the pride that comes from building a new nation.
 Nowhere is this delight more evident than here in the wine country of the Western Cape. Indeed, wine could be taken as a metaphor for the new South Africa. Old-style wines, obsolete techniques and winemakers living in the past are being pushed aside, sometimes gently, sometimes abruptly, to make way for the new. 
 Under apartheid, the wine industry closed ranks, clinging to the old ways. "Foreign" grapes like chardonnay and pinot noir were banned. When they were grown in defiance of the law, their names could not be used to describe the wines made from them. Once, the principal South African white grape was chenin blanc, known here as steen. It is still the Cape's most widely planted variety. But today, it takes a back seat to chardonnays and sauvignon blancs, among the better South African wines. The Cape currently produces some of the finest sauvignon blancs in the world. 
In the past, pinotage, a cross between pinot noir and cinsault, an undistinguished French hot-climate grape, was South Africa's unique contribution to the world's wines. It still accounts for about 20 percent of the Cape's red wine production. But the new generation of winemakers are either tearing out pinotage vines or working to develop a new, more attractive pinotage-style wine.
In almost two weeks of visiting old acquaintances and meeting new winemakers, some of them sons and daughters of the men and women who were making wine here in grimmer times, I found remarkable optimism about the future, even though the country is suffering from serious unemployment -- officially 35 percent -- and a painfully weak currency. "The enthusiasm of these young people and the amount of experimentation going on is really astonishing," said John Platter, founder and for more than 15 years editor and publisher of the guide to South African wines that still bears his name. 
American consumers first experienced the new breed of South African wines with the arrival in the early 1990's of the sauvignon blancs of Mulderbosch Vineyards here in Stellenbosch, 30 miles east of Cape Town. The winemaker Mike Dubrovic still turns out his flinty, racy sauvignon blancs, but now he has stiff competition. I particularly liked the sauvignons of Andre van Rensburg at Vergelegen Estate, especially the Reserve from the Schaapenberg Vineyard. A few producers in the Loire Valley might compete with this wine, but no one else -- certainly not in California. Two other Cape wineries, Durbanville Hills and Neil Ellis, also produce sauvignon blancs I liked.
These wines should be able to lure some American enthusiasts away from chardonnay. But for those who refuse to be swayed, South Africa makes some intriguing versions. The best South African chardonnays manage brilliantly to combine French brightness and acidity with California's fruit. 
I particularly enjoyed a couple of chardonnays from the De Wetshof Estate in Robertson, a region once given over to raising race horses. Bateleur is Danie de Wet's best, but I preferred his more intense Chardonnay d'Honneur. The limestone soil that once gave horses strong bones does good things for chardonnay, too.
Springfield Estate, another Robertson winery, produces one of the more interesting wines I encountered here, a chardonnay called Methode Ancienne. If ever there was a white wine worthy of the "cult" designation, this is it. Night harvesting, no sulphur, almost three months of native yeast fermentation and a year in oak on the lees produce a chardonnay of monumental proportions. This is true, at least, when the winemakers are lucky; they successfully make Methode Ancienne only about one harvest in three. I'm not sure that any of it has yet reached the United States, but then it wouldn't be a cult wine if anyone could actually buy it, would it?
Other chardonnays worth seeking out that do show up in America include Rustenberg's Five Soldiers (named after trees in the vineyard), and wines from Hamilton Russell vineyards at Hermanus and Warwick Estate here in Stellenbosch. Delaire and De Wetshof both produce good unwooded chardonnays.
South African chenin blanc in the bad old days was for the most part a dull wine. Now, a few courageous vintners, mindful that chenin is also the grape of some glorious Vouvrays, are out to restore its reputation. Ken Forrester's unwooded dry chenin, along with semisweet versions from Mr. Forrester and from Morgenhof Estate, just might bring some respectability and a bit of lustre to poor chenin blanc.
Sparkling wines other than Champagne are often not worth the trouble it takes to open the bottle. South Africa's, the few sampled at least, turn out to be an unexpected treat. I especially liked Graham Beck's Brut, which is a 50-50 chardonnay/pinot noir blend, and two sparklers from Cabriere Estate: the Cuvee Belle Rose, a rose from pinot noir grapes, and the all-chardonnay blanc de blancs, which, I found, goes extremely well with Namibian oysters. None of these wines are going to knock Krug's Clos du Mesnil off its well-deserved pedestal, but they will give lots of lesser Champagnes serious competition. 
The best way to enjoy the Cabriere wines is at the Haute Cabriere Cellar Restaurant high on the Franschhoek Pass Road looking out over the spectacular Franschhoek Valley. The best way to enjoy the restaurant is in the company of Achim von Arnim, who makes the wines and owns the restaurant with Matthew Gordon, the chef. If Mr. von Arnim is in an expansive mood, which he usually is about 365 days a year, he will sabre open your bottle of his wine. If he is in a very expansive mood, he will show one of the women in your party how to do it. Try to get that kind of treatment in Champagne.

GRAPHIC: Photo: QUICK STUDY -- South Africa's winemakers are embracing new ways. (Hans Georg Roth/Corbis)

HEADLINE: FILM REVIEW; 
A Music Teacher Trims the Curriculum but Not Her Enthusiasm

BYLINE:  By STEPHEN HOLDEN 

 BODY:
Watching Anne Boyd -- the Australian composer, music professor and embattled heroine of the documentary film "Facing the Music" -- teach classes in composition, it is clear she is one of those rare teachers who changes the life of almost every student who crosses her path. Stout with short grayish-blond hair and a bluntly emphatic manner, Ms. Boyd metamorphoses from a dowdy middle-aged academic into a fire-breathing idealist whenever she talks about music. If an actor were to portray her on the screen, only one with the impassioned grandeur of a Vanessa Redgrave or Judi Dench could do her justice.
 Ms. Boyd is especially eloquent on the subject of Beethoven who, she says, believed artists to be society's ultimate elite. One of the more revealing stories she tells her students describes the divergent attitudes of Beethoven and Goethe when they encountered a group of aristocrats while taking a walk. Where Goethe was deferential, Beethoven, to his companion's chagrin, unceremoniously cut through the middle of the group as though he were the king. 
 Ms. Boyd may not put on royal airs, but her sympathies clearly lie with Beethoven. When she talks about music, God often appears in the same sentence, since great music, she insists, is a direct spiritual connection to the eternal. She can't help but lay her heart on the line. In one of the film's most touching scenes, she becomes so overwrought while helping a student improve a work in progress that she delivers a sermon that reduces the student to tears. After Ms. Boyd leaves the room, the student rips up her manuscript in despair, but a lesson has been taught; composing should be a do-or-die emotional commitment.
"Facing the Music" which opens today at Film Forum in Manhattan, was directed by Bob Connolly and Robin Anderson, the husband-and-wife team responsible for well-regarded documentaries like "First Contact" and "Rats in the Ranks." Since it was completed, Ms. Anderson died of cancer at 51. The movie was filmed while Ms. Boyd was chairman of the music department of the University of Sydney during a time of sharp financial cutbacks that threatened her department's integrity, if not its existence.
On the evidence of the classes, meetings and student performances the film observes, it is an outstanding department whose faculty members, energized by Ms. Boyd's commitment, give their all. As the cutbacks necessitate trims in the curriculum, her loyal staff follows her example by picking up the slack and teaching many more hours than contractual obligation requires.
But Ms. Boyd is no diplomat. She is the kind of stubborn true believer who can be a thorn in the bureaucracy's side, and she tends to play the self-martyring victim. Although her colleagues are willing to make sacrifices, there are limits to the responsibilities they are ready to assume.
Early in the movie, when the vast majority of the university faculty members are ready to strike to protest the cutbacks, Ms. Boyd is a holdout who insists that closing the university for even a day would be a tragedy. Eventually she changes her mind and once enlisted in the cause becomes an enthusiastic striker eager to persuade university suppliers not to cross picket lines.
"Facing the Music" often feels like two movies loosely sewn together. By far the most compelling of the two is its portrait of Ms. Boyd, a woman who for all her quirks and self-dramatizing flourishes, emerges as a noble spirit on the side of the angels. The other, more mundane movie, deals with the politics of university financing, the relationship between the faculty and the administration, and the underappreciation of the arts.
But as observers of an institution, the filmmakers lack the patience and thoroughness of a Frederick Wiseman. As effectively as "Facing the Music" conveys a sense of crisis, its detailing of the institutional nuts and bolts and the social, political and economic processes eroding the music department is sketchy and ultimately one-sided.

FACING THE MUSIC

Written, directed and produced by Bob Connolly and Robin Anderson; director of photography, Mr. Connolly; edited by Ray Thomas; music supervisor, Christine Woodruff; released by Film Australia in association with Arundel Films, the Australian Broadcasting Corporation and Channel Four (U.K.) Australia. At the Film Forum, 209 West Houston Street, west of Sixth Avenue, South Village. Running time: 89 minutes. This film is not rated.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Anne Boyd, a music teacher, is the focus of the Australian documentary "Facing the Music." (Penelope Clay/Film Forum)

HEADLINE: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE; 
A City Always on a Wave

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL BRICK 

DATELINE: HOUSTON 

 BODY:
Ask if this city is going through a bust and receive a classic Texas response: We've seen bigger.
 Memories of the mid-1980's, when the local economy ran dry, haunt Houston. 
In the late 1970's, Houston's office market benefited from economic factors that were hurting the rest of the country. The Arab oil embargo, the Iran hostage situation and a recession helped make oil drilling wildly profitable. Developers added 31 million square feet of office space from 1975 to 1979, and another 84.2 million from 1980 to 1984. 
 Then the banking and savings and loan industries collapsed; the top four bank failures were in Texas. The economy of Mexico, a large trading partner for Texas long before the North American Free Trade Agreement, collapsed around the same time. Oil prices fell. Vacancy rates ran as high as 35 percent.
The modern Houston economy is built on energy but it is supported by the medical and technology industries in the suburbs. By the end of 2001, there was roughly 56.6 million square feet of space in 198 buildings in the suburbs and 81.8 million square feet in 221 buildings over all, according to Trione & Gordon, a Houston brokerage firm. Suburban markets like the Westchase/Energy Corridor in West Houston and the Galleria near downtown have had significant development, and recently the central business district has received some interest. 
The first developer to start a downtown skyscraper since the 1980's was Hines Interests; the project was the Enron tower, as yet unfinished. MICHAEL BRICK
